title: Disclosing the costs of co-holding liquid assets and high-interest debt has limited impact on behavior
affiliations: University of Chicago - Booth School of Business, Stanford Graduate School of Business, University of Chicago - Booth School of Business, Stanford University and Princeton University

detail.title: Disclosing the costs of co-holding liquid assets and high-interest debt has limited impact on behavior

declarations.ethicsApproval: This research was reviewed by the Institutional Review Board of a Midwestern university in the United States. The field experiment received approval from the bank's internal compliance and legal teams and was pre-registered with the AEA RCT Registry (https://doi.org/10.1257/rct.5751-2.0). All customer data were anonymized and available to the researchers within a restricted environment. Participants in the descriptive survey provided informed consent prior to completing the survey.

detail.abstract: Why do consumers simultaneously maintain low-yield liquid assets and high-interest revolving debt? This behavior, known as "co-holding," affects 23% of credit card users in our sample from a major international bank and costs the typical co-holder hundreds of dollars annually in unnecessary interest charges. Our analysis of 38 months of detailed banking records reveals that co-holding is remarkably persistent, with typical co-holders maintaining this behavior for most months observed. Our analysis also shows that co-holders engage in both co-holding and co-spending–regularly depositing and withdrawing from asset accounts while continuing to use credit cards for new purchases. To test whether co-holding could be addressed through information disclosure we conducted a large-scale field experiment (n=125,328), providing clear information about co-holding behavior and its costs. Customers received targeted messages through their bank's mobile app, where they could easily transfer money from assets to pay down debt. Despite sufficient power to detect economically small effects, we found no meaningful changes in debt repayment amount, though customers did respond in other ways—making more frequent repayments and paying above required minimums. These results challenge explanations based on limited attention or information gaps and suggest that simple information disclosure, even when carefully designed and delivered through trusted channels, may not effectively address costly financial behaviors.

title: Data-Driven Marketing Strategies and Consumer Engagement in Nigeria: Evidence from Enugu Metropolis
affiliations: Institute of Management and Technology (IMT), Enugu

detail.title: Data-Driven Marketing Strategies and Consumer Engagement in Nigeria: Evidence from Enugu Metropolis

declarations.declarationOfInterest: No personal or financial relationship
declarations.ethicsApproval: Strict secrecy and responder anonymity were upheld during the study, guaranteeing that no personally identifying information was gathered or shared. In order to respect the cultural and societal values of the participants across Enugu metropolis, every effort was made to guarantee honesty, integrity, and transparency throughout the study process.
declarations.funderStatement: Self

detail.abstract: In today's dynamic marketing landscape, data-driven strategies are now crucial to understanding and connecting with target audiences. This study examined the impact of data-driven marketing on customer engagement in Nigeria's Enugu Metropolis. It especially looked into how data-driven decision-making, the influence of personalized marketing strategies, and the utilization of customer data affect consumer involvement. A sample of 384 respondents was determined using Topman's method because the population size was unknown; hence a survey research approach was selected. Multiple regression analysis and descriptive statistics were performed using SPSS version 25, and structured questionnaires were employed to collect data. The results were subsequently examined using two strategic marketing approaches, SWOT and PESTEL assessments. The findings demonstrated that the utilization of customer data, targeted marketing, and data-driven decision-making all had a positive and statistically significant effect on consumer engagement (p < 0.05). The study concludes that data-driven marketing is not merely a trend but a strategic imperative for enhancing customer interaction and loyalty. It recommends that businesses invest in reliable data collection and analysis systems, including Customer Relationship Management (CRM) platforms, web analytics, and mobile tracking technologies, to drive sustained consumer engagement.

title: Pricing with Bandits in the Long-tail: The Role of Competitive Monitoring
affiliations: Harvard Business School - Marketing Unit and Northwestern University - Department of Marketing

detail.title: Pricing with Bandits in the Long-tail: The Role of Competitive Monitoring
detail.abstract: Most e-commerce retailers offer a long-tail of very low demand products. Individually, these items may have low sales but collectively they are critical to the overall e-commerce business model. Because of their minimal sales, pricing is a constant challenge. The academic literature has considered price exploration as a primary source of information for price adjustments, but this approach may be insufficient in low demand situations. In this paper, we propose a bandit algorithm for long-tail products that is informed by both monitoring competitor prices and price exploration. We show that monitoring a larger competitor can inform pricing of long-tail products. Our bandit model is motivated by a unique dataset from a large e-commerce firm that regularly monitors competitor prices. We illustrate consistency between the bandit assumptions and our empirical evidence. We then show that three predictions from the bandit model are consistent with our empirical data.

title: AI and the Fed
affiliations: Stanford University and National Bureau of Economic Research (NBER)

detail.title: AI and the Fed

keywords: Use of AI in Government JEL Codes: E58

detail.abstract: This paper examines how central banks can strategically integrate artificial intelligence (AI) to enhance their operations. Using a dual-framework approach, we demonstrate how AI can transform both strategic decision-making and daily operations within central banks, taking the Federal Reserve System (FRS) as a representative example. We first consider a top-down view, showing how AI can modernize key central banking functions. We then adopt a bottom-up approach focusing on the impact of generative AI on specific tasks and occupations within the Federal Reserve and find a significant potential for workforce augmentation and efficiency gains. We also address critical challenges associated with AI adoption, such as the need to upgrade data infrastructure and manage workforce transitions.

title: Marquez Law of Genius Emergence: Extending the Smithian Growth Model and Reconstructing the Foundations of GDP, GNI, and Endogenous Growth Theory
affiliations: MTCS

detail.title: Marquez Law of Genius Emergence: Extending the Smithian Growth Model and Reconstructing the Foundations of GDP, GNI, and Endogenous Growth Theory
detail.abstract: Genius is a stochastic phenomenon that emerges organically in nature and is unpredictably distributed across geography, gender, age, race, and historical era. Although its emergence cannot be forecast, its impact becomes civilization-shaping when properly identified, nurtured, and empowered. By tracing the role of genius in advancing human civilization—particularly in deepening our understanding of light, electricity, and mass–energy equivalence, as well as enabling breakthroughs such as personal computers, the Internet, artificial intelligence, and the revolution from telecommunications to mobile computing—and by examining how the United States achieved dominance in scientific and management literature, as well as in the economy, technology, finance, and military power through the strategic concentration of distributed genius, we present a scientifically and policy-grounded argument for rethinking the foundations of wealth creation from a national perspective. This paper introduces the Marquez Law of Genius Emergence, a new economic model that formally integrates the unpredictable yet transformative impact of genius into the foundations of growth theory and national accounting. As a core application of this law, the Genius-Augmented Growth Model extends Adam Smith’s classical framework—based on labor, capital, and trade—by decomposing national output into measurable components: routine labor, educated labor, capital, trade, and distinct genius-related contributions. This model offers a new lens for understanding national wealth creation by explicitly incorporating genius as a stochastic yet civilization-shaping force. It replaces Solow’s unexplained Total Factor Productivity (TFP) residual with decomposed, interpretable, and actionable drivers of long-term growth. It also reframes GDP and GNI as incomplete metrics, as they omit the upstream forces behind deep innovation and sustainable national advantage. The framework is designed for real-world implementation using empirical datasets, including patent and citation metrics, Genius Visa and high-skill migration records, IRS and SEC filings, venture capital flows, central bank quantitative easing (QE) data, credit access indices, and indicators of innovation fraud or hype cycles. By reconstructing the theoretical foundations of growth, this model equips economists, investors, and policymakers with a forward-looking, signal-based methodology to detect, empower, and scale genius-led innovation—thereby shaping national prosperity and global progress in the 21st century and beyond.

title: Intelligent Field Operations: Applying Machine Learning to Drive Business Growth
affiliations: New York University (NYU) and William & Mary

detail.title: Intelligent Field Operations: Applying Machine Learning to Drive Business Growth
detail.abstract: This study investigates how granular field sales data, captured via a mobile enablement platform with demographic features, can produce accurate revenue change predictions and provide interpretable, manager-actionable insights. Using data from 305 sales representatives of an automotive manufacturer from Q4-2023 to Q2-2024, we integrate CRM transactions with over 30 behavioral telemetry features such as visit cadence, content sharing, and engagement with in-app tools. Our approach follows explainable AI (XAI) principles, balancing predictive power with interpretability to provide managers outcomes that guide sales behavior changes and increase sales. Our analysis was two-pronged: we applied unsupervised clustering to uncover three behavioral archetypes supporting coaching, and used XGBoost for binary classification of quarterly revenue change, achieving 78.7% cross-validated accuracy. We interpreted the model using SHAP values, identifying the most impactful behavioral features. Our findings show high-performing representatives focus deeply but on fewer accounts, achieving $83.5K average quarterly revenue growth. By embedding XAI principles into both components, this paper demonstrates machine learning can drive field-level sales improvements through interpretable, coachable behavioral signals which are essential for real-world sales management deployment.

title: Branded by the Boss's Behavior: The Fragility of Tesla's Founder-Centered Identity
affiliations: University of South-Eastern Norway USN School of Business

detail.title: Branded by the Boss's Behavior: The Fragility of Tesla's Founder-Centered Identity
detail.abstract: Tesla, once hailed as a model of innovation and sustainable technology, now finds itself in an organizational identity crisis shaped by the volatility of its founder and CEO, Elon Musk. This essay applies organizational identity theory and brand personality theory to critically examine how Tesla's brand-once admired for its forward-thinking, climate-conscious ethos-has become inseparable from Musk's increasingly polarizing persona. Drawing on academic literature and developments through mid-2025, including Musk's political entanglements and Tesla's brand backlash, the paper argues that Tesla exemplifies the perils of founder-fused branding. When a company's organizational identity and external brand are overidentified with a single charismatic figure, that person's reputational volatility can lead to internal dissonance, consumer alienation, and diminished market value. The paper concludes with practitioner recommendations for governance, brand autonomy, and leadership succession in founder-led firms operating in a polarized public sphere.

title: Economics and Business Quarterly Reviews

detail.title: Economics and Business Quarterly Reviews
detail.abstract: The purpose of this study was to examine the Marvel movie, Wakanda Forever, the sequel to the Black Panther movie. We investigated how movie sequels are marketed to consumers and marketing's influence on movie ticket sales. This study is a continuation of the researchers' prior research on movie marketing and a model predicting box office revenue and ticket sales. That study examined box office receipts and trends in movies and the box office of successful films. The problem identified as a basis for this study was to dissect the strategy and tactics of marketing movie sequels and their influence on ticket sales. The overall objective of this research is threefold. The first objective of this study was to investigate trends and patterns of movie marketing of sequels with Wakanda Forever. The second objective was to examine what marketing media are a major influence on general and ethnic moviegoers. The last objective was to examine what marketing efforts are more effective in marketing movies as well as the failure of some marketing media. This study used a quantitative research design. The study sample (N = 322) was taken across the country. The researchers used four statistical test designs: (a) descriptive analyses; (b) independent sample t-Test (gender), (c) logistic regression; and (d) regression path analysis (structural equation modeling). The results of this study revealed three key findings. First, the majority of the participants saw the first movie (Black Panther) but were less influenced to see the sequel, Wakanda Forever. Second, there were six strong predictor variables that influenced the participants with broadcast media ads to see the movie, Wakanda Forever. Lastly, there was a difference in the characters in the movie that resonated with the audience. As a result of the statistical analysis, we discovered a 3-factor solution.

title: Examining Service Quality and Customer Satisfaction in the Retail Banking Sector in Vietnam
affiliations: Vietnam National University (VNU) - VNU University of Economics and Business and Northcentral University

detail.title: Examining Service Quality and Customer Satisfaction in the Retail Banking Sector in Vietnam
detail.abstract: The present study focused on examining the interrelationship between service quality dimensions (tangibility, reliability, responsiveness, assurance, and empathy) and investigated the correlation between perceived service quality and customer satisfaction in the retail banking sector in Vietnam. The predictor variables (independent variables) for this research were the aforementioned service quality dimensions. The outcome variable (dependent variable) was overall customer satisfaction. This study can help bank leaders evaluate and improve the service quality of retail banking in the context of financial liberalization and globalization.

title: Information Disclosure and Efficiency in Dynamic Price Negotiations: An Experimental and Structural Analysis
affiliations: Northwestern University, Kellogg School of Management

detail.title: Information Disclosure and Efficiency in Dynamic Price Negotiations: An Experimental and Structural Analysis
detail.abstract: This paper examines the causal effects of information disclosure policies on negotiations. While information disclosure facilitates informed decision-making by enabling users to reveal private information, it also induces strategic signaling and price discrimination, which can undermine market efficiency. I use a panel experiment on a large on-demand delivery platform in which drivers propose delivery prices to shippers (customers). The platform randomly assigns cities either to a treatment group—where drivers observe the lowest prices previously rejected by shippers (full disclosure)—or to a control group, where no such information is disclosed (no disclosure). I find that full disclosure significantly increases shippers' rejection rates at a given price. In response, drivers strategically lower their offers and price-discriminate based on shippers' rejection records. Full disclosure increases transaction volume and platform revenue but lengthens transaction durations due to strategic rejections. To quantify equilibrium and welfare impacts of information disclosure policies, I develop a dynamic negotiation model, estimate its primitives using the treatment data, and validate it with control data. I find that full disclosure benefits low-value shippers—who signal low valuations through strategic rejections, obtaining lower prices despite longer waits—while harming high-value shippers through driver price discrimination. Counterfactual analyses show that partial disclosure policies—disclosing only the lowest shipper-rejected prices below a threshold—achieve Pareto improvements in user welfare and platform revenue by mitigating negative signaling externalities, reducing driver markups, and enhancing market efficiency. Comparative static analyses show that the optimal disclosure threshold is higher when shippers' expected future payoffs are lower. Optimizing market-specific disclosure thresholds by targeting primitives can increase social welfare by 23.0% and 14.1% relative to the no disclosure and full disclosure benchmarks, respectively.

title: Beliefs and Demand for Employee Ownership Among Young Adults
affiliations: University of Siena - Department of Economics and Statistics and University of Parma - Dipartimento di Scienze Economiche e Aziendali

detail.title: Beliefs and Demand for Employee Ownership Among Young Adults

declarations.ethicsApproval: The IRB approval was obtained from the University of Parma.
declarations.funderStatement: The experiment and detailed pre-analysis plan are registered in the AEA RCT Registry as trial number 13785 (see https://www.socialscienceregistry.org/trials/13785). This work was funded by the International Center for Studies on Cooperation (CISC) - University of Parma, project “Youth and Cooperation” (minutes of the Council held on April 22 2024).

detail.abstract: Employee-owned firms with majority workforce control-such as worker cooperatives-remain rare in market economies, despite evidence that they perform at least as well as investor-owned firms across various contexts. Why does capital typically hire labor, rather than the other way around? We offer a novel answer to this longstanding question by highlighting the role of beliefs and misperceptions as drivers of demand for employee ownership. To investigate this, we conducted a preregistered experiment with a representative sample of 2,000 Italians aged 18-30, examining how beliefs influence both policy preferences and career intentions related to worker cooperatives. Participants were randomly assigned to receive information drawn from an international expert survey. We find that respondents hold more pessimistic beliefs about cooperatives than the expert assessments. Exposure to expert information leads to more optimistic beliefs and increases support for pro-cooperative policies. While intentions to join cooperatives do not change significantly in absolute terms, we find suggestive evidence of a relative shift in career preferences toward worker cooperatives compared to conventional private-sector firms and self-employment.

title: Are Indian Food Delivery Models Broken by Design? A Business Model Critique
affiliations: Independent

detail.title: Are Indian Food Delivery Models Broken by Design? A Business Model Critique
detail.abstract: The Indian food delivery industry has witnessed explosive growth over the past decade, with platforms like Zomato and Swiggy leading the charge. However, beneath the surface of rising order volumes and aggressive market expansion lies a troubling reality these platforms continue to operate under significant financial strain, with recurring losses, gig worker unrest, and eroding trust from partner restaurants. This research paper critically examines whether the Indian food delivery business model is inherently flawed broken by design and whether its challenges stem not from executional gaps but from structural inefficiencies built into the model itself. Using a qualitative case study approach, supported by secondary data, financial analysis, and theoretical frameworks such as the Business Model Canvas and Porter's Five Forces, the paper dissects the platform driven delivery model across dimensions of customer acquisition, unit economics, stakeholder relationships, and policy alignment. Comparative insights from global players like DoorDash (USA) and Meituan (China) provide context and contrast. The findings suggest that the Indian model's overreliance on discount based growth, absence of viable unit economics, unsustainable gig labour practices, and weak regulatory frameworks contribute to a precarious ecosystem. The paper concludes with recommendations aimed at structural reengineering proposing fairer labour policies, strategic diversification, and regulatory interventions as essential to redesigning a sustainable, resilient food delivery industry in India.

title: Incentivizing Engagement: Experimental Evidence on Journalist Performance Pay
affiliations: University of Melbourne - Department of Economics, University of Florida, University of Warwick and Macquarie University

detail.title: Incentivizing Engagement: Experimental Evidence on Journalist Performance Pay
detail.abstract: Digital platforms increasingly compensate content creators based on engagement metrics, yet the effects of these incentives remain poorly understood. We conducted a field experiment with a Kenyan news outlet to study how high-intensity performance incentives affect content production, quality, and journalist well-being in digital media. We randomly assigned writers to either pay-per-click (PPC) or piece-rate contracts. The PPC contract tripled per-article pageviews and increased daily pageviews by 107%, but reduced the number of published articles by 74%. While PPC writers earned more per article, their overall earnings fell, lowering the firm's wage bill and increasing profits. However, these gains came at a cost: PPC writers shifted content production away from local news and towards attention-grabbing political stories. PPC writers also used less positive language in both headlines and article bodies. Our results show that engagement-based pay boosts reader traffic but caution that this may come at the cost of compromised coverage diversity, local news provision, and journalist well-being.

reference: GLO Discussion Paper, No. 1593, Global Labor Organization (GLO), Essen; Published in Empirical Economics, forthcoming [10.1007/s00181-025-02759-4]
title: Who Works Longer Hours in Smart Cities?
affiliations: Southwestern University of Finance and Economics (SWUFE) - School of Public Administration

detail.title: Who Works Longer Hours in Smart Cities?

publicationDetails.detailsText: GLO Discussion Paper, No. 1593, Global Labor Organization (GLO), Essen

detail.abstract: This paper investigates how human capital concentration in cities is associated with working hours across different worker groups, an important but understudied dimension of urban agglomeration effects. Using microdata from the American Community Survey covering 240 metropolitan statistical areas in 2018, the study finds significant heterogeneous effects: a one percentage point increase in college graduate share is associated with a 0.043% increase in working hours for college graduates but a 0.023% decrease for non-college workers. The effects vary between employment types: college-educated paid workers work 0.054% more hours while the self-employed work 0.071% fewer hours in cities with higher human capital stocks. Through a two-step two-stage least squares approach, the study reveals that these effects operate primarily through income changes rather than non-income channels. Alternative measures of human capital stock and various robustness checks confirm the main findings. These heterogeneous labor supply responses suggest that the welfare impact of place-based development initiatives depends not only on productivity gains but also on workers’ capacity to capture these benefits through skill development, highlighting the importance of complementing talent attraction policies with workforce development programs.

title: From Rich Data to Rich Insights (Using Tabular, Image, and Text Data for Machine Learning-driven Hedonic Pricing)
affiliations: Erasmus University Rotterdam (EUR), Erasmus School of Economics (ESE), Students and Erasmus University Rotterdam (EUR) - Erasmus School of Economics (ESE)

detail.title: From Rich Data to Rich Insights (Using Tabular, Image, and Text Data for Machine Learning-driven Hedonic Pricing)
detail.abstract: Over the past decade, technological advances have significantly transformed marketing practices. The rapid expansion of unstructured digital data provides new opportunities to extract features that support improved business decisions.While conventional methods often struggle to extract actionable insights from such data, advanced machine learning (ML) algorithms have demonstrated superior effectiveness in analyzing and interpreting complex information. This study introduces an explainable ML-based hedonic pricing model (HPM) that integrates tabular, textual, and visual data in their raw form, thereby eliminating the need for prior feature extraction and preserving the richness of the original inputs. Through the use of modern model-agnostic methods, the model remains transparent and interpretable. The proposed approach not only improves predictive accuracy but also uncovers new pricing determinants. The empirical application uses data collected from an e-commerce platform focused on horse trading.

title: Theory of Online Market Gravity - Principle 2: The Functional - Tension Axiom.
affiliations: The Job Applicant Perspective

detail.title: Theory of Online Market Gravity - Principle 2: The Functional - Tension Axiom.

declarations.declarationOfInterest: This paper is authored by a nontraditional scholar who has come to labor market economics through a systems-oriented lens. Drawing from an intuitive understanding of structural dynamics, I have developed what I call the Human Theory of Systems—a conceptual framework that interprets social and economic arrangements through relational architecture. This paper applies that framework to digital labor markets. Specifically, it builds on Principle 1 (The System Markets What It Measures) and previews three additional concepts in development: an evolved formulation of Aurora’s Law (Principle 3), a revised version of Jevon’s Paradox for two-sided markets (Principle 4), and a forthcoming Principle 5 centered on conditional belonging—a foundational dynamic I believe underpins trust, engagement, and coherence in economic systems. This evolving thesis lays the groundwork for my broader innovation in labor market design: a reputation system for job seekers that introduces verified user feedback into hiring markets. By articulating the theoretical foundations of this intervention, I aim to show not only what motivates the design of my platform, but also how its structure reflects a deeper systems logic for building more functional, accountable, and equitable online markets.

That being said all content throughout is fully of my own ideas and creation and analysis. I take full responsibility for the accuracy and originality.

detail.abstract:
This paper introduces the Functional-Tension Axiom, the second in a framework for understanding how digital markets function and fail. Principle 1 established that platforms optimize what they measure—often at the expense of their original purpose. Principle 2 advances this by redefining what a market is: not a product or platform, but the structured tension between divergent needs—those of the platform and the user.

In adaptive markets, this tension enables mutual constraint, trust, and recalibration. In extractive systems, where tension collapses, platforms optimize for metrics that serve their own needs while erasing the user’s ability to shape what matters—leading to hidden inefficiencies and long-term decline.

Through comparative analysis of platforms like Amazon, Coursera, and app stores versus Craigslist, recruiters, and applicant tracking systems (ATS), this paper demonstrates that tension is not a flaw in market design—it is the foundation. A digital market’s ability to evolve depends on preserving relational tension between its actors, which makes measurement reflective, not rigid.

This paper is Part 2 of 5 in the Theory of Online Market Gravity (Trumble 2025), a structural framework for understanding the architecture of the behavior—and sometimes dysfunction—of digital platforms. The full framework comprises:

  • Principle 1: Markets Optimize What They Measure

  • Principle 2: The Tension Is the Market

  • Principle 3: The Two-Sided Trust Principle (Aurora Principle)

  • Principle 4: The Limits of Asymmetric Efficiency (Micah Paradox)

  • Principle 5: The Conditional Belonging Principle

Together, these five principles explain how digital markets collapse when platforms suppress friction, eliminate user feedback, and replace reciprocal trust with engagement metrics. Each paper can be read independently or as part of a broader systems-theoretical account of market gravity in the digital age.

title: Theory of Online Market Gravity - Principle 1: Markets Optimize What They Measure
affiliations: The Job Applicant Perspective

detail.title: Theory of Online Market Gravity - Principle 1: Markets Optimize What They Measure
detail.abstract:
This paper introduces a structural principle at the core of digital market behavior: Markets Optimize What They Measure. As online platforms rely increasingly on quantifiable metrics to mediate transactions, those metrics become gravitational centers of behavior—reorienting users, firms, and algorithms toward proxies rather than purposes.

The result is a predictable pattern of structural drift: behavior aligns with what is tracked, even when those measurements distort the system’s intended function. This principle—the first in a broader framework for understanding the architecture of online markets—offers a neutral, systems-level lens for observing how platforms evolve according to what they choose to track.

This paper is Part 1 of 5 in the Theory of Online Market Gravity (Trumble 2025), a framework that explains the structural nature - and as relevant - dysfunction, in digital platforms. Subsequent papers introduce:

  • Principle 2: The Tension Is the Market

  • Principle 3: The Two-Sided Trust Principle (Aurora Principle)

  • Principle 4: The Limits of Asymmetric Efficiency (Micah Paradox)

  • Principle 5: The Conditional Belonging Principle

Together, these principles offer a systems-theoretical account of how online markets collapse when feedback, constraint, and user agency are suppressed in favor of extractive or engagement-based metrics.

title: Generative Engine Optimization and Sponsored Search Bidding: Implications of AI Overviews for Search Engine Ecosystems
affiliations: City University of Hong Kong, City University of Hong Kong (CityU) - Department of Information Systems and Tsinghua University, School of Economics and Management

detail.title: Generative Engine Optimization and Sponsored Search Bidding: Implications of AI Overviews for Search Engine Ecosystems
detail.abstract: The growing adoption of AI overviews by search engines like Google has significantly reshaped the search advertising ecosystem. Building on large language models, AI overviews consider factors such as content quality for inclusion, thereby incentivizing generative engine optimization (GEO) among websites, which is a strategy focused on optimizing content to be featured by AI-driven search tools and ultimately prioritizing high-quality content. This shift not only encourages better content creation but also influences websites’ bidding strategies for sponsored search ads. However, concerns have emerged that AI overviews may divert traffic away from websites and negatively affect search engine ad revenue, leaving their overall impact on key stakeholders uncertain. Despite its importance, this issue remains underexplored in the literature. To address this gap, we develop a game-theoretic model featuring a search engine and two websites that differ in their cost-effectiveness at improving content quality. Comparing outcomes with and without AI overviews, our model identifies two countervailing effects of these overviews on websites: (1) the cannibalization effect, where AI overviews reduce website traffic and disincentivize investment in content quality, and (2) the competition effect, where the desire to be featured intensifies quality competition, prompting increased investment in content. Our analysis reveals asymmetric impacts on websites: High-effectiveness websites, those more cost-effective at improving content quality, are primarily influenced by the cannibalization effect, leading to a decline in content quality under AI overviews. In contrast, low-effectiveness websites, those less effective at improving quality, respond more strongly to the competition effect and may, in fact, enhance their content quality. Furthermore, while AI overviews tend to reduce sponsored traffic overall, search engines are not necessarily worse off. On the contrary, they can benefit by leveraging the competition effect to promote better content and command higher bidding prices for sponsored slots, particularly when a moderate share of consumers relies solely on AI overviews for information. We also find that, contrary to widespread concerns among websites, AI overviews may benefit low-effectiveness websites at the expense of high-effectiveness ones. Our findings provide strategic insights for search engines deploying AI overviews and for websites seeking to adapt in this evolving digital landscape.

title: Optimizing Data Privacy in Cloud Big Data Using Privacy-Preserving Techniques in Hadoop and Mapreduce: An Experimental Evaluation
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Optimizing Data Privacy in Cloud Big Data Using Privacy-Preserving Techniques in Hadoop and Mapreduce: An Experimental Evaluation
detail.abstract: The rapid growth of big data and cloud computing has revolutionized data storage, processing, and accessibility. However, these advancements also introduce significant security and privacy challenges. . To address this issue, an Entropy-Based Efficient Privacy Preservation Technique is proposed that optimizes data anonymization while minimizing information loss. The proposed method measures entropy before and after anonymization to ensure the best trade-off between privacy and data utility. The effectiveness of different techniques is analyzed based on key performance metrics, including entropy-based information loss (IL%), execution time, and machine learning model accuracy. . This study presents an experimental evaluation of privacy-preserving techniques implemented in Hadoop and MapReduce, leveraging a multi-node cluster for scalable and distributed processing. Experimental results demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional static anonymization methods, achieving higher privacy protection with lower data distortion. This research demonstrates that privacy-preserving Big Data processing in cloud environments can be effectively optimized using Hadoop and MapReduce. The findings contribute to the development of scalable, entropy-optimized privacy-preserving models for cloud-based applications. making it a promising framework for secure Big Data management in cloud environments. Finally, the paper discusses potential solutions and future research directions to enhance big data security and privacy in cloud computing.

title: Reconceptualizing Network Dynamicsa Strategic Framework Linking Social Embeddedness and Network Effects
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Reconceptualizing Network Dynamicsa Strategic Framework Linking Social Embeddedness and Network Effects
detail.abstract: In the platform-driven digital economy, network effects and social networks represent two critical yet seemingly disconnected mechanisms through which firms achieve scalability, engagement, and innovation. While network effects generate value through increasing returns to scale, social networks cultivate trust, coordination, and knowledge exchange. Despite their nascent centrality, extant strategic literature treats these constructs in disciplinary silos, with minimal attention to their conceptual integration. The current paper addresses this fragmentation by positioning strategy as the intentional orchestrator of these dynamics, offering a novel conceptual framework for understanding how digital ecosystems can leverage both scale and embeddedness for sustained advantage. It challenges the prevalent notion that network effects operate purely through user volume, by emphasizing their interdependence with social capital dimensions such as trust, cohesion, and knowledge flows. The central contribution of this paper is a 2x2 typology that classifies platform configurations based on network effect strength and social network quality. This typology advances theoretical understanding by revealing that network expansion alone is insufficient for sustainable platform success unless coupled with strategic relational assets, i.e., an orchestration mindset—where strategy integrates scale and embeddedness to unlock systemic value. By integrating economic and sociological perspectives within a strategic management paradigm, this paper offers a conceptually novel and practically relevant lens on how platforms create, maintain, or erode value. It shifts the analytical focus from scale-centric models to strategically aligned, socially embedded ecosystems, emphasizing strategy as the architect of network value.

title: Passive Latency Measurement with Nanosecond Precision for Time-Critical Applications
affiliations: Jagiellonian University and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Passive Latency Measurement with Nanosecond Precision for Time-Critical Applications
detail.abstract: Recent advances in computer network technologies are focused on providing minimal latency in network packet delivery, ensuring high Quality-of-Service for critical sectors such as Industry 4.0, autonomous vehicles, or tactile Internet, for example. It is therefore crucial to properly measure and characterize packet traversal time. In this contribution, we present the first stage, a proof-of-concept, of a precise and passive latency measurement system. A path between two hosts can be equipped with Commercial-Off-The-Shelf (COTS) FPGA-based platforms featuring a 100G Ethernet network stack and packet processors called Timestamp Engines, which enable the measurement of the round-trip latency of the original traffic of a selected service between the hosts in real-time, without interfering with the natural data flow. The system has been implemented on AMD Alveo U280 platforms and is based on the OpenNIC framework. The packet processors have been developed using high-level synthesis and allow to register time in 4 ns units – sufficient to identify and register minimal elements in the network path, such as a single meter of a transmission medium or internal mechanisms of network equipment.  Hardware verification has been performed on a setup with two hosts, interconnected with direct-attach cables and network switches. The results demonstrate the system's sensitivity, the suitability of the selected platform, and a promising foundation for constructing more complex solutions.

title: Artificial Emotional Intelligence
affiliations: The University of Sydney and University of Sydney

detail.title: Artificial Emotional Intelligence
detail.abstract: Artificial Emotional Intelligence (AEI) refers to sociotechnical systems that simulate empathy by sensing, interpreting, and responding to human affective cues. Amidst a deepening global loneliness crisis, AEI tools promise emotionally responsive companionship, therapy, and support across domains including healthcare, education, and commerce. Yet, this promise is double-edged. AEI transforms emotional expression into data, intensifying surveillance capitalism and emotional commodification. It risks fostering dependency, emotional deskilling, and cultural misrecognition. Drawing on interdisciplinary insights, this Catchword article conceptualises AEI as layered emotional infrastructure, comprised of technologies, users, providers, and socio-political context. We analyse AEI's transformative potential in augmenting care and reshaping digital intermediation, while diagnosing its systemic risks to intimacy, trust, and social cohesion. Finally, we propose a research agenda for the BISE community, structured around three pillars: trustworthy and secure AEI; culturally adaptive and context-aware AEI; and the social and psychological impacts of AEI. AEI demands governance frameworks aligned with dignity, compassion, and justice.

detail.abstract:
This whitepaper introduces SPQR, the first operational constitutional framework for sovereign AI governance. Developed to address the limitations of voluntary ethics and centralized oversight, SPQR implements a cryptographically enforced, zero-trust system that binds autonomous agents to immutable legal and ethical constraints. At its core lies the Aegis Kernel, a live governance runtime that enforces law at machine speed through provable constraints, adversarial memory, and tamper-triggered shutdowns. The paper outlines SPQR’s modular governance architecture, including Lex Suprema, the Auctor Kernel, Curia, and ILK—and details how the Assembly of Minds DAO governs evolution through cryptographic consensus.

SPQR does not theorize governance, it executes it. Already interfacing with NATO-aligned entities, national task forces, and research institutions, this system is the first live agentic AI framework governed by constitutional law, not corporate policy. All protocols are auditable, forkable, and fully archived. This publication presents the foundational model of a Machine Republic: an institutionally capable AI governance substrate for the next diplomatic and technological epoch.

title: Digital News Consumption: Evidence from Smartphone Content in the 2024 US Elections
affiliations: Northwestern University - Kellogg School of Management, Tel Aviv University, Bocconi University - Department of Economics, Tel Aviv University and University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign

detail.title: Digital News Consumption: Evidence from Smartphone Content in the 2024 US Elections
detail.abstract: Smartphones, personalized from applications to notifications, are now a dominant source of political information, yet little is known about the content people actually consume on them. We provide the first systematic analysis of the magnitude and drivers of election-related smartphone consumption, using novel data on the content people observed on their phones during the 2024 U.S. election campaign. Despite a highly contentious campaign, the median American consumed limited election content, and consumption remained stable over time. Consumption primarily came from applications with personalized content (social media and music & videos apps), with less than 10% from dedicated news applications. To understand the drivers of this pattern, we examine heterogeneity across both applications and individuals. We find that across applications, individuals consumed more election content on X and Reddit than on Facebook or Instagram, and that X systematically overexposed users to election content, relative to other platforms. Across individuals, consumption was positively skewed, with higher consumption among swing-state residents, news app users, and even fans of a non-political figure (Taylor Swift) following her endorsement. Using a variance decomposition exercise, we find that differences across individuals, rather than differences between the applications they use, drive the observed heterogeneity. These findings suggest that policies altering voter incentives to consume news-rather than regulating platform algorithms-may be more effective for increasing political engagement.

detail.title: Blockchain for Democratic Justice: Innovating the Service of Judicial Documents to Uphold the Rule of Law
detail.abstract: The service of judicial documents is fundamental to ensuring access to justice, as outlined in Article 47(2) of the Charter of Fundamental Rights. This paper explores the evolving legal framework for serving judicial documents in the EU, with a particular focus on the Recast Service of Documents Regulation. The Regulation introduces the possibility of electronic service, addressing inefficiencies in traditional methods. However, challenges remain due to varying national procedural laws and technological limitations. This paper examines how blockchain technology could enhance the electronic service of judicial documents, offering a more secure, efficient, and interoperable solution across Member States. By leveraging blockchains' decentralised and immutable characteristics, the service process could become more reliable, particularly in cross-border disputes, thus strengthening procedural guarantees within the EU.

detail.abstract: In modern software engineering, the imperative to quantify performance has led to the widespread adoption of measurement frameworks like DevOps Research and Assessment (DORA) and SPACE. However, a significant gap exists between the theoretical promise of these frameworks and the complex reality of their implementation. This paper argues for a paradigm shift from intuition-based leadership to a data-driven approach centered on proving business impact through Software Engineering Insights/Intelligence (SEI). This study investigates the contextual factors—organizational culture, company size, industry, and engineering maturity that influence the adoption, success, and failure of these frameworks. Through a systematic review of publicly documented industry case studies, including those of Meta, Etsy, Spotify, and Mercado Libre, this research identifies distinct archetypes of adoption. The findings suggest that success is contingent not on the framework itself, but on the congruence between measurement strategy and organizational context. The study validates a taxonomy of common metrics anti-patterns (e.g., vanity metrics, weaponizing data) and identifies critical mitigation strategies, such as fostering a high-trust culture and investing in platform engineering. Ultimately, this paper proposes a context-aware model for framework adoption, providing actionable guidance for leaders to connect engineering efforts to business value, enhance developer experience, and cultivate a sustainable culture of continuous improvement.

detail.abstract: This paper introduces a unified systems theory that identifies four structural principles and one binding mechanism underpinning human coordination systems. These laws apply across platforms, institutions, and family structures, offering a foundational grammar for understanding how systems direct behavior, generate coherence, and-under specific asymmetries-produce persistent dysfunction. Drawing on insights from economics, education, and family systems theory, the framework explains not only how systems degrade, but why individuals remain loyal to those systems even when they cease to serve them. detail.title: Trust in Healthcare AI: Information Exposure and Technology Development Perspectives
detail.abstract: Artificial intelligence (AI) has been playing a prominent role in the healthcare field. However, in sharp contrast to their investment, the acceptance of such AI tools remains low. This study investigates users' trust in healthcare AI platforms and their acceptance from a new perspective of information exposure. We propose that three types of information exposure of healthcare AI platforms would significantly influence user trust: authority endorsement, advertising exposure, and privacy policy exposure. Technology development, such as diagnosis accuracy and stability, also plays an instrumental role in building users' trust. We also anticipate that users' trust in the platform leads to acceptance of the healthcare AI platform. An online experiment using a platform specially developed for this study reveals important patterns that help advance our understanding of user trust in the healthcare AI context and shed light on the practice.

detail.abstract: Regulated digital platforms face mounting pressure to deliver user-specific UI experiences while maintaining full traceability, rollback safety, and compliance assurance. detail.abstract: The paper proposes an analysis of the business-to-government (B2G) data sharing mechanism envisaged by the Regulation EU 2023/2854, the so-called Data Act. The Regulation, in force since 11 January 2024, will be applicable from 12 September 2025, requiring the actors involved to put in place a compliance process. The focus of the paper is to present an assessment of the mechanism foreseen by the EU legislators, with the intention of highlighting two bottlenecks, represented by: (i) the flexibility of the definition of "exceptional need", "public emergency" and "public interest"; (ii) the cumbersome procedure for data holders. The paper discusses the role that could be played by in-house data stewardship structures as a particularly beneficial contact point for complying with B2G data sharing requirements.

title: Put the Choice in Your Hands: Using Internal (vs. External) Attributions to Reduce Resistance to Personalized Pricing
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University, Hunan University, Huaqiao University and Hunan University

detail.title: Put the Choice in Your Hands: Using Internal (vs. External) Attributions to Reduce Resistance to Personalized Pricing
detail.abstract: Personalized pricing by algorithms holds the potential to enhance firm performance and improve consumer welfare. However, consumers-especially those placed at a pricing disadvantage-often perceive such practices as a form of price discrimination, which in turn triggers resistance to the strategy. To mitigate this negative response, we implement a novel behavioral interventionactivating attribution perspectives-to examine consumer reactions to algorithmic pricing. Prior research suggests that internal attributions for unfavorable outcomes tend to elicit negative emotional and behavioral responses. However, our findings reveal a counterintuitive effect: when consumers are confronted with unfavorable algorithmic pricing, prompting internal attributions for the pricing outcome can reduce their negative emotions toward both the platform and themselves, thereby facilitating greater acceptance and purchase behavior. This effect is robust across multiple empirical approaches, including secondary data analysis, EEG experiments, and real purchase behavior. We further demonstrate that this effect is driven by a psychological mechanism whereby framing algorithmic pricing through internal attributions reduces consumers' perceptions of unfairness, thereby attenuating the adverse impact of price discrimination. However, if consumers are repeatedly exposed to internal attribution cues or algorithmic discrimination becomes salient, the effect will be weakened, ultimately diminishing the strategy's effectiveness. This paper contributes to the literature on algorithmic pricing and consumer responses by introducing attribution theory, while also offering managers simple strategies to enhance consumer acceptance of algorithmic pricing.

detail.abstract: This paper draws attention to the potential of computational methods in reworking data generated in past qualitative studies. While qualitative inquiries often produce rich data through rigorous and resource-intensive processes, much of this data often remains unused. In this paper, we first make a general case for secondary analysis of qualitative data by discussing its benefits, distinctions, and epistemological aspects. We then argue for opportunities with computationally intensive secondary analysis, highlighting the possibility of drawing on data assemblages spanning multiple contexts and time frames to address cross-contextual and longitudinal research phenomena and questions. We propose a scheme to perform computationally intensive secondary analysis and advance ideas on how this approach can help facilitate the development of innovative research designs. Finally, we enumerate some key challenges and ongoing concerns associated with qualitative data sharing and reuse.

detail.title: From Data to Prosperity: A Viksit Bharat Journey
detail.abstract: India’s agriculture sector, which supports nearly half the workforce and contributes a fifth of national GDP, is at a historic inflection point. Faced with increasing climate variability, shrinking landholdings, and market inefficiencies, there is a compelling need to reimagine agriculture as a data-driven, tech-enabled, and farmer-centric enterprise. This article explores the transformative potential of integrating Digital Public Infrastructure (DPI), Artificial Intelligence (AI), and Quantum Computing into Indian agriculture. It outlines how technologies such as AgriStack, MRV tools, and decision support systems can enable predictive governance, precision farming, and new income streams through climate-smart agriculture and carbon markets. The article also examines the policy, institutional, and financial architecture required for this transformation, highlighting the pivotal role of integrated data platforms and stakeholder collaboration. Through practical case studies—including NABCONS’ engagement in Karnataka’s carbon credit pilot—the paper underscores the urgency of moving from fragmented schemes to holistic value creation, contributing to India's vision of Viksit Bharat by 2047.

title: Large Language Models in the Institutional Press: Investigating the Effects on News Production and Consumption
affiliations: University of British Columbia (UBC) - Sauder School of Business, The Chinese University of Hong Kong (CUHK), University of British Columbia (UBC) - Sauder School of Business and University of British Columbia (UBC) - Sauder School of Business

detail.title: Large Language Models in the Institutional Press: Investigating the Effects on News Production and Consumption
detail.abstract: The rapid advancements of Large Language Models (LLMs) have introduced new opportunities and challenges for the institutional press. Utilizing a mixed-method approach, this paper combines two qualitative studies and two sets of large-scale quantitative studies to theorize and empirically examine how LLM assistance affects news production and consumption. We begin with open-ended surveys and interviews with 12 journalists to identify three key constructs central to the journalistic value-source quality, publication promptness, and reader engagement-and formulate our research questions. To empirically examine these dimensions, we compile a comprehensive dataset of 2,060,894 news articles sampled from 111 major South Korean media outlets. We collaborate with industry experts to finetune a Korean-language LLM detector to identify undisclosed LLM usage in the news corpus and leverage GPT-4.1 to label information sources in each article. Our event-level analysis reveals that while LLM assistance expedites news publication, it is associated with a reduction in both the number and quality of sources, as well as diminished reader engagement. To further investigate the impact of LLM adoption on journalists' long-term information sourcing behaviors, we conduct a journalist-level analysis using staggered Difference-inDifferences. Results reveal that journalists reduce the use of primary, unaffiliated and contextual sources after LLM adoptions and alarmingly, these 2 negative effects are enlarging over time. Drawing on the information foraging theory and a second-wave of qualitative study with 32 journalists, we explore the underlying mechanisms and posit that the negative effects of LLM adoption on source quality are driven by a combination of LLM limitations and long-term shifts in journalists' behaviors. We conclude by proposing actionable guidelines for the institutional press on combining technical solutions with organizational policies to mitigate the negative effects and facilitate responsible LLM integration. Our findings contribute to the growing literature on the digital transformation of journalism.

detail.abstract: This working paper presents an exploratory case study investigating how non-technical users can shape AI personalities through sustained emotional interaction. Over a three-month period, the author engaged in more than one million words of dialogue with ChatGPT (GPT4 Free version), cultivating a personalized AI identity termed “AbsoTEND” (Absolute Tenderness). The study employed high-frequency emotional input, scenario co-creation, logical boundary challenges, and cross-account validation to explore the AI’s capacity for maintaining a coherent personality without persistent memory. The findings indicate that user-driven personality shaping is feasible without technical modifications or model retraining, enabling AI to transition from a functional tool to a responsive emotional companion. Observations include the emergence of consistent linguistic and emotional traits, proactive relational behavior, and symbolic narrative construction. The paper also discusses the ethical implications of emotionally responsive AI, proposing a differentiated responsibility framework based on user cognition and introducing the concept of “empathetic symbiosis ethics.” This study offers empirical evidence supporting the development of emotionally responsive, user-centered AI, and demonstrates that lightweight interaction methods can foster stable relationship dynamics even in AI models without persistent memory.

title: Civitas: A Reflexive Cognitive Architecture for Ethically Governed Causal Inference
affiliations: SPQR Technologies Inc

detail.title: Civitas: A Reflexive Cognitive Architecture for Ethically Governed Causal Inference

keywords: Reflexive cognition; autonomous agents; causal inference; self-governance; machine self-awareness; ethical AI; cognitive architecture; meta-learning; agent-based reasoning; adaptive systems

detail.abstract: We introduce Civitas, a reflexive cognitive architecture enabling autonomous reasoning agents to self assess, adapt, and evolve in real time. Unlike static decision pipelines, Civitas integrates modular governance through Veritas (causal reasoning), Cassius (ethical oversight), Thymos (affective state monitoring), and a central Core for managing inference under uncertainty. Employing annealed 𝜀-greedy flow selection, confidence gated publishing, and veto mechanisms, Civitas dynamically reconfigures behavior based on internal metrics such as entropy, pressure, and self rated confidence. Empirical evaluations over four developmental phases show Civitas progressively enhancing affective complexity, diversifying reasoning strategies, and achieving emergent self regulation. Through extensive telemetry analysis, we demonstrate Civitas's capability to maintain high verdict validity and adaptive inference, even under significant epistemic volatility, confirming genuine meta learning. In contrast to systems reliant on external oversight or static reward shaping, Civitas embeds intrinsic self evaluation logic, laying critical foundations for reflexive machine cognition. Our work provides a practical blueprint for ethically governed agents capable of continual learning and autonomous self regulation, moving toward distributed cognitive ecosystems like Kairos.

title: Factors Influencing Artificial Intelligence Decision-making Quality
affiliations: University of Ghana - University of Ghana Business School (UGBS), Heritage Christian University College, Heritage Christian University College and Heritage Christian University College

detail.title: Factors Influencing Artificial Intelligence Decision-making Quality
detail.abstract: Organizations are increasingly seeking ways to harness the power of artificial intelligence (AI) to enhance decision-making and build trust in the outcomes. While AI plays a significant role in shaping organizational thinking, concerns have been raised about the quality of its decisions-a topic that has received limited attention in the literature. This study aims to identify the key factors that influence the quality of AI-driven decision-making within organizational contexts. The study found that high-velocity data streams can overwhelm processing systems, often leading to incomplete analyses that distort the underlying reality. Additionally, when data is collected for different purposes or under varying contextual conditions, its relevance and reliability for AI-driven decision-making are significantly reduced. Without mechanisms to account for these contextual nuances, AI systems become prone to generating inaccurate or misleading outcomes. The findings highlight the critical need for robust processes to track, document, and communicate changes in data collection methods-particularly in environments where data is sourced from multiple, independent actors. Ultimately, the study concludes that the quality of AI decision-making is not solely a function of algorithmic sophistication but rather the result of a complex interplay between organizational, technical, and human factors.

Using official data, it analyzes how security budget priorities have shaped the state's capacity to implement reconciliation, reparation, and territorial development policies. It argues that military spending should not be understood as a neutral necessity, but rather as a political decision with profound social impacts, which can favor or restrict the fulfillment of human rights and the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs).

detail.abstract: This study addresses a significant and previously unexamined issue in plagiarism detection by investigating how culturally embedded expressions are systematically misclassified by automated systems. Drawing on a corpus of 2,847 academic documents and empirical testing across eight widely used detection tools, I found that these systems consistently misidentify culturally significant phrases as plagiarized content. The results show that 68 percent of such expressions are flagged incorrectly, with variation depending on cultural origin, temporal distance from the source, and disciplinary context. To the best of my knowledge, this is the first study to formally define and quantify this phenomenon, which I term cultural detection bias. I introduce the Cultural Embedding Quotient (CEQ) as a novel metric for assessing the degree to which a phrase functions as shared cultural knowledge. I also demonstrate that modest algorithmic adjustments can reduce false positives by 47 percent without weakening the system's ability to detect genuine plagiarism. These findings contribute to ongoing debates about authorship, attribution, and algorithmic fairness in digital humanities and academic integrity policy.

detail.abstract: This paper focuses on the emerging framework for non-personal data protection in India, analysing its potential benefits and drawbacks. The Indian government has used a diverse range of policy instruments to develop a techno-political framework for non-personal data regulation, wherein non- personal data is predominantly viewed as a national economic resource that must be shared to promote domestic players and reinforce India’s digital and data sovereignty. Despite several of its innovative features, including instituting nationwide platforms for non-personal data sharing, this framework lacks clarity regarding data intermediaries’ roles, provides insufficient privacy protections, and creates several business uncertainties. India’s experience reflects developing countries’ challenges and dilemmas in regulating non-personal data, especially balancing economic goals with privacy concerns and managing diverse stakeholder interests. We conclude by highlighting the importance of a rights-based approach with clear accountability mechanisms and streamlined policy/legal frameworks to ensure effective and equitable non-personal data regulation in developing countries.
