detail.title: A Bi-Level Capacity Allocation Model of Integrated Energy System Oriented For Electricity-Carbon-Hydrogen Coupled Zero-Carbon Park Considering Robust Operation
detail.abstract: Zero-carbon park is basic hub support for new-type power system as well as dual-carbon goal of China, which can effectively optimize energy structure, promote energy coupling, and achieve zero-carbon operation of the system. It is key issue on how to provide an optimization planning scheme for capacity allocation of zero-carbon park integrated energy system, especially considering comprehensive interaction among operation uncertainty, multi-energy coupling, zero-carbon emission, etc. Firstly, this paper proposes a coupling operation architecture of zero-carbon park integrated energy system including wind-photovoltaic-hydrogen-storage elements and constructs physical characteristic models for each equipment. Secondly, considering the uncertainties of system supply and demand interaction, a bi-level planning optimization model is established for electricity-carbon-hydrogen coupling. The upper level aims to minimize investment costs for planning the capacity and quantity of energy system equipment, the lower level aims to minimize the net load for the operational scheduling of the park's equipment. The two-stage robust optimization method is applied to deal with the uncertainty of the wind, photovoltaic and load demand. Finally, the validity of the bi-level planning optimization model is verified with the example of a zero-carbon park in South China, and the sensitivity analysis is carried out on the key factors such as the uncertainty of the wind, photovoltaic and the load demand, the investment of the carbon capture equipment, and the time-of-use pricing. The results show that the bi-level planning optimization model of zero-carbon park integrated energy system can achieve the zero-carbon park emission goals, improving system's economy, stability, and robustness, offering technical pathway for the planning and construction of zero-carbon park.

title: Energy and Information
affiliations: Universidad Simon Bolivar

detail.title: Energy and Information
detail.abstract: The literature contains many contradictory conceptual descriptions of the relation between Energy and Information. Here I argue that Information is not energy. Information is a representation or description of spatiotemporal arrangements (order) of matter and energy, encoded onto a physical substrate. Known substrates include electromagnetic waves, material structures, chemical molecules, and neural networks—whether in brains or computers. In quantum mechanics, when information pertains to elementary particles, the object of study and the substrate encoding the information coincide. This leads to view energy and information as the same phenomenon, leading to counterintuitive and often perplexing interpretations of reality. The proposed definition distinguishes between thermodynamic entropy and information entropy, enabling a consilient bridge between quantum and classical mechanics, genetic information, human knowledge, personal models of the world, consciousness and empathy. It facilitates the study of different kinds of information—especially the kind that generates free energy and enables useful work, as studied by infodynamics. The central insight is that energy and information are distinct, irreducible properties of the universe. Understanding their interplay requires considering four foundational elements: spacetime, matter, energy, and information. These clarifications are fundamental for research in natural and artificial intelligence.

reference: Chicago Journal of International Law, Volume 26, No. 1, Pp. 107-130
title: Satellite Infrastructures and Law in the Making of Planetary Knowledge
affiliations: New York University School of Law and New York University (NYU) - Institute for International Law and Justice (IILJ)

detail.title: Satellite Infrastructures and Law in the Making of Planetary Knowledge

publicationDetails.detailsText: Chicago Journal of International Law, Volume 26, No. 1, Pp. 107-130

detail.abstract:
Imaginations of Planet Earth as-a-whole—that is, Earth conceived in planetary terms by wide publics—have been shaped over several decades by the growing capabilities of artificial Earth satellites to image the whole Earth, to specify all locations, and to integrate the Earth’s diverse orbital space with everyday human activities. Different Earth orbits are becoming more densely used, more securitized, more intensely managed from Earth, and more integral to activities on Earth.

 This Article focuses on two categories of satellite systems that contribute directly to planetary knowledge, Global Navigation Satellite Systems (GNSS) and Earth Observation Satellite Systems (EOSS). GNSS and EOSS have earlier military and intelligence origins, but were readily associated with 1990s-type “globalization”—the encouragement of trade and communication, and the monitoring and discouragement of illicit activities and flows. More recently both have also been integral to a process of “planetization”—the construction and wide diffusion of understandings of Earth in planetary terms, as a shared and contingent habitat with many dependencies. This Article traces the policies and conditions under which data from these satellite systems has become (for the time being) open and widely available to general publics, and the basis for “planetary” infrastructural development and dependence.

We argue that the major GNSS have all become “infrastructural”: broadcasting without charge freely available signals which enable timing, positioning, and navigation via receivers and downstream products for billions of users, as well as a fast-increasing range of important environmental uses. EOSS supply images and other data which flow into scientific models of Earth systems and many business and governmental use cases—with or without charge or restriction, depending on the provider and on government controls. EOSS have become, or are becoming, infrastructural for many forms of planetary knowledge. However, the provision of comprehensive, free-to-all, and highly reliable GNSS and EOSS data and services is not legally embedded or guaranteed, and it is far from assured. Both are “dual use” and vulnerable to kinetic or cyber disruption in conflict. GNSS are government-provided but readily spoofed or jammed, and governments are seeking to develop more resilient alternatives. EOSS are often privately owned or government-controlled, and the data or downstream products are increasingly liable to private enclosure or to government restriction on release. Questions about their assured availability and extension swirl together with renewed nationalism, military prioritization, and contestations of “planetary” politico-legal thinking and its imaginaries. It is now necessary to “think infrastructurally” about legal, policy, and economic means to ensure the reliable and universal availability, sustenance, and supplementation of these important foundations of planetary knowledge.

title: Hope in a Digital Age: Law as a Tool for Ensuring Children's Safety and Future Online in Ghana
affiliations: Kwame Nkrumah University of Science and Technology, Ghana, Kwame Nkrumah University of Science and Technology, Ghana and Kwame Nkrumah University of Science and Technology

detail.title: Hope in a Digital Age: Law as a Tool for Ensuring Children's Safety and Future Online in Ghana

declarations.declarationOfInterest: There are no third-party personal or financial interests influencing this research
declarations.ethicsApproval: There are no ethical breaches in this research as the methodology employed was entirely doctrinal.
declarations.funderStatement: The research was self-funded. Conference attendance was partly funded by the conference organisers

contentFormat.other: Conference Paper - First Annual ChYRP International Conference on Children's Rights, Hebrew University of Jerusalem, Israel

detail.abstract: Technological advancement and the internet space have created a digital world in which children can easily participate. From a very young age children are exposed to and have access to smart phones, televisions, tablets, laptops, and computers which enable them access online materials and programmes. This digital age has led to a growing body of literature analysing the impact of technology on children, especially literature highlighting the advantages and disadvantages of information communication technology for children. The greatest concern of parents and governments is the safety of children online. They, nonetheless, also acknowledge that children’s participation in the digital world cannot be avoided. The digital world is now an integral part of children’s development and future. Digital technology holds opportunities and resources for children’s learning and development at limited cost, regardless of the location. Focusing on Ghana and using a socio-legal research approach, this paper analyses how law can be used to ensure the safety of children online and to protect them from the adverse effects of their online activities. The paper reviews existing literature, statutes, and cases on children’s participation and safety online in Ghana. It emphasizes the specific challenges children face in this digital world, and the nature of legal issues and interventions in the Ghanaian context as a developing African society. It also draws insights from the African Union Child Online Safety and Empowerment Policy, Rwanda’s policy on child online protection and safety initiatives in Kenya, Uganda, and Zambia. The paper argues that rather than clamp down on children’s use of digital technology, Ghana and other Africa countries must create the right legal environment for children to participate in the digital world safely. The paper is in four parts. Part one introduces and outlines the framework of this paper. Part two reviews and analyses relevant literature on children’s use of digital technology. Part three discusses and analyses relevant international and Ghanaian legal instruments that ensure children’s safety in the use of digital technology both in the present and in the future. The last part outlines the findings of the paper, recommendations, and concluding remarks.

title: Ai Companionship: A Step Forward or Backward in Addressing Loneliness?
affiliations: Ss. Cyril and Methodius University

detail.title: Ai Companionship: A Step Forward or Backward in Addressing Loneliness?

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The author declares no conflict of interests.

detail.abstract: Loneliness is one of the biggest global problems of our era and has severe consequences both for individual health and society at large. AI companions, such as social robots or chatbots, are one technological means increasingly relied on to fend off loneliness. It is argued in this paper that while AI companions could help with easing loneliness, the increased reliance on them to address loneliness, especially in everyday contexts, might undermine the problem it tries to address. AI companions do not have an experiencing living body, so they cannot understand or empathize with human beings; additionally, the human–AI relationship lacks mutual relationality and is characterized by simulated relationality. So, even if AI companions, by behaving empathically and by their simulated relationality, can ameliorate the negative feeling of being alone, they could not substantially address the reasons for loneliness. Despite this, AI companions have many features that exploit human psychology and that appear all-positive for the user, which makes them highly appealing. However, because of these all-positive conditions, and because they are social actors with the power to contribute in shaping social practices, AI companions could transform, for the worse, how humans understand and what they expect out of human–human relationships. Thus AI companions might contribute to more human isolation, which would increase the chances of loneliness, or they could bring about a new type of loneliness, where one is without the negative feeling that accompanies loneliness but still lacks the desired quantity and/or quality of human relationships.

title: Accounting and Reporting of Co-operatives in the UK: Practices, Challenges and Recommendations
affiliations: University of Birmingham - Birmingham Business School

detail.title: Accounting and Reporting of Co-operatives in the UK: Practices, Challenges and Recommendations

declarations.funderStatement: We would like to sincerely thank the University of Birmingham for their financial support through the Business School’s Research and Impact funds, and acknowledge the financial support received by the Economic and Social Research Council’s Impact Acceleration Fund.

detail.abstract: This report explores the accounting and reporting practices and challenges faced by co-operatives in the UK, enterprises operating under principles of democratic control and mutual benefit. These defining principles set co-operatives apart from both investor-owned business and traditional for-profit or non-profit organisations. Accounting standards, such as the International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) and UK Generally Accepted Accounting Practice (GAAP), are tailored to investor-owned business and business driven by the profit motive, focusing primarily on increasing financial returns and shareholder value. As a result, these standards fail to adequately address the accountability needs of co-operatives, creating challenges for co-operatives in aligning their accounting practices and reporting with their purpose, core values, and governance structures. Drawing on interviews with co-operative practitioners, accountants, researchers, and regulators, this report provides insights into current practices, the obstacles co-operatives face, and potential pathways for improvement. Its primary objectives are to explore the accounting landscape for UK co-operatives, highlight key challenges, and offer recommendations to better align accounting practices and frameworks with the core principles and values of co-operatives.

title: The Illusion of Competition
affiliations: Independent

detail.title: The Illusion of Competition
detail.abstract: Markets do not operate under genuine freedom. Dominant entities establish the parameters (through lobbying, data monopolization, and network externalities). Consumers seldom possess authentic choices . As monopolistic ecosystems ensnare them (for instance, Google Search, Amazon Marketplace). Power inherently consolidates. In the absence of robust interventions, markets gravitate toward oligopoly or monopoly. Legal frameworks frequently favor established players. If competition is indeed an illusion, then permitting “the market” to govern societal structures is also a deceptive portrayal of neutrality and jurisprudence must intervene not solely to rectify pricing mechanisms, but also to safeguard liberty and equity. Concentrated economic power correlates with concentrated political power. If markets are manipulated or monopolized, citizens forfeit their autonomy, akin to conditions under an authoritarian regime. Thus, democracy necessitates not only a division of powers within the government, but also within the economic sphere.

title: Coordinating Pro-Social Practices in Decentralized Relationships: The Case of the Buy-One-Give-One Model
affiliations: Ohio State University (OSU) - Fisher College of Business, Purdue University, Ohio State University (OSU) - Fisher College of Business and Yonsei University

detail.title: Coordinating Pro-Social Practices in Decentralized Relationships: The Case of the Buy-One-Give-One Model
detail.abstract: With social preferences playing an increasingly pivotal role in consumer decisions, supply chains are facing critical new dimensions on which coordination becomes important. A case in point is the retail adoption of the buy-one-give-one (BOGO) model - a sales approach in which a retailer pledges it will donate one unit of product to charity for each consumer purchase. This retail decision inevitably has repercussions up the supply chain. In this paper, we demonstrate that supply chain participants are aligned in their preferences over when to adopt the BOGO sales model. Such unanimity arises despite the self-interest of participants leading to conflicting decisions on traditional pricing and stocking choices. The salve that ensures coordination is the ability of input prices to adjust in ways that naturally share externalities proportionally among supply chain partners. Additionally, the criteria for BOGO adoption is efficient in that it maximizes welfare. In an extension, we demonstrate that these properties of unanimity and efficiency expand beyond the BOGO case to a wider set of pro-social decisions made along the supply chain.

title: Measuring Workplace Spirituality Through Yoga: Implications for HR and Leadership
affiliations: Lovely Professional University, Woxsen University and Lovely Professional University

detail.title: Measuring Workplace Spirituality Through Yoga: Implications for HR and Leadership
detail.abstract: Purpose: The study developed and validated a scale to measure workplace spirituality in the Indian context, drawing upon the four classical paths of Yoga-Karma, Bhakti, Raja, and Jnana Yoga. Methodology: A mixed-methods approach, incorporating a literature review, expert insights, and quantitative analysis, was employed to design and validate the scale. The scale was validated using responses from 232 bank employees in the Delhi/NCR region. This study also investigated the impact of the scale on organizational commitment, work-life balance, and job satisfaction using SEM through AMOS 23. Findings: The scale demonstrated reliability, with Cronbach alpha values ranging from .933 to .837. Furthermore, confirmatory factor analysis conducted on the scale showed satisfactory results. SEM model testing revealed that Karma Yoga was the strongest predictor of outcome variables, explaining 59% of the variance in these variables, followed by Raja Yoga, which had a significant impact on all variables (41%). Bhakti Yoga was found to have a significant impact on both affective commitment and job satisfaction (5%), while Jnana Yoga was observed to have a significant negative effect on outcome variables (-16%). Practical Implications: The scale can help managers evaluate and support employees' spiritual well-being, particularly in the Indian context, leading to improved organizational performance and the cultivation of values-based leadership. Originality: By operationalizing different yoga paths, the study closed a critical measurement gap and provided insights into workplace spirituality from an Indian perspective.

title: The Dual Impact of Technological Investment: Spillover Benefits from Quantum to Classical Computing
affiliations: University of Toronto - Rotman School of Management and University of Southern California - Marshall School of Business

detail.title: The Dual Impact of Technological Investment: Spillover Benefits from Quantum to Classical Computing
detail.abstract: Scholars have found that market forces often incentivize socially suboptimal diversification in technological innovation trajectories. These insights focus on settings where innovators are in a race to create a new technology that replaces an incumbent technology. We extend these findings by modelling a setting where investments in the development of a new technology can generate positive spillovers, broadly defined as benefits firms could obtain in their core trajectory from innovating in another trajectory. We test our model findings in the market for computing, where there is evidence that firms with prior investments in classical computing (i.e., an incumbent technology) have been able to improve the efficacy of those investments by experimenting and investing in quantum computing (i.e., a new technology). Consistent with our model results, we find that: 1.) firms with classical computing investments invest more in quantum computing than those without classical computing investments, and 2.) the difference in investments between these two groups is reduced as the likelihood of the commercialization of a quantum computer increases. Our model also suggests that in a market with technology spillovers, firm investments in the new technology may be less than, more than, or equal to the socially optimal level. These model results further suggest that a firm's investments in quantum computing may still be socially optimal ex ante, even if the firm never ultimately develops a commercially useful, fault-tolerant quantum computer, ex post.

title: Effect of Product Variety on Food Waste: A Consumer-Level Analysis
affiliations: Pennsylvania State University - Smeal College of Business, Smeal College of Business, Pennsylvania State University and Pennsylvania State University - Smeal College of Business

detail.title: Effect of Product Variety on Food Waste: A Consumer-Level Analysis
detail.abstract: Problem definition: The received wisdom in the field of operations management on product variety is that it is generally detrimental to efficiency. But there is not much evidence that supports this, and nowhere near enough is known on why or how product variety is linked to various notions of inefficiency, including waste. To contribute to the field's understanding of how product variety influences waste in supply chains, we explore the link between food product variety and food waste at the consumer level, where a great majority of food waste occurs in economic terms. Methodology/results: We collect granular post-consumer food waste data and daily menus over a full academic year for multiple dining halls of a large U.S. public university. Besides establishing the first-order effect -- that higher product variety (increased choice on the dining menu) is associated with higher food waste -- and estimating the magnitude of this effect, we scrutinize several contextual factors that moderate it by imposing a sense of 'time pressure' on the diners. We find that an additional main dish on the menu results in a 6.72% increase on average in post-consumer food waste. We also discover that factors imposing greater time pressure on the diners (e.g., classes, exams, and absence of trays) significantly reduce and sometimes altogether eliminate this positive link between variety and waste. Managerial implications: Our findings offer insights on the variety-waste tradeoff endemic in restaurant and dining operations; while increasing product variety may enhance consumer satisfaction, it comes at the cost of higher food waste, which could lead to significant environmental and economic consequences. Managers seeking to reduce waste without compromising variety could adopt interventions that impose mild time pressure.

title: Statistical Modeling of SOFR Term Structure
affiliations: King's College London and King's College London

detail.title: Statistical Modeling of SOFR Term Structure

declarations.ethicsApproval: This research was supported by UKRI.

detail.abstract: SOFR derivatives market remains illiquid and incomplete so it is not amenable to classical risk-neutral term structure models which are based on the assumption of perfect liquidity and completeness. This paper develops a statistical SOFR term structure model that is well-suited for risk management and derivatives pricing within the incomplete markets paradigm. The model incorporates relevant macroeconomic factors that drive central bank policy rates which, in turn, cause jumps often observed in the SOFR rates. The model is easy to calibrate to historical data, current market quotes, and the user's views concerning the future development of the relevant macroeconomic factors. The model is well suited for large-scale simulations often required in risk management, portfolio optimization and indifference pricing of interest rate derivatives.

title: Classifying and Contextualizing the Unknown: An Interpretable Algorithm for Open Set Recognition
affiliations: University at Buffalo (SUNY) - School of Management, University at Buffalo, SUNY,  University at Buffalo, Department of Industrial and Systems Engineering, Students, University at Buffalo, University at Buffalo and State University of New York (SUNY) - University at Buffalo

detail.title: Classifying and Contextualizing the Unknown: An Interpretable Algorithm for Open Set Recognition
detail.abstract: Open set recognition (OSR) is a problem that tasks machine learning classifiers with labeling both known instances and those that appear unfamiliar. Existing OSR methods rely on probability-or distance-based thresholds to classify unknown instances, largely restricting the potential for understanding how these instances may relate to known classes. This paper introduces a novel OSR algorithm that removes the need for thresholding by using a continuous abatement model to adjust predicted class probabilities based on similarity in feature space. The algorithm returns a set of |K| + 1 confidence values for any test instance, where |K| is the number of known classes included in training, and the open set is treated as the |K| + 1 st class. These confidence values enable accurate classification and interpretable contextualization across known and unknown instances. We evaluate our approach on four datasets, including two focused on predicting the combinatorial problem class (e.g., bin packing, lot sizing) of integer programming instances. Our method consistently outperforms existing OSR techniques, while, for the first time, enabling contextualization between unfamiliar inputs and known classes-an advantage with relevance in domains such as diagnostics, defect detection, and optimization, among others.

title: Re-evaluating Short-and Long-Term Trend Factors in CTA Replication: A Bayesian Graphical Approach
affiliations: Université Paris Dauphine, AI For Alpha, AI For Alpha, AI For Alpha, AI For Alpha and AI For Alpha

detail.title: Re-evaluating Short-and Long-Term Trend Factors in CTA Replication: A Bayesian Graphical Approach
detail.abstract: Commodity Trading Advisors (CTAs) have historically relied on trend-following rules that operate on vastly different horizons-from long-term breakouts that capture major directional moves to short-term momentum signals that thrive in fast-moving markets. Despite a large body of work on trend following, the relative merits and interactions of shortversus long-term trend systems remain controversial. This paper adds to the debate by (i) dynamically decomposing CTA returns into short-term trend, long-term trend and market beta factors using a Bayesian graphical model, and (ii) showing how the blend of horizons shapes the strategy's risk-adjusted performance.

title: Cultural Analysis of the Legend of the Whistler
affiliations: EDUKIVOTOS

detail.title: Cultural Analysis of the Legend of the Whistler
detail.abstract: This academic project explores the Colombian legend of El Silbón through multidisciplinary lenses, examining its role as a myth in shaping ethics, emotions, social norms, identity, and economic potential. Analyzed from theories by Durkheim, Aristotle, Plutchik, Moscovici, and Harvey, El Silbón is shown to function as a pedagogical, symbolic, and cultural resource. The study reveals its adaptability to modern media, its emotional and psychological depth, and its use in tourism, ritual, and intergenerational transmission. It argues that the legend is not only a vessel of fear but also of identity, memory, and community resilience.

title: Where Ashes Sing: The Poetics of Collapse in the Psalms and the Interdisciplinary Pathways of Healing Leadership

detail.abstract: This paper explores the poetic architecture of collapse within the Psalms and reinterprets spiritual downfall as a transformative space rather than a site of shame. Through an interdisciplinary lens-bridging theology, psychology, leadership studies, and organizational management-this study investigates how the Psalms reframe emotional breakdown as sacred ground for renewal. The metaphor of ashes singing becomes a central theological and aesthetic motif: a symbol of the soul's surrender that paradoxically generates new songs of resilience and grace. Drawing from trauma psychology, theories of authentic leadership, and the adaptive principles of crisis management, this paper argues that the Psalms are not only spiritual documents but also frameworks for emotional intelligence and ethical leadership. In David's laments and confessions, we discover a new grammar of strength: one that does not deny fragility but redeems it. The Psalms invite modern leaders-not only in faith communities but also in organizational settings-to integrate emotional transparency, poetic vulnerability, and reflective courage into their leadership paradigms.

title: Stock Price Informativeness, Managerial Horizon, and Dynamic Incentive Provision
affiliations: University of Oregon, Lundquist School of Business

detail.title: Stock Price Informativeness, Managerial Horizon, and Dynamic Incentive Provision
detail.abstract: This paper examines how stock price informativeness affects the effectiveness of price-based managerial compensation. Stock prices fluctuate with publicly observed macroeconomic shocks and impound private signals of managerial performance through information-based trading. Because sequentially optimal contracts overly exploit prices as forward-looking performance benchmarks, greater price informativeness can discourage long-tenure managers from pursuing long-term value creation. For managers bound to long-term employment, renegotiable contracts based solely on terminal cash flows can tie pay to internal interim forecasts, potentially outperforming rigid contracts based on both stock prices and cash flows. The study also finds that, depending on the composition of uncertainty in long-term firm fundamentals, managerial incentives can strengthen with firm-specific risk, and a strictly intermediate level of stock-price informativeness can be optimal.

title: Effect of Exchange Rate on the Market Capitalization Segments of Indian Stock Market
affiliations: Annamalai University - Department of Business Administration and Annamalai University - Department of Business Administration

detail.title: Effect of Exchange Rate on the Market Capitalization Segments of Indian Stock Market

publicationDetails.detailsText: South Eastern European Journal of Public Health, Volume XXV, S2, Pp. 3921-3925, December 2024.

detail.abstract: The present article attempts to examine the effect of Exchange Rate on the market capitalization segments of the Indian stock market. The monthly data is observed from the period of April 2012 to March 2022 and employed Correlogram, Johansen's Cointegration, and Granger Causality tests on Exchange Rate and Indian stock market's market capitalization segments (BSE LargeCap, BSE MidCap, & BSE SmallCap indices). It reveals that the Exchange Rate has a long-run relationship with the BSE LargeCap and BSE MidCap indices segments of market capitalization of Indian stock market.

title: Disability-Inclusive Workforce Planning
affiliations: Xi'an Jiaotong-Liverpool University (XJTLU), University of Texas at Dallas - Naveen Jindal School of Management and School of Economics and Management, Tsinghua University

detail.title: Disability-Inclusive Workforce Planning
detail.abstract: Socially responsible firms are increasingly motivated to hire people with disabilities (PWD). Doing so, however, can lower average service quality and raise training costs, making managers unsure how many PWD to employ and whether to invest in specialized training. Governments try to help with two subsidies: one pays for every PWD hired, the other for every PWD trained. Thus, it is important to investigate when these subsidies help or hurt the very workers they are meant to support, and which subsidy mix best improves their welfare within a fixed public budget. We  build a stylized game-theoretic model of a socially responsible firm serving customers who value both service quality and disability inclusion. The firm chooses the share of PWD hires and whether to train them. In the laissez‑faire benchmark (i.e., no government intervention) the firm hires PWD only when customer prosociality exceeds a threshold and increases their share as prosociality rises, yet may withhold training at high prosociality to avoid costs. A training subsidy can unintentionally reduce PWD hiring if training costs are moderate and customer prosociality is high; a small hiring subsidy can lead the firm to hire more PWD but stop training them, cutting their pay. Optimal public policy is simple and “pure”: (i) either subsidy works when training is inexpensive; (ii) a training-only subsidy works when training costs are moderate; (iii) an employment-only subsidy works when training is costly. These patterns remain even when only part of the PWD workforce can be trained. Managers should match their disability-inclusive hiring and training choices to both customer sentiment and training costs. Policymakers should recognize that well‑meant subsidies can backfire under certain conditions. Instead of mixing both subsidy types, it could be possible for policymakers to pick a single instrument that fits local cost conditions, thereby safeguarding PWD welfare.

title: Facilitating Digital Transformation of SMEs via AI-Enhanced Financial Education and Digital Skill Development Solutions: A Strategic Necessity
affiliations: University of London

detail.title: Facilitating Digital Transformation of SMEs via AI-Enhanced Financial Education and Digital Skill Development Solutions: A Strategic Necessity
detail.abstract: Small and Medium-sized Enterprises (SMEs) represent the foundation of the global economy; nonetheless, they consistently fall behind in digital transformation (DT) due to resource restrictions, talent deficiencies, and inadequate financial literacy. This study paper contends that the synergistic amalgamation of Artificial Intelligence (AI)-driven financial education and digital upskilling solutions provides a scalable, tailored, and economical approach to surmount these obstacles and expedite SME digital transformation. We examine the distinct challenges encountered by SMEs, investigate the theoretical underpinnings for AI application in education and finance, delineate the architecture and capabilities of prospective AI-driven solutions, provide evidence of effectiveness, address implementation factors and ethical concerns, and propose avenues for future research. This paper presents a complete framework for policymakers, solution providers, financial institutions, and SME leaders aiming to achieve sustainable growth and competitiveness via enhanced digital adoption.

title: Skycharge: Deploying Unmanned Aerial Vehicles For Dynamic Load Optimization in Solar Small Cell 5g Networks
affiliations: BITS Pilani

detail.title: Skycharge: Deploying Unmanned Aerial Vehicles For Dynamic Load Optimization in Solar Small Cell 5g Networks
detail.abstract: The power requirements posed by the fifth-generation and beyond cellular networks are an important constraint in network deployment and require energy-efficient solutions. In this work, we propose a novel user load transfer approach using airborne base stations (BS) mounted on drones for reliable and secure power redistribution across the micro-grid network comprising green small cell BSs. Depending on the user density and the availability of an aerial BS, the energy requirement of a cell with an energy deficit is accommodated by migrating the aerial BS from a high-energy to a low-energy cell. The proposed hybrid drone-based framework integrates long short-term memory with unique cost functions using an evolutionary neural network for drones and BSs and efficiently manages energy and load redistribution. The proposed algorithm reduces power outages at BSs and maintains consistent throughput stability, thereby demonstrating its capability to boost the reliability and robustness of wireless communication systems.

title: Rethinking Accountability in the Age of Ai Tax Governance: Sovereign Power, Algorithmic Control, and Democratic Legitimacy
affiliations: University of Piraeus

detail.title: Rethinking Accountability in the Age of Ai Tax Governance: Sovereign Power, Algorithmic Control, and Democratic Legitimacy
detail.abstract: The digitalization of tax administration through AI remains under-theorized in accounting and public governance research, despite its accelerating adoption globally. The study addresses this gap by developing an integrated conceptual framework that combines accountability theory, socio-materiality, boundary work, algorithmic governance, and normative ethics. It examines how AI-driven tax systems redistribute discretion, reshape institutional logics, and generate new governance tensions. Three core propositions highlight emerging accountability challenges around actor ecosystems, algorithmic opacity, and institutional hybridization. The paper contributes to both theory and practice by clarifying how Digitalization 3.0 transforms public sector accountability, offering a foundation for future empirical research, policy design, and practical governance safeguards as governments often adopt AI in sensitive fiscal domains.

title: Machine Learning-Driven Scenario Planning for the Energy Mixture
affiliations: Koç University and Koç University

detail.title: Machine Learning-Driven Scenario Planning for the Energy Mixture
detail.abstract: This study presents a data-driven approach using machine learning (ML) methods to forecast electricity generation and analyze carbon emissions under various scenarios. The research compares traditional time series models with advanced ML algorithms including CatBoost, XGBoost, and LightGBM, implementing both single-output and multi-output modeling approaches. A novel set covering optimization method is introduced to determine optimal combinations of energy generation sources, achieving a $0.57$ total root mean squared error compared to $2.14$ for traditional methods. The study develops and analyzes multiple scenarios including Carbon Neutral Future, Domestic Priority, and Carbon Reduction scenarios, integrating them with a grid search algorithm to optimize capacity planning coefficients. Results demonstrate that while renewable energy capacity is projected to increase $2.2$ times by $2029$, carbon emissions remain significant due to continued fossil fuel dependency, particularly during peak demand periods. The Grid Search scenario shows the most promising results for emission reduction, while the Domestic Priority scenario leads to higher emissions. This research provides valuable insights for policymakers in developing data-driven, sustainable energy strategies aligned with international commitments like the Paris Agreement and Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism, while offering a methodological framework that can be adapted for different energy markets.

title: Scheduling of Rejected Orders and Recycling in Distributed Heterogeneous Flow Production Under Qualification, Availability and Budget Constraints
affiliations: Fujian Jiangxia University

detail.title: Scheduling of Rejected Orders and Recycling in Distributed Heterogeneous Flow Production Under Qualification, Availability and Budget Constraints
detail.abstract: This study proposes a novel Two-stage Scheduling Framework (TSSF) for order acceptance and scheduling with recycling strategy in distributed heterogeneous non-permutation flow shop environments. The framework employs a hybrid logic-based Benders decomposition with constraint programming approach in the first stage to determine initial order acceptance and factory assignments under strict operational constraints, followed by an adaptive negotiation mechanism in the second stage that reconsiders rejected orders through deadline flexibility, compensation adjustments, and outsourcing options. The negotiation process utilizes multi-criteria scoring functions to evaluate order potential while incorporating a quadratic stability penalty to balance profit maximization against schedule disruption. Comprehensive computational experiments demonstrate that TSSF achieves near-optimal solutions for small instances and maintains computational efficiency for large-scale problems where exact methods fail, with the negotiation mechanism successfully recovering a significant portion of initially rejected orders across various budget scenarios and instance sizes. The results validate that the proposed framework provides a practical and efficient approach for industrial scheduling problems by effectively integrating customer flexibility considerations into the order acceptance process while maintaining operational stability.

title: Factors Affecting the Status of Utilisation of Primary Health Care Facilities Upgraded under the Uganda Reproductive Maternal and Child Health Improvement Project
affiliations: University of Cumbria

detail.title: Factors Affecting the Status of Utilisation of Primary Health Care Facilities Upgraded under the Uganda Reproductive Maternal and Child Health Improvement Project

declarations.declarationOfInterest: No financial relationship
declarations.ethicsApproval: Approval provided to conduct research among health practitioners through the Ministry of Health of Uganda.
declarations.funderStatement: Self funded research

detail.abstract: The report evaluates the factors that affect the effective utilisation of Investments made with regard to infrastructure and equipment in primary health care facilities under the Uganda Reproductive Maternal and Child Health Project. The study has three objectives; to determine the extent to which existing government policy environment support the effective utilisation of investments, to determine the extent to which human resource factors affect the utilization of investments, and to determine the extent to which existing maintenance practices affect the utilization of investments made with regard to infrastructure and equipment. A contextual and theoretical review of literature is made to identify key relational concepts with regard to performance. The study employed a case study design and was carried out on a representative sample among a total of 81 facilities situated in 61 Districts in Uganda. These facilities were recently upgraded with infrastructure and equipment facilities to provide enhanced community health care. Self-administered questionnaires were sent to health workers at these facilities, leaders, and administrators in the respective districts. There were a total of 120 questionnaires sent with a response rate of 91. The study found that infrastructure and equipment factors do not have a significant influence on the utilization of the facilities while human resource and institutional management factors were found to significantly affect the status of utilisation of facilities. The study exemplifies the impact of human resource and institutional management capacity on the utilisation of facilities that are upgraded for the provision of primary health care. The study further recommends recruitment of sufficient human resources, alignment of drug restocking systems and the provision of adequate housing facilities for staff at the respective facilities. In conclusion, the success of investments in primary health care facilities is heavily dependent on the availability and capacity of human resources and effective institutional management.

title: The Flexibility-Efficiency Nexus in Industrial Heat Electrification: Optimal Management of Coupled Heat Pump-Storage Systems
affiliations: University of Naples Federico II, University of Naples Federico II, University of Naples Federico II, University of Naples Federico II, University of Naples Federico II and University of Naples Federico II

detail.title: The Flexibility-Efficiency Nexus in Industrial Heat Electrification: Optimal Management of Coupled Heat Pump-Storage Systems
detail.abstract: The electrification of industrial heat is a key strategy for decarbonising industrial energy-intensive processes and reducing greenhouse gas emissions. However, this transition leads to increased electricity demand, making energy flexibility essential for the reliable and efficient integration of electrified systems. This study investigates the flexibility-efficiency nexus in industrial heat electrification through the optimal management of a coupled heat pump and thermal energy storage system. A mixed-integer linear programming model is developed to optimise operations over a one-year horizon, minimising energy costs while accounting through a piecewise linearisation for the non-linear performance of the heat pump and the varying electricity price and outdoor temperature.A novel index, the Flexibility Response Potential (FRP), is introduced to quantify the system’s ability to shift electricity demand in response to external signals. The proposed model is applied to a case study of an Italian industrial facility. Multiple system configurations, combining different heat pump capacities and thermal storage volumes, are simulated to evaluate the performance in terms of energy efficiency, operational flexibility, and economic feasibility. This comprehensive parametric analysis supports robust design and sizing decisions. Results show that the optimised operational strategy of the integrated thermal energy storage system enables the heat pump to operate more frequently in its high-efficiency range, improving the average performance (COP) by up to 15% and reducing CO₂ emissions by 1.8–12% compared to the traditional operation of the electrified system, and by over 70% when compared to a scenario with heating systems fuelled with natural gas. Electricity costs are reduced by up to 30%, and payback times remain below 12 years for the most effective configurations.The study provides practical design guidelines and confirms the techno-economic viability of heat pump-thermal storage systems in industrial decarbonisation strategies, highlighting their role as distributed flexibility resources within increasingly electrified energy infrastructures.

title: From Rituals to Resilience: A Policy Perspective on Modernising Certification in Aviation
affiliations: Cranfield University

detail.title: From Rituals to Resilience: A Policy Perspective on Modernising Certification in Aviation
detail.abstract: Aviation has long been considered a High Reliability Organisation (HRO), renowned for its low accident rates and robust safety systems. However, emerging cyber-physical technologies and increasingly complex aircraft systems challenge the adequacy of traditional certification tools. This paper critiques the continued reliance on legacy reliability standards such as MIL-HDBK-217, arguing that they institutionalise ritualistic processes that obscure systemic risk. Through a detailed case analysis of the Boeing 787 battery fires and comparative review of FAA and EASA regulatory pathways, the paper highlights how deterministic assumptions and regulatory inertia undermine resilience. It proposes a policy roadmap for certification reform grounded in complexity-aware methodologies, including Systems-Theoretic Process Analysis (STPA), Physics-of-Failure (PoF), and digital twin-based scenario modelling. The analysis underscores the urgent need for international harmonisation, sunset clauses for obsolete standards, and adaptive oversight frameworks that can keep pace with technological evolution. By reframing certification as a dynamic governance challenge, this paper aligns with the broader policy discourse on systemic safety and offers actionable insights for transport regulators, policymakers, and industry stakeholders.

title: A Cross-Environment Transfer Learning Method for Industrial Robot State Perception: Anomaly Detection Research from Laboratory to Factory Settings
affiliations: Chongqing University, Chongqing University, Chongqing University, Chongqing University, Chongqing University, Chongqing University and Chongqing University

detail.title: A Cross-Environment Transfer Learning Method for Industrial Robot State Perception: Anomaly Detection Research from Laboratory to Factory Settings
detail.abstract: Industrial robot condition monitoring is critical for production safety, yet real-world factories face low-frequency, single-modality sensor constraints, limiting anomaly detection accuracy. Due to hardware, cost, and production limitations, adding external sensors is often impractical. To address this, we propose a Dynamic-Masking Transfer Anomaly Network (DMTAN) that pretrains on multi-source high-frequency lab data and transfers learned feature modeling knowledge to factory settings with only low-frequency internal sensors, enabling robust and reliable anomaly detection. A multi-source dataset combining low-frequency internal and high-frequency external sensors is constructed in the lab as the source domain. Two target domains are defined: (1) lab data with external sensors removed, simulating factory sensor configurations for validating the transfer strategy; and (2) real factory data with only internal sensors, used to evaluate generalization in actual deployment. To bridge the domain gap, a dynamic masking mechanism gradually suppresses external sensor input during training. A Dynamic Temporal Heterogeneous Graph Attention Network (DTHAN) models structural and semantic relationships across joints and sensor types, while the Informer module captures long-range dependencies. A dynamic weighted loss and pretraining–finetuning strategy further enhance adaptability under distribution shifts. Experiments show DMTAN achieves a 6.2% F1-score improvement over non-transfer models on lab anomaly data and yields the lowest MAE, MSE, and MAPE on real factory data. Without requiring extra sensors, it offers a transferable, low-cost solution for accurate anomaly detection in complex robotic environments.

title: Multi-Criteria Decision Support for Supplier Selection in the Facility Management
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, Université de Bourgogne and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Multi-Criteria Decision Support for Supplier Selection in the Facility Management
detail.abstract: This paper presents a novel mathematical optimization framework for systematic supplier-site assignment in multi-site facility management procurement. The research addresses the critical challenge of matching supplier capabilities with heterogeneous site requirements while incorporating dynamic decision-maker preferences into the selection process.We introduce an innovative correlation function that quantifies supplier-requirement alignment across multiple characteristic dimensions. The framework incorporates a dynamic weighting system $W(P)$ that adapts baseline weights in real-time based on organizational preferences through influence coefficients $\alpha_{x_i,j}$, enabling seamless integration of strategic objectives while maintaining mathematical rigor through normalization constraints. Our approach successfully adapts classical warehouse location theory to procurement optimization by replacing transportation costs with similarity-based scoring mechanisms. The framework is validated through a comprehensive computational example using synthetic facility management data involving two sites (corporate office and manufacturing plant) and three suppliers. Results demonstrate the system's capability to systematically evaluate supplier combinations. The dynamic weighting mechanism successfully prioritizes service capabilities over certifications based on decision-maker preferences. The proposed methodology transforms subjective procurement decisions into objective, quantifiable evaluations, providing procurement managers with a systematic tool for evidence-based supplier selection in complex multi-site environments.

detail.abstract: The book, A-Z Contemporary Essays in Ghanaian Law (A Edition: Volume 1), was birthed from the desire to provide a well-researched resource for readers, including legal practitioners, legal academics, researchers, law students, and the public. It discusses various legal topics, focusing on contemporary issues arising from them. The A Edition centres on contemporary and emerging issues across the following areas: Administration of Estates, Vesting Assent and Accountability; Adoption within and outside Ghana; Advancement, Resulting Trust, and Gift; Appeals, Permissible Leaves, and Timelines; Arbitration (Court-Referred) and Delays; Artificial Intelligence; and Aviation and Passenger Rights in Ghana. This A Edition is the first of several series to come. It features carefully selected topics in Ghanaian law, arranged alphabetically for easy navigation. In addition to identifying and exposing readers to contemporary issues in law, this book serves as a valuable guide for legal research, pointing to resources relevant to the topics discussed. It also provides handy reference material for researching legal matters requiring a quick turnaround. Furthermore, it satisfies and inspires curious minds eager to understand the position and development of the law on the topics explored in this book. This book stands out because the editors and contributors, representing various legal education and practice aspects, have infused their diverse experiences into this project.

title: A Scalable Semi-Supervised Parallel Processing Framework for Robustdefect Detection in Tft-Lcd Manufacturing
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, Hong Kong Polytechnic University, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: A Scalable Semi-Supervised Parallel Processing Framework for Robustdefect Detection in Tft-Lcd Manufacturing

keywords.keywords: TFT-LCD ManufacturingSemi-Supervised ROI DetectionGrad-CAMSliding Window MechanismMajority Voting EnsembleAutomated Product Quality Evaluation

detail.abstract: High-throughput, automated defect detection is critical for cost-effective TFT-LCD manufacturing.This study introduces a novel framework integrating Canny-Harris edge detection, Class ActivationMapping (CAM) with PYLON-RN50E and DenseNet-201-GGC, and an Optimal Majority VotingEnsemble (OMVE) with DenseNet-201, PYLON-RN50E, and EfficientNetv2-s-CBAM, enhanced bya Sliding Window Mechanism (SWM). Leveraging semi-supervised learning, the framework achievesrobust region-of-interest (ROI) localization and defect classification with minimal annotation effort,ideal for high-mix production environments. Evaluated on datasets of 5,000–35,000 image patches, itdelivers classification accuracies of 95.81% (Majority Voting Ensemble) and 96.33% (OMVE), with94.01% ROI detection accuracy (PYLON-RN50E). Benchmarking against state-of-the-art methodsdemonstrates superior accuracy, robustness, and efficiency, driven by advanced feature extractionand parallel processing. This framework’s scalability and adaptability position it as a transformativesolution for TFT-LCD manufacturing and extend its impact to diverse industries.

title: Remittances and income diversification in Bolivia’s rural sector
affiliations: Oklahoma State University, affiliation not provided to SSRN and Cyprus University of Technology

detail.title: Remittances and income diversification in Bolivia’s rural sector
detail.abstract: This article examines the role of remittances in income diversification strategies in Bolivia’s rural sector. Remittances can be consumed or invested by the recipient. As an investment, funds can be used for farming or to finance other nonfarm productions. In this article, we use a large and nationally representative survey to estimate the effect that remittances have on the probability of producing income from nonfarm activities (diversification) by using a bivariate probit model. Our evidence shows that remittances increase the probability that a rural family engages in nonfarm activities, at least in some regions of Bolivia. We also find evidence that the sender’s decision to remit and the recipient’s decision to diversify may be jointly determined. As such, this suggests that remittances may serve as a mechanism to overcome localized failures in Bolivia’s capital markets.

title: Ethica (Ordine Geometrico Demonstrata) As Executable Metaphysics_Functional Translation Into Python Logic
affiliations: Independent

detail.title: Ethica (Ordine Geometrico Demonstrata) As Executable Metaphysics_Functional Translation Into Python Logic
detail.abstract: This work presents a full-system formal translation of Baruch Spinoza’s Ethics into a structured and functional Python ontology. Each of the five books — from De Deo (On God) to De Libertate Humana (On Human Liberty) — is encoded using object-oriented classes, axiomatic functions, and executable propositions. By rendering Spinoza’s metaphysics as a programmable structure, the system models substance, attribute, mode, idea, and affect in a logically traceable, testable form. This translation enables both philosophical analysis and computational experimentation: ideas can now be reasoned with, simulated, and composed algorithmically. The result is not merely a digitization, but an executable metaphysics — a working foundation for formal epistemology, ethical cognition, and ontological engineering.

title: Exploring Sustainability Trends in the European Food Startup Ecosystem
affiliations: University of Macedonia, University of Macedonia and University of Macedonia

detail.title: Exploring Sustainability Trends in the European Food Startup Ecosystem
detail.abstract: Globally, the food business is becoming increasingly focused on sustainability, and startups are essential to fostering this. This study examines data from 940 food related startups to investigate sustainability trends in the European food startup ecosystem. We discovered research trends and grouped startups utilizing text analysis and clustering algorithms. Our study identified several common sustainability themes among food entrepreneurs in Europe, including Food Waste and Digital Services, Organic Health Products and Supplements, Sustainable and Plant-Based Foods, Healthy Meal Services and Global Food Supply Chain Solutions. Geographic analysis highlights the UK, Germany, and Spain as leaders within the European food startup ecosystem, which has seen robust growth from 2013 to 2020, followed by a stability period. The Healthy Meal Services cluster has received the most significant funding, reflecting its established and mature market presence, while the Food Waste and Digital Services cluster also shows a broad engagement in funding, particularly in the lower funding ranges, indicating active investment in early-stage ventures. Our findings can help bridge the gap between entrepreneurial and sustainable growth research, which has received limited empirical support in the past few years.

title: Co2 Valorization to Sodium Bicarbonate: A Techno-Economic Feasibility Study within an Italian Waste-to-Energy Plant
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, Polytechnic University of Milan, Politecnico di Milano - Dipartimento CMIC "Giulio Natta", affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and A2A S.p.A.

detail.title: Co2 Valorization to Sodium Bicarbonate: A Techno-Economic Feasibility Study within an Italian Waste-to-Energy Plant
detail.abstract: As anthropogenic CO2 emissions continue to contribute significantly to global warming, the development of innovative strategies for converting CO2 into value-added products has become increasingly critical. CO2 utilization encompasses a range of technologies that transform carbon dioxide into fuels, chemicals and materials, reframing it as a resource rather than a waste stream. This paradigm shift supports both emissions reduction and the advancement of a circular economy by integrating carbon capture with downstream conversion processes.Within this framework, Waste-to-Energy (WtE) plants offer a strategic opportunity for CO2 valorisation. Among the potential pathways, sodium bicarbonate production is particularly attractive due to its application in dry flue gas treatment for the removal of SOx and other acidic pollutants.This study investigates the integration of sodium bicarbonate production from captured CO2 in the context of an Italian WtE facility. A conceptual process flowsheet is developed using Aspen Plus® V14 and its feasibility is evaluated from energy, economic, and environmental perspectives. The analysis aims to support the future design and implementation of a pilot-scale plant, contributing to the deployment of CO2 utilization technologies in WtE systems.

title: Spatial Matching of Random Samples on a Circle: Theoretic Analysis and Applications on Ride-Hailing Systems
affiliations: University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign, The Chinese University of Hong Kong, Shenzhen and The University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign

detail.title: Spatial Matching of Random Samples on a Circle: Theoretic Analysis and Applications on Ride-Hailing Systems
detail.abstract:
This paper investigates the problem of spatially matching two sets of random samples—n of one type and m of another (n \leq m)—independently and uniformly distributed on a circle with unit circumference. Although central to various stochastic systems, exact analytical characterization of the optimal matching cost remains challenging.

We make several key contributions. First, for the one-direction matching problem (clockwise distance), we derive an exact closed-form integral expression for the expected average matching cost, F_1(n,m) = \int_0^1 z^m (2-z)^{n-1} \dd z, providing a precise analytical formula---a rarity in the stochastic-matching literature. Second, we establish tight non-asymptotic bounds for both F_1(n,m) and F_2(n,m), the expected average cost in the two-direction problem (shortest arc distance). Specifically, we prove that F_1(N,N+M) and F_2(N,N+M) are both \Theta(\tfrac{1}{M+\sqrt{N}}), offering crucial insights into the system behavior with large populations or significant supply-demand imbalances. Third, for the more complex two-direction case, we develop a highly accurate and explicit approximation for F_2(n,m), given by \tfrac{1}{8(m+1)} + \tfrac{3}{8}F_1(n,m). The approximation error is numerically shown to be uniformly bounded by 0.00055 and quickly converges to zero as m grows.

These analytical advancements offer valuable tools for system design and operational decision-making.  We showcase their practical utility within a canonical model of an on-demand ride-hailing system. Leveraging the matching cost formulas, we design an optimal state-dependent delayed matching policy, which strategically improves matching by pooling supply and demand, yet avoids excessive waiting. This policy significantly reduces average passenger waiting times, as demonstrated in extensive numerical experiments.

title: Optimal Decisions for Liquid Staking: Allocation and Exit Timing
affiliations: Columbia University, Columbia University, Columbia University - Department of Industrial Engineering and Operations Research and Columbia University

detail.title: Optimal Decisions for Liquid Staking: Allocation and Exit Timing
detail.abstract: In this paper, we study an investor's optimal entry and exit decisions in a liquid staking protocol (LSP) and an automated market maker (AMM), primarily from the standpoint of the investor. Our analysis focuses on two key investor actions: the initial allocation decision at time t = 0, and the optimal timing of exit. First, we derive an optimal allocation strategy that enables the investor to distribute risk across the LSP, AMM, and direct holding. Our results also offer insights for LSP and AMM designers, identifying the necessary and sufficient conditions under which the investor is incentivized to stake through an LSP, and further, to provide liquidity in addition to staking. These conditions include a lower bound on the transaction fee, for which we propose a fee mechanism that attains the bound. Second, given a fixed protocol design, we model the optimal exit timing of an individual investor using Laplace transforms and free-boundary techniques. We analyze scenarios with and without transaction fees. In the absence of fees, we decompose the investor's payoff into impermanent loss and opportunity cost, and provide theoretical results characterizing the investor's payoff and the optimal exit threshold. With transaction fees, we conduct numerical analyses to examine how fee accumulation influences exit strategies. Our results reveal that in both settings, a stop-loss strategy often maximizes the investor's expected payoff, driven by opportunity gains and the accumulation of fees where fees are present. Our analyses rely on various tools from stochastic processes and control theory, as well as convex optimization and analysis. We further support our theoretical insights with numerical experiments and explore additional properties of the investor's value function and optimal behavior.

title: Am I the Patsy? LETF Issuance is Signal, Not Noise: How Trading LETFs a Day Late can make you a Dollar Richer
affiliations: Independent

detail.title: Am I the Patsy? LETF Issuance is Signal, Not Noise: How Trading LETFs a Day Late can make you a Dollar Richer

declarations.declarationOfInterest: Rob Bezdjian is a legally represented whistleblower focused on the structural design and distribution of complex financial products, primarily Leveraged Exchange-Traded Funds (LETFs) and Notes. His work centers on uncovering systemic inefficiencies, regulatory gaps, and investor risks inherent in these products. By disclosing replicable, rules-based profitability derived from issuer behavior, he seeks to demonstrate that these instruments are not merely flawed, but structurally designed to mislead—constituting potential systemic fraud.
declarations.funderStatement: Self Funded

detail.abstract:
This paper introduces the "Day Late-Dollar Richer" (DLDR) strategy, a systematic, rules-based trading model that exploits predictable issuance and redemption behavior in Leveraged and Inverse Exchange-Traded Funds (LETFs). 

Building on the author's prior forensic framework introduced in Deception by Design: Leveraged ETFs, Structural Fraud, and the Proof of Outperformance (Bezdjian, SSRN ID: 5347238), which quantified over $100 billion in net issuance profits for LETF sponsors, this model transforms those flows into a replicable, high-return signal-and, potentially, forensic proof of issuer-level structural fraud. 

By analyzing daily changes in shares outstanding and trading with a one-day lag, the strategy consistently generates profits across asset classes where traditional ETFs do not. Unlike prior academic literature that focuses primarily on volatility decay and compounding effects, this paper presents empirical evidence that share issuance behavior is itself predictive, a structural signal created by the ongoing exploitation of investors and now harnessed by this model.
These findings raise urgent questions around product design, fiduciary responsibility, and regulatory oversight. LETFs are functionally zero-sum instruments. Every dollar of investor loss often translates to a corresponding gain for issuers or their counterparties—by design, not by chance. What was once described as "random decay" is now exposed as an arbitrage-able signal. For the first time, the public has a tool to reverse the transfer.
Note on Scope and Data Access: To ensure clarity and accessibility, this paper presents a representative subset of LETFs. The full dataset and backtest output have been submitted to the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) under whistleblower protection. All methodology is fully disclosed to support independent validation, replication, and legal inquiry.

title: Cultural Analysis of the Legend of Sombreron
affiliations: EDUKIVOTOS

detail.title: Cultural Analysis of the Legend of Sombreron
detail.abstract: This work explores the Colombian legend of El Sombrerón through interdisciplinary analysis, integrating theories from psychology, semiotics, anthropology, and cultural economics. It investigates the myth's emotional and psychological impact, its role in rituals, and its use in tourism and cultural industries. By examining how it evokes fear, admiration, or nostalgia, and how it contributes to the creation of crafts, festivals, and heritage narratives, the legend emerges as both a symbolic and economic tool of social representation and collective identity.

title: Transforming the Organization: Unlocking Potential for Sustainable Success
affiliations: Walden University

detail.title: Transforming the Organization: Unlocking Potential for Sustainable Success

declarations.funderStatement: No outside founder.

detail.abstract: Organizations must evolve to remain competitive in today's intricate business landscape, making effective organizational change essential. However, implementing these changes often entails risks and costs, resulting in many companies encountering difficulties during their transformation efforts. Notably, approximately 70% of organizational transformation initiatives fail to achieve their objectives. This qualitative study explores the factors that influence the success of organizational changes, focusing on four critical elements that contribute to successful change efforts: the need for initiation, effective leadership, smooth implementation, and stakeholder resistance. Employing a phenomenological approach, the research aims to provide practical insights into the real-world challenges of business transformation, thereby enhancing existing qualitative studies and addressing gaps in the current literature. The findings underscore the pivotal role of leadership in the successful execution of organizational change, emphasizing two key aspects: fostering an organizational climate that promotes change readiness and actively involving stakeholders in the process. The study reveals that team commitment and participation are essential for effectively implementing organizational transformations. A comprehensive change management analysis introduces a suggested model to facilitate effective organizational transitions. Grounded in empirical research and well-established theoretical frameworks, this model offers valuable insights by identifying key strategies and mechanisms that organizations can employ to navigate the complexities of change.

title: Zoning Impact Analysis: Texas Senate Bill 785
affiliations: George Washington University - Law School and Land Use Atlas, Inc.

detail.title: Zoning Impact Analysis: Texas Senate Bill 785

publicationDetails.detailsText: National Zoning Atlas Research Brief Series (2025)

detail.abstract:
Texas Senate Bill 785 (2025) aimed to increase the amount of land municipalities zone for manufactured housing. Using the comprehensive repository of data in the National Zoning Atlas (NZA), this paper finds that: 

• SB 785 would increase the amount of land zoned for manufactured housing. 
• 44% of the 579 municipalities in the NZA dataset would have to enact zoning reforms to comply with SB 785. 
• 56% would comply with, or be exempt from, SB 785. 

In addition, the paper recommends that Texas legislators refine definitions, include a "good faith" clause, and require reporting to ensure the legislation works as intended. [Note: This brief was used to inform legislative outcomes; the law discussed passed and was made law in 2025.

title: Navigating State Fragility: The Role of ESG, Biodiversity, and Resource Rents in Africa
affiliations: Mediterranean School of Business

detail.title: Navigating State Fragility: The Role of ESG, Biodiversity, and Resource Rents in Africa
detail.abstract: State fragility in Africa remains a critical barrier to sustainable development, manifesting through institutional weaknesses, governance breakdowns, and vulnerability to environmental and sociopolitical shocks. This study investigates whether Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) performance, biodiversity protection, and rent dependency can serve as strategic tools to reduce fragility across 24 African countries over the period 2006-2023. Using a fixed effects panel regression with robust standard errors, the analysis reveals that stronger ESG performance and biodiversity-related benefits are significantly associated with lower levels of state fragility. In contrast, rent dependency does not show a consistent impact on fragility, indicating that reliance on resource wealth alone is not enough to ensure stability. These findings challenge the assumptions of the resource curse and show that strong governance and environmental care are not just ethical goals; they are essential for building national resilience and long-term peace. The current analysis aligns with broader policy frameworks such as the African Union's Agenda 2063 and the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), particularly those targeting peace, strong institutions, and environmental sustainability.

reference: Brazilian Journal of Operations & Production Management, volume 22, issue 2, 2025[10.14488/BJOPM.2493.2025]
title: The Role of Digital Supply Chain Practices in Enhancing Firm Performance: Insights from the Manufacturing Sector of Bangladesh
affiliations: Bangladesh University of Professionals (BUP) - Centre for Higher Studies and Research and American International University-Bangladesh

detail.title: The Role of Digital Supply Chain Practices in Enhancing Firm Performance: Insights from the Manufacturing Sector of Bangladesh

declarations.funderStatement: BUP Research Centre (BRC) under Bangladesh University of Professionals.

publicationDetails.detailsText: Brazilian Journal of Operations & Production Management, volume 22, issue 2, 2025[10.14488/BJOPM.2493.2025]

detail.abstract:
Purpose: This study examines the impact of digital supply chain practices (DSCP) on firm performance (FP) in the context of Bangladesh's manufacturing sector, with a focus on supply chain responsiveness (SCR) and customer development (CD) as mediating factors.

Design/methodology/approach: A quantitative research design was employed, utilizing partial least squares structural equation modeling (PLS-SEM) to analyze survey data collected from 438 participants representing manufacturing firms in Bangladesh. The model evaluates the direct effects of DSCP on FP, as well as the mediating roles of SCR and CD.

Findings: Results indicate that DSCP positively and significantly impacts FP, with SCR and CD serving as effective mediators in this relationship. The study demonstrates that digital integration in supply chains enhances responsiveness and customer engagement, ultimately leading to improved organizational performance.

Through increased operational efficiency, streamlined logistics, and improved decision-making, the results show that Digital Supply Chain Practices (DSCP) are essential for boosting company performance. By empowering businesses to quickly adjust to market needs, minimize interruptions, and maximize resource usage, DSCP improves supply chain responsiveness and, in the end, increases agility and competitive advantage. Additionally, by enhancing engagement, trust, and service quality, DSCP improves customer development, which supports long-term business success and sustainability in Bangladesh's manufacturing industry.

Research limitations/implications: The study is limited by its focus on the manufacturing sector in Bangladesh, which may affect the generalizability of findings to other industries or regions. Future studies should examine additional variables, such as organizational culture and market conditions, that may influence DSCP's effectiveness.

Practical implications: The findings provide actionable insights for managers seeking to enhance performance through digital supply chain integration. Investing in digital tools can improve responsiveness and customer satisfaction, driving organizational success in competitive markets.

Social implications: This study underscores the potential of digital transformation to improve supply chain efficiency, fostering economic growth and sustainability in emerging economies like Bangladesh.

Originality/value: This research contributes to the limited literature on digital supply chains in developing economies, offering empirical evidence of their role in improving firm performance.

title: Service Sharing Strategies for Competitive Platforms
affiliations: Shanghai Maritime University (SMU), Nankai University, Nankai University and Fudan University, School of Management

detail.title: Service Sharing Strategies for Competitive Platforms
detail.abstract: Problem definition: With escalating competition among e-commerce giants like Amazon, JD.com, and Tmall, some platforms resorted to "exclusive agreements", risking antitrust violations and intense conflicts with manufacturers. This study explores an alternative: how platforms can use service sharing to incentivize manufacturers to voluntarily "choose one out of two", aiming to understand platform competition dynamics. Methodology and results: Using a game-theoretic model, we analyze interactions between two competing platforms' service sharing strategies and the manufacturer's platform choice and service utilization, factoring in service levels, commissions, and channel competition. Our analysis reveals that over-high service sharing reduces demand and profit; platforms must offer differentiated services to successfully induce exclusivity; competition can create a prisoner's dilemma. Also, under conditions of low commissions, intense competition, and a rival's superior services, a platform should refrain from service sharing even when it has the option to enforce exclusivity. Managerial implications: Our theoretical findings deliver key management insights for platforms. Service homogenization-exemplified by JD.com and Tmall's converging logistics and after-sales-drives manufacturers to adopt multiple platform strategies, escalating conflicts and prompting costly "choose one out of two" tactics. Instead, platforms should prioritize service uniqueness over mere parity to secure exclusive manufacturer partnerships, eschewing mindless mimicry of rivals. They must also assess market conditions to avoid over-provisioning services and falling into a prisoner's dilemma. Importantly, " choose one out of two " is not universally beneficial; in certain scenarios, platforms should forgo service sharing and let manufacturers operate on rivals' platforms as well.

Using the OLI (ownership, location, internalization) framework and cross-cultural theories, we present updated findings based on data collected from 2013 to 2024, extending beyond the initial scope and period examined in earlier studies.
