title: Circular Economy: Research and its Evolution on Sustainable SMEs
affiliations: Jaipuria Institute of Management

detail.title: Circular Economy: Research and its Evolution on Sustainable SMEs
detail.abstract: The purpose of the current study is to define the Circular Economy in relation to sustainability issues that are relevant to small businesses. Numerous analyses, including descriptive, co-citation, and coword analyses, have been carried out to map the field. We have reviewed the literature about the works that have been published on the topic of CE. The statistical data is solely sourced from the Scopus database to reduce any potential ambiguities and redundancies arising from alternative databases. Here is a collection of diagrams with descriptive and bibliographic properties. The Vos viewer and RStudio used for data visualisation. The current analysis focuses on various perspectives on the topic, including analysis from the perspective of environmental science and research from various industry angles. To summarise, the study identified three distinct clusters and delineated prospective research areas that are closely associated with the concepts of circular economy and sustainability.

title: Developing Predictive Models for Stock Market Behavior Using Machine Learning and Econometrics
affiliations: Rhodes College

detail.title: Developing Predictive Models for Stock Market Behavior Using Machine Learning and Econometrics
detail.abstract:
Predicting stock market behavior remains a formidable challenge due to its volatility and multifactorial nature. This paper introduces a novel hybrid framework that integrates machine learning techniques, including Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks and Gradient Boosting Machines, with econometric models like ARIMA and GARCH. By combining the strengths of these approaches, we address non-linear dependencies while ensuring robust time-series analysis.
Using a comprehensive dataset of historical stock prices, macroeconomic indicators, and sentiment data, our findings reveal that the hybrid model outperforms traditional standalone methods, achieving up to 20% higher predictive accuracy. This framework not only uncovers critical insights into the interplay between macroeconomic trends and sentiment-driven market shifts but also provides actionable tools for investors and policymakers, bridging the gap between computational intelligence and traditional financial modeling.

title: Exploring Employee Engagement in Performance Management
affiliations: PES University

detail.title: Exploring Employee Engagement in Performance Management
detail.abstract: A vital element of performance management that affects both employee happiness and company success is employee engagement. The present research delves into the complex notion of employee engagement in the framework of performance management, scrutinizing its causes, consequences, and fundamental workings. The present study does a thorough literature analysis to identify and analyse the important aspects that influence employee engagement. These factors include leadership behaviour, organizational justice, performance appraisal techniques, and psychological needs satisfaction. Additionally, the reciprocal relationship between employee engagement and performance results is highlighted by examining the dynamic interplay between employee engagement and performance management methods. This study offers a deeper understanding of how firms can promote and maintain employee engagement through efficient performance management practices by drawing on insights from multiple studies and theoretical frameworks. In the conclusion, this study highlights the significance of employee engagement as a fundamental driver of organizational success and employee satisfaction.

title: Investigating How 'Social Media Influencers' Shape the Purchasing Decisions of Indian Customers in the Realm of Sustainable Organic Cosmetic Products
affiliations: Management Education and Research Institute

detail.title: Investigating How 'Social Media Influencers' Shape the Purchasing Decisions of Indian Customers in the Realm of Sustainable Organic Cosmetic Products
detail.abstract: 'Influence' means the strength to finesse another person to do something that she/he might not want to do earlier. That could be a positive or negative action on anybody or anything. This mental ability of the influencer results in a new form of marketing strategy named 'Influencer Marketing'. Business organizations have been using this influencer marketing strategy in their selling strategies starting with the development of social networking platforms. Though it appears to have gained traction recently, this is actually the older, simpler kind of word-of-mouth marketing that has been around for a while. Another possibility is that the influencer marketing strategy is a more developed form of the reference marketing plan. In this study, the researcher looked at how Indian consumers' purchasing decisions about organic cosmetics products are influenced by social media influencers. The aim of the research is, "To investigate the role and influence of 'social media influencers' on the purchasing behaviour of Indian customers in the realm of organic cosmetic products". The purpose is to identify the impact of 'social media influencers' on buying behaviour of domestic customer towards organic products. Three different factors that are determined from the survey have been used to evaluate the purchasing behaviour. In order to get participant opinions, the study employs an exploratory research methodology and a survey method using a structured questionnaire. The convenience sampling approach, which is non-probability, is used to choose the participants. 200 replies were gathered from various regions in Uttar Pradesh. For the purpose of evaluating hypotheses, Liner Regression Analysis, Anova is used to assess the data is this research. Result of analysis shows, buying behaviours of the consumer is direct depends on the social media influencer.

title: Aggregate Investment and Consumption in a Continuous Time Stochastic Blanchard-Yaari Model with CRRA Utility
affiliations: University of Glasgow, Umeå University, University of Glasgow  and University of Leicester - Department of Mathematics

detail.title: Aggregate Investment and Consumption in a Continuous Time Stochastic Blanchard-Yaari Model with CRRA Utility

declarations.declarationOfInterest: None of the authors has any competing interests to declare.
declarations.funderStatement: Kempe Foundation "Distributional and Behavioural Dynamics in Fund Management, Pensions and Life Cycle Wealth: On the Role of Inflation, Mortality and Inequality"

detail.abstract: We present a continuous time stochastic overlapping generations model in the spirit of Blanchard (1985), Farmer et al. (2011) and Benhabib et al. (2014). Agents are assumed to have CRRA utility and face a constant probability of death rate. Investment assets are a risk-less bond as well as a risky asset reflecting systemic risk in the economy, for example the stock market. Our model distinguishes itself from Farmer et al. (2011) which is set in discrete time and from Benhabib et al. (2014) who look at idiosyncratic risk in wages, which vanishes in aggregation. We use Martingale techniques to determine aggregate variables and derive their dynamics. Our article also closes gaps in the mathematical theory behind continuous time stochastic overlapping generation models that have been ignored in previous literature. We demonstrate the applicability of our results within the example of a small open economy and observe that some modest level of foreign exchange volatility benefits aggregate consumption, while some level of risk aversion benefits aggregate wealth.

title: Comparing the Evolutionary Trajectories of Industry 4.0 and 5.0: A Management Fashion Perspective
affiliations: University of South-Eastern Norway USN School of Business and Buskerud and Vestfold University College

detail.title: Comparing the Evolutionary Trajectories of Industry 4.0 and 5.0: A Management Fashion Perspective
detail.abstract: The concept of Industry 4.0 has received enormous levels of attention since it was introduced in 2011 and continues to be a dominant management trend. However, during the last few years, Industry 5.0 has emerged as an alternative visionary management concept. Although Industry 5.0 builds on and is related to its predecessor, it provides a different vision of the future of industry. Therefore, the aim of this paper is to carry out an in-depth examination of these two related management concepts, using management fashion theory as an interpretive framework and lens. Viewing Industry 4.0 and 5.0 from this vantage point involves analyzing and tracing the involvement activities of the suppliers of the two concepts as well as gauging the concepts' demand-side impact. Generally, the comparative analysis of the cases of Industry 4.0 and 5.0 indicates that, while the growth and popularity of Industry 4.0 appear to have plateaued, it remains at a high level. Although Industry 5.0 is growing in popularity and is gaining followers and supporters, it is still a much more marginal concept and movement. This study contributes to the management fashion literature by showing how two highly related but competing management concept movements coevolve. Furthermore, the two cases provide novel insights into the trajectories and lifecycles of fashionable management concepts, in particular, the early phase where actors are actively attempting to generate credibility and legitimacy and drum up support and enthusiasm for their preferred ideas.

title: When Supply Chains Run Dry: Spillovers Intensify the Economic Impact of Water Scarcity
affiliations: University of Graz

detail.title: When Supply Chains Run Dry: Spillovers Intensify the Economic Impact of Water Scarcity

declarations.funderStatement: This research is funded by the European Union’s Horizon Europe research and innovation program under grant agreement no. 101081358 (ACCREU).

detail.abstract: This paper explores the role of global supply chains in amplifying the macroeconomic losses caused by local climate shocks. Combining global multi-regional input-output tables, high-resolution water availability data, and subnational gross value added (GVA) for Europe's NUTS-3 regions, I find that supply chain spillover effects substantially amplify the macroeconomic losses caused by local water scarcity shocks. The negative effects are persistent and regions that are already drier today are the most vulnerable to supply chain transmitted water scarcity shocks. A counterfactual analysis reveals that over the period 2000-2019, the total cumulative European gross value added losses attributable to these shocks amounts to €12.3 trillion. This is more than three times the €3.7 trillion in estimated GVA losses when supply chain spillover effects are not accounted for. This paper highlights both the importance of integrating supply chain spillovers into climate impact assessments and the need for adaptation measures to enhance the supply chain resilience under future warming.

title: A Computational Toolbox for Evaluating Commodity Project Investments under Ambiguity
affiliations: Adam Smith Business School, University of Glasgow and University of Glasgow - Adam Smith Business School

detail.title: A Computational Toolbox for Evaluating Commodity Project Investments under Ambiguity

declarations.declarationOfInterest: None of the authors has any competing interests to declare.
declarations.funderStatement: This research was partly supported by the Norwegian Research Council, grant 352447 - “Risk-resilient aquaculture: Balancing profitability with environmental sustainability in investment and operations under uncertainty.”

detail.abstract: We consider large-scale commodity project investments within a real options framework where, in addition to risk, the investor faces true uncertainty, henceforth referred to as ambiguity. Within this framework, we use a new Monte Carlo based method to determine the optimal exercise time and the value of the real option representing the worth of an investment project. Model ambiguity arises due to uncertain parameter values in the model, and its severity is captured via confidence intervals of parameter estimates. This is the situation in most real-world projects; however, in academic work, it seems largely ignored. The classical Monte Carlo approach of Longstaff and Schwartz is unable to deal with such a setup. Our proposed approach, therefore, provides a significant extension of the computational toolbox for real options. Our approach is based on the insight that the value of a real option has an interpretation as the solution of a reflected backward stochastic differential equation (RBSDE), and that the part of the dynamic optimization process which depends on model ambiguity translates to a point-wise optimization of the driver function of the related RBSDE. This insight is then combined with a computational methodology for solving RBSDEs known as the Stratified Regression One-step Forward Dynamic Programming algorithm. To demonstrate the applicability of our framework, we consider a standard model of aquaculture investment and quantify the ambiguity premium due to parameter uncertainty. Our numerical results demonstrate that the ambiguity premium is substantial and that an increase in uncertainty leads to an earlier optimal harvesting time.

title: Urbanization and Labor Share: Evidence from China's Great Migration
affiliations: Zhejiang Gongshang University, Zhejiang University, The Chinese University of Hong Kong (CUHK) - Department of Economics and Zhejiang University

detail.title: Urbanization and Labor Share: Evidence from China's Great Migration
detail.abstract: This paper examines changes in firm-level labor share during rapid urbanization. We develop a theoretical framework in which rural-to-urban migration increases the labor share of local firms by substituting labor for capital and increasing the skill wage premium. Using a "shift-share" instrumental variable approach, we show that migration inflows increase the labor share of local firms in China. To test the mechanisms predicted by the model, we show that migration inflows reduce capital per worker and raise the relative wages of skilled labor, while lowering the skill composition of firm employment. Finally, heterogeneity analysis shows that the effect is more pronounced among private firms and among migrants with relatively high levels of education, with no significant differences by gender.

title: Alternative Dispute Resolution (ADR): Importance, Need, and Implementation in Pakistani Family, Civil and Corporate Litigation
affiliations: University of Karachi

detail.title: Alternative Dispute Resolution (ADR): Importance, Need, and Implementation in Pakistani Family, Civil and Corporate Litigation

declarations.ethicsApproval: This studey aims to get basic knowledge of ADR. The area of ADR in Pakistani legal system and effects of international standards for ADR and application of those laws and rules in Pakistani system. The article provides detailed discussion and comparative study of formal and Informal ADR in Pakistan.

detail.abstract: Alternative Dispute Resolution (ADR) refers to a variety of processes that help parties to dispute to resolve the disputes without a trial. Common ADR methods include mediation, arbitration, conciliation, and negotiation. ADR is widely acknowledged as a cost-effective, time-efficient, and less adversarial alternative to conventional litigation. It puts a full stop to the disputes effectively rather to protracted litigation in the courts and tribunals. Across the globe, ADR has been embraced to reduce the burden on courts and to provide more accessible justice at the very ease and convenience of parties to dispute. In Pakistan, the formal legal system has become increasingly burdened with a growing backlog of civil and corporate cases, often resulting in delays of several years. This inefficiency underscores the urgent need to adopt ADR as an effective mechanism for dispute resolution. Pakistan's legal framework provides for ADR in statutes such as the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (as amended), the Arbitration Act, 1940, and the Recognition and Enforcement (Arbitration Agreements and Foreign Arbitral Awards) Act, 2011. This article explores the importance and need for ADR in Pakistan, examines its implementation in civil and corporate litigation, and references both international and Pakistani laws to highlight its efficacy.

title: Revisiting the Barangay Micro-Business Enterprises Act of 2002: A Policy Evaluation Using National-Level Data
affiliations: National Graduate Institute for Policy Studies (GRIPS) and University of the Philippines

detail.title: Revisiting the Barangay Micro-Business Enterprises Act of 2002: A Policy Evaluation Using National-Level Data
detail.abstract: While micro, small, and medium enterprises are widely considered as the backbone of the Philippine economy, their potential to contribute more to development is often hindered by high levels of informality. To help address the issue of enterprise informality, the government enacted the Barangay Micro-business Enterprises (BMBEs) Act of 2002, with the aim of formalizing microenterprises through the provision of incentives. Using data from a national-level census of BMBEs and business counselors directly involved in the implementation of the law, this study sought to evaluate the BMBE Law vis-à-vis its goal of reducing informality. In doing so, it focused on evaluating business registration, incentives and benefits received by the BMBEs, impact on microenterprises' formalization rate, and impact on BMBEs' business operations and development. Results from the descriptive statistics reveal that the law has been largely ineffective in addressing informality and fostering microenterprise development. In this light, this study recommends policy amendments to account for the recent enactment of the Tax Reform for Acceleration and Inclusion (TRAIN) Law, administrative burdens, and conflicting regulatory priorities. However, given the lengthy legislative amendment process, a more immediate approach would be for implementing agencies to update the implementing rules and regulations and conduct awareness campaigns to enhance the policy's reach and impact.

title: Sustainability Practices of Mining Companies and Community Well-Being: Is the Community Empowerment Initiative the Missing Link?
affiliations: Methodist University College Ghana

detail.title: Sustainability Practices of Mining Companies and Community Well-Being: Is the Community Empowerment Initiative the Missing Link?
detail.abstract: The overarching purpose of the study was to adopt theoretical and practical methods of assessing the impact of mining companies' sustainability practices (environmental, social, economic, and ethical) on community well-being through community empowerment and engagement. The study relied on stakeholder, social capital, and engagement theories to develop a conceptual model examining the interrelationships among the various dimensions espoused for the study. Based on a positivist paradigmatic approach, a quantitative research approach surveyed 503 respondents from four selected mining communities (Tarkwa, Obuasi, Prestea, and Bogoso). Structural Equation Modelling (SEM), particularly AMOS 24 software, was employed to analyse the collected data. The study finds that among the four sustainability practices implemented by the mining companies, ethical sustainability was the only practice that directly influenced the community's well-being. The study's findings indicate that the mining companies' sustainability practices alone cannot yield the expected results of improving community well-being. Therefore, community empowerment initiatives are crucial to enhancing the effectiveness of mining companies' sustainability practices in improving the socioeconomic and health outcomes of local communities affected by mining operations.

title: A Systematic Review of Issues and Challenges Associated with Women Entrepreneurs
affiliations: St Aloysius Deemed to be University and Srinivas Institute of Management Studies

detail.title: A Systematic Review of Issues and Challenges Associated with Women Entrepreneurs
detail.abstract: Purpose: An entrepreneur is a development driver. It aids in maintaining the economic growth process going. The economic growth of each country decides the status of its citizens. The development of the economy will remain incomplete without the development of entrepreneurs. Women are also a part of the entrepreneurship movement in the country. There is a shift in the role played by a woman in the economy. In recent decades, the study of women's entrepreneurship has increased. Women encounter several challenges in engaging in commercial activities or conducting entrepreneurial tasks. As entrepreneurs, women confront various socioeconomic and other issues. This article adds a literature review on the problems and challenges of women entrepreneurs. Design/Methodology/Approach: Literature research to examine the notion of entrepreneurship, women entrepreneurs, determinants, concerns, and challenges of women entrepreneurs. The data from textbooks, articles published in Google scholar, Research Gate, and Academia databases, and a thesis from shodhganga. Findings/Result: As per the study, women are playing multi-role and facing different challenges, from setting up the business to its continuation. The government takes various measures to motivate women's entrepreneurship in the country. The work-life balance of women entrepreneurs is very challenging. Digitalization has brought challenges and opportunities to women in continuing their businesses. Highly educated women must be encouraged to run their businesses instead of working under someone. Originality/Value: Women entrepreneurs, motivators, concerns, and obstacles are assessed and presented. Paper Type: Conceptual Research.

title: Strategic Management of Metal Fabrication MSMEs in Gujarat, India
affiliations: Edgewood College and Manipal GlobalNxt University, Malaysia

detail.title: Strategic Management of Metal Fabrication MSMEs in Gujarat, India

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The authors have no financial or personal relationship with other people or organization that would be perceived to be influenced in our study.
declarations.ethicsApproval: The survey was conducted on the condition that no information provided by the respondents shall be divulged to the public except it would be used for this study
declarations.funderStatement: There is no external funding for the study

detail.abstract: Mediation Regression (Hayes Model 6) test was conducted to determine if Porter's Five Forces had impact on Performance of firm through the mediation of Strategic Agility and Resource Based View. The target population was Micro, Small, and Medium Enterprises (MSMEs) in Metal Fabrication Industries (MFI) in Gujarat, India. A sample study was conducted by randomly selecting 300 sample units from the target population. The total effect of Porter's Five Forces on Performance of firm is significant (b = 0.32, t (298) = 6.20, p < 0.001). The direct effect of Porter's Five Force on Performance of Firm is significant (b=0.26, t (298) =3.65, p <0.001) The three indirect effects-i) Porter's Five Forces mediated through Strategic Agility on Performance of Firm (b =-0.02, Boot LLCI =-0.10, Boot ULCI = 0.08) is not significant; ii) Porter's Five Forces mediated through Resource Based View on Performance of Firm (b = 0.04, Boot LLCI = 0.01, Boot ULCI = 0.09) is significant; and iii) Porter's Five Forces serially mediated through Strategic Agility and Resource Based View on Performance of Firm (b = 0.04, Boot LLCI = 0.01, Boot ULCI = 0.07) is significant. These results suggest that the MFI-MSMEs are not applying the rules of strategic sensitivity, leadership unity, and resource fluidity in the strategic management of firm. Further, the results suggest that the firms are effectively applying the strategic rules of management for product and process innovation.

title: ACCOUNTABILITY REPORT 2.0: An independent evaluation of online trust and safety practice.
affiliations: Jonathan E. Shipp SRL and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: ACCOUNTABILITY REPORT 2.0: An independent evaluation of online trust and safety practice.
detail.abstract: This report presents the findings and analysis of the Internet Commission’s second reporting cycle. It looks at how organisational cultures, systems and processes shape online experiences and how they comprise ethical business practice. We focus on internet safety, freedom of speech and the ways in which decisions are made about content, contact and conduct online. We found that leading organisations (i) value the voice of their users, (ii) demonstrate coordinated oversight to anticipate negative impacts, and (iii) use innovation to balance safety and freedom online.

title: Cultural Analysis of the Legend of La Candileja
affiliations: EDUKIVOTOS

detail.title: Cultural Analysis of the Legend of La Candileja
detail.abstract: This study explores the Colombian legend of La Candileja as a complex cultural artifact that integrates ethical, emotional, symbolic, and pedagogical dimensions. It examines how the myth functions as a tool for moral instruction, emotional regulation, and social control within rural communities. Drawing from theories in anthropology, philosophy, semiotics, and education, the analysis reveals the legend’s role in shaping territorial identity, reinforcing intergenerational norms, and adapting to modern media. La Candileja remains a living cultural technology, bridging memory, fear, and collective ethics through symbolic continuity and narrative transformation.

title: Justiciability of the Fundamental Objectives and Directive Principles of State Policy Under Chapter Two of the 1999 Constitution: Lessons from Other Jurisdictions
affiliations: Igbinedion University, Okada - School of Law

detail.title: Justiciability of the Fundamental Objectives and Directive Principles of State Policy Under Chapter Two of the 1999 Constitution: Lessons from Other Jurisdictions

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The author declares that there is no conflict of interest related to the authorship or publication of this paper. No financial, personal, or organizational relationships influenced the research or its findings.
declarations.ethicsApproval: This study did not involve human participants or clinical data and therefore did not require ethics approval.
declarations.funderStatement: This research received no specific grant or funding from any public, commercial, or not-for-profit funding agency.

keywords: African Charter on Human and Peoples’ Rights

detail.abstract:
Abstract

This paper explores the provisions of Chapter II of the 1999 Constitution of the Federal Republic of Nigeria and the approaches Nigerian courts have taken toward their enforcement. It argues that the widespread belief in the non-justiciability of these provisions stems less from constitutional limitations and more from structural inequality and class politics, which tend to disadvantage the poor and vulnerable. The work examines the content of Chapter II in detail and compares Nigeria’s legal position with that of other jurisdictions, particularly India, Ghana, Kenya, the United States, and the United Kingdom.

Through this comparative analysis, the study highlights how judicial activism in other countries has expanded the reach of socio-economic rights, offering practical lessons for Nigeria. It also considers the relevance of international human rights instruments, especially the African Charter on Human and Peoples’ Rights, and their potential to strengthen the recognition of these rights within Nigeria’s legal framework.

The research adopts a doctrinal and comparative methodology, relying on case law, statutes, scholarly writings, and international materials. It reflects on the relationship between civil and socio-economic rights and argues for a more integrated approach that treats all categories of rights as mutually reinforcing. The study concludes by recommending reforms and interpretive shifts that would support the enforceability of socio-economic rights and promote greater social justice and accountability in Nigeria.

title: Buy Now, Pay Later: The Hidden Effects of Consumer Liquidity on Retail Prices and Inventories
affiliations: Washington University in St. Louis - John M. Olin Business School, Washington University in St. Louis and Shanghai Jiao Tong University (SJTU) - Antai College of Economics and Management

detail.title: Buy Now, Pay Later: The Hidden Effects of Consumer Liquidity on Retail Prices and Inventories
detail.abstract: Consumer liquidity is a critical market friction whose role in retail environments is rarely examined in inventory management and pricing literature. Motivated by the rapid adoption of Buy Now Pay Later (BNPL) contracts---an interest-free, short-term consumer borrowing product---we examine how consumer liquidity affects a retailer's pricing and inventory management decisions. We analyze these decisions in a setting that involves three parties: a retailer, consumers, and a FinTech firm. The goal of the retailer is to jointly set the inventory level and price of a product to maximize its expected profit. The retailer's customers are both price sensitive and cash constrained. We capture this latter new feature by extending classic demand models and explicitly modeling both consumers' willingness to pay and ability to pay. For customers who are willing to pay the product's full price but are not able to do so in one payment, the FinTech firm offers BNPL contracts. The FinTech firm pays the retailer an endogenized discounted price, determined by its cost of capital and customers' risk of default, in exchange for collecting the product's full price from customers over multiple installments. We show that this setting admits a unique Nash equilibrium and characterize the long-term impacts of BNPL contracts on the retailer's profit, product's price, product's availability, and consumer surplus. A key insight provided by our analysis is that although BNPL contracts alleviate the effects of liquidity friction, they limit the retailer's ability to allocate its inventory among its customers efficiently. This can reduce both the retailer's profit and consumer surplus, indicating that BNPL services may not be appropriate for all products and markets.

title: A Bi-Level Optimization Method for Integrated Warehouse Design, Storage Location Assignment, and Order Picking
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, Islamic Azad University and Islamic Azad University

detail.title: A Bi-Level Optimization Method for Integrated Warehouse Design, Storage Location Assignment, and Order Picking
detail.abstract: This study presents an innovative bi-level optimization model that simultaneously addresses three core components of warehouse planning: shelving technology selection, storage location assignment, and order picking. Unlike traditional models that treat these elements separately, the proposed approach integrates strategic, tactical, and operational decisions into a unified framework. At the upper level, the model allocates warehouse space among three shelving technologies based on setup costs and space efficiency, aiming to minimize construction costs. At the lower level, it optimizes item-to-location assignment and order picking under probabilistic demand across multiple periods. The model accounts for equipment constraints, inventory balance, and routing efficiency. A feedback mechanism updates shelf capacity estimates iteratively between the two levels. To solve this complex structure, an enumerative heuristic method is used, combining discrete leader-level search with GAMS-based follower optimization. The model’s key innovations include: (1) full integration of all warehouse planning layers, (2) incorporation of uncertainty in demand, and (3) a practical, computationally feasible solution method. Numerical results demonstrate significant cost savings and improved space utilization compared to conventional methods. This model offers a robust decision-support tool for warehouse designers operating under uncertain and dynamic conditions.

title: Socio-legal Reflections on Zimbabwe's Lithium Industry: The Role of Public Participation in Resource Governance and Environmental Justice
affiliations: University of the Free State and University of South Africa (UNISA)

detail.title: Socio-legal Reflections on Zimbabwe's Lithium Industry: The Role of Public Participation in Resource Governance and Environmental Justice

declarations.declarationOfInterest: NA
declarations.ethicsApproval: NA
declarations.funderStatement: NA

detail.abstract: Zimbabwe has one of the largest lithium deposits in Africa. As the world strives to decarbonise and to relinquish energy sources that produce harmful emissions, the demand for lithium is rising to astronomical levels. Zimbabwe's lithium is a prime target for the producers of lithium-ion batteries used in electric cars, smartphones, laptops, and solar panels for domestic use. However, Zimbabwe's law and mining policy need to include measures to ensure that citizens properly participate in and profit from its extractive activities, including the mining of lithium. Outdated mining legislation and past experience show that the exploitation of a resource can be a curse in Zimbabwe, as in the smuggling of diamonds and the sequestration of the wealth generated by gold mining to only a few individuals. Public participation in decision-making in the lithium industry is a scarce commodity, and it is generally expected that a repeat of the catastrophic circumstances of Zimbabwean gold and diamond mining is likely to be seen in the lithium industry. This article examines the social implications of the lack of effective regulation of Zimbabwe's lithium industry. It assesses Zimbabwe's current decision to ban raw lithium exports and answers the question whether this has positive social implications for communities that live near lithium deposits.

title: Organizational Civic Culture: Workplaces as Engines of Democratic Participation
affiliations: University of Maryland Robert H. Smith School of Business, Columbia University - Columbia Business School, Management, Harvard Kennedy School of Government and University of Michigan, Stephen M. Ross School of Business

detail.title: Organizational Civic Culture: Workplaces as Engines of Democratic Participation

declarations.declarationOfInterest: NA
