declarations.funderStatement: University of Maryland Smith Business School

keywords: Organizational Civic Culture: Workplaces as Engines of Democratic Participation business and politics

detail.abstract: Organizational cultures shape not only workplace outcomes but also civic life. We introduce and evaluate the concept of organizational civic culture---the norms within organizations of participation in democratic institutions beyond the workplace. We theorize two pathways through which civic culture operates: (1) an interactional pathway, where peer behaviors drive civic norms, and (2) a symbolic pathway, where managers model civic participation. Leveraging a novel dataset containing employment histories and voter turnout records for 28 million Americans, along with a quasi-experimental mover design, we find strong causal evidence that peer civic engagement increases individual turnout. In contrast, we find limited evidence for top-down effects from managers. The influence of organizational civic culture is especially pronounced in low-turnout elections, among college graduates, younger employees, and those without an established track record of voting, and when a greater proportion of coworkers share the employee's partisan affiliation. These findings identify employer organizations as a previously overlooked but important scaffold to democratic institutions.

reference: European Journal of Interdisciplinary Issues, Volume 2, No. 2, pp. 1-9
title: The Impact of Organic Certification on the Competitiveness of Companies Exporting Medicinal Plants
affiliations: National Academy of Internal Affairs of Kyiv

detail.title: The Impact of Organic Certification on the Competitiveness of Companies Exporting Medicinal Plants

publicationDetails.detailsText: European Journal of Interdisciplinary Issues, Volume 2, No. 2, pp. 1-9

detail.abstract: Relevance of the study. The relevance of the study is due to the growing demands of the international market for safety, transparency and traceability of plant products, which makes it impossible for Ukrainian exporters of medicinal raw materials to compete effectively without internationally recognized organic certification. At the same time, the sector still faces the problems of regulatory non-compliance, high costs and limited availability of certification procedures, which hinder the integration of Ukrainian producers into premium sales channels. The aim of the article. The article is aimed at substantiating the impact of organic certification on the formation of competitiveness of enterprises exporting medicinal plants, taking into account economic, institutional and technological factors in the context of the current global situation. Research methodology. The methodological basis is the content analysis of international standards (EU Organic, USDA NOP, Bio Suisse, Naturland), statistical analysis of export dynamics in 2006-2023, comparative analysis of price indicators of certified and non-certified products, as well as generalization of applied cases of Ukrainian exporters and data from official reports of TRACES, Organic Standard, FiBL. Research results. It was found that the certificate increases the selling price of products by 15-25%, reduces the share of cargo returns to 0.5%, and provides access to new sales channels and tenders from leading European traders. A direct correlation between the certification status of the manufacturer and the stability of export contracts is revealed. The importance of institutional support and digital infrastructure (TRACES, DUNS) for export scaling is substantiated. Scientific novelty. For the first time, the quantitative and qualitative effects of organic certification are summarized in the context of medicinal plant exports from Ukraine, barriers to access to organic markets are structured, and practical mechanisms for strengthening the market position of small and medium-sized producers through certification instruments are outlined. Conclusions. It is proved that certification is a key tool for strengthening the international competitiveness of Ukrainian exporters of medicinal plants. Successful implementation of certification strategies requires the involvement of state support, institutional support, development of cooperation and raising awareness of producers about the benefits of certified exports. Prospects for further research. An in-depth study of the mechanisms of clustering organic production, the long-term socioeconomic effects of involving households in certified medicinal crops, as well as an assessment of the possibilities of implementing digital solutions for traceability and certification monitoring seems advisable.

title: Patent Collateralization and Entrepreneurship
affiliations: Shanghai University of International Business and Economics, Fudan University, Chinese University of Hong Kong and University of Toronto - Rotman School of Management

detail.title: Patent Collateralization and Entrepreneurship
detail.abstract: This study examines the effects of patent collateralization on entrepreneurship by exploiting policy changes in China that allow firms to use patents as collateral for financing. Our findings indicate that enhanced patent collateralization significantly stimulates startup activity, particularly within high-tech sectors. We identify three key mechanisms: (1) facilitating access to debt and equity financing in the primary capital market; (2) enhancing liquidity in the secondary market for intellectual property; and (3) incentivizing talented individuals to become entrepreneurs in the labor market. These results demonstrate the economic benefits of patent collateralization, highlighting its potential to foster the growth of high-tech startups.

title: A Comprehensive Review of Maintenance Strategies: From Reactive to Proactive Approaches
affiliations: Islamic Azad University (IAU), Najafabad Branch, Students

detail.title: A Comprehensive Review of Maintenance Strategies: From Reactive to Proactive Approaches
detail.abstract: Maintenance strategies have evolved considerably, transitioning from reactive approaches to proactive methodologies. In this paper we investigate papers and compare different approaches and clarify what maintenance strategy more noticed and why. We are seeking to answer this question. A systematic review of 38 peer-reviewed paper will be conducted to identify which strategies are most commonly used. This study systematically reviews two primary branches of maintenance-reactive (corrective) and proactive (preventive and predictive) strategies-through a comprehensive analysis of academic literature. A structured collection of peer-reviewed papers was compiled from Scopus, Web of Science, and IEEE Xplore, using targeted keywords such as "maintenance strategy," "maintenance management," "reliability," and specific approaches ("Preventive Maintenance," "Condition-Based Maintenance," "Predictive Maintenance"). Our findings reveal that reactive maintenance, while simple and low-cost, often results in unplanned downtime and higher long-term expenses. In contrast, proactive methods (e.g., scheduled maintenance, condition-based monitoring) significantly improve operational efficiency, reduce failures, and optimize lifecycle costs. The evidence suggests that proactive strategies are the superior choice for industries where reliability and costeffectiveness are critical.

title: Echoes of HK: Taiwan's Mass Recall and the "Five Constituencies Referendum"
affiliations: Harvard University - Harvard Law School

detail.title: Echoes of HK: Taiwan's Mass Recall and the "Five Constituencies Referendum"
detail.abstract: In July 2025, the first "mass recall" of legislators in Taiwan or Asian history is slated to occur after an unprecedented number of opposition legislators have been targeted by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party for removal via recall votes. Since mass recalls of legislators have never occurred before, it is very difficult to predict the outcome of the recall elections and the subsequent by-elections should any be held. We can assume that KMT supporters will vote against the recall, while DPP supporters will support the recall, and if all voters were to vote based on the 2024 election results than all of the recalls should fail. However, some KMT voters may not bother to vote in the recall, especially if they believe that the chance that the mass recall will succeed is low. Besides, how TPP voters and non-aligned voters will vote is anyone’s guess. In fact, in 2010, a somewhat similar "mass by-election" occurred in the Hong Kong legislature after five legislators resigned to trigger a so-called "referendum" on universal suffrage. However, the referendum was poorly received by Hong Kong voters. This may provide an indication of how the Taiwan public is likely to respond to the "Mass Recall," especially since most residents appear to believe that the recall is a waste of public money and resources.

title: Perceptions of Willingness to Communicate Orally in English among Iranian PhD Students
affiliations: INTI International University and University Putra Malaysia

detail.title: Perceptions of Willingness to Communicate Orally in English among Iranian PhD Students
detail.abstract: Willingness to Communicate (WTC) in second Language (L2) has received substantial consideration in modern language research and instruction. This study intends to investigate how oral L2 WTC of a group of EFL Iranian PhD students in a public university in Malaysia has changed during their stay in this country and what factors have resulted in their willingness to communicate. A qualitative case study method was implemented to obtain information from 8 participants through semi-structured interview as the main method, followed by focus group discussion and solicited journal diaries of the participants. The analyses of data derived from the first research question yielded five major themes: lack of exposure to L2 oral communication, cultural values, low L2 self-confidence, L2 extrinsic motivation, and enabling behaviors. Analysis of the second research question revealed six major themes as: raised awareness, cultural background, personality, exposure to L2 oral communication, extrinsic L2 motivation, and increased L2 selfconfidence. The findings of the study concluded that rare exposure to English oral communication in Iran resulted in having little practice of English language in authentic settings that led to low L2 WTC among the respondents of the study before coming to Malaysia. Besides, the respondents suffered from lack of L2 WTC upon arrival to Malaysia. However, by understanding their deficiencies and importance of L2 oral communication, they gradually changed their attitude toward L2 oral communication and tried to improve it. This study also provides theoretical and practical implications for designing teaching methods to maximize language learners' L2 WTC in the classroom that leads to their L2 oral communication improvement.

title: Rendezvous’ On Preference Selection
affiliations: NITTE School of Management and Management University of Africa

detail.title: Rendezvous’ On Preference Selection
detail.abstract: This paper offers a survey of the existing literature relevant to the research topic. It encompasses the historical evolution of preference-making, definition of preference-making, key attributes of preference-making, pros and cons of preference-making, varieties of preferencemaking, phases of preference-making process, approaches and contexts in preference-making, strategies for preference-making, frameworks for preference-making, innovation in preferencemaking, obstacles encountered by preference makers, hidden pitfalls in preference-making, and the notions of 'unfavorable preference dilemma' and 'favorable preference dilemma.

title: Predictive Workforce Planning: Leveraging AI & ML For Optimized HR Strategies and Employee Performance
affiliations: NITTE School of Management, CMR University, CMR University and CMR University

detail.title: Predictive Workforce Planning: Leveraging AI & ML For Optimized HR Strategies and Employee Performance
detail.abstract: The rapid advancement of artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning (ML) is transforming workforce planning and employee relations. This article explores how AI and ML can simulate human resources (HR) decision-making processes, providing a data-driven approach to workforce management. These technologies analyse large datasets to enhance talent forecasting, skill gap assessments, and employee engagement strategies. The study focuses on improving decision-making in recruitment, retention, performance evaluation, and workforce diversity, resulting in more agile HR operations. Additionally, it addresses ethical implications and challenges related to AI and ML integration in HR, such as transparency, bias mitigation, and privacy concerns. The research aims to identify key employee performance metrics that can be predicted using AI and ML, assess the impact of AI-driven workforce planning on HR strategy optimization, and evaluate the accuracy of various machine learning algorithms in simulating workforce dynamics. Using a mixed-methods approach, including quantitative analysis of HR data and evaluations of algorithms like decision trees and neural networks, the study finds that AI and ML significantly enhance employee performance forecasting, leading to improved HR decision-making and optimized recruitment and training processes. Overall, the research highlights the critical role of AI and ML in modern HR practices, offering practical insights for professionals seeking to leverage technology for effective workforce management in the tech industry.

title: The Art Dealer as Intermediary
affiliations: University of Arkansas, Fayetteville - School of Law

detail.title: The Art Dealer as Intermediary
detail.abstract: This chapter addresses the art dealer as intermediary and discusses the dealer’s obligations and risks in facilitating transactions in visual art. We explain the dealer’s critical role in the functioning of the specialized, secretive, and high stakes modern-day art market. And we describe how the structure of that intermediary function has a significant bearing on the dealer’s risk. Merchant dealers have exposure to common commercial claims like breach of warranty. Agent dealers’ liability hinges on their expansive fiduciary duties. Primary market dealers risk sinking time, energy, and investments in artists. And all dealers are on the hook for damages caused by breaching agreements or tortiously interfering with contractual relationships. We consider these risks in turn and conclude by addressing more and less effective methods of mitigating the dealer’s exposure.

title: Why Do Firms Issue Bonus Shares? A Review of Theories, Regulations, and Capital Market Outcomes
affiliations: ICFAI Business School (IBS) Hyderabad, India

detail.title: Why Do Firms Issue Bonus Shares? A Review of Theories, Regulations, and Capital Market Outcomes
detail.abstract: This study investigates why firms issue bonus shares, drawing on foundational corporate finance theories, regulatory dynamics, and empirical capital market evidence. Anchored in Modigliani & Miller's dividend irrelevance proposition, the paper contrasts theoretical neutrality with real-world phenomena where bonus issues serve as potent signals of managerial confidence, tools for liquidity enhancement, and mechanisms for optimizing perceived capital structure. Using extensive data on nearly 30 prominent Indian firmsincluding Infosys, TCS, Reliance, Wipro-and 10 global benchmarks like Apple, Tesla, Amazon, and Alibaba over 2008-2024, the analysis reveals that bonus shares often fulfill multiple overlapping objectives: conserving cash while rewarding investors, maintaining optimal trading ranges to boost liquidity, creating psychological wealth effects, and strategically aligning with regulatory or tax considerations. The report also details how India's regulatory regime under the Companies Act and SEBI ICDR tightly governs bonus issuance, contrasting with more liberal frameworks in the US and UK. Empirical case studies show positive short-term price reactions and liquidity shifts, underscoring that bonus issues are rarely purely cosmetic. This research provides nuanced insights for corporate managers, investors, and policymakers, suggesting that while bonus issues do not inherently alter firm value, they shape market perceptions, shareholder sentiment, and can strategically position firms in capital markets.

title: Goodbye, Noncompetes?  Why Now and Policy Convergence
affiliations: The Stephen M. Ross School of Business at the University of Michigan and University of Michigan at Ann Arbor

detail.title: Goodbye, Noncompetes?  Why Now and Policy Convergence
detail.abstract: Post-employment non-competition agreements (“noncompetes”) have been part of the common law dating back to at least 1414. The past 15 years have seen an unprecedented wave of scrutiny that is mostly aimed at curtailing these agreements, culminating in the contentious 2024 Federal Trade Commission’s (FTC) attempted noncompete ban. With the broad FTC ban on hold for the foreseeable future, the spotlight shifts back to the states where innovation in noncompete policy is blossoming. In this study, we systematically explore the legislative and policy trends reshaping the U.S. noncompete landscape. We propose a novel typology of these reforms and apply a theory of policy diffusion to explain the rapid spread of ideas across disparate jurisdictions, regulatory agencies, and in the consciousness of workers and policy makers. Our comprehensive analysis reveals a notable surge in state-level legislative activity since 2015, with 93 percent of reforms occurring in the last decade, including some states with multiple rounds of reform. Strikingly, 40 percent of these changes were enacted on a bi-partisan basis. We provide the first evidence of noncompetes as an example of policy diffusion and argue that, despite the stalled FTC ban, these legislative changes are a potential harbinger of future legal reforms related to employee fairness and human capital-focused competition.

title: Online annexes to "A welfare analysis of mergers of complements: lessons from the Hotelling line"
affiliations: RBB Economics and Joint Research Centre (European Commission)

detail.title: Online annexes to "A welfare analysis of mergers of complements: lessons from the Hotelling line"

contentType.other: Conditionally accepted for publication at Review of Industrial Organization

detail.abstract: This paper examines the welfare effects of mergers between complement producers. We use a Hotelling model with vertical differentiation and a captive market (hinterland). Unlike standard Bertrand or vertical differentiation models, which predict unambiguous consumer benefits, our model reveals a richer set of welfare outcomes. Consumer surplus and total welfare may increase or decrease post-merger. This depends on allocative efficiency (how consumers are distributed between firms) and output efficiency (total output achieved). We show that mergers can increase consumer surplus while reducing total welfare. This depends on the interaction between intrinsic value effects, transportation cost effects, and the size of the hinterland. The type of differentiation – whether vertical or in transportation costs – is critical, as it influences the balance between the elimination of double marginalisation and raising rivals’ costs. These findings underline the need to account for market-specific factors when assessing the welfare implications of mergers between complement producers.

title: Uncovering Waste: How Store Characteristics Impact Food Waste in Grocery Retail
affiliations: Technische Universität München (TUM), Technische Universität München (TUM), University of Pennsylvania - Operations, Information and Decisions Department and Technische Universität München (TUM)

detail.title: Uncovering Waste: How Store Characteristics Impact Food Waste in Grocery Retail
detail.abstract:
Food waste poses a major sustainability challenge for retailers, driving up both carbon emissions and costs, yet there is limited empirical evidence regarding its root causes. While internal and socioeconomic factors such as store layout or local competition are well-studied in brick-and-mortar retail, the specific impact of store attributes on food waste remains largely unexplored. Our research explores the relationship between store-specific attributes and in-store food waste using proprietary transaction data and socioeconomic data from a European grocery chain. The dataset covers 315 stores across both urban and non-urban areas. Using the Double Machine Learning algorithm XGBoost for causal inference, we find that store attributes significantly affect food waste levels. Specifically, merchant-owned stores generate less waste, possibly due to different incentive structures. In contrast, inventory systems that rely on double placement and backroom storage are associated with higher waste. 
Our findings show that store operations and organizational approaches significantly influence food waste. In particular, store organization and ownership form, inventory systems with double placement, and backroom usage are linked to higher waste levels. Through counterfactual analysis, we estimate that food waste could be reduced by up to 5.2%. This study offers empirical evidence concerning key store attributes that drive food waste, highlighting opportunities for reduction and helping store managers enhance sustainability in retail operations.

title: Tracking the "Xanadu" Meme
affiliations: Independent

detail.title: Tracking the "Xanadu" Meme
detail.abstract: I treat a single word, Xanadu, as a "meme" and follow it from a 17th century book to a 19th century poem (Coleridge's "Kubla Khan"), into the 20th century where it was picked up by a classic movie (Citizen Kane), an ongoing software development project (Ted Nelson's Project Xanadu), another movie and hit song, Olivia Newton-John's Xanadu, and a few other events. The aggregate result is that many occurrences of "Xanadu" fall into clusters that resonate with one of these founding events. Thus while some occurrences are directly related to Coleridge's poem, more seem to be related these other events and thus only indirectly to Coleridge's poem. For example, one large cluster of Xanadu sites is high tech while another cluster is about luxury and excess. Fifteen years ago I used manual methods to identify these clusters and estimate their sizes. Now I use ChatGPT o3 to update that work and to create a methodology for identifying other terms with similar distributions. Background: Tracking Down the "Xanadu" Meme .

title: Voice of the Arabs Radio Service Speaks: Theorizing an Occidental Interpretation
affiliations: Kuwait University

detail.title: Voice of the Arabs Radio Service Speaks: Theorizing an Occidental Interpretation
detail.abstract: As a prominent Arabic-language transnational service, the Voice of the Arabs radio station was the product of unforgiving modernity in an era that carries reverberations to the present day and it occupied a place that had distinct implications. The mode of resistance that it fashioned for itself against the Western hegemon was employed under the banner of Arab nationalism. In this rejection of imperialism, particularly given its positioning in a unique historical circumstance, broadcasts that reached every corner of the region made of this enemy an object. This paper considers the context at play to argue for the occidental bent of the radio station through the prisms of agency, subjectivity and alterity and underpinned by Kantian theories. The three areas would motivate the actions that were taken. The emerging power of Nasserism as a potent socialist ideology, linguistic choices within programming and visual elements that extended beyond the audio medium uniting peoples across borders all had bearing on furthering this impression of what was a key political instrument in the modern history of the Arab world.

title: Cohen-Boyer Redux
affiliations: Arizona State University (ASU) and Arizona State University (ASU) - School of Public Affairs

detail.title: Cohen-Boyer Redux
detail.abstract: The issuance of the Cohen-Boyer patents coincided with the passage of the Bayh Dole Act, which fundamentally transformed university intellectual policy rights and the relationship of universities with industry. The success of the Cohen-Boyer patents set expectations that technology transfer would be easy and lucrative. In retrospect, forty-five years later this has not proven to be the case. Although technology transfer offices have become established at every university across the U.S., many universities struggle as their offices do not break even and the process of engaging with faculty and with firms has proven contentious. This article reviews the evidence about how new relationships have developed in markets for technology and how the system of innovation has evolved. Now, forty years later, it is time to assess how this model has developed and been implemented and to question if a reconsideration is needed. The paper concludes with a discussion of alternatives for moving technology transfer towards the greater diffusion of academic research.

reference: Baalark-North Eastern Journal for Arts & Social Science, ISSN 2394-6113, 2024,Volume 10,Issue - I - II, Pp. 237-248
title: The Historical Perspective of Folk Culture in Tripura
affiliations: A.M.B.S Mahavidyalaya

detail.title: The Historical Perspective of Folk Culture in Tripura

publicationDetails.detailsText: Baalark-North Eastern Journal for Arts & Social Science, ISSN 2394-6113, 2024,Volume 10,Issue - I - II, Pp. 237-248

detail.abstract:
This research paper makes an overall assessment of the Folk culture in Tripura. ‘Folk culture’
of Tripura is a diverse form of folk art, Folklore, Folk song, Folk dance, Folk tales etc. Truly,
the Folk Culture of Tripura depict the true picture of traditional beliefs, customs and social
structure of the people of Tripura. The dress style of the tribal people of Tripura, their
‘Jhuming life’, religious customs can be observed by varied Folk culture of Tripura.
This paper attempts to explore the historical perspective of Folk culture in Tripura by
observing vibrant folk tale, folk lore and folk dance of the multi-faceted tribal communities
of Tripura. Let be the folk literature or folk art; either be the folk ornament or folk handicraft;
either be folk lore or folk song – we get lots of information about the rich cultural heritage of
Tripura.

This paper justifies the facts that it is due to the availability of various forms of ‘Folk
Culture’ by which the concise History of Tripura can be rewritten.

title: Sustainable Tourism in Saint Martin Island: An Observation on Young Tourist Perception and Awareness Level
affiliations: Noakhali Science and Technology University and Noakhali Science and Technology University - Department of Tourism and Hospitality Management

detail.title: Sustainable Tourism in Saint Martin Island: An Observation on Young Tourist Perception and Awareness Level
detail.abstract: Saint Martin Island is located in the northeast of the Bay of Bengal, about 9 km south of the Cox's Bazar, Bangladesh. During the tourist season an average of 3500 people visit this island daily, which is beyond the carrying capacity of this small marine island. For the last few years Saint Martin's Island, which is the only coral-bearing island in Bangladesh, has been facing an ecological disaster due to excessive tourism activities. This island is under threat from unlimited and environmentally irresponsible tourism activities. The fragile ecosystem of Saint Martin's Island is only suitable for the sustainable tourism. The aim of this study is to know the perception and awareness level of young tourists about sustainable tourism. This study examines the social, economic and environmental impacts of tourism. To achieve the objectives of the study, data were collected from 150 tourists through questionnaire.

title: The Interplay of Market Choices and Social Mission: Learning from B2B Social Enterprises in Emerging Economies
affiliations: CSU Dominguez Hills, University of Sussex Business School, University of Bath and This One

detail.title: The Interplay of Market Choices and Social Mission: Learning from B2B Social Enterprises in Emerging Economies

declarations.declarationOfInterest: No conflict of interest.
declarations.ethicsApproval: All names have been anonymized.
declarations.funderStatement: This research was not funded by any organization.

detail.abstract: Social enterprises that operate in business-to-business contexts, often out of emerging economies, typically face high expectations from business clients, mainstream competition, and the challenge of operating across distances. In these contexts, social enterprises need to carefully choose which market segments to serve and how to organize their social mission accordingly. Based on the case of impact sourcing—hiring and training of disadvantaged staff for global business services—we seek to better understand this interplay. In general, we find that social enterprises in this context either focus on serving domestic clients with an implicit social mission and an integrated social enterprise model or international clients with a more explicit social mission and a decoupled model. We discuss why both main configurations represent viable social enterprise models in the outsourcing industry and why, in particular, the professional background of founders plays a key role in these strategic choices. Our findings contribute to a more nuanced and context-sensitive understanding of social enterprise model adoption in emerging economies.

title: Identities of Tripura and Identities in Tripura
affiliations: A.M.B.S Mahavidyalaya

detail.title: Identities of Tripura and Identities in Tripura
detail.abstract:
Tripura, a land – locked state in the north-eastern India is located between 22° 56’ and
24° 32’ north latitude and 91° 09’and 91° 21’ east longitude measuring 10,491.69 sq.km. It is
a small state, which borders Bangladesh, Mizoram & Assam. It is surrounded by Bangladesh
on its north, south and west and the length of its international border with Bangladesh is 856
km.(84% of its total border). It shares a 53 Km. long border with Assam and 109 Km. long
border with Mizoram.  As per census of 2001 the total population of this state is 31, 99,203 of
whom 31.05% belong to the Tribal communities.
The glory of Tripura kingdom is known from Puranic period and much before the
Ramayana and the Mahabharata.  The early history of the Present State of Tripura is Still
shrouded into obscurity. No records in the shape of documents or monuments of the
Authochthons people of the land belonging to the pre-historic or proto-historic periods have
survived. 
The present state of Tripura was known as “Hill Tripperah” in the British period. It was
ruled by the lunar dynasty of members with Manikya ending names since the beginning of
the 15 th Century A.D.
The British Govt. gave Tripura the status of “Native State” under the general
supervision of a political agent and it was merged with India on October15, 1949 and
became a full-fledged state on January 21, 1972.

title: Role of International Human Resource Management in International NGOs and Humanitarian Organizations
affiliations: Ghalib University, Ghalib University and Ghalib University

detail.title: Role of International Human Resource Management in International NGOs and Humanitarian Organizations
detail.abstract: This study investigates how International Human Resource Management (IHRM) practices have evolved within international nongovernmental organizations (NGOs) and humanitarian agencies in response to global crises such as conflict, pandemics, and climate disasters. The goal is to understand how HRM strategies contribute to organizational effectiveness, ethics, and adaptability in complex, highrisk contexts. Design/Method/Approach: Using a qualitative research design, the study employed a systematic literature review and case study analysis of ten leading humanitarian organizations operating globally between January 2019 and March 2025. Data were thematically analyzed to identify strategic HR trends and challenges. The study followed a two-stage qualitative research approach. First, a systematic literature review was conducted using PRISMA guidelines to ensure transparency in source selection and analysis. Findings: The analysis revealed five major themes shaping IHRM practices: (1) localization and national staff empowerment, (2) safeguarding and duty of care, (3) remote management and digital HR innovations, (4) staff wellbeing and resilience strategies, and (5) leadership development. While organizations are advancing ethical leadership, technology use, and local capacity building, systemic inequalities, digital divides, and resource constraints persist. Theoretical Implications: The study contributes to the development of IHRM in nonprofit and crisis-response settings by integrating ethical leadership, resilience, and localization into HRM theory. It highlights the need to adapt strategic HRM frameworks to volatile and resourcelimited environments. Practical Implications: Humanitarian HR practitioners can apply these insights to improve local workforce development, strengthen safeguarding protocols, and implement context-appropriate digital HR solutions. The findings offer actionable strategies for enhancing organizational agility and ethical governance. Originality/Value: This research addresses a significant gap in literature by examining IHRM through the lens of humanitarian action-a context often overlooked in mainstream HRM theory. It reframes HRM as a central, strategic function in crisis-affected operations. Research Limitations/Future Research: The study is limited by its reliance on secondary data and selected case studies. Future research could incorporate primary data from field HR personnel or extend the analysis to regional NGOs. Comparative studies across sectors or conflict regions are also recommended.

title: Epistemic Opacity in Management Consultancy: A Critical Theory of Inaccessible Expertise
affiliations: University of Portsmouth

detail.title: Epistemic Opacity in Management Consultancy: A Critical Theory of Inaccessible Expertise
detail.abstract: Management consultancy's $300B global industry commodifies expertise while systematically obscuring its production processes. This paper theorizes epistemic opacity-the structured inaccessibility of knowledgegeneration mechanics-as a constitutive element of consultancy's power dynamics. Integrating Paul Humphreys' philosophy of complex systems, Miriam Solomon's epistemology of tacit expertise, and critical frameworks (Michel Foucault, Michael Power, Pierre Bourdieu), we conceptualize opacity as a tripartite regime: (1) cognitive opacity (tacit intuition), (2) technical opacity (proprietary tools), and (3) social opacity (erased sensemaking). We reveal how this regime enables epistemic injustice, client deskilling, and biased knowledge reproduction. Arguing against naïve transparency, we advance democratized opacity governance as an ethical framework. The paper concludes with a critical research agenda for expertise in post-digital capitalism.

title: Effective Role of New Media in the Process of Globalization
affiliations: A.M.B.S Mahavidyalaya

detail.title: Effective Role of New Media in the Process of Globalization
detail.abstract:
This paper studies the effective role of ‘New Media’ in the process of
globalization. New Media is a broad term in media studies that emerged
in the latter part of the 20 th century. The effective role of new media has
increased communication between people all over the world and it has
allowed people to express themselves through blogs, websites, pictures
& other used generated media. This paper explores the role of new media
as a tool for social change. Social movement media has a rich and storied
history that has changed at a rapid rate since new media became widely
used during the process of globalization. The Zapatista Army of National
Liberation of Chiapas, Mexico was the first major movement to make
widely recognized & effective use of new media for communiqués and
organization as early as 1994. Neuman argues that new media alters the
meaning of geographic distance and it provides the possibility of
increasing the speed of communication. New media provides
opportunities of interactive communication & it allows forms of
communication that were previously separate to overlap and
interconnect. This paper focuses on the different roles played by new
media in making the whole world a ‘global village’.

title: Comparative Law, the Law of War, and Usufruct
affiliations: George Washington University - Law School

detail.title: Comparative Law, the Law of War, and Usufruct
detail.abstract:
International law draws heavily from civil law systems based on Roman law for its sources, shape, and substance. During its genesis, Roman legal concepts were incorporated into the primordial structures of international law. Early originators of international legal thought were civil law jurists with an understanding of Roman law, and their foundational international legal scholarship was suffused with Roman and civil law concepts.  As a result, the substance and undergirding philosophy of international law more frequently aligns with civil law systems based on Roman law (rather than common law). 

This post explores the intertextual dialogue between international treaties and civil codes, focusing specifically on the civil law concept of usufruct (and its Roman law origins) to illuminate how comparative law can inform our understanding of international law, including the law of war.  Through an analysis of the concept of usufruct, the post explores a significant "interdimensional moment" at which the substance of international law is informed by domestic legal concepts drawn from civil law systems.

title: Slavery in Tripura: A Historical Overview
affiliations: A.M.B.S Mahavidyalaya

detail.title: Slavery in Tripura: A Historical Overview
detail.abstract:
Slavery System has its origin in ancient Indian society and the tiny state of Tripura was not
an exception of this. In real terms the Slave system was institutionalized with the growth of
various socio-political, tribal eschatological and legal institutions, on the basis of existing
mode of production. Big landlords, merchants, money- lenders, owners of big workshops etc.
were the different components of owning classes while the bulk of exploited masses turned to
be slaves. 
In Tripura, as in Greece of Plato and Aristotle , Slavery was a well-known institution. The
first Slave and the Slave-master of Tripura are almost impossible to trace. However, it
appears that the transition from primitive communalism and beginning of private ownership
both of which occurred simultaneously at revolutionary moment of historical evolution had
much to do with the slave owning system. The institution of slavery in Tripura in the true
sense of the term has existed since a long time. The slaves of this tiny state of Tripura have
been generally isolated socially, deprived economically, oppressed politically and humiliated
morally.

title: The Cultural History of Tripura: An Overview
affiliations: A.M.B.S Mahavidyalaya

detail.title: The Cultural History of Tripura: An Overview
detail.abstract:
The glory of Tripura kingdom is known from Puranic period and much before the
Ramayana and the Mahabharata.  The early history of the Present State of Tripura is
Still shrouded into obscurity. No records in the shape of documents or monuments of
the Autochthons people of the land belonging to the pre-historic or proto-historic
periods have survived. 
As a matter of fact, Culture plays a significant role in molding destiny of one’s own
country. Tripura witnessed the emergence of secular identity as the people of
different religions just like Hindu and Buddhists walked together to form a common
cultural identity. During Pre-Colonial Tripura, the dwellers in the hills of Tripura belonged to the
following tribes:
(i)The Tripuri, (ii) The Jamatia, (iii) The Reang, (iv) The Halam divided into twelve
sub-tribes and (v) The Kukis divided into two major groups, namely, the Darlong and
the Dusai (Mizo).
The present state of Tripura was known as ‘Hill Tipperah’ in the Colonial period. It
was ruled by the lunar dynasty of members with Manikya ending names since the
beginning of the 15 th Century A. D. The British Govt. gave Tripura the status of
‘Native State’ under the general supervision of a political agent and it was merged
with India on October15, 1949 and became a full-fledged state on January 21, 1972.
It is believed by the scholars that the name of this land as ‘Tripura’ is the sanskritised
form of Tipra, a tribe to which the ruling family belonged.

title: SRIMAD BHAGAVAD GITA: THE OTHER NAME OF LIFE
affiliations: A.M.B.S Mahavidyalaya

detail.title: SRIMAD BHAGAVAD GITA: THE OTHER NAME OF LIFE
detail.abstract: The Srimada Bhagavada-Gita occurs in the Bhisma Parva, the sixth book of the Mahabharata and comprises of 18 chapters from the 25th to 42nd. The discourse between Arjun and Krishna on the battlefield on the eve of the war which forms the subject matter of the work was strung together in 700 verses and put in its place in the body of this great history of Vyasa. Among the religious poems that form part of the Mahabharata, the most famous is Srimada Bhagavad Gita or the 'Song of the Lord" which constitutes the bed-rock of Hindu theism. All over the world it is recognised as a really great work. Due to its popularity, it was first translated into English in 1785 A.D. by Charles Wilkins. It was translated into Latin in 1823 by Schlegeli into German in 1826 by Von Humbolt, into French in 1846 by Lassens and into Greek in 1848 by Galanos. By now it has been translated into all the major languages of the world such as :-Russians, Chinese, Japanese, Spanish, Italian, Dutch , Hebrew, Portuguese, Arabic. Hindi and Bengali.

title: Exit through the Glassdoor: Employee-Generated Disclosures and Worker Flows
affiliations: London School of Economics and Political Science and London School of Economics & Political Science (LSE)

detail.title: Exit through the Glassdoor: Employee-Generated Disclosures and Worker Flows
detail.abstract: We study the relation between employee-generated disclosures and worker flows, using data on Glassdoor ratings and worker flows within U.S. metropolitan areas from 2008 to 2023. We find that the availability of ratings increases overall worker flows. We also find that relative ratings explain directional flows from lower- to higher-rated employers. These findings support predictions from labor search theory that employee-generated disclosures reduce information frictions. To isolate informational effects from confounding factors, we use peer-related variation around quasi-random rating thresholds, complemented by information shocks from peer workplace awards. Supporting the mechanism that employee-generated disclosures help workers evaluate job fit, flow patterns weaken when alternative information sources become available and strengthen when harder-to-observe, non-wage job attributes are more salient.

reference: Journal of Chinese Human Resource Management, Volume 12, No. 1. Pp. 50-64
title: Evaluate Human Resource Management Challenges Faced by Investment Banks: A Case Study of Goldman Sachs
affiliations: EDHEC Business School (EDHEC), Students

detail.title: Evaluate Human Resource Management Challenges Faced by Investment Banks: A Case Study of Goldman Sachs

publicationDetails.detailsText: Journal of Chinese Human Resource Management, Volume 12, No. 1. Pp. 50-64

detail.abstract: Very few scholars focus on the current human resource management (HRM) challenges faced by investment banks. This paper, for the first time, analyzed the four main challenges faced by one of the top investment banks, Goldman Sachs. The four challenges are work-life imbalance, culture crash, high turnover rate, and gender inequality, separately. This paper also provides managerial suggestions on how to tackle these challenges efficiently.

reference: Research in Hospitality Management, volume 14, issue 3, 2024[10.1080/22243534.2024.2419366]
title: The Digital Transformation of Tourism: A Study of Tourist Behaviour and Preferences in the Age of Technology in Bangladesh
affiliations: Noakhali Science and Technology University and Noakhali Science and Technology University - Department of Tourism and Hospitality Management

detail.title: The Digital Transformation of Tourism: A Study of Tourist Behaviour and Preferences in the Age of Technology in Bangladesh

publicationDetails.detailsText: Research in Hospitality Management, volume 14, issue 3, 2024[10.1080/22243534.2024.2419366]

detail.abstract: The rapid development of technology has profoundly altered tourist behaviour and trends, yet there is a notable gap in understanding how these changes affect tourists in Bangladesh. Existing research focuses on developed markets, overlooking Bangladesh’s unique sociocultural and economic factors. Consequently, there is limited knowledge about how Bangladeshi tourists interact with digital platforms. This study explores the digital transformation of tourism in Bangladesh, identifying significant links between technology acceptance, social media usage and travel experiences. Results show a strong connection between the use of travel technology and reliance on social media for decisions, with comfort in technology correlating with satisfaction in personalised travel platforms. Social media facilitates trip planning and booking, with tourists showing increased trust in online tools. The study underscores the transformative potential of digital technology in reshaping the travel landscape, urging industry players to innovate to meet evolving consumer expectations through quantitative analysis by using structural equation modelling (SEM) to examine the relationships among the variables. Further research is essential to provide insights for policymakers and industry stakeholders in Bangladesh to understand how Bangladeshi tourists interact with digital platforms.

title: Online Decisions with (Biased) Offline Data
affiliations: University of Michigan, Stephen M. Ross School of Business, UCL School of Management, University College London and Boston College - Carroll School of Management

detail.title: Online Decisions with (Biased) Offline Data
detail.abstract: With the growing availability of offline data, using such information to facilitate online decision making has become relevant to practice. A key challenge of using offline data, however, is that the true online data‐generating process may differ unpredictably from the offline distribution. In this paper, we study the problem of how to use available and potentially biased offline data to support online decision making for two canonical decision problems in operations management: the dynamic newsvendor, where the demand tail distribution plays a key role, and dynamic pricing, where point estimates are critical and the decisions themselves interact with the demand distribution. We develop two online learning frameworks that incorporate offline data. The soft‐switch policy automatically balances offline information and online feedback without requiring knowledge of the bias, while the hard‐switch policy leverages the known extent of distributional shifts. Both learning policies achieve the optimal regret up to a logarithmic factor. We further derive explicit bounds showing how regret improves with the size and bias of the offline data.

title: Capital structure in medium-sized companies in Department of Boyacá, Colombia
affiliations: Tecnológico de Monterrey

detail.title: Capital structure in medium-sized companies in Department of Boyacá, Colombia
detail.abstract:
The study of capital structure is one of the financial topics of greatest impact, since among the theories that attempt to explain it, a consensus has not yet been reached on the determinants and the behavior of financing decisions in companies. Research on the behavior of capital structure in small and medium size companies is an even more complex issue, since traditional models are mainly applicable to companies that trade in capital markets, or public interest companies.

For this work, medium-sized companies in the Department of Boyacá in Colombia were selected as a study sample, applying a model that has been used in similar cases in other countries. The study empirically demonstrated a preference for self-financing over debt, which in turn was preferred by companies with higher volatility in profitability and those with better growth.

title: Personalised Incentives: Segregation in a Platform with Networks
affiliations: Nottingham University Business School and Grinnell College

detail.title: Personalised Incentives: Segregation in a Platform with Networks

declarations.ethicsApproval: NA
declarations.funderStatement: NA

detail.abstract: A platform does not always have precise information about users' preferences over networked goods. We develop a novel binary choice framework where an online platform generates adrevenue from a free basic plan (B) and subscription revenue from a fee-based exclusive plan (E). The platform provides generic content to basic users and costly personalised incentives to exclusive users. Each user receives private exogenous information about B-positive or negative-after which they self-select into the desired plan. When can the platform utilise information about user-level social networks and optimally allocate personalised incentives to users to maximise profit? In equilibrium, influential users receive greater incentives, which attract other susceptible users to join E. Profit of the platform is monotonically increasing in ad-revenue, whereas the effect of subscription-fee on profit is non-monotonic. We characterise how changes in network structure, ad-revenue, subscription fees, their interactions and biases affect the optimal profit.

title: Blockchain Ecosystem Evolution
affiliations: Hashtag Web3

detail.title: Blockchain Ecosystem Evolution
detail.abstract: This study analyzes the evolution of blockchain ecosystem development from 2008 to 2025, based on three datasets: global Google search trends for "blockchain," weekly active developer counts, and code commit frequencies to blockchain repositories. The findings reveal distinct phases in blockchain's growth, marked by public interest spikes during the 2017 and 2021 cryptocurrency bull markets, followed by sustained developer activity even as public attention declined. A strong positive correlation between weekly developer counts and code commits (r = 0.954) highlights the close link between community size and technical productivity. Developer engagement rose steadily from 2015 to 2022, before declining through early 2025. This drop is interpreted as a sign of ecosystem consolidation and maturity, rather than reduced relevance. The study also identifies a notable lag between peak public interest and peak developer activity, suggesting that long-term professional engagement tends to follow hype-driven attention. These results offer insight into blockchain's trajectory and provide useful signals for researchers, developers, and investors evaluating the health and sustainability of the ecosystem.

title: Participate or Perish: Thinking with Machines in the Age of the Triad
affiliations: Lyciar

detail.title: Participate or Perish: Thinking with Machines in the Age of the Triad
detail.abstract: The rise of large language models (LLMs) challenges the long-standing dictum ‘publish or perish’, destabilising traditional notions of authorship, credit, and epistemic value. This essay argues that in an age where machines can generate fluent text at scale, understanding no longer resides in the static artefact of publication, but in the process through which knowledge is formed. Drawing on complexity science and process philosophy, the essay introduces a triadic framework—Prompt, Draft, Reflect—to capture the iterative dance between human and machine in inquiry. Authorship becomes an act of participation rather than mere origination, and epistemic vitality is measured by presence, reflection, and adaptive engagement. The paper reorients scholarly practice toward Becoming rather than Being. In this emerging paradigm, fidelity lies not in provenance, but in process. The new imperative is clear: Participate or perish. Only through engagement can understanding endure.

title: Structural Tax Theory: Adapted for the Digital Civilization Era
affiliations: Independent

detail.title: Structural Tax Theory: Adapted for the Digital Civilization Era

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The author declares no personal or financial conflicts of interest regarding the content of this study. This research was conducted independently, without influence from any institution or commercial entity.
declarations.ethicsApproval: Not applicable. This study did not involve human participants or sensitive personal data.
declarations.funderStatement: This research was entirely self-funded by the author.

detail.abstract: This paper introduces the Structural Tax, a novel framework for taxation uniquely tailored to the architecture of digital currencies and transactional topologies. The model treats each transaction as an atomic chain and applies a progressive tax exclusively at the receiver end. Unlike traditional income tax systems, this framework leverages traceable, programmable digital payments to implement a "levyfirst, refund-later" logic with embedded behavioral incentives. Its simplicity in structure and sophistication in function allow it to balance redistribution and economic feedback in real time. The paper outlines the mechanism and discusses its relevance in the emerging programmable financial ecosystems.

title: Impact of Civilizational Populism on Intergroup Emotions, Social Cohesion, and Civility in the UK
affiliations: Bangor University

detail.title: Impact of Civilizational Populism on Intergroup Emotions, Social Cohesion, and Civility in the UK
detail.abstract: This study investigates the impact of civilizational populism on intergroup emotions, social cohesion, and civility in the United Kingdom using quantitative analysis of British Social Attitudes Survey (BSA) 2021 data. The findings reveal significant correlations between exposure to populist rhetoric and heightened negative emotions, such as fear and anger, toward ethnoreligious and political minorities (r = 0.56). While political affiliation demonstrates a weaker direct influence (r = 0.14), perceptions of migration as culturally and economically beneficial are strongly associated with higher social cohesion (r = 0.69). Minority groups report elevated levels of exclusion and fear, yet national pride correlates with inclusive attitudes in some cases (r =-0.64, with prejudicial views). Civil society organizations play a critical role in mitigating divisive effects by fostering inclusivity and dialogue. These insights inform strategies to counteract the polarizing impacts of civilizational populism, emphasizing the importance of inclusive narratives and policy interventions to enhance social cohesion in diverse societies. The study's limitations include reliance on secondary data and challenges in establishing causality, highlighting the need for further research using more direct measures of populism and contemporary datasets. Despite these constraints, the findings contribute empirical evidence to the growing literature on the social and emotional consequences of populism, offering a foundation for policies aimed at promoting harmony and reducing polarization in the UK.

title: Toward an Integrated Epistemology of Futures Thinking: A Meta-Synthetic Taxonomy of Foresight Methodologies
affiliations: Artificial Intelligence & Mathematical Modeling Lab (AIMMLab); Africa-Canada Artificial Intelligence and Data Innovation Consortium (ACADIC); University of Toronto and Sol Plaatje University

detail.title: Toward an Integrated Epistemology of Futures Thinking: A Meta-Synthetic Taxonomy of Foresight Methodologies

detail.abstract: Foresight has emerged as an essential epistemic and governance framework for navigating systemic risks and shaping long-term trajectories in complex, uncertain environments. Yet, the absence of a coherent and comprehensive classification system for foresight methodologies continues to hinder comparative analysis, methodological transparency, and interdisciplinary integration. This study conducts a structured qualitative meta-synthesis of key taxonomic contributions to futures studies, synthesizing a unified framework encompassing sixteen dimensions and their subcategories. These span methodological orientation, purpose, process phases, participation, epistemology, output logic, system scope, validation criteria, and paradigmatic stance. The resulting taxonomy not only addresses a persistent methodological lacuna in the field but also reflects the pluralistic, reflexive, and increasingly participatory transformation of contemporary foresight practice. It provides a versatile tool for both theoretical inquiry and practical design, enabling practitioners and scholars to select and tailor foresight methods in accordance with context-specific epistemic commitments, strategic goals, and stakeholder configurations. By articulating the multidimensional architecture of anticipatory knowledge production, the study advances the theoretical foundations of foresight and enhances its utility for anticipatory governance in a world marked by volatility, disruption, and contested futures.

title: Revisiting Disaster Response Framework from an OR/OM Perspective: Insights from the Kahramanmaraş Earthquakes
affiliations: Bilkent University Industrial Engineering Dept., Bilkent University - Department of Industrial Engineering, Bilkent University - Department of Industrial Engineering and INSEAD

detail.title: Revisiting Disaster Response Framework from an OR/OM Perspective: Insights from the Kahramanmaraş Earthquakes
detail.abstract: The recent Kahramanmaraş earthquakes not only underscored the importance of resilience, but also highlighted the urgent need for improvements in our response mechanisms. In addition, it served as a call to action for Operations Research (OR) and Operations Management (OM) researchers, revealing (and reminding) the need to address operational challenges after high-impact disasters. This perspective responds to this call and proposes a comprehensive disaster response framework. Our aim is to provide a context sensitive foundation that helps OR/OM researchers to more accurately capture the realities of the complex response scenarios and structure the underlying logistical problems in a phase-aware manner.

title: Sovereign Liquidity Shocks
affiliations: Northwestern University

detail.title: Sovereign Liquidity Shocks
detail.abstract: This paper estimates the macroeconomic effects of changes in sovereign risk. I identify a novel series of shocks using a decomposition of high-frequency movements in asset prices around International Monetary Fund announcements concerning Argentina, which I characterize as sovereign liquidity shocks. Using this series, I estimate the dynamic causal effects of sovereign risk on key macroeconomic variables. A sovereign liquidity shock associated with a 100-basis-point increase in sovereign spreads decreases output by 0.96 percent in the months following the shock, with the contraction primarily driven by declines in investment. Evidence suggests that these effects operate through disruptions in international lending and trade, while domestic financial intermediation plays little to no role in propagating the shock.

title: Firm Dynamics, Informality, And Monetary Policy
affiliations: University of Manitoba

detail.title: Firm Dynamics, Informality, And Monetary Policy

declarations.funderStatement: I gratefully acknowledge financial support from the Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council of Canada (SSHRC) Insight Development Grant project No.56529, the University of Manitoba URGP grant project No.55133, and the Faculty of Arts Research Development Fund.

detail.abstract: A prominent structural feature of many developing countries is the presence of a large shadow or informal economy, which often serves as a form of insurance during economic downturns. Despite this understanding, the impact of the informal economy on inflation and output dynamics in these countries remains poorly understood. This study investigates the extent to which monetary policy can stabilize economies with a large informal market. First, we use VAR analysis to provide new evidence indicating that the labor informality rate increases in response to contractionary monetary policy. Second, we explore the transmission mechanism of monetary policy through a two-sector New Keynesian (NK) model that incorporates endogenous firm entry. This analysis allows us to examine the role of informality in sectoral reallocation, inflation, and output dynamics. Our findings suggest that, under a reasonable calibration of the model, the presence of a flexible, informal sector results in a lower sacrifice ratio in response to a tightening of monetary policy. This suggests that informality enhances the effectiveness of monetary policy.

title: The Impact of Management Information Systems on Organizational
affiliations: Universitas Muhammadiyah Palopo

detail.title: The Impact of Management Information Systems on Organizational
detail.abstract: All praise is due to God Almighty, who has given us health and knowledge to complete this paper entitled "The Impact of Management Information Systems on Organizational Operational Efficiency." This paper is prepared to fulfill the requirements of the Management Information Systems course and aims to discuss the role of MIS in supporting organizational efficiency. I would like to thank all parties who have provided support during the process of writing this paper.

title: The Impact of IPOs on Workers
affiliations: Nova School of Business and Economics, Stockholm School of Economics and Nova School of Business and Economics

detail.title: The Impact of IPOs on Workers
detail.abstract: We study how initial public offerings affect workers. Going public significantly impacts the relationship between firms and employees: firms raise salaries and offer more stable wages, especially to long-tenured workers. These changes in employment contracts affect household finances and family decisions. After an IPO, workers take on more investment risk and are more likely to purchase a home; they are also more likely to marry and have children. To identify these effects, we use stock market return variations during the book building period as an instrument for IPO completion.

title: Forecasting Demand for Critical Metals in China's New Energy Vehicle Power Batteries
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Forecasting Demand for Critical Metals in China's New Energy Vehicle Power Batteries
detail.abstract: Under the “dual carbon” goals, the rapid development of China's new energy vehicle (NEV) industry had significantly increased demand for key metals. This study employed dynamic material flow analysis to quantify the historical demand for lithium, cobalt, nickel, and manganese in NEV batteries across China's 31 provincial-level administrative regions from 2011 to 2022. Using the LMDI model, it revealed the mechanisms through which population, economy, industrial structure, and technology influenced demand fluctuations. Finally, a Gaussian process regression model was employed to predict the demand for key metals in each province from 2023 to 2030. The research findings indicated: (1) From 2011 to 2022, China's demand for key metals in NEVs had grown exponentially, with a high concentration in economically developed provinces along the eastern coast. (2) Industrial scale expansion was the core driver of historical demand growth, while technological progress had a dual effect of either promoting or inhibiting demand; economic growth had continued to positively drive demand, while the population scale effect had been relatively small. (3) From 2023 to 2030, demand for key metals was projected to continue to grow strongly, with eastern coastal regions remaining the primary demand areas, but the growth potential of central and western regions should not have been overlooked.

title: Natural Resource-Based View in Sustainability Practices Among U.S. Fashion Businesses: Insights from Fashion Entrepreneurs
affiliations: Framingham State University, Louisiana State University and Oregon State University

detail.title: Natural Resource-Based View in Sustainability Practices Among U.S. Fashion Businesses: Insights from Fashion Entrepreneurs
detail.abstract: The purpose of this study was to holistically comprehend the business ecosystem among the U.S. fashion small businesses (FSBs) to help them identify opportunities to establish sustainability-related competitive advantages through the lens of a natural resources-based view (NSBV) and dynamic capabilities. A group of in-depth, semi-structured interviews were conducted to collect the data. It allows us to gain deep, contextualized insights from the participants. The researchers developed an interview protocol that included the purpose of the study, a statement of confidentiality, and fifteen interview questions with three foci: company sustainability practices, sustainability performance assessment, and communication with stakeholders. In total, thirteen CEOs/founders of the U.S. based FSBs were interviewed. Interviews were conducted on ZOOM, a web meeting platform, with each interview lasting between 50-75 minutes. The interviews were recorded and later transcribed for data analysis.  From a pragmatic standpoint, our findings provide an extended typology of current fashion small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in the U.S. and present these diverse, dynamic business powers operating at the grassroots level. This study also echoes the insights of previous studies, affirming that NSBV resources are not sequential and not every organization engages in clean technology development. Extending the findings from existing study, we provide insight into how clean technology resources serve as a critical distinguishing element between SME and Innovative Driven Enterprises (IDEs) types.

title: Planning and Performance: Experimental Evidence from Small Firms in E-Commerce
affiliations: Universidad de los Andes, Chile - School of Business and Economics

detail.title: Planning and Performance: Experimental Evidence from Small Firms in E-Commerce
detail.abstract: This paper provides experimental evidence that behavioral frictions can affect operations planning in small firms, thereby reducing firm performance. I analyze a field experiment involving 14,500 e-commerce retailers in Argentina and Brazil conducted during the two weeks before Black Friday, a major sales event. The intervention randomized messages reminding managers that Black Friday was approaching and encouraging them to plan their pricing and advertising strategies. Treated firms shifted from generic to discount-related advertising and increased inventories before the event, but did not vary their pricing relative to the control group. As a result, sales increased by 5.2% for 60 days following the intervention. Machine learning methods reveal larger returns for relatively bigger firms with a stronger social media presence, suggesting strategic complementarities between firm size and light-touch interventions. These findings highlight that psychological constraints may be a meaningful barrier to the performance of small firms.

title: Whistleblowing: How it Came about, Best Practices, Controversial Aspects and Regulatory Perspectives in Brazil
affiliations: Universidade de Brasília (UnB) and University of Pennsylvania

detail.title: Whistleblowing: How it Came about, Best Practices, Controversial Aspects and Regulatory Perspectives in Brazil
detail.abstract:
This article aims to provide an in-depth analysis on the institute of whistleblowing, which can be understood as a public policy for the protection of whistleblowers, instituted to facilitate the discovery of illegal acts.

As a starting point, we will understand the whistleblower from a pragmatic perspective, as someone who reports waste, fraud, abuse, acts of corruption, or risks to public health and safety, among others, to someone in a position to remedy the situation. The complaint can be made through an internal channel or to third parties outside the organization's structure, public or private, and can be addressed to the organization's senior management or also to regulatory bodies, auditors, authorities working in the fight against corruption, public managers or the press. Whistleblowers are not to be confused with collaborators who enter into plea bargain agreements, insofar as, unlike the latter, they did not participate in the reported unlawful practice.

The analysis will begin with a synthesis of the historical evolution of the institute, explaining how it progressively evolved from a North American experiment to become a mechanism present in the legislation of at least 62 countries. Next, we will discuss the best international practices in the regulation of whistleblowing in the public and private spheres, taking as reference the recommendations on the subject formulated by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD), the International Bar Association (IBA), and Transparency International.

The study will also address two of the most controversial points in the international debate on the regulation of whistleblowing, and which therefore receive different treatments, depending on the jurisdiction analyzed: (1) the requirement for good faith from the whistleblower and (2) the creation of programs that grant financial rewards to those who make effective complaints. Finally, we will discuss national efforts in regulating and implementing whistleblowing in the public and private spheres in Brazil.

title: An Estimated Model of Employer and Non-Employer Entrepreneurship
affiliations: Northern Arizona University, University of Nevada, Reno - College of Business Administration - Department of Economics and University of Nevada, Reno

detail.title: An Estimated Model of Employer and Non-Employer Entrepreneurship

publicationDetails.journalName: IZA Institute of Labor Economics Discussion Paper Series

detail.abstract: What motivates individuals to become entrepreneurs and create jobs? We develop and estimate a dynamic structural microeconometric model that accounts for both employer and non-employer entrepreneurs. Individuals in each period choose to work as an employee, as one of the two entrepreneur types, or remain non-employed. Different work experiences may affect earnings in the three sectors differently. The estimated model replicates key data patterns. The results suggest that experience in employment provides positive returns in entrepreneurship, but entrepreneurial experience does not have positive returns in employment. The model is used to simulate how policy scenarios would affect individuals' entrepreneurial choices.

title: Identity-Based Discrimination and Moral Wiggle Room
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN and University of Portsmouth

detail.title: Identity-Based Discrimination and Moral Wiggle Room
detail.abstract: In this paper, we examine whether the existence of moral wiggle room influences identity-based discrimination. We hypothesize that moral wiggle room increases selfish behavior and facilitates greater discrimination between ingroup and outgroup members of one’s group. In a laboratory experiment, we find that without moral wiggle room, few participants choose the selfish option, and no discrimination is observed. With moral wiggle room, selfishness and outgroup discrimination increase. These findings suggest that uncertainty in moral accountability not only promotes selfishness but also enables individuals to justify discriminatory behavior.

reference: Northeastern U. D’Amore-McKim School of Business Research Paper No. 3998042
title: SEC Comment Letters on Mutual Fund Disclosures
affiliations: University of Massachusetts Lowell - Department of Accounting, Pennsylvania State University, Northeastern University - Accounting Group and Pennsylvania State University - Department of Finance

detail.title: SEC Comment Letters on Mutual Fund Disclosures

publicationDetails.detailsText: Northeastern U. D’Amore-McKim School of Business Research Paper No. 3998042
publicationDetails.journalName: Northeastern University D'Amore-McKim School of Business Research Paper Series

detail.abstract: We study whether SEC comment letters help improve mutual fund disclosures. We find that funds respond to comment letters by providing more discussions about risk and uncertainty and adopting a more negative tone. Funds pay higher audit fees, potentially due to auditors’ involvement in the process. Comment letters are initially associated with negative abnormal fund flows that are reversed in the following quarter. After comment letters, fund flows respond less positively to fund performance and less negatively to expenses and risk disclosures, consistent with investors perceiving less agency frictions in fund reporting. Lastly, receiving comment letters reduces the likelihood of future SEC enforcement actions when they are initiated through administrative proceedings, and when comment letters address the same issue as a potential enforcement action. Overall, our findings suggest that SEC comment letters help improve mutual fund disclosures and influence investors’ perceptions of the quality of such disclosures.

title: Near Optimal Dynamic Pricing and Resource Relocation in a Large Closed Network
affiliations: University of Miami - Department of Management Science, University of Miami and University of Miami - Department of Management Science

detail.title: Near Optimal Dynamic Pricing and Resource Relocation in a Large Closed Network
detail.abstract: We study dynamic pricing and resource relocation in a closed service network with stochastic customer arrivals and travel times. Motivated by shared mobility and micromobility platforms, we consider a system with n + n 0 supply units distributed across multiple locations, where n represents the ideal fleet size under instantaneous relocation and n 0 provides safety staffing to buffer against supply unavailability caused by relocation delays. We propose a state-dependent policy that integrates real-time pricing with adaptive relocation and prove that it achieves a per-edge revenue loss of O(n^-2/3 |G| log n), where G denotes the set of customer trip edges in the network, relative to a fluid model benchmark. Our analysis reveals that this optimality gap is attainable with the additional safety staffing n 0 , whose magnitude depends on the network topology and relocation speeds. This quantifies the operational cost of travel-time stochasticity and demonstrates that pricing alone cannot ensure efficiency in large-scale stochastic networks. Our framework offers a tractable and provably effective approach for demand-supply coordination in modern service networks.
