detail.abstract: The U.S. business environment is currently characterized by unprecedented levels of uncertainty, driven by a confluence of geopolitical shifts, volatile economic conditions, and the transformative potential of artificial intelligence. Small to Medium-sized Businesses (SMBs), while facing unique challenges due to their resource constraints, also possess distinct advantages that enable them to thrive during turbulent times. This white paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the key factors impacting SMBs, including trade policies, economic pressures, and AI adoption. More importantly, it demonstrates how SMBs' inherent agility and flexibility position them to potentially outperform larger enterprises during periods of uncertainty. By embracing their natural advantages and implementing targeted strategies, SMBs can transform challenges into competitive opportunities.

title: The Influence of Leader Agreeableness on Business Model Innovation of Technology Start-Ups——A Moderated Mediation Effect Model
affiliations: Yanshan University

detail.title: The Influence of Leader Agreeableness on Business Model Innovation of Technology Start-Ups——A Moderated Mediation Effect Model
detail.abstract: Purpose-This study aims to investigate the direct effects of leader agreeableness on business model innovation of technology start-ups and the mediating role of strategic schema change as well as the moderating role of digital economy environment turbulences.Design/methodology/approach-This study take the Chinese science and technology enterprises as the research object. A total of 545 valid questionnaires from CEO and senior managers was applied to examine the hypotheses.Findings- The results show that leader agreeableness affects business model innovation through the strategic schema change, too high or too low affinity is not conducive to technology star-ups’ business model innovation. Both technological turbulence and market turbulence, negatively moderated the promoting effect of strategic schema change on business model innovation. Moreover, the mediating role of strategic schema change is significantly different under different circumstances of environmental turbulence.Originality/value- The research conclusions further deepen the application of personality psychology in the field of innovation management, providing essential practical reference and fostering new perspectives for the technology star-ups’ business model innovation.

title: Toxic Ties: The Effect of Political Disconnectedness on Corporate Divestments Following Political Shocks
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, Bentley University, affiliation not provided to SSRN and UNIVALI - Universidade do Vale do Itajai

detail.title: Toxic Ties: The Effect of Political Disconnectedness on Corporate Divestments Following Political Shocks
detail.abstract: Nurturing corporate political ties is often seen as a valuable strategy in emerging markets. However, research has shown that their value is contingent upon the stability of the political environment. Drawing on resource dependence and political embeddedness theories, we expand this literature by developing and testing a theory that explains how corporate political ties that turn toxic after a political shock influence corporate divestment decision. We examine the 2006 presidential impeachment in Brazil as an exogenous shock that suddenly reversed the policies benefiting politically connected firms, linking previous political ties to corruption and undue influence. Our robust evidence indicates that companies with politically connected directors experienced economic downturns during the transitional government, leading to significantly increased divestment activity. We also find support for the resource dependence mechanism. Our theory is robust to a series of tests and potential confounding events, contributing to the literature at the intersection of market and nonmarket strategies.

title: Runoff Simulation and Prediction in Cold Region Basins Based on the Modified of Swat Model
affiliations: Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS) - Northwest Institute of Eco-Environment and Resources, Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS) - Northwest Institute of Eco-Environment and Resources, Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS) - Northwest Institute of Eco-Environment and Resources, Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS) - Northwest Institute of Eco-Environment and Resources and Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS) - Northwest Institute of Eco-Environment and Resources

detail.title: Runoff Simulation and Prediction in Cold Region Basins Based on the Modified of Swat Model
detail.abstract: As a key component of the hydrological cycle and an important indicator in water resource assessment, clarifying the changes in runoff is crucial for water resource management in cold regions. This study takes the runoff volume from 1960 to 2022 as the research period and simulation target, dividing it into two periods: 1963-1990 and 1991-2022. Subsequently, the contribution sources of watershed runoff for these two stages were calculated based on the random forest model, and the water source conservation capacity of the watershed was calculated and evaluated based on the optimal model parameters. The results show: 1) In both stages, the R2 of runoff simulation reached above 0.70, and the values of NSE and KGE were above 0.65, indicating good simulation effects in both the calibration and validation periods. On a monthly scale, the runoff volume during the flood season was higher than that in the non-flood season, with the maximum measured runoff values in July for 1963-1990 and in August for 1991-2022; 2) Surface runoff, baseflow, and subsurface flow contribute 34.15%, 42.07%, and 23.78% of the total runoff volume on an annual scale, respectively. Surface runoff and baseflow are the main sources of runoff replenishment during the ablation period and non-ablation period, respectively; 3) The annual average water source conservation capacity of the watershed is 66.256 mm, the average water source conservation rate is 15.846%; 4) Under four climate scenarios, both precipitation and runoff are increasing, with the largest increase in runoff under the SSP5-8.5 climate scenario. The future runoff simulation in this study can estimate the impact of climate change on water resources and help formulate adaptation and mitigation measures.

title: Reframing the Afcfta's Theoretical Underpinnings under the Neoclassical Trade Theory Lens
affiliations: Desiderio Consultants Ltd.

detail.title: Reframing the Afcfta's Theoretical Underpinnings under the Neoclassical Trade Theory Lens
detail.abstract: The African Continental Free Trade Area (AfCFTA) represents a monumental effort towards advancing economic integration in Africa. This paper critically examines the primary economic theories underpinning the AfCFTA's projected benefits, focusing on neoclassical trade theory concepts such as comparative advantage, economies of scale, and dynamic gains from trade. It elucidates how these theories are expected to foster efficient resource allocation, enhance productivity, and stimulate economic development across the continent. Furthermore, it addresses the nuanced discussion of whether the AfCFTA exhibits characteristics of mercantilism, arguing that its foundational principles are antithetical to mercantilist tenets, despite some superficial overlaps related to developmental regionalism and import substitution and industrialization strategies. In conclusion, the AfCFTA is primarily conceptualized as a trade liberalization instrument designed to foster a positive-sum game through enhanced market integration and accelerated industrialization. A robust understanding of the Agreement's underlying economic logic is crucial for policymakers and Development Partners in designing more effective implementation strategies and proactively addressing potential challenges. It is important to acknowledge, however, that a key limitation of this analysis, and indeed the AfCFTA itself, which stems from the complexity of implementing such a vast and transformative agreement, coupled with the inherently long-term nature of its projected economic transformations.

title: Data-Driven Water Resources Modeling: A Case Study of the Jucar Hydrographic Confederation
affiliations: Universidad de Alicante, CETaqua and Universidad de Alicante

detail.title: Data-Driven Water Resources Modeling: A Case Study of the Jucar Hydrographic Confederation
detail.abstract: A monthly explanatory hydrological model was developed and applied to the Jucar Hydrographic Confederation (JHC). The JHC is characterized by high spatial heterogeneity, strong regulation, and multiple water uses. The model uses a database of over 20,000 monthly records (1988–2023). These records include meteorological data, water demand from various sectors, and hydrological observations from 94 control points.The model is based on machine learning techniques, employing non-linear regression algorithms trained according to resources. A regular 40×40 km spatial grid is incorporated to make sure coherence and traceability assign input variables. The model innovatively uses a first-order autoregressive model (AR(1)) to represent hydrological memory. The current month's resource state depends on the previous month's (Value_t–1). This variable enhances the model’s explanatory power. Results show high predictive performance: R² = 0.991 for reservoirs, R² = 1.000 for aquifers, and R² = 0.775 for rivers (after outlier filtering).This approach enables the analysis of the system’s observed behaviour without requiring physical calibration or future projections, offering a robust, scalable, and replicable tool. It supports operational water planning and also scenario analysis in contexts of climate uncertainty or increasing pressure on water resources.

title: Enhancing Multi-Step Water Level Forecasting in Urban Drainage Systems Using an Autoregressive Seq2seq Learning Combined with Cnn and Gru
affiliations: Hohai University, Hohai University, Zhejiang University, Zhejiang University and Hong Kong Polytechnic University

detail.title: Enhancing Multi-Step Water Level Forecasting in Urban Drainage Systems Using an Autoregressive Seq2seq Learning Combined with Cnn and Gru
detail.abstract: Accurate multi-step water level forecasting in urban drainage systems (UDSs) is essential for flood early warning and adaptive drainage management. However, conventional recurrent neural network-based models, such as gated recurrent units (GRUs), often suffer from substantial performance degradation over extended forecasting horizons due to recursive error accumulation and limited spatial awareness. This study proposes an enhanced deep learning framework that systematically improves GRU-based forecasting through three progressive strategies: (1) autoregressive sequence-to-sequence learning to mitigate error accumulation (GRU-AR), (2) multi-point synchronous prediction to capture spatial dependencies (GRU-AR-M), and (3) hybrid integration of one-dimensional convolutional neural networks with GRU for spatiotemporal feature extraction (CNN-GRU-AR). The framework was evaluated on a campus-scale drainage system and validated with field data from a Swiss combined sewer network. Results consistently demonstrate the effectiveness of all three enhancements. In the numerical case, CNN-GRU-AR increased the average Nash efficiency coefficient (NSE) from 0.74 to 0.94 and reduced the mean absolute error (MAE) by 59.1% compared to the standard GRU over a 60-minute forecasting horizon. In real-world validation, the model improved average NSE from 0.81 to 0.91 and reduced MAE by 21.5% over a 90-minute horizon. Notably, in the two cases, NSE at the 60- and 90-minute lead times improved from 0.48 to 0.89 and 0.45 to 0.81, respectively, confirming significantly enhanced long-term performance. The model also maintained high robustness under complex rainfall events, spatially distributed conditions, and noisy rainfall forecasts. These findings confirm the potential of CNN-GRU-AR for real-time, accurate, and scalable water level forecasting in operational UDSs.

title: Development and Scale-Up of Pulsed Electric Field for Seafood Processing in Small and Medium Industries

detail.title: Development and Scale-Up of Pulsed Electric Field for Seafood Processing in Small and Medium Industries

keywords.keywords: Pulsed Electric Field (PEF)SeafoodSmall and medium industries (SMI)Inactivation microbeSupervisory Control and Data Acquisition (SCADA)

detail.abstract: Pulsed Electric Field (PEF) technology is an effective non-thermal method for microbial inactivation in fishery products. This study integrates the development of a PEF system from laboratory scale to small and medium industrial (SMI) scale, with a 2-ampere current configuration, conveyor system, and Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition (SCADA) control. The system can process up to 20 kg per cycle in a total of 4 minutes 45 seconds. The best PEF performance test of 10.5 kV/cm on seafood products had bacterial reduction results on tuna at 94.59%, shrimp at 44.16%, and squid at 80.47%. The PEF performance test was continued on media containing bacterial cells directly to obtain a reduction of 35.17%. Protein reduction remained low at moderate intensity (<1%) in each seafood, but it increased significantly at the high intensity. Evaluation based on ISO 9241-11 and Nielsen heuristics showed effectiveness, efficiency, and user satisfaction scores >4.1 with low error rates. LCA analysis showed that the PEF device was significantly better than the conventional system for water use in seafood processing. The research findings confirm that a SCADA-based PEF conveyor system is an efficient, safe, and user-friendly solution for decentralized seafood processing, especially in developing countries.

title: Multi-Objective Travel Choice Optimization for Multimodal Public Transport: A Multi-Objective Deep Reinforcement Learning Algorithm
affiliations: Lanzhou Jiaotong University, Lanzhou Jiaotong University and Lanzhou Jiaotong University

detail.title: Multi-Objective Travel Choice Optimization for Multimodal Public Transport: A Multi-Objective Deep Reinforcement Learning Algorithm
detail.abstract: To explore the feasibility and effectiveness of applying deep reinforcement learning to solve travel choice problems in multimodal public transport systems, this paper proposes a multi-objective optimization model that simultaneously aims to minimize travel time and maximize travel time reliability. To accurately capture the complex routing and transfer behaviors involved in multimodal travel, a node-splitting method is adopted to extend the representation of the multimodal transport network. To solve this multi-objective problem, a multi-objective deep reinforcement learning algorithm based on deep Q-networks is developed. In terms of feasibility, we evaluate the quality of the learned Pareto-optimal solutions using the hypervolume indicator. Results from Experiment 1 demonstrate that the proposed multi-objective deep reinforcement learning framework can effectively solve the multi-objective optimization problem. In terms of effectiveness, we benchmark the proposed algorithm against the industry-standard Non-dominated Sorting Genetic Algorithm Ⅱ (NSGA-Ⅱ). Experiment 2 shows that the proposed multi-objective deep reinforcement learning algorithm achieves comparable Pareto front quality with significantly higher computational efficiency. These findings indicate that, beyond delivering accurate solutions, the proposed approach can substantially improve computational speed, offering a novel and efficient methodology for addressing travel choice problems in complex multimodal public transportation systems.

title: Reducing Queuing Delay in Multi-Cqf Deterministic Networks Via Effective Phase Alignment
affiliations: Southern University of Science and Technology, Peng Cheng Laboratory, Anhui University of Technology, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, Southern University of Science and Technology, affiliation not provided to SSRN and Peng Cheng Laboratory

detail.title: Reducing Queuing Delay in Multi-Cqf Deterministic Networks Via Effective Phase Alignment
detail.abstract: Cyclic Queuing and Forwarding (CQF), a core mechanism of Time-Sensitive Networking (TSN), provides deterministic latency without complex gating calculations. However, scaling CQF to larger deterministic networks introduces challenges such as increased link delays and synchronization inaccuracies, which reduce the effective time interval in each CQF time slot and lower usable bandwidth. To address this, Multi-CQF was introduced, utilizing three or more queues to absorb the effects of link delays and decouple transmission from reception timing, enhancing bandwidth utilization. However, this improvement incurs a trade-off: the queuing delay upper bound increases from T (one time slot) in traditional CQF to 2T in Multi-CQF (3-queue). This extended queuing delay subsequently elevates end-to-end delay, which can compromise the network’s ability to meet strict real-time requirements and degrade service quality.In this paper, we propose the Effective Phase Alignment (EPA) mechanism to reduce queuing delay in Multi-CQF by aligning the effective phase (phase difference between the sending and receiving windows). By optimizing this phase alignment, the upper bound of the average queuing delay of all flows can be reduced from 2T to 1.5T. In cases of perfect alignment, the queuing delay can be minimized to match the performance of traditional CQF. This approach significantly reduces queuing delay, making Multi-CQF better able to meet the stringent requirements of modern deterministic communication networks.

title: Apologies by Gender Motivation: Facing Shame or Avoiding it
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Apologies by Gender Motivation: Facing Shame or Avoiding it
detail.abstract: This study examined the role of shame acceptance and shame avoidance in the relationship between gender motivation and apologizing behaviors. To investigate this role, the study measured gender motivation, shame management, and apology motivation among 309 employees in a private company. The results revealed that shame acknowledgment mediates the relationship between gender motivations and apology motivation. The results also suggest that even when individuals who adhere to pressured feminine norms engage in shame avoidance behavior, their tendency to apologize increases due to motivations such as relationship value and fear of sanction. These findings highlight that shame avoidance does not always lead to reluctance to apologize and underline the importance of gender motivation in shaping apology behavior. Managers can facilitate positive changes in employees' shame and apology strategies by fostering an organizational climate that promotes gender equality and a culture in which employees have equal access to rewards, resources, and opportunities.

title: Third Places and Housing Market Dynamics in Urban and Rural Neighborhoods
affiliations: University of Vermont - College of Agriculture and Life Sciences - Department of Community Development and Applied Economics and University of Vermont

detail.title: Third Places and Housing Market Dynamics in Urban and Rural Neighborhoods
detail.abstract: This study examines how third places—informal gathering spots like coffee shops and bars—influence neighborhood housing values as a measure of local quality of life. Using two-way fixed effects regression on business data from five Great Lakes states, we find a significant positive association between third-place establishments and housing prices. The effect is strongest for eating and drinking venues, particularly in metropolitan areas where such amenities are highly capitalized into housing values. In nonmetropolitan areas, impacts are weaker and often statistically insignificant. These findings demonstrate how geography and social context shape third places' influence on housing markets, offering implications for development.

title: Leadership and Worker Well-Being – Cross-Sectional Study in Companies and Institutions
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, Universidade de Aveiro, affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Leadership and Worker Well-Being – Cross-Sectional Study in Companies and Institutions
detail.abstract: Well-being is a growing concern in the global health debate, with leadership recognized as a key element that can enhance well-being or contribute to stress. This study aimed to assess the relationship between leadership competencies and supervision satisfaction, their impact on workers’ well-being and stress, and the differences across business activity areas. A cross-sectional observational study was conducted with 444 workers from Portuguese companies and institutions, contacted through convenience sampling. Data were collected from November 2023 to March 2025 through a questionnaire comprising validated scales: SFSSQ (Supervision Satisfaction), PSS-10 (Perceived Stress), JAWS (Job Well-being), and QCL (Leadership Competencies). Leadership competencies and satisfaction with supervision were significantly correlated with well-being (ρ = 0.514, p < 0.001 and ρ = 0.577, p < 0.001) and stress (ρ = -0.336, p < 0.001 and ρ = -0.336, p < 0.001). The Coordinator role was most strongly associated with well-being, while the Facilitator role was associated with lower stress. Statistically significant differences were identified across professional areas for all variables, except stress. The results suggest that all leadership competencies are valued, with a preference for organization, participation, innovation, and clear structure. Differences between areas highlight the need to study the more vulnerable areas, such as healthcare, and underscore the importance of aligning leadership styles with organizational culture. This study reinforces the importance of leadership in promoting well-being and reducing stress in the workplace, highlighting the need to invest in leadership training that aligns competencies with team needs and the specific contexts of each organization.

title: Multi-Objective Optimization for Mep Module Bin Packing Considering Transportation Stability and Assembly Sequence
affiliations: Beijing University of Technology and Beijing University of Technology

detail.title: Multi-Objective Optimization for Mep Module Bin Packing Considering Transportation Stability and Assembly Sequence
detail.abstract: Transportation of prefabricated Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing (MEP) modules critically links off-site fabrication and on-site assembly, influencing project quality and schedules. These modules exhibit complex characteristics, including irregular geometry, heterogeneous composition, off-center mass distributions, and sensitive internal precision instruments, rendering them vulnerable to improper handling. Existing loading strategies often disregard safety requirements and fail to accommodate stringent assembly sequence constraints. To address these issues, this study presents a multi-objective optimization method for MEP module transportation and loading. An accurate centroid calculation model is developed for irregular, heterogeneous modules with asymmetrical mass distributions. A mathematical model minimizes reshuffling effort and normalized centroid deviation, subject to comprehensive geometric and physical constraints. A dual-encoding strategy integrates loading sequence and orientation, supported by a novel 3D Bin Packing Algorithm incorporating Center-Line Priority Loading and Non-Geometric Centroid Alignment (3DBP-CLP-NGCAM). This algorithm is embedded in an enhanced Non-dominated Sorting Genetic Algorithm II (NSGA-II). Experimental results indicate stable convergence within 200 generations, producing Pareto-optimal loading schemes. Relative to the initial results, f1 and f2 demonstrated overall decreases of 54.5% and 11.9%, respectively. Compared to traditional methods, the approach reduces reshuffling by 6.4% and centroid deviation by 30.4%. Detailed schemes for seven vehicles satisfy all constraints, validating non-geometric centroid modeling and center-line strategy. The findings provide theoretical foundations and practical guidance for optimizing prefabricated MEP module transportation.

title: From Wealth to Welfare: Systemic Complementarities for the Age of AI
affiliations: Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) - Sloan School of Management and Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) - Sloan School of Management

detail.title: From Wealth to Welfare: Systemic Complementarities for the Age of AI
detail.abstract: Over the past century, general-purpose technologies (GPTs), such as electricity, the combustion engine, and the Internet, have played a central role in driving global welfare. They helped extend life expectancy and civil and labor rights and reduce infant mortality and poverty. However, these transformations did not happen based on the GPT's technical capabilities alone. We unlocked their potential by introducing necessary system-level complements into our social and economic systems. Today, artificial intelligence (AI) is the rising GPT on the horizon, promising to reshape how we live and work. However, like its predecessors, AI's welfare-generating power is not promised without intention. If we want AI to enhance welfare rather than merely generate wealth, we must invest in the appropriate system-level complements to catalyze a shift toward our collective goals. This article is dedicated to identifying these complements and suggesting where complex systems science offers unique insights for their development. In the remainder of this article, we define GPTs as disruptive innovations that improve over time, spur advancements across multiple sectors, and fundamentally reshape industries, markets, and organizational practices. We further define system-level complements as the social institutions, cultural norms, capital investments, and human and scientific resources required to realize the welfare benefits of a GPT.

title: Understanding Dynamic Competition: New Perspectives on Potential Competition, “Monopoly,” and Market Power
affiliations: University of California, Berkeley - Business & Public Policy Group

detail.title: Understanding Dynamic Competition: New Perspectives on Potential Competition, “Monopoly,” and Market Power
detail.abstract: This article is an effort to further advance what has come to be known as the dynamic competition paradigm, which prioritizes innovation over efficiency and favors the dynamic over the static and the future over the present. Moreover, it recognizes that, with digitization (what some call the fourth industrial revolution), the nature of innovation itself has changed, and along with it the nature of competition. To better understand the evolving nature of competition, enforcement agencies, courts, and legislatures must develop and apply new economic models of innovation and competition. As Richard Posner observed, "Antitrust doctrine has changed more or less in tandem with changes in economic theory, albeit with a lag." The purpose of this article is to outline a dynamic competition economic theory/paradigm that I have been endeavoring to launch for 30 years; I call it dynamic competition. As will become evident, there is not yet universal agreement on what this framework entails and how to apply it. I will elaborate on a framework that I claim is a coherent framework, one that is not selectively appealed to when it suits the enforcement agencies or analysts wishing to find a new way to support old shibboleths.

title: Osad-Sam: Customizing Segment Anything Model with Multi-Modal Prompts for One-Shot Anomaly Detection
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Osad-Sam: Customizing Segment Anything Model with Multi-Modal Prompts for One-Shot Anomaly Detection
detail.abstract: One-shot anomaly detection is essential in industrial scenarios where labeled data is scarce, and anomalies are diverse. While traditional methods require extensive training and parameter tuning, foundational models like the Segment Anything Model (SAM) offer a low-resource training alternative. In this paper, we propose One-Shot Anomaly Detection with Segment Anything Model (OSAD-SAM), a novel multimodal prompts framework that leverages the contextual flexibility of text prompts alongside the precision of image prompts to enhance anomaly classification and segmentation. OSAD-SAM first performs anomaly segmentation in parallel using text prompts (i.e., expert knowledge) and image prompts (i.e., prior knowledge), and then further enhances anomaly detection by fusing the anomaly segmentation results from these two modalities (i.e., text and image). In the text prompts module, it refers to the cascade of patch-level anomaly region localization and pixel level anomaly region refinement. In the image prompts module, it refers to the cascade of target-specific prompts extraction and anomaly refinement. To alleviate the ambiguity of multi-scale anomaly masks, we employed a fine-tuning approach that requires training only two weight parameters (i.e., lightweight training). The training process only takes a few seconds, yet it improves anomaly detection performance. Extensive experiments on the MVTec and VisA datasets demonstrate that OSAD-SAM achieves state-of-the-art results, significantly outperforming existing methods in both anomaly classification and segmentation tasks.
