detail.abstract: This study examines the factors influencing minority entrepreneurs' engagement with marketing consulting services (MCS), using an integrated framework of the Resource-Based View and Social Cognitive Theory. Three empirical studies were conducted. The first evaluated how access to support ecosystems and financial assistance affects MCS engagement. The second assessed the role of perceived compatibility between entrepreneur values and service provider culture on intention to use MCS. The third examined how entrepreneurial self-efficacy moderates, and trust mediates, this compatibility-intention relationship. Results show that support access significantly improves engagement, perceived compatibility strongly predicts intention, and self-efficacy and trust further shape these effects. These findings offer actionable insights for MCS providers, nonprofit support organizations, and policymakers seeking to promote inclusive entrepreneurship and enhance service adoption among minority-owned businesses.

title: Hit the GAS: Designing Optimal Generalized Ad-supported Subscription Mechanisms
affiliations: Erasmus University Rotterdam, Rotterdam School of Management, Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University and Erasmus University Rotterdam (EUR)

detail.title: Hit the GAS: Designing Optimal Generalized Ad-supported Subscription Mechanisms
detail.abstract: Digital Content Platforms (DCPs), such as Netflix and Spotify, rely on subscriptions and advertising as their primary revenue sources. Traditional revenue models, such as subscription-only and ad-only options, either limit user accessibility or compromise user experience. In response, DCPs have started to combine these two models by offering a two-tier menu: a free ad-supported tier for price-sensitive users and a paid ad-free tier for ad-sensitive users. In this paper, we introduce the Generalized Ad-Supported Subscription (GAS) mechanism-a broad class consisting of subscription-fee and ad-intensity combinations that spans the entire spectrum from fully ad-supported to fully subscription-based access. Using the principles of mechanism design, we characterize a revenue-maximizing GAS mechanism and contrast it with ad-only, subscription-only, and the two-tier menu. Further, we estimate our model parameters and empirically validate our theoretical results in the context of Video-on-Demand platforms. Our analysis shows that the optimal GAS mechanism yields a substantially higher revenue than the ad-only and subscription-only mechanisms. More importantly, this additional revenue improvement does not come at the expense of consumer surplus-this shows that the GAS mechanism improves the overall economic pie by better matching user preferences.

title: Who Becomes a Father? The Rising Importance of Parenting Skills
affiliations: Linnaeus University - Centre for Labour Market and Discrimination Studies and Stockholm University - Swedish Institute for Social Research (SOFI)

detail.title: Who Becomes a Father? The Rising Importance of Parenting Skills
detail.abstract: The conditions under which men become fathers have shifted markedly in recent decades. As women's earnings have risen and paternal leave policies have expanded, expectations for men's involvement in child-rearing have grown. We argue that these changes have increased the importance of parenting skills in men's selection into fatherhood. Using rich Swedish administrative data and a sibling fixed effects design, we find that non-cognitive ability-a key dimension of parenting skills-has become an increasingly strong predictor of fatherhood over time, even after controlling for marriage, earnings, and partner characteristics. We further exploit a 2002 reform that expanded reserved paternity leave to show that increased expectations for paternal involvement amplify selection on non-cognitive ability. These findings suggest that societal shifts have reshaped who becomes a father-specifically, in ways that increasingly reward men's parenting skills.

title: Revealing Preferences through AI Adoption: The Effect of Risk Attitudes On Prompting Effort
affiliations: East Texas A&M University and East Texas A&M University

detail.title: Revealing Preferences through AI Adoption: The Effect of Risk Attitudes On Prompting Effort
detail.abstract: This paper analyzes "prompt engineering" through the economic lens of self-insurance against the risk of errors from noisy AI systems. To formalize this approach, we model an agent under cognitive load allocating effort between working unassisted and prompting an AI assistant. The theoretical model demonstrates that an agent's optimal prompting effort is driven by their attitude towards risk. Specifically, the model proves that risk-averse agents rationally "over-invest" in prompting effort, while risk-loving agents "under-invest." This outcome stems from the covariance between the marginal utility of performance and the marginal product of prompting. This alignment is positive for risk-averse agents, effectively boosting the AI's perceived productivity. The novel implication is that prompting effort is a rich economic behavior that can be used to reveal an individual's underlying risk preferences. These findings offer a new focus for understanding heterogeneity in AI adoption and provide a novel basis for the empirical measurement of risk attitudes.

title: Impact of Excess Body Mass on Employment Prospects in Australia
affiliations: Macquarie University, Macquarie University and Macquarie University, Macquarie Business School

detail.title: Impact of Excess Body Mass on Employment Prospects in Australia
detail.abstract: This paper investigates whether overweight and/or obese individuals experience diminished employment prospects in the labour market in Australia. Exploiting the 2006 to 2019 panel dynamics of the Household, Income and Labour Dynamics in Australia survey data, we implement empirical strategies that account for the historical role of previous-period employment and previous-period body mass on current employment. We uncover less than compelling evidence that individuals carrying excess body mass (as measured by body mass index, BMI) are less likely to be employed in Australia. Results from the dynamic correlated random effects probit, which imposes an auxiliary distributional assumption on unobserved time-constant heterogeneity, disclose negative associations between BMI (as a categorical or continuous variable) and employment. When the auxiliary assumption is relaxed through the generalised methods of moment (GMM) procedure, none of the body mass coefficients attain statistical significance. Conducting a granular analysis by gender groups, no association between excess body mass and employment is evident, regardless of the empirical strategy that is adopted. Investigating the channels of effect, while the results reveal a role for health-related productivity difference as a source of excess body mass-related employment penalty for women, the finding does not hold when the GMM procedure is implemented. Overall, we fail to garner fully convincing evidence that excess body mass reduces individuals’ employment prospects in Australia, though the converse cannot be ruled out.

title: Optimal Pricing with Dynamic In-Consumption Social Interactions
affiliations: New York University Shanghai, China Europe International Business School (CEIBS) and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Optimal Pricing with Dynamic In-Consumption Social Interactions
detail.abstract: In many contexts of digital consumption, social interaction becomes a vital component that affects consumers' overall experience and willingness to pay for digital products or services. In these settings, the value of digital consumption depends not only on the intrinsic quality of the product but also on social influences among consumers, presenting new challenges for firms: reduced direct control over product value and increased uncertainty in real-time user experience. Therefore, it is essential for firms to understand how social interaction reshapes market demand and how to strategically manage this dynamic to improve profitability. To address these questions, we develop a continuous-time model in which a consumer's willingness to pay for the product is dynamically determined by both their idiosyncratic value and social interactions with other consumers. Our findings show that social interactions rotate demand distribution and create an additional option value of participation. Moreover, upward and downward social influences have an asymmetric impact on the option value of and the firm's profit. We characterize how the firm adjusts participation threshold and access pricing depending on how the option value varies with marginal consumer types. We compare equilibrium demand and profit to the benchmark scenario without social interactions.

title: When Polanyi Met Competition Policy: Market Fundamentalism, Crisis, and Reform in the 21st Century
affiliations: University of Sao Paulo - Faculdade de Direito and University of São Paulo (USP)

detail.title: When Polanyi Met Competition Policy: Market Fundamentalism, Crisis, and Reform in the 21st Century
detail.abstract: Karl Polanyi and his analytical framework in economic sociology remain overlooked by competition policy scholarship. Notably, the concept of "embeddedness", central to Polanyi's contribution, oqers a valuable perspective to trace the development of this regulatory mechanism over time. The social and political concerns of an emerging industrial society marked the birth of competition policy as a device for embedding the early 20 th-century market economy. However, in the following decades, new market fundamentalist narratives disembedded markets, with competition policy contributing to this process by deviating from its non-market origins. Today, this governance tool faces the challenges of 21 stcentury civilization, with the celebrated consensus on its principles long lost. New social and political concerns arising from market power demand the re-embedment of markets through competition. This article explores this Polanyian dynamic of embeddedness-disembeddedness-re-embeddedness by reframing the history of competition policy in diqerent institutional realities-the United States, the EU, and Brazil. It also discusses how diverse institutional conditions shaped alternative responses towards market fundamentalism throughout the past century. The revival of Polanyi's ideas not only helps us understand how we arrived here but also provides important insights into the inevitable role that "nonmarket" dimensions play in the reform agenda currently surrounding competition policy.

title: New Pricing, New Rules: The Market Impact of the 2024 NAR Settlement
affiliations: Virginia Commonwealth University and University of Memphis

detail.title: New Pricing, New Rules: The Market Impact of the 2024 NAR Settlement
detail.abstract: On March 15, 2024, the National Association of Realtors® settled a case filed in Missouri that charged agents and brokers colluded to set commissions. The case was focused on the plaintiffs' argument that the market lacked competition in commission setting, and furthered the perception that residential Realtors® have not made a convincing case for service differentiation or contribution to the transaction. The new rules took effect August 17, 2024. The biggest change is that listings may no longer make offers of compensation to a buyer agent on any NAR-affiliated multiple listing service (MLS). Furthermore, a buyer's agent must now have a written contract with a home shopper, clearly specifying their fee, before they may show that client a house. This study employs regression analyses on a national dataset of home sales transactions to evaluate the policy's effect on real estate transaction valuation and probability of transaction failure. Shifting the commission responsibility to buyers could lead to notable changes in transaction values as buyers adjust their budgets to cover the added expense of agent fees. Furthermore, because buyer agent commissions are no longer bundled into the home's purchase price and cannot, currently, be financed through the mortgage, buyers may face increased out-of-pocket expenses at closing, which could raise the likelihood of transaction failure.

title: Decomposing the Systematic and Idiosyncratic Components of the Diffusive and Tail Risks in Individual Equity Options
affiliations: Old Dominion University, Louisiana State University, Baton Rouge - Department of Finance and Financial Risk Management  LLC

detail.title: Decomposing the Systematic and Idiosyncratic Components of the Diffusive and Tail Risks in Individual Equity Options

declarations.funderStatement: Canadian Derivatives Institute (CDI)

detail.abstract: Implied volatility surfaces of individual equity options exhibit persistent volatility, pronounced skew, and upward-sloping term structures. These features correlate with market index patterns, but also reflect stock-specific sources of return variation. We develop an affine jump-diffusion model that decomposes returns into systematic and idiosyncratic diffusive and jump components, incorporating leverage effects, asymmetric jumps, and a time-varying jump intensity. Estimated on 50 large-cap U.S. stocks from 2006-2021, the model closely matches the dynamics of implied volatility and yields substantially lower pricing errors than nested alternatives. It offers novel insights into the risk-neutral dynamics of equity return variation.

title: Does Continuing Education Deter Misconduct? Evidence from Investment Advisers
affiliations: Hong Kong University of Science & Technology (HKUST) - Department of Accounting and University of Georgia - J.M. Tull School of Accounting

detail.title: Does Continuing Education Deter Misconduct? Evidence from Investment Advisers
detail.abstract: This study examines whether continuing education (CE) requirements deter investment adviser misconduct. Regulators often impose CE requirements to ensure professional service quality and protect clients from bad actors. Although CE requirements are widely used, causing firms to spend billions of dollars on CE each year, little is known about the effectiveness of CE. We exploit the staggered implementation of CE requirements by the North American Securities Administrators Association (NASAA) to examine the impact of CE. While we do not find evidence that CE requirements impact average investment advisers, we find that CE requirements significantly reduce misconduct among high-risk advisers. This reduction in misconduct is concentrated in rules-based misconduct. We also find that CE requirements remain effective within firm environments prone to misconduct. These findings suggest that CE can serve as an effective regulatory tool to discipline bad actors in financial markets and should interest regulators who are concerned with maintaining professional competency through continuing education requirements.

detail.abstract: This article examines the global homeland security satellite imagery market, an integral and rapidly expanding application segment within the broader commercial satellite imaging and data services industries. While not a standalone market, its critical role in national security and disaster response drives robust growth. The commercial satellite imaging and data services markets are projected to see significant expansion by 2030-2034, with Compound Annual Growth Rates (CAGRs) ranging from approximately 7% to over 18%. North America leads the market due to strong government investment, while Asia-Pacific is set for the fastest growth. Key drivers include escalating geopolitical tensions and advancements in satellite technology (AI, ML, SAR). However, the market faces challenges from high initial costs, complex regulations, and potential government spending cuts. The competitive landscape features major players like Maxar, Planet, and BlackSky, who are deeply integrated with government contracts. Strategic recommendations focus on stable government funding, enhanced public-private integration, and commercial diversification to harness this evolving sector's full potential for national security.

title: Entrepreneurial Human Capital and Firm Informality
affiliations: Universidad de Alicante, Universidad de Alicante and Universidad de Alicante

detail.title: Entrepreneurial Human Capital and Firm Informality

declarations.declarationOfInterest: We do not have conflicts of interests

detail.abstract: This paper assesses the role of entrepreneurial human capital in shaping firm informality in developing economies. We build a life-cycle general equilibrium model in which individuals choose their education level and occupational path under limited tax enforcement and financial frictions. Entrepreneurs differ in managerial ability, which is endogenously enhanced by college education. Calibrated to Brazil, the model predicts that increasing college attainment significantly reduces informality, primarily by reallocating entrepreneurial talent toward larger, more productive, and formal firms. These firm-level adjustments translate into higher GDP per capita and aggregate productivity, with the magnitude of these effects depending on the severity of credit market imperfections. Overall, our results highlight a novel mechanism linking human capital accumulation to formalization and suggest that relaxing both credit and education constraints is essential for development. We validate the model's predictions using microdata, exploiting Brazil's 1996 education reform to provide empirical support.

title: Assessing Novice Programmers' Perception of ChatGPT: Performance, Risk, Decision-Making, And Intentions
affiliations: Don Honorio Ventura State University and Don Honorio Ventura State University

detail.title: Assessing Novice Programmers' Perception of ChatGPT: Performance, Risk, Decision-Making, And Intentions

declarations.declarationOfInterest: Authors state no conflict of interest.
declarations.ethicsApproval: The authors obtained informed consent from all individuals included in this study.
declarations.funderStatement: This study was supported by Don Honorio Ventura State University.

detail.abstract: This study explores the novice programmers' intention to use chat generative pretrained transformer (ChatGPT) for programming tasks with emphasis on performance expectancy (PE), risk-reward appraisal (RRA), and decision-making (DM). Utilizing partial least squares structural equation modeling (PLS-SEM) and a sample of 413 novice programmers, the analysis demonstrates that higher PE of ChatGPT is positively correlated with improved DM in programming tasks. Novice programmers view ChatGPT as a tool that enhances their learning and skill development. Additionally, novice programmers that have a favorable RRA of ChatGPT tend to make more confident and effective decisions, acknowledging potential risks but recognizing that benefits such as quick problem-solving and learning new techniques outweigh these risks. Moreover, a positive perception of ChatGPT's role in DM significantly increases the inclination to use the tool for programming tasks. These results highlight the critical roles of perceived capabilities, risk assessment, and positive DM experiences in promoting the adoption of artificial intelligence (AI) tools in programming education.

title: Culture and Social Organizations in the Great Reversal: Europe and China, 1000-2000
affiliations: Stanford University - Department of Economics, Northwestern University - Department of Economics and Bocconi University - Department of Economics

detail.title: Culture and Social Organizations in the Great Reversal: Europe and China, 1000-2000
detail.abstract: Why did the industrial revolution occur in Europe and not in China, despite China being well ahead of Europe in terms of economic and technological achievements several centuries earlier? We revisit this long-standing question from a new perspective. We emphasize the importance of the different social organizations that diffused in these two parts of the world in the centuries that preceded the industrial revolution: kin-based organizations in China, vs corporations in Europe. We explain their cultural origins, and discuss how these different organizations shaped the evolution of legal systems, political institutions and human capital accumulation in these two parts of the world. Our main argument is that European corporations played a crucial role in the scientific and technological innovations that ultimately led to the industrial revolution.

title: Linking Wealth and Punishment Effectiveness: Punishment and Cooperation under Congruent Heterogeneities
affiliations: Bard College - Bard College Berlin

detail.title: Linking Wealth and Punishment Effectiveness: Punishment and Cooperation under Congruent Heterogeneities
detail.abstract: Global and local cooperation in supplying global public goods is often insufficient. In this respect, laboratory experiments show that peer punishment is an effective cooperation-enhancing instrument. However, it is unclear whether peer punishment would facilitate cooperation and public good provision even under congruent heterogeneities in wealth and punishment effectiveness. To this end, we experimentally study the effect of peer punishment under joint heterogeneities, where either the richest or the poorest member is also the most effective punisher. We compare these joint heterogeneities to treatments with single heterogeneities in either endowment or punishment effectiveness and to a baseline symmetry treatment with homogeneous parties. We find that heterogeneity in punishment effectiveness does not matter for cooperation, whereas endowment heterogeneity reduces cooperation compared to symmetry. This is because rich members contribute a lower portion of their endowment to the public good than their poorer counterparts. We also observe that cooperation is higher under joint heterogeneities in endowment and punishment effectiveness than under endowment heterogeneity (with no differences than under symmetry). This holds even when the rich party gains less from cooperation and is the most effective punisher.

title: Interview SAVOV/CHAIEHLOUDJ : EU Competition Policy -Present Challenges and Future Directions
affiliations: TERESclaims

detail.title: Interview SAVOV/CHAIEHLOUDJ : EU Competition Policy -Present Challenges and Future Directions
detail.abstract: In this inaugural episode of the Uplawder Conversation Series, Professor Walid Chaiehloudj joins Vasil Savov for a critical and forward-looking discussion on the current state and future trajectory of EU competition policy. Drawing on recent developments, they explore key challenges related to private enforcement, the integration of sustainability objectives, the application of the Digital Markets Act (DMA), and the evolving frameworks for merger control and State aid. Through the lens of emblematic cases - Illumina/Grail, Towercast, and Heineken -the conversation sheds light on institutional shortcomings and emerging legal responses. Professor Chaiehloudj emphasizes the urgent need to rethink the enforcement model to more effectively balance innovation, legal certainty, and the Union’s broader economic and environmental ambitions.

title: Social Media as a Catalyst for Democratization and Good Governance in Nigeria
affiliations: Institute of Management and Technology (IMT), Enugu

detail.title: Social Media as a Catalyst for Democratization and Good Governance in Nigeria

declarations.declarationOfInterest: No personal and financial relationship
declarations.ethicsApproval: This research employed a qualitative design based on documentary analysis of secondary sources, including scholarly articles, media reports, policy documents, and official records. The study did not involve any direct interaction with human participants, nor did it collect any personal, sensitive, or identifiable data. All sources used in this work are publicly available and properly cited in accordance with academic standards. As such, the research does not pose any risk to individuals or organizations and does not require formal ethical approval from an institutional review board (IRB) or ethics committee.
declarations.funderStatement: Self

detail.abstract: In today's digital age, communication technologies have become central to shaping political dynamics across the globe. Social media, in particular, has emerged as a powerful tool for influencing democratic development and governance. This study critically examines the role of social media in Nigeria's democratization process and the promotion of good governance from the return to civilian rule in 1999 to the present. Focusing on platforms such as Twitter (now X), Facebook, WhatsApp, and YouTube, the research explores how these digital spaces have fostered political participation, civic engagement, and interaction between citizens and government institutions. The study aims to: assess the extent to which social media has facilitated democratization, advance good governance and identify the challenges associated with leveraging social media. Adopting a qualitative research design, the study utilizes documentary analysis of secondary sources, including scholarly articles, media reports, policy documents, and official records. The study employs SWOT and PESTEL frameworks to evaluate the internal and external factors shaping the use of social media in Nigeria's democratic landscape. Findings indicate that social media has played a significant role in enhancing democratic awareness, improving transparency, and empowering youth-led activism. Nevertheless, issues such as misinformation, online censorship, surveillance, and digital exclusion remain persistent obstacles. The study concludes that while social media does not replace conventional democratic institutions, it has become an essential complement to participatory governance. It recommends policy reforms, improved digital literacy, increased platform accountability, and inclusive stakeholder engagement to harness the full democratic potential of social media in Nigeria.

title: Scenario-Based Electricity Generation Capacity Planning for 2030: A Comparative Assessment of Parametric and Data-Driven Approaches for Türkiye
affiliations: Koç University and Koç University

detail.title: Scenario-Based Electricity Generation Capacity Planning for 2030: A Comparative Assessment of Parametric and Data-Driven Approaches for Türkiye
detail.abstract: This study examines the future of Türkiye's electricity generation system by creating and evaluating five strategic policy scenarios for 2030. Each scenario reflects different national priorities, such as achieving carbon neutrality, expanding renewable energy, and attaining domestic energy independence. A dual-methodological framework is employed, using a parametric capacity expansion model built on amortizationadjusted projections and policy-weighted investment distributions, as well as a datadriven forecasting approach that utilizes machine learning and deep learning techniques. The study forecasts the technology-specific capacity paths and compares their environmental and strategic implications across scenarios. The results demonstrate significant trade-offs between different policy pathways and highlight the complementary strengths of theoretical and empirical modeling approaches. The findings suggest that hybrid planning frameworks combining parametric transparency with data-driven adaptability offer a promising foundation for long-term electricity capacity planning that aligns with climate and security goals.

title: Alternative Loss Function in Evaluation of Transformer Models
affiliations: Triple Sun, University of Warsaw - Faculty of Economic Sciences and University of Warsaw - Faculty of Economic Sciences

detail.title: Alternative Loss Function in Evaluation of Transformer Models
detail.abstract: The proper design and architecture of testing machine learning models, especially in their application to quantitative finance problems, is crucial. The most important aspect of this process is selecting an adequate loss function for training, validation, estimation purposes, and hyperparameter tuning. Therefore, in this research, through empirical experiments on equity and cryptocurrency assets, we apply the Mean Absolute Directional Loss (MADL) function, which is more adequate for optimizing forecast-generating models used in algorithmic investment strategies. The MADL function results are compared between Transformer and LSTM models, and we show that in almost every case, Transformer results are significantly better than those obtained with LSTM.

title: Illinois Senate Bill 328 Endangers the Economic Wellbeing of Illinois Families and Opens the Floodgates for Nationwide Economic Harm
affiliations: Independent

detail.title: Illinois Senate Bill 328 Endangers the Economic Wellbeing of Illinois Families and Opens the Floodgates for Nationwide Economic Harm
detail.abstract: Illinois Senate Bill 328 (SB 328), which will become law unless Governor J.B. Pritzker vetoes it, marks a serious mistake in legal prudence, economic competitiveness policy, and constitutional balance.  To better understand the broader economic fallout of SB 328 beyond Illinois, the analysis quantifies how this legislation would impose litigation costs on businesses and consumers across the United States. The data and analysis reveals that SB 328 is not just a threat to Illinois’ legal and business climate, it is a national economic hazard.

title: Understanding Filipino Consumers' Willingness and Reluctance Toward Rabbit Meat Consumption
affiliations: Jose Rizal Memorial State University, Davao del Sur State College, Mindanao State University at Naawan, Mariano Marcos State University and Romblon State University

detail.title: Understanding Filipino Consumers' Willingness and Reluctance Toward Rabbit Meat Consumption

declarations.ethicsApproval: Although the study did not undergo formal review by a research ethics board, the research team ensured that all ethical principles in conducting research involving human participants were strictly observed. Participation was entirely voluntary, and informed consent was obtained from every respondent prior to data collection. Each participant was clearly informed about the purpose, scope, and nature of the study, including the types of information collected and how the data would be used. The researchers also explained that participants had the right to decline or withdraw from the survey at any time, without any form of penalty, consequence, or obligation. To safeguard participant rights and privacy, anonymity and confidentiality were strictly maintained. No personally identifiable information was recorded, and all responses were treated with the highest level of discretion. Data were used solely for academic purposes and were stored securely to prevent unauthorized access. Furthermore, the researchers took steps to minimize any potential psychological or social risks by ensuring that all questions were non-invasive, culturally appropriate, and framed in a neutral, non-judgmental manner. Participants were also assured that their responses would be aggregated for analysis and would not be traced back to them individually. In both the face-to-face and online formats, a brief orientation statement was provided to ensure that participants fully understood their rights and the voluntary nature of their participation. Generally, the study adhered to the core ethical principles of voluntariness, informed consent, confidentiality, and non-maleficence, ensuring that the dignity, safety, and autonomy of all respondents were respected throughout the research process.

detail.abstract: Filipinos remain reluctant to consume rabbit meat and no empirical study has examined the underlying reasons for this hesitation whether psychological, cultural, or informational leaving a critical gap in designing effective interventions. Using a mixed-methods approach, data were collected from 229 respondents across the country to examine the socio-demographic and psychographic factors influencing willingness and reluctance to consume rabbit meat. Respondents were categorized into three consumption segments, the have consumed, not consumed but willing, and not consumed and not willing. Chi-square tests and multinomial logistic regression (MNL) were used to identify associations and significant predictors of consumption behavior. Bivariate analysis showed strong associations between consumption segments and gender, age, and employment status. Women and older individuals were more likely to resist rabbit meat consumption, while young adults and males showed greater openness. Remarkably, consumption was highest among low-income groups, suggesting informal access and challenging assumptions that rabbit is a premium meat. The pooled MNL model showed the best fit, confirming that consumption is shaped not only by economic constraints but also by culturally embedded perceptions and emotional discomfort. Economic constraints and awareness increased both willingness and actual consumption, while psychological and cultural barriers significantly reduced them. The findings highlight that increasing rabbit meat acceptance requires more than awareness campaigns. It necessitates emotionally intelligent, culturally sensitive strategies that reframe rabbit meat's identity. Effective interventions must segment audiences based on gender, age, and economic context while addressing culturally and psychologically ingrained aversions. This study contributes to the growing body of behavioral food research and provides actionable insights for promoting alternative proteins in traditionally reluctant markets.

title: Educating Builders of Africa's Future: The Role of ALU's IBT Program in Fostering Pan-African Trade Competencies
affiliations: African Leadership University, African Leadership University, African Leadership University, African Leadership University and African Leadership University

detail.title: Educating Builders of Africa's Future: The Role of ALU's IBT Program in Fostering Pan-African Trade Competencies
detail.abstract: Africa's continental integration hinges on a workforce able to navigate the African Continental Free Trade Area (AfCFTA) and realise Agenda 2063's "skills revolution." This study interrogates whether the African Leadership University's re-engineered BSc (Hons) International Business & Trade (IBT) can supply that talent. Drawing on a 1,934-page documentary corpus analysed in NVivo and framed by Human Capital Theory, Innovation Diffusion, and Post-colonial Pedagogy, we benchmarked IBT against seven flagship business programmes across five sub-regions. The resulting Curriculum Alignment Index (CAI) places IBT at 7.9-roughly double the peer mean of 4.0 (t = 21.32, p < .001; Cohen's d = 8.06) owing to its 90 % Africa-centric content, 65 % experiential hours and 80 % blended delivery. Early graduate signals corroborate this curricular edge. A six-month tracer (n = 22) found 72 % of alumni working in AfCFTA-related sectors, a median first-year salary of US$10,473-five times the regional graduate average-and an employer Net Promoter Score of +86. These outcomes suggest that IBT graduates act as immediate implementation agents, diffusing trade-facilitation know-how within logistics firms, chambers of commerce and policy secretariats. Methodologically, the study combines comparative programme review, inferential statistics, and thematic coding to offer the first empirically grounded evaluation of an AfCFTA-aligned business curriculum. Practically, it identifies five low-cost, high-leverage design elements-including a Pan-African case-study bank and a two-stage internship loop-that can be replicated across African higher-education institutions. We conclude that ALU-IBT provides a scalable blueprint for closing Africa's trade-skills gap and accelerating continental economic integration. Future research should test these findings longitudinally through the programme's five-year monitoring and evaluation roadmap, which captures graduate AfCFTAengagement indices and capstone adoption rates.

title: SERENA: System for Evaluating Risks and Extreme Natural activities on Agriculture and Application to World Economies A Forward-Looking Analysis using Global Circulation Models Data
affiliations: Amundi Technology and Amundi Institute

detail.title: SERENA: System for Evaluating Risks and Extreme Natural activities on Agriculture and Application to World Economies A Forward-Looking Analysis using Global Circulation Models Data
detail.abstract: The SERENA methodology introduced in this paper integrates geospatial climatemodel data on crop production into an economic modeling environment. We examine the spillover effects of extreme weather events on commodity prices and inflation using a novel bottom-up framework. Drawing on Representative Concentration Pathway (RCP) scenarios and atmosphere-ocean general circulation models (AOGCMs), we simulate climate-induced supply shocks and trace their transmission to commodity markets and broader inflation dynamics. Monte Carlo simulations are embedded to capture the uncertain and evolving nature of weather-related risk, resulting in forecasts across alternative climate pathways. Our results indicate that extreme weather events can trigger commodity price shocks that exceed 100% by 2040 in certain scenarios, with significant transmission to consumer prices: On average, a 1% commodity price increase leads to a 2% increase in CPI inflation. These results underscore the need for the construction of new climate-informed economic modeling tools capable of translating physical climate risk into actionable signals for the financial and policy sectors.

title: Policy by Committee
affiliations: New York University (NYU) - Department of Finance, University of Notre Dame, Mitchell E. Daniels, Jr School of Business, Purdue University and Yale University

detail.title: Policy by Committee
detail.abstract: Committees shape decisions across numerous settings, but empirical examination of group decision-making remains limited due to measurement challenges. We address these challenges by constructing a novel dataset of Federal Open Market Committee members' arguments and decisions from over forty years of meetings. Contrary to prevailing theories emphasizing private information aggregation, we find that members employ distinct models to interpret public information, with committee decisions favoring models that better fit recent data. We develop a theoretical framework showing that committees can improve decision-making but must balance against the risk of excess sensitivity to recent data.

title: Iterated Revelation: How to Incentivize Experts to Reveal Novel Actions
affiliations: Royal Holloway, University of London

detail.title: Iterated Revelation: How to Incentivize Experts to Reveal Novel Actions
detail.abstract: I examine how a decision maker can incentivize an expert to reveal novel actions, expanding the set from which he can choose, without making ex-ante commitments regarding as-of-yet unrevealed actions. The outcomes achievable by any (incentive compatible) mechanism are characterized by the iterated revelation protocol: a simple dynamic interaction where, each round, the expert reveals novel actions and the decision maker adds actions to a shortlist; when nothing novel is revealed, the mechanism ends with the expert choosing an action from the shortlist. Greedy strategies—where the decision maker optimizes myopically-delineate the decision maker's maximal payoff achievable by any efficient mechanism.

title: American Expatriate Employment Patterns
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN and U.S. Department of the Treasury, Office of Tax Analysis (OTA)

detail.title: American Expatriate Employment Patterns
detail.abstract: This paper presents the first large-scale empirical analysis of American expatriate employment patterns, using US administrative tax data from 2008 to 2022. Despite estimates of 4.4 to 9 million Americans living abroad, limited data has constrained our understanding of how they engage in global labor markets. Drawing on information from tax filings, we examine employment tenure, firm affiliation, industry, occupation, income, and demographic characteristics. Our findings reveal that most American expatriates work for foreign rather than US-based employers, that long-term residence abroad is common, and that self-employment rates vary substantially by region and income levels by employer type. Modest gender differences also emerge. These patterns depart from traditional models of corporate-initiated expatriation and point to a more multifaceted and decentralized structure of American global labor market participation, with implications for research, corporate practice, and policy.

title: Regulatory Sandboxes: One Decade On
affiliations: American University - Washington College of Law

detail.title: Regulatory Sandboxes: One Decade On
detail.abstract:
Regulatory sandboxes have spread like wildfire since the U.K. Financial Conduct Authority launched its sandbox for financial technology businesses (fintech) one decade ago. Despite widespread adoption, however, there is little empirical evidence available to assess whether the signature sandbox policy combination of regulatory rollbacks and regulatory guidance is in fact good policy. The empirical evidence that is available suggests that regulatory sandboxes are beneficial for the tech firms that participate in them, but tells us nothing about how regulatory sandboxes have impacted the broader enterprise of regulation, or whether the innovation generated by sandbox participants is beneficial for anyone other than the innovating firms themselves. From the outset, there were reasons to be concerned about sandboxes' deregulatory impact and grounds for skepticism about the type of regulatory learning that sandboxes would facilitate. A decade of experience with fintech sandboxes has not allayed those concerns; sometimes it has deepened them. 

Careful attention to sandbox design features can mitigate some concerns, but we should not skip straight to design questions without first considering whether a regulatory sandbox is appropriate at all. A reckoning with the sandbox model is particularly necessary at this moment, when there is a push to use sandboxes to further innovation in generative artificial intelligence (AI). It is becoming increasingly clear that simply scaling up generative AI will not solve its limitations, just as it is becoming increasingly clear that generative AI tools have significant negative impacts on privacy, intellectual property rights, and our environment (among other things). In these circumstances, it seems foolhardy to rush headlong into adopting sandboxes that roll back legal protections in order to let AI thrive.

title: Democratizing Illiquid Assets: Liquidity Transformation and Performance in Interval Funds
affiliations: University of Notre Dame - Department of Finance, University of Notre Dame - Department of Finance and University of Notre Dame - Mendoza College of Business

detail.title: Democratizing Illiquid Assets: Liquidity Transformation and Performance in Interval Funds
detail.abstract: Interval funds are a rapidly growing evergreen investment vehicle that offers structured liquidity through periodic redemption opportunities, enabling institutional and retail investors to invest in illiquid private assets. Using a comprehensive U.S. dataset covering interval funds and ETFs, we investigate whether interval funds effectively compensate investors for limited liquidity and facilitate efficient liquidity transformation compared to continuously tradable ETFs. Consistent with our theoretical framework, we find that interval funds significantly outperform both passive and active ETFs in illiquid and information-insensitive asset categories, particularly non-traditional fixed-income investments, even after fees and expenses. However, interval funds underperform ETFs in liquid and information-sensitive equity categories, highlighting potential agency conflicts stemming from reduced market-based managerial incentives. Additionally, we document investor-level externalities: interval funds that offer institutional share classes outperform retail-only funds, and flows into institutional classes predict incremental future returns relative to retail flows, indicating superior selection skill among sophisticated investors. Finally, the structured liquidity of interval funds results in improved investor timing decisions relative to daily-tradable ETFs, further underscoring the benefits of limited liquidity.

title: A Text-Based Analysis of Technical Contributions to 3GPP
affiliations: Northwestern University - Center on Law, Business, and Economics, BRELA Research in Economics and Legal Analytics and TUM School of Management

detail.title: A Text-Based Analysis of Technical Contributions to 3GPP
detail.abstract: Measuring firms’ contributions to 3GPP standards development is increasingly important for patent licensing, policymaking, and strategic positioning. However, existing approaches relying on counts of submitted Technical Documents (TDoc) fail to account for the wide variation in TDoc content, purpose, and technical significance. This study explores the use of metadata (such as type and status), bibliometric data (number of pages, figures, tables, references, etc), and semantic data extracted from the full text of contributions to better assess the nature and value of companies’ contributions to 3GPP standards. We focus on RAN1, which is a particularly important WG, and the WG that is most closely associated with patented innovations. In spite of the great importance of RAN1, RAN1 standards development has been particularly difficult to study, as there are few contributions that are subject to a binary approval decision. Instead, companies submit large numbers of diverse discussion papers, and consensus emerges gradually. Here, we show that it is possible and useful to identify different categories of RAN1 discussion papers (“Research Papers”, “Position Papers”, and “Summaries”), and we show how to account for double-counting of contributions. Further work is needed to account for heterogeneity between contributions in terms of complexity, novelty, and impact.

title: Provincial Governance and Financial Inclusion: Micro Evidence from Rural Vietnam
affiliations: Vietnam National University (VNU) - VNU University of Economics and Business

detail.title: Provincial Governance and Financial Inclusion: Micro Evidence from Rural Vietnam
detail.abstract: Do government institutions improve financial inclusion for households and wage earners in a transitional country? We answer this question in Vietnam, a socialist-oriented market economy that has seen rapid economic growth, while balancing economic prosperity with equity, social inclusion, and bolstering the state’s governance and public administration performance. Our micro-econometric analysis provides fresh evidence that households in provinces with better institutions are more likely to receive larger formal loans, and have bank accounts, savings books, and ATM cards. Also, wage earners living in provinces with higher quality institutions are more likely to be covered by compulsory social insurance. The finding is robust to the choice of econometric specifications and control variables. Our research result implies that improving the quality of provincial institutions (or governance) is an effective way of enhancing financial inclusion for households and wage earners in rural Vietnam.

title: Financial Price of Sin Stocks Across Religions
affiliations: London School of Commerce

detail.title: Financial Price of Sin Stocks Across Religions
detail.abstract:
This paper examines the pricing of sin stocks across religious contexts using monthly data for 833 publicly listed firms from 1990 to 2025. Sin stocks—defined as firms involved in alcohol, tobacco, gambling, or military industries—are matched with sector-specific non-sin counterparts to isolate abnormal returns. The analysis finds that sin stocks consistently earn significant excess returns relative to both industry comparables and the market. The sin premium is strongest in the gambling and military sectors and is notably higher in countries with substantial Abrahamic religious presence, where moral restrictions on vice-related activities are more stringent. In contrast, the premium is weaker or even negative in atheist and non-Abrahamic settings.
Fama–MacBeth cross-sectional regressions confirm that religious context significantly predicts sin stock return differentials, controlling for firm-level characteristics and broader cultural traits. These findings suggest that religion systematically shapes investor preferences and contributes to persistent mispricing. The study advances the literature on cultural finance, ethical investing, and the role of moral norms in asset pricing.

title: Carbon Pricing Policies and Global Climate Change - Critical Perspectives
affiliations: Bournemouth University Business School

detail.title: Carbon Pricing Policies and Global Climate Change - Critical Perspectives
detail.abstract: The paper considers carbon pricing policies that have developed in response to global climate change concerns. There have been significant international institutional climate change policy drivers to harness a global effort to reduce adverse anthropogenic (humaninduced) effects on the climate system. Following the Kyoto Protocol (1997) and then the Paris Agreement (2015) many countries have adopted carbon pricing policies with various mechanisms that in combination had achieved coverage of some 28 per cent. of global carbon emissions by 2025 according to the World Bank. There are both mandatory and voluntary carbon markets that are effectively specialised human-construct commodity markets. Carbon pricing has encouraged structured financial engineering based on measured carbon emissions in different jurisdictions. Further research will be necessary to assess whether the progress in carbon pricing and carbon markets is sufficiently effective in achieving positive outcomes at national and global levels. Governments may face increasing pressure to consider the balance between carbon pricing policies and promotion of carbon management technologies especially if the latter prove to be more effective and/or acceptable to businesses and the wider public. This paper identifies some controversies and challenges in the development of carbon pricing and concludes with a consideration of important issues to address in the future.

title: When Polanyi Met Competition Policy: Market Fundamentalism, Crisis, and Reform in the 21st Century
affiliations: University of Sao Paulo - Faculdade de Direito and University of São Paulo (USP)

detail.title: When Polanyi Met Competition Policy: Market Fundamentalism, Crisis, and Reform in the 21st Century
detail.abstract: Karl Polanyi and his analytical framework in economic sociology remain overlooked by competition policy scholarship. Notably, the concept of "embeddedness", central to Polanyi's contribution, oqers a valuable perspective to trace the development of this regulatory mechanism over time. The social and political concerns of an emerging industrial society marked the birth of competition policy as a device for embedding the early 20 th-century market economy. However, in the following decades, new market fundamentalist narratives disembedded markets, with competition policy contributing to this process by deviating from its non-market origins. Today, this governance tool faces the challenges of 21 stcentury civilization, with the celebrated consensus on its principles long lost. New social and political concerns arising from market power demand the re-embedment of markets through competition. This article explores this Polanyian dynamic of embeddedness-disembeddedness-re-embeddedness by reframing the history of competition policy in diqerent institutional realities-the United States, the EU, and Brazil. It also discusses how diverse institutional conditions shaped alternative responses towards market fundamentalism throughout the past century. The revival of Polanyi's ideas not only helps us understand how we arrived here but also provides important insights into the inevitable role that "nonmarket" dimensions play in the reform agenda currently surrounding competition policy.

title: Financial Regulation and AI: A Faustian Bargain?
affiliations: Yale School of Management and Stanford University

detail.title: Financial Regulation and AI: A Faustian Bargain?
detail.abstract: We examine whether and how granular, real-time predictive models should be integrated into central banks' macroprudential toolkit. First, we develop a tractable framework that formalizes the tradeoff regulators face when choosing between implementing models that forecast systemic risk accurately but have uncertain causal content and models with the opposite profile. We derive the regulator's optimal policy in a setting in which private portfolios react endogenously to the regulator's model choice and policy rule. We show that even purely predictive models can generate welfare gains for a regulator, and that predictive precision and knowledge of causal impacts of policy interventions are complementary. Second, we introduce a deep learning architecture tailored to financial holdings data-a graph transformer-and we discuss why it is optimally suited to this problem. The model learns vector embedding representations for both assets and investors by explicitly modeling the relational structure of holdings, and it attains state-of-the-art predictive accuracy in out-of-sample forecasting tasks including trade prediction.

title: Determinants Affecting Digital Financial Consumer Protection: Evidence from 135 Countries
affiliations: Vietnam National University (VNU) - VNU University of Economics and Business

detail.title: Determinants Affecting Digital Financial Consumer Protection: Evidence from 135 Countries
detail.abstract: Asymmetric information in digital financial markets is increasingly becoming a severe problem in the digital era. Consumers of digital finance suffer from asymmetric information compared to financial agents due to the complexity of services and their passive position in collecting, analyzing, and processing information. This study offers measures to improve the practice of digital financial consumer protection (DFCP) through quantitative analysis, using a sample of 135 countries from 2014 to 2018. This manuscript indicates that two groups of factors positively affect financial consumer protection: market size (openness) and technological readiness. The results show that technological improvement and economic openness factors worldwide are seen as tremendous opportunities in the digital age, rather than challenges, for strengthening financial consumer protection. Governments thus need to adopt policies that focus on absorbing new technology, encouraging innovation, and opening the economy instead of controlling actions to protect their citizens.

title: Environmental Monitoring: Role of Social Forestry in the Protection of Environment.
affiliations: Associate Professor, Department of Sociology  Government First Grade College, Kanakapura and GOVERNMENT FIRST GRADE COLLEGE

detail.title: Environmental Monitoring: Role of Social Forestry in the Protection of Environment.

declarations.declarationOfInterest: Not Applicable
declarations.ethicsApproval: Not Applicable
declarations.funderStatement: Not Applicable

publicationDetails.detailsText: Journal of Design, Web of Science (SCI) Indexed., Special Issue 11(7), 654–658.DOI:10.5281/zenodo.15977037

detail.abstract: Environmental monitoring is a process and an activity which is used to describe the state of the environment. It is mainly concerned with the environmental impact assessments and also on the human activities that have harmful effects on the natural environment. Monitoring strategies and programmes are generally designed to establish the current status of an environment or to establish a baseline and trends in environmental parameters. Many monitoring programmes are designed to not only establish the current state of the environment but also predict future conditions. One such monitoring program is giving focus to Social Forestry. Everyone is aware that without an environment it is difficult to survive. If we save nature, nature will save us. If we don’t preserve the trees, future generations cannot survive and they do not get fresh air to breathe. Everyone should cultivate the habit of gardening and a lot of efforts should be made by the people to protect the environment and also to save nature. As forests are the most inevitable natural resources it is the duty of every citizen to protect the environment. Social Forestry should be given much importance as it involves community participation and also serves as the main source of livelihood for local people. Management of social forestry should be the main objective of society as the human population is heavily dependent on forest resources. Efforts should be initiated by the government, NGOs, officials, and people in this regard.

reference: 85 Maryland Law Review Online _ (2026); University of Missouri School of Law Legal Studies Research Paper
title: Toys As Evidence
affiliations: University of Missouri at Kansas City - School of Law

detail.title: Toys As Evidence

publicationDetails.detailsText: 85 Maryland Law Review Online _ (2026); University of Missouri School of Law Legal Studies Research Paper

detail.abstract:
This essay asks and answers a single question, which arose in the course of a symposium at the National Museum of Toys And Miniatures. Could the study of consumer goods improve our collective understanding of what constitutes unlawful discrimination, including how evidence is admitted in U.S. federal courts? A possible answer, which is informed by the historical record, is toys and related consumer goods may improve our collective understanding for three reasons.

The first reason is studying consumer goods provides a window into how society views African Americans, perhaps due to its unique ability to capture the revealed preferences of individuals. Another reason is the study of consumer goods offers a relatively safe distance from which to draw conclusions about how transaction-level decisions impact U.S. public policies and 
practices. A third reason is the study of consumer goods validates calls for additional government intervention, so as to remove unrecognized barriers to full participation in ostensibly free markets. 

Such interventions, often, seek to improve efficiency rather than to limit unlawful discrimination. Nonetheless, these reforms frequently assure that Black folks are treated just like everybody else. For these reasons, among others, this author encourages scholars and practitioners to make greater use of transaction-level information (i.e., information generated in the normal course of business). 

Race-neutral government interventions, such as Professor Jasmine Gonzalez Rose’s useful suggestions about how the Federal Rules Of Evidence should be applied going forward, may serve as a less-than-salient way to remove hidden barriers to full participation. One way to implement these suggested reforms is to make much greater use of transaction-level information. Transaction-level information is any data that is generated in the normal course of business such as a seller’s purchasing data (i.e., what they buy), a seller’s profit-market information (i.e., net effects) or a buyer’s feedback (i.e., compliments or complaints, which arise from buyer-seller transactions).
