title: Evaluating the Effectiveness of UNDP's Livelihood Diversification Programme in Enhancing the Climate Resilience of the Tripura Indigenous Community in Chittagong Hill Tracts (CHT)
affiliations: United Nations - Development Programme (UNDP)

detail.title: Evaluating the Effectiveness of UNDP's Livelihood Diversification Programme in Enhancing the Climate Resilience of the Tripura Indigenous Community in Chittagong Hill Tracts (CHT)

declarations.declarationOfInterest: University Publication as a part of completing Master of Social Science in Development Studies under the Department of Economics, Jahangirnagar University

detail.abstract: Nestled within the unique socio-ecological landscape of the Chittagong Hill Tracts (CHT) of Bangladesh, the Tripura indigenous community faces mounting threats from climate change. Their traditional, land-based livelihoods are increasingly vulnerable to extreme weather events and environmental degradation. This study examines the effectiveness of a United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) livelihood diversification programme in strengthening the community's climate resilience. Using a multidisciplinary approach that incorporates economics, anthropology, and development studies, the research evaluates the programme's objectives, implementation strategies, and outcomes. The analysis considers how alternative livelihood options introduced by UNDP have affected the Tripura community's adaptive capacity and socioeconomic resilience. It also explores broader socioeconomic challenges and environmental vulnerabilities, such as limited access to essential services, land degradation, and water scarcity, that the community contends with. By critically assessing the programme's successes, shortcomings, and lessons learned, this research generates evidence-based insights and practical recommendations. These findings are intended to inform future development initiatives aiming to foster climate resilience and sustainable livelihoods among indigenous communities in the CHT and similar contexts.

title: Female Heights and Sexual Dimorphism in Argentina
affiliations: Universidad Torcuato Di Tella

detail.title: Female Heights and Sexual Dimorphism in Argentina
detail.abstract: This contribution examines new data on female heights extracted from records of a female prison near La Plata, Argentina. The data provides insights about the net-nutrition condition of lower-class women in Buenos Aires, Argentina’s wealthiest province. This data shows a remarkably poor growth in female stature: 1.8 cm over eight decades (from the 1870s to the 1940s). Yet Buenos Aires female prisoners were the tallest among a group of twelve Latin American countries. Their heights were equivalent to the 30th to 40th percentile of contemporary female standards of heights. This suggests that these women were relatively well-fed and relatively healthy. Compared with the heights of male prisoners, female heights seemed to have followed a similar path; in the long run the stature sexual gap remained rather stable.

title: Central Bank Transparency Under Adaptive Learning
affiliations: Marquette University

detail.title: Central Bank Transparency Under Adaptive Learning
detail.abstract: The impact of central bank transparency on the evolution of agents’ expectations for the Mexican case is evaluated in this paper via a New Keynesian model with adaptive learning and survey forecasts. Among multiple scenarios analyzed, the data prefer the observed transparency degree followed by the Mexican central bank, where the central bank not only credibly communicates the inflation target but also discloses relevant information about its policy rule. The results indicate that agents exhibit a faster learning speed than the U.S. and a declining perception of inflation persistence. Plus, the model-implied learning mechanism can match the empirical inflation expectations from the Survey on Expectations of Private Sector Specialists. Moreover, there is evidence suggesting that higher degrees of transparency increase the effectiveness of monetary policy in stabilizing the economy.

title: Reactive Power Optimization Method for Active Distribution Network Based on Deep Learning
affiliations: Wuhan University, Wuhan University, affiliation not provided to SSRN, Wuhan University, affiliation not provided to SSRN, Wuhan University and Wuhan University

detail.title: Reactive Power Optimization Method for Active Distribution Network Based on Deep Learning
detail.abstract: In response to the problem that traditional reactive power optimization methods cannot meet real-time requirements, this paper proposes a comprehensive reactive power optimization method for active distribution networks based on deep learning algorithms. Firstly, based on the feature extraction characteristics of graph convolutional neural network(GCN), a feature parameter set of distribution network operation status containing topological information was constructed; Secondly, based on the operation rules of Deep Belief Networks(DBN), a network structure parameter optimization method based on Genetic Algorithm(GA) algorithm is proposed; Finally, based on the feature parameter set and policy set, the neural network was trained to obtain the final reactive power optimization model, and the effectiveness of the proposed method was verified through case analysis. This method uses deep learning neural networks to simplify the reactive power optimization process, significantly reducing computational requirements and decision-making time, and achieving fast output of reactive power optimization strategies.

title: Accumulation of Phenol Derivatives and Microplastic in Ferromangansese Nodules (Fe-Mn) from Polish Exclusive Economic Zone
affiliations: University of Gdansk, University of Gdansk, University of Gdansk, University of Gdansk, University of Gdansk, affiliation not provided to SSRN, University of Gdansk and University of Gdansk

detail.title: Accumulation of Phenol Derivatives and Microplastic in Ferromangansese Nodules (Fe-Mn) from Polish Exclusive Economic Zone
detail.abstract: Polymetallic iron-manganese (Fe-Mn) nodules from the Baltic Sea are increasingly seen as a valuable source of rare earth elements (REE) and technology-critical elements (TCE). However, no prior studies have examined their potential to accumulate toxic organic pollutants, which may affect REE recovery processes. Here, we report the first detection of endocrine-disrupting phenol derivatives: bisphenol A, 4-nonylphenol, and 4-tert-octylphenol as well as microplastics in Fe-Mn nodules from the Polish Exclusive Economic Zone. Phenol concentrations were 5–151 times higher in nodules than in sediments below. We identified 29 microplastic particles, dominated by industrial polymers such as neoprene and chlorosulfonated polyethylene. Our results show that Fe-Mn nodules can function not only as geochemical resources but also as sinks for organic pollutants. With increasing interest in nodule exploitation, recovery methods should be adapted to minimize phenol derivatives and microplastic release into the environment and reduce health risks.

title: Adaptive Network Dynamics and Behavioral Contagion in Multi-State Drug Use Propagation
affiliations: Lehigh University, affiliation not provided to SSRN and Rochester Institute of Technology

detail.title: Adaptive Network Dynamics and Behavioral Contagion in Multi-State Drug Use Propagation
detail.abstract: Addictive behavior spreads through social networks via feedback among choice, peer pressure, and shifting ties, a process that eludes standard epidemic models. We present a comprehensive multi-state network model that integrates utility-based behavioral transitions with adaptive network rewiring, capturing the co-evolutionary dynamics between drug use patterns and social structure. Our framework distinguishes four distinct individual states by combining drug use behavior with addiction status, while allowing individuals to strategically disconnect from drug-using neighbors and form new connections with non-users. Monte Carlo simulations show that rewiring reshapes contagion, pulling high-degree nodes into drug-free clusters and stranding users on sparse fringes. Systematic exploration of the four-dimensional parameter space reveals sharp phase transitions reminiscent of critical phenomena in statistical physics, where small changes in recovery rates or addiction conversion rates trigger dramatic shifts in population-level outcomes. Most significantly, the rewiring probability emerges as the dominant control parameter, establishing adaptive network management as more influential than biological susceptibility factors in determining addiction prevalence. Our findings challenge traditional intervention paradigms by revealing that empowering individuals to curate their social environments may be more effective than targeting individual behavioral change alone.

title: Equivalence and Near-Equivalence of Solutions to Principal-Agent Problems
affiliations: Arizona State University (ASU) - Economics Department and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Equivalence and Near-Equivalence of Solutions to Principal-Agent Problems
detail.abstract: For a broad class of principal-agent problems, and for “almost all” specifications of the distribution of the agent’s type, any two optimal mechanisms are equivalent: conditional on each type of the agent, neither the principal nor the agent cares which mechanism is in force. Nearly-optimal mechanisms are nearly equivalent. This provides substantial reassurance about numerical analysis of mechanisms in applied work, and has important theoretical implications as well. The model allows for both adverse selection and moral hazard. The substantive assumptions are that the set of types is finite, and a separability assumption on the agent’s utility.

title: Conceptual Foundations and Development of Sustainable Team Dynamics
affiliations: Steel Authority of India Limited, SAIL Refractory Unit

detail.title: Conceptual Foundations and Development of Sustainable Team Dynamics
detail.abstract: The emergence of sustainable team dynamics concept reflects a critical evolution in organizational theory, aligning the foundations of effective teamwork with imperatives of sustainability. This paper proposes an integrative conceptual framework of Sustainable Team Dynamics (STD) that brings together constructs from organizational behavior, team science, and positive psychology. Grounded in Social Exchange Theory, IMOI (Input–Mediator–Output–Input) model and psychological safety models, the framework posits that factors such as organizational culture, team composition, task characteristics, and social capital shape psychological safety and resilience, which in turn influence team performance and long-term sustainability. To strengthen the theoretical model, a survey of 448 team members was conducted using a structured 24-item Likert questionnaire mapped to eight latent constructs. Descriptive statistics confirmed high internal agreement on team functioning, and correlation analyses supported the model’s directional expectations. Organizational culture, psychological safety and resilience emerged as key predictors of performance, retention and sustainability. These results strengthen the empirical credibility of the STD framework and reinforce its potential for guiding leadership development and sustainable team-building strategies. The paper concludes with implications for leadership development and sustainable HR practices, directions for further validation and practical implementation.

title: Regulatory Barriers to the Pan-African Payment and Settlement System (PAPSS) under AfCFTA: Multi-Country Analysis for Enhanced Intra-African Trade
affiliations: African Leadership University, African Leadership University, African Leadership University, African Leadership University and African Leadership University

detail.title: Regulatory Barriers to the Pan-African Payment and Settlement System (PAPSS) under AfCFTA: Multi-Country Analysis for Enhanced Intra-African Trade
detail.abstract: Purpose-The Pan-African Payment and Settlement System (PAPSS) is critical to realising the African Continental Free Trade Area (AfCFTA), yet adoption remains patchy and uneven. This study interrogates the regulatory frictions that slow PAPSS uptake in Rwanda, Ghana, Kenya and Nigeria and quantifies the opportunity cost of inaction for the wider continent's trade agenda. [2] Design/methodology/approach-We integrate institutional, diffusion-ofinnovation and resource-dependence theory within a mixed-methods design. An AI-assisted content analysis of more than 80 statutory texts produces a sixdimension Regulatory Readiness Index (RRI), while an augmented Poisson gravity model, calibrated with World Bank and Afreximbank data, simulates trade gains under alternative cost-reduction scenarios. [3] Findings-Currency-convertibility restrictions, divergent KYC/AML thresholds and data-localisation clauses emerge as the most binding constraints. RRI scores range from 56.7 (Nigeria) to 65.0 (Kenya), explaining crosscountry variance in early PAPSS transaction volumes. Full PAPSS roll-out coupled with moderate regulatory harmonisation could trim average payment costs by 40-50 %, raising bilateral intra-African trade by 10-30 % within the next decade. [4] Research implications-By empirically isolating how coercive, mimetic and resource logics condition payment-system diffusion, the paper advances theorisation of fintech integration in emerging markets and offers a replicable AIenhanced methodology for regulatory benchmarking. [5] Practical implications-Policymakers should prioritise phased FX liberalisation, mutual KYC recognition and a pan-African fintech-passport regime; without these reforms, AfCFTA's digital-trade protocol risks underdelivery. [6] Originality/value-This is the first multi-country investigation to fuse AIdriven regulatory analytics with econometric trade modelling, delivering an evidence-based roadmap for an interoperable African payments union and a template for future digital-trade research.

title: From Perception to Protection: Effect of Subjective Risk Perceptions on Flood Insurance Uptake
affiliations: University of Georgia and UGA Ag & Applied Economics

detail.title: From Perception to Protection: Effect of Subjective Risk Perceptions on Flood Insurance Uptake

declarations.ethicsApproval: This study was approved by IRB.

detail.abstract: Understanding factors affecting decisions to buy hazard insurance is important, yet subjective risk perceptions are less studied. This paper examines individual perceptions of frequency and severity of hurricanes relating to flood insurance uptake in the US coastal zone, assessing magnitude of potential omitted variable bias using Robustness of Inference to Replacement technique and controlling for endogeneity using the Special Regressor approach. Results indicate that the impact of Perceived Risk Frequency (PRF) on insurance uptake decisions is positive and statistically significant; a one unit increase in annual PRF is estimated to increase flood insurance uptake by 16.17 percent. The effect of Perceived Risk Severity (PRS) is also positive and significant, but the estimated effect is much smaller; a $1000 increase in expected damages increases flood insurance uptake by only 0.14 percent. Interaction effects for PRS indicate a crowding out effect for coastal households with private shoreline protection (seawalls and bulkheads).

title: FX Interventions and Capital-Constrained Banks: Evidence from USD/ILS Spot, Forward, and Option Markets
affiliations: German University of Applied Sciences, Saarbrücken and The Hong Kong Polytechnic University

detail.title: FX Interventions and Capital-Constrained Banks: Evidence from USD/ILS Spot, Forward, and Option Markets
detail.abstract: Using confidential daily data, we examine the Bank of Israel's foreign exchange interventions from 2013 to 2019. We find that a 1 billion US dollars (USD) purchase leads to a 0.82% depreciation of the Israeli Shekel (ILS)-a strong effect compared to other studies. We show that this effectiveness can partially be attributed to the limited risk-taking capacity of global banks. The interventions also widen the negative deviation from covered interest parity and influence the higher-order moments of risk-neutral expectations derived from options prices. We find that USD purchases shift the USD/ILS distribution upwards and reduce crash risk. Moreover, the options market anticipates and prices in upcoming interventions.

title: Machine Learning-Based Early Prediction of Hospitalization in Hemodialysis Patients During Ambulance Transport to the Emergency Department
affiliations: Dalhousie University, Dalhousie University and Dalhousie University

detail.title: Machine Learning-Based Early Prediction of Hospitalization in Hemodialysis Patients During Ambulance Transport to the Emergency Department
detail.abstract: Background and Objective: High rates of emergency department (ED) use present a significant challenge for healthcare systems globally, with hemodialysis patients among the most frequent users. However, not all dialysis patients presenting to the ED require hospitalization. Accurately predicting hospitalization needs for these patients, especially those transported by ambulance, is essential for effective resource allocation and timely intervention.Methods: This study analyzed a cohort of chronic hemodialysis patients in Halifax, Nova Scotia, Canada, from January 2014 to July 2018. The dataset included 879 hemodialysis ambulance transports to the ED, and several predictors of hospitalization based on assessments by paramedics prior to transport, including vital signs, chief complaint, age, sex, and the number of days from the last dialysis treatment. We utilized machine learning (ML) methods, including random forest, k-nearest neighbors, support vector machine, XG-Boost, and neural network, addressing class imbalance through internal and external balancing techniques to provide accurate and reliable risk prediction models for hospitalization. To ensure the interpretability and transparency of model decisions, Explainable AI (XAI) methods, such as Local Interpretable Model-agnostic Explanations (LIME) and SHapley Additive exPlanations (SHAP), were integrated into the analysis.Results: The XGBoost model demonstrated superior performance, achieving an F1-score of 0.77 and an Area Under the Curve (AUC) of 0.84 for hospitalization following ED transport. Integrating XAI methods (LIME and SHAP) provided insights into model-driven decision-making processes, highlighting key clinical predictors influencing subsequent hospitalization after ambulance transport to the ED,  such as higher heart rate, lower blood pressure, lower oxygen saturation, and lower Canadian Triage and Acuity Scale (CTAS) score.Conclusion: Machine learning models, particularly XGBoost combined with Explainable AI techniques, effectively predict hospitalization needs of hemodialysis patients following ambulance transport to ED.

title: Quantlet: The Code Snippet Knowledge Platform
affiliations: Bucharest University of Economic Studies, International Research Training Group 1792 "High Dimensional Nonstationary Time Series", Humboldt-Universität zu Berlin, Blockchain Research Center Humboldt-Universität zu Berlin, National University of Singapore (NUS) and Bucharest University of Economic Studies

detail.title: Quantlet: The Code Snippet Knowledge Platform
detail.abstract: Many researchers increasingly rely on code snippets, algorithms, and information they find online to address complex problems. While these resources can provide immediate solutions, they often come from unverified sources and lack the context necessary for correct application. This growing dependence on readily available, sometimes ill-advised, information can lead to significant missteps, including inefficient code, flawed methodologies, or incorrect conclusions. As a result, researchers may unwittingly propagate errors or overlook more robust, appropriate solutions that are crucial for scientific progress. This paper presents the integration of the Quantlet and Quantinar platforms, collectively referred to as the Q2 ecosystem, aimed at overcoming challenges faced by applied scientists and researchers due to the vast and fragmented array of data and code available online. The focus of this integration is to enhance accessibility and usability of academic resources by effectively linking research with pertinent code and datasets. The study introduces an adaptive clustering algorithm that organizes and dynamically groups academic content from Quantinar alongside code and computational results from Quantlet, thus linking academic theory and practice. With these technical advancements, the Q2 framework aspires to enhance transparency and reproducibility within the academic research landscape. Ultimately, it aims to provide a cohesive learning environment that meets the evolving needs of the academic community, empowering researchers in their pursuit of knowledge and facilitating deeper insights into complex data-driven methodologies.

title: Asset Bubbles, R&D, and Endogenous Growth
affiliations: Hong Kong Baptist University, School of Economics, Zhejiang University and Peking University HSBC Business School

detail.title: Asset Bubbles, R&D, and Endogenous Growth
detail.abstract: How do asset bubbles affect innovation and long-run economic growth? This paper addresses this question in the semi-endogenous growth framework by incorporating idiosyncratic productivity shocks and endogenous credit constraints in the R&D sector. We demonstrate that pure bubbles attached to intrinsically useless assets and equity bubbles attached to intermediate goods firms can coexist and relax credit constraints. These bubbles boost entrepreneurs' TFP, stimulate R&D, and enhance growth along the transitional path, but they generally do not affect the long-run economic growth rate. The model's mechanisms and predictions are validated by aggregate and firm-level evidence, revealing a positive correlation between equity bubbles and R&D investment, with stronger effects during periods of tightened financial constraints.

title: Energy Transition, Price-Quantity Market Interactions and Inflation -A Model-guided Study and CIVAR Empirics for the US Explaining Fossilflation and Greenflation
affiliations: The New School - Department of Economics and University of Melbourne

detail.title: Energy Transition, Price-Quantity Market Interactions and Inflation -A Model-guided Study and CIVAR Empirics for the US Explaining Fossilflation and Greenflation

declarations.funderStatement: no external funding

detail.abstract: Much Keynesian-oriented research on energy policies has studied the effects of quantity shocks on sector expansions and contraction. The New Keynesian literature has considered the energy transition and their effects on relative prices due to fossil fuel and renewable energy shocks resulting from carbon tax and subsidies. We consider sectoral dynamic interactions of quantities and prices in markets after shocks. The issue here is then to what extent do prices and quantities change when there are quantity shocks. On the other hand, how sizable are the price and quantity effects when there are price shocks? New Keynesian literature refers to the monopolistic competition theory and the Lerner measure, capturing demand elasticity, and relies on expected future marginal costs and markups, studying equilibrium relative price change. Instead of using this proposition, or partially assuming or estimating elasticities, we undertake here model-guided econometric VAR and CIVAR estimations, to understand the size of the interaction effects of quantity and price shocks in markets not necessarily in equilibrium, but when market variables have moved below or above some trends. As to the energy transition, we show that in higher carbon intensity sectors  prices and quantities move differently as compared to less carbon-intensive sectors. As we demonstrate, the relative quantity and price changes show sectoral dependency – the price and quantity shock responses are dependent on the carbon intensity of the sectors.

title: Colonial Anthropology and its Interest in the Study of Amazigh Culture in Algeria (1830 -1962)
affiliations: École Normale Supérieure de Laghouat

detail.title: Colonial Anthropology and its Interest in the Study of Amazigh Culture in Algeria (1830 -1962)

declarations.declarationOfInterest: no interest
declarations.ethicsApproval: Citation . Attia, O., & Ibrahim, H. L. (2025). Colonial anthropology and its interest in the study of Amazigh culture in Algeria (1830–1962). Science, Education and Innovations in the Context of Modern Problems, 8(9), 418–426.
declarations.funderStatement: no funder

detail.abstract: This study aims to clarify certain issues in the history of Algeria during the colonial period from 1830 to 1962, during which France mobilized all its resources to make Algeria a country of French language, identity, and religion. This was achieved through projects that utilized Amazigh cultural heritage to fulfill its objectives. France focused on anthropological studies to examine Algerian society, determine the systems governing it, explain the relationships that bind it, and understand its communication language. With the support of the colonial administration, military officers, administrators, and anthropological translators were able to conduct various studies based on the diversity of Algerian cultural heritage. On this basis, they succeeded in understanding the organizational, linguistic, and social cultural structure, as well as the customs, traditions, dialects, and rituals that characterize Algerian society, in order to use them to control Algerian society.

title: John Taylor's Contributions to Economics
affiliations: Stanford University, Hoover Institution and Rutgers University, New Brunswick - Department of Economics

detail.title: John Taylor's Contributions to Economics
detail.abstract: John B. Taylor is one of the greatest macroeconomists of the late 20th and early 21st centuries. This paper surveys his seminal contributions to monetary theory, policy rules, and macroeconomic modeling. Taylor’s work on rational expectations, staggered contracts, and the development of the Taylor Rule transformed the theory and practice of monetary policy. Through scholarship, policy engagement, and public service, Taylor has profoundly influenced academic research and central banking practice, establishing rules-based policy as a central paradigm in macroeconomics.

title: Revisiting Meritocratic Taxation
affiliations: University of Florida Fredric G. Levin College of Law

detail.title: Revisiting Meritocratic Taxation
detail.abstract:
This paper is a preliminary draft and is being made available for the purpose of discussion and feedback. I welcome comments, suggestions, and constructive critique. Please feel free to reach out if you would like to share feedback or request an updated version of the manuscript (scuderi@law.ufl.edu)

This article examines the role of merit and desert in tax policy. These concepts are frequently invoked in political debates to support social and economic reforms. However, they are often infused with meanings that advance specific political—rather than policy—agendas, thereby threatening the very values they claim to uphold: justice, fairness, and equality. Policies related to the allocation of the tax burden and the redistribution of tax revenues are particularly susceptible to such manipulations. Drawing on extensive debates in political philosophy and economics, the article explores how perceptions of fairness have historically shaped the relationship between governments and taxpayers. Rather than aiming to resolve the moral debates surrounding tax policy, it reopens the question of whether—and to what extent—meritocratic and desert-based principles should inform taxation. In particular, it examines potential solutions for repurposing the normative justifications for meritocratic taxation to address the limitations of meritocracy. The article argues that meritocratic taxation can remain a valuable policy tool when coupled with an analysis of the economic efficiency and behavioral impact of the measure. Ultimately, this article seeks to preserve the philosophical coherence of certain existing tax measures while offering a normative framework for future reforms that is independent of an (often imperfect) justice-based rationale.

title: Labor Unions, Bargaining Power, and its Effects on Employment
affiliations: Pontifical Catholic University of Rio de Janeiro (PUC-Rio)

detail.title: Labor Unions, Bargaining Power, and its Effects on Employment
detail.abstract: This paper studies how firms respond to an increase in labor union bargaining power. I begin with a simple dynamic model when firms face tenure-based adjustment costs and anticipate higher future liabilities. The model predicts that firms respond by adjusting the composition of their workforce. I test these predictions exploiting the 2012 introduction of mandatory ultractivity in Brazilian collective bargaining agreements, which extended the terms of expired contracts until a new one is signed. Using staggered treatment timing and a difference-indifferences design, I find that firms after exposure to an ultractivity CBA reduce hiring by 9%, with no change in overall separations. However, separations rise among hightenure and production workers and fall among low-tenure employees. The findings support model's prediction and suggest that stronger union protections can lead to unintended firm behavior, with trade-offs between job security and employment opportunities.

title: Local versus central public land governance: evidence from the spatial analysis of land auctions in Ukraine
affiliations: Kyiv School of Economics and Kyiv School of Economics

detail.title: Local versus central public land governance: evidence from the spatial analysis of land auctions in Ukraine
detail.abstract: Who is better in managing public land-local or central governments? We are looking at this empirical issue by using the web-scrapped universe of the data on farmland rental auctions in Ukraine that could be organized either by local or central governments. On average, auctions organized by local councils are 24 percentage points are more likely to result in a successful transaction, in 28% higher land rental prices and 62% larger price increase during the bidding phase of the auction than those organized by the central government. We explain these results by systematic differences in incentives and accountability behind the organizers.

reference: in Fairness and International Taxation, Ira K. Lindsay and Benita Mathew, eds. (Hart Publishing, 2025).
title: Justice as Mutual Advantage in International Taxation
affiliations: University of Surrey - School of Law

detail.title: Justice as Mutual Advantage in International Taxation

publicationDetails.detailsText: in Fairness and International Taxation, Ira K. Lindsay and Benita Mathew, eds. (Hart Publishing, 2025).

detail.abstract: The international tax policy landscape is evolving from one in which international cooperation was limited in scope and focused on preventing double-taxation to one with much greater ambitions for limiting tax competition and allocating taxation rights between jurisdictions.  This new context calls for new approaches to fairness in international taxation.  Traditional approaches to normative analysis of international tax, such as tax neutrality principles, do not provide a unique solution for the question of how to divide tax revenue between states.  The leading theories of distributive justice in political philosophy, including both egalitarian theories and consequentialist theories, are unlikely to yield workable principles of tax fairness because they are not well-suited to contexts where agreements are negotiated by governments accountable to their own citizens.  Justice as mutual advantage, which represents one strand of the social contract tradition dating back to Thomas Hobbes and David Hume, provides a middle path between international altruism and the unbridled pursuit of self-interest.  Just rules are those that divide the gains from cooperation in a way that benefits all cooperators and provide each with a reason to support the cooperative scheme.  What is fair in international tax policy depends upon the antecedent interests of various countries, their degree of bargaining power, and the scope of potential gains from tax co-operation. Fair rules give states that uphold the rules some combination of greater tax revenue and higher economic growth than they would otherwise enjoy and allocate these gains so that no state can expect to negotiate a better deal if it undermines the rules.  Justice as mutual advantage may require that nations that otherwise might benefit from tax competition receive compensation for agreeing to rules that restrict their right to use tax incentives to attract inbound investment. It differs from more ambitious theories in permitting pre-existing inequalities in entitlements and bargaining power to influence the outcome of agreements.  Because it is parsimonious in its moral commitments, it can identify agreements that partisans of greatly differing theories of justice can agree are unjust.  Justice as mutual advantage thus tempers self-interest and facilitates cooperation without demanding a level of sacrifice that makes adoption implausible under the current institutional order.

title: Can Artificial Intelligence Help Fight Climate Change?
affiliations: National Chengchi University , National Taiwan University and National Central University - Department of Finance

detail.title: Can Artificial Intelligence Help Fight Climate Change?
detail.abstract: Firms with greater AI adoption, measured by the proportion of AI specialists among employees, exhibit lower carbon emissions. A difference-indifferences analysis around Google's 2015 TensorFlow release supports a causal link. AI enables firms to improve climate-related innovation, management practices, and disclosure quality. AI also helps reduce climate-related environmental violations and mitigate negative capital market outcomes faced by highemission firms, including valuation discounts, reduced green institutional ownership, and lower analyst forecast accuracy. However, firms that have poor ESG performance or use AI for operational expansion exhibit increased emissions. These findings highlight the dual roles of AI in corporate decarbonization.

title: Term-Structure of Equity Risk and the Cross-Section of Currency Returns
affiliations: Insper Institute of Education and Research

detail.title: Term-Structure of Equity Risk and the Cross-Section of Currency Returns
detail.abstract: We use the term-structure of equity risk to build novel currency risk factors and show that they are priced in the cross-section of currency returns. Currencies more exposed to the level and curvature risk-factors offer a lower risk premium, while those more exposed to the slope factor offer a higher risk-premium. A portfolio that buys the high risk factor exposure currencies and shorts the low risk factor exposure currencies captures risk-return dispersion, and the excess returns of these strategies can be understood as compensation for a globally traded shock. We rationalize the results with a reduced form SDF model.

title: A Simulation Experiment on a Built-In Self Test Equipped with Pseudorandom Test Pattern Generator and Multi-Input Shift Register (MISR)
affiliations: Sultan Qaboos University - Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering

detail.title: A Simulation Experiment on a Built-In Self Test Equipped with Pseudorandom Test Pattern Generator and Multi-Input Shift Register (MISR)
detail.abstract: This paper investigates the impact of the changes of the characteristic polynomials and initial loadings, on behaviour of aliasing errors of parallel signature analyzer (Multi-Input Shift Register), used in an LFSR based digital circuit testing technique. The investigation is carried-out through an extensive simulation study of the effectiveness of the LFSR based digital circuit testing technique. The results of the study show that when the identical characteristic polynomials of order n are used in both pseudo-random test-pattern generator, as well as in Multi-Input Shift Register (MISR) signature analyzer (parallel type) then the probability of aliasing errors remains unchanged due to the changes in the initial loadings of the pseudo-random test-pattern generator.

title: Historical Foundations of STEM/STEAM Technologies in Education: A Semiotic Perspective
affiliations: Saratov State Academy of Law

detail.title: Historical Foundations of STEM/STEAM Technologies in Education: A Semiotic Perspective

declarations.declarationOfInterest: no interest

detail.abstract: STEM technologies have emerged as one of the most widely discussed topics in contemporary educational discourse, valued for their interdisciplinarity, emphasis on innovation, and encouragement of creativity. STEM and its expanded version, STEAM, are increasingly recognized as central to 21st-century educational innovation. This paper analyzes the historical foundations of these approaches through the lens of semiotics-a methodological framework that transcends disciplinary boundaries. By comparing the development of STEM/STEAM with the historical evolution of European educational systems, the study demonstrates that these modern educational models are deeply rooted in philosophical and scientific traditions. Drawing from semiotic and comparativehistorical methodologies, the analysis highlights mathematics as a central and historically privileged element, tracing its conceptual origins from ancient philosophy to modern science. The paper concludes with a forward-looking perspective, suggesting the likely incorporation of psychological and social sciences into the STEAM framework, following patterns observed in its historical development.
