title: Strategic Intelligence in Market Design: Integrating Econometrics, Machine Learning, and Game Theory for Innovation-Driven Decision Making
affiliations: Independent

detail.title: Strategic Intelligence in Market Design: Integrating Econometrics, Machine Learning, and Game Theory for Innovation-Driven Decision Making

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The author declares that there are no conflicts of interest—financial, personal, or institutional—that could be perceived as influencing the objectivity, integrity, or outcomes of this study. This work was undertaken independently and reflects the sole intellectual contribution of the author.
declarations.ethicsApproval: This study did not involve human participants, patient data, or sensitive personal information. As such, formal ethics approval was not required. The research adheres to the principles of academic integrity and responsible scholarship.
declarations.funderStatement: This research did not receive any specific grant from funding agencies in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors. It was self-funded as part of the author's independent scholarly exploration.

detail.abstract: In an era defined by market turbulence, digital disruption, and relentless innovation, the need for strategic intelligence in decision-making has never been more pressing. Traditional marketing approaches rooted in economic rationality are increasingly challenged by the complex dynamics of contemporary consumer behavior, competitive agility, and technological acceleration. This paper proposes an integrative framework that synthesizes econometrics, machine learning, and game theory to support innovation-driven decision-making in strategic marketing and entrepreneurial contexts. Econometrics provides a rigorous foundation for understanding demand, pricing elasticity, and market structure through empirical data analysis. However, its static assumptions and linear logic often fall short in capturing non-linear consumer patterns. Machine learning addresses this limitation by enabling real-time, adaptive insights from unstructured and high-dimensional data. Its predictive power enhances segmentation, personalization, and retention strategies, allowing firms to navigate volatile markets with greater precision. Complementing both is game theory, which models strategic interdependencies among market actors. From pricing wars to innovation races, game-theoretic logic uncovers the deeper strategic incentives that drive decision-making under uncertainty and competition. This triadic integration enables firms not only to anticipate market movements but also to proactively design markets that align innovation, value creation, and competitive advantage in ways that can foster sustainable and socially responsible outcomes. The article develops a conceptual and methodological synthesis, using simulation and real-world data to compare the effectiveness of the integrated approach versus traditional methods. Findings indicate that strategic decisions informed by this integrative lens lead to higher agility, more robust innovation pathways, and improved performance metrics across diverse sectors, including those advancing environmental, social, and governance (ESG) goals. This research contributes to the emerging discourse on smart marketing ecosystems, responsible innovation, and computational decision-making. It invites scholars and practitioners to reconceptualize market design not merely as reactive forecasting, but as an intelligent, adaptive, and ethically-informed strategic process that can directly support sustainable and responsible investing.

title: Relative Valuation in Practice: A Hands-On Guide for Financial Modelling Using Excel
affiliations: ICFAI Business School (IBS) Hyderabad, India

detail.title: Relative Valuation in Practice: A Hands-On Guide for Financial Modelling Using Excel
detail.abstract: This guide offers a comprehensive and practitioner-oriented exploration of relative valuation, a cornerstone of modern equity analysis and corporate finance. Emphasizing simplicity, speed, and market relevance, relative valuation estimates a firm's value by comparing its financial multiples to those of peer companies. Unlike intrinsic valuation methods that require forecasting future cash flows, this approach leverages observable market data-such as price-to-earnings (P/E), EV/EBITDA, and price-to-book (P/B) ratios-to infer fair value. The book meticulously outlines the strengths and limitations of each multiple, provides guidance on industry-specific metrics, and highlights the critical importance of selecting appropriate peer groups. Through Excel-based modeling, readers learn to construct valuation tables, perform scenario and sensitivity analyses, and derive valuation ranges with practical implications. A full case study on Dabur India Ltd. illustrates the real-world application of multiple-based valuation, reinforcing key concepts and emphasizing the role of judgment in financial modeling. This work is especially relevant in emerging markets where intrinsic valuation inputs are often unreliable, and market-based multiples offer a practical alternative. Overall, the guide bridges academic principles and practitioner tools, making it a valuable resource for students, analysts, and corporate finance professionals.

title: Dynamic Asset Allocation with Partially Reversible Retirement Decisions
affiliations: Department of Mathematics, KAIST, Kyung Hee University - Department of Applied Mathematics  and Sungshin Women's University

detail.title: Dynamic Asset Allocation with Partially Reversible Retirement Decisions
detail.abstract: This paper studies a dynamic asset allocation problem with partially reversible retirement decisions, in which individuals can transition between working and retirement by incurring fixed reemployment costs. While retirement offers greater utility per unit of consumption but lower income, reemployment entails both financial and psychological costs, creating trade-offs that influence optimal decision-making. Building on the utility-based frameworks of Farhi and Panageas (2007) and Dybvig and Liu (2010), we extend the model to allow return-to-work options, incorporating switching costs and capturing richer utility dynamics. Using a dual-martingale approach, we reformulate the problem into an optimal switching problem, which leads to a system of variational inequalities characterizing the optimal strategies. Our analysis highlights how switching costs, utility gains from retirement, and income structures jointly shape retirement and reemployment behavior. Numerical results further illustrate the implications of partial reversibility, bridging the gap between irreversible and fully reversible retirement models.

title: Marxist Marginalism
affiliations: EURODOS

detail.title: Marxist Marginalism
detail.abstract: This short paper presents the Marxian value theory and its contradiction. As an alternative Marginalism is introduced and it is shown that the price of a commodity is equal to marginal labour value multiplied with the wage rate. Furthermore, the theory of marginal productivity is criticised, and it is shown that the returns on capital consist of marginal labour units.

title: The Power of Position Sizing in Portfolio Management
affiliations: Columbia University - Columbia Business School

detail.title: The Power of Position Sizing in Portfolio Management
detail.abstract: Position sizing represents one of the most critical yet often overlooked aspects of successful portfolio management. While investors frequently focus on identifying winning investments or timing market entries, the decision of how much capital to allocate to each position can ultimately determine whether a portfolio thrives or merely survives market volatility. This fundamental discipline bridges the gap between investment theory and practical wealth preservation, serving as the primary mechanism through which investors control risk while optimizing returns. Whether for individual investors, hedge fund managers, or institutional portfolio managers, position sizing plays a critical role in preserving capital, optimizing returns, and navigating the inherent uncertainties of financial markets. This paper examines the theoretical and practical dimensions of position sizing, highlighting its role in risk management and portfolio optimization. We also evaluate common position sizing methodologies and their implications for portfolio management.

title: Struggling for creativity and the beauty of human error - copyright authorship meets generative AI and neuroscience
affiliations: University College London

detail.title: Struggling for creativity and the beauty of human error - copyright authorship meets generative AI and neuroscience
detail.abstract:
This paper explores the fundamental role of human error and struggle in the context of copyright-protectable works and sophisticated generative AI (genAI) technologies. While AI tools offer creators unprecedented assistance in eliminating mistakes and perfecting outputs, this paper argues that imperfection, frustration, and emotional complexity are not only central to the human creative process but are also normatively essential for authorship under copyright law.

Drawing from interdisciplinary insights and applying Jane C. Ginsburg’s benchmarks for originality (detailed conception and controlled execution) the paper demonstrates that genAI content fails to meet the threshold for authorship, primarily due to the absence of the controlled execution integral to human creativity. The paper then turns to the human nervous system in order to justify that such outcome is in fact normatively sound and does not require any legislative amendment. It brings evidence to this populated academic debate from the discipline of neuroscience.

Overall, the paper contends that copyright law should prioritise process over product, recognising creativity as deeply human, error-prone, and emotionally driven, in stark contrast to the sterile predictability of machine output.

title: Sources of Return Variation and Options Pricing: Evidence from Indian Options Market
affiliations: Indian Institute of Management Ahmedabad and Indian Institute of Management (IIM) Ahmedabad

detail.title: Sources of Return Variation and Options Pricing: Evidence from Indian Options Market
detail.abstract: This paper examines how the composition of stock return variation, driven by market-wide information, firm-specific information (public and private), or noise, influences investor perceptions of volatility and tail risk as reflected in the single-stock options (SSO) market. Using a structural VAR-based decomposition on Indian stocks from 2010-2024, we find that informed return variation is associated with lower implied volatility and tail risk, while noisy return variation increases both. Within the information component, market-wide information share increases perceived volatility and tail risks, while firm-specific information reduces both risks. Private firm-specific information plays a particularly important role in dampening perceived volatility and tail risk, while public information helps alleviate perceived left-tail risk, especially during crisis. These results highlight an unexplored aspect of rational pricing of risk in the SSO market, wherein market participants take into account the informational structure of underlying returns while pricing stock options.

title: Unifying DCF Valuation Across Traditional and Cryptoassets
affiliations: Independant

detail.title: Unifying DCF Valuation Across Traditional and Cryptoassets

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The author declares no competing financial or personal interests that could have influenced the research presented in this paper.
declarations.ethicsApproval: No ethical approval was required for this study, as it does not involve human participants, clinical data, or sensitive information. All data used are publicly available from financial markets or academic sources.
declarations.funderStatement: This research did not receive any specific grant from funding agencies in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.

detail.abstract: Discounted cash flow (DCF) valuation is often thought to apply only to income-generating assets. This paper challenges that view by introducing a dual-risk valuation framework that extends DCF logic to assets with arbitrary monetization formats, including cryptocurrencies. The framework separates two structural primitives: a benchmark discount rate c, reflecting external opportunity cost, and a valuation distortion ratio K, capturing belief-based deviations from unbiased expectations. Their interaction yields an effective discount rate c_eff, which rationalizes investor-implied valuations while preserving structural consistency. We formalize this decomposition analytically, derive closed-form expressions for c_eff in terminal-value settings, and present a scalar approximation of fair value for multi-period cases with uniform expectations. This enables tractable valuation of cryptoassets such as Bitcoin, which lack income streams, and hybrid DeFi instruments that combine staking yields or synthetic cash flows with terminal resale value. The model also accommodates expectation heterogeneity and sentiment-driven mispricing by explicitly quantifying informational risk. By grounding DCF in structural opportunity cost and empirical expectation divergence, this approach dissolves the traditional dichotomy between productive and nonproductive assets. It provides a unified, interpretable, and empirically implementable valuation framework suitable for both traditional and blockchain-based assets.

title: Statistical vs. Operational Model Selection: The Value of Model Misspecification in Algorithmic Hiring
affiliations: The University of Hong Kong - Faculty of Business and Economics, The University of Hong Kong - Faculty of Business and Economics and University of Michigan, Stephen M. Ross School of Business

detail.title: Statistical vs. Operational Model Selection: The Value of Model Misspecification in Algorithmic Hiring
detail.abstract: Algorithmic screening plays an increasingly central role in modern recruitment, yet how firms should select model complexity to improve hiring outcomes remains unclear. This study reframes model selection as a strategic design choice shaped by two foundational trade-offs: the classical bias–variance trade-off from statistical learning and a benefit–penalty trade-off that links classification outcomes—true and false positives and negatives—to operational payoffs. We develop a theoretical framework in which firms estimate candidate expected quality using models that may be overspecified (including extraneous features) or underspecified (omitting relevant ones) relative to the ground-truth model. We show that overspecification can improve outcomes in moderately selective environments by amplifying quality dispersion and increasing true positives, while underspecification can reduce false positives and false negatives in high-selectivity settings by acting as a conservative filter. We further identify conditions under which a simpler or more complex model outperforms the other regardless of the ground-truth specification. Specifically, a simpler model is preferred when misclassification costs are high; a more complex model is preferred when the benefit of accurate identification of qualified candidates is high; and the correctly specified model is optimal when both misclassification costs and the benefit of accurate identification of qualified candidates are high. These findings overturn the classical presumption that correct specification is always optimal and demonstrate that model complexity should be treated as a context-sensitive design choice—one that links statistical estimation to operational payoff.

title: Reclaiming Human Learning in the Age of Generative AI: Reflections from Technology Entrepreneurship and Higher Education in the Philippines
affiliations: Ateneo de Manila University

detail.title: Reclaiming Human Learning in the Age of Generative AI: Reflections from Technology Entrepreneurship and Higher Education in the Philippines

declarations.ethicsApproval: Data collection protocols were approved by the University's Research Integrity Office. Client testimonial consent was also given.

detail.abstract:
As generative artificial intelligence becomes increasingly embedded in educational discourse and practice, two dominant narratives have emerged: one that celebrates its promise to make formal education obsolete, and another that resists its integration out of fear or uncertainty. Caught between these poles, educators are often portrayed as either out of touch or overly optimistic. This reflective position paper offers an alternative view based on grounded experience with the integration of large language models (LLMs) such as ChatGPT, Claude, and Gemini in both classroom instruction and student-led applied work in a Philippine university context.

Drawing from my role as Program Director and Lab Director at Ateneo de Manila University, I reflect on efforts to incorporate generative AI not as a replacement for education, but as a catalyst for developing deeper judgment, initiative, and social responsibility among students. Through the BUILD initiative, students are encouraged to engage with these tools in real-world settings, not simply to master them, but to critique, adapt, and apply them meaningfully. This paper also addresses internal forms of gatekeeping and institutional resistance, arguing that permission to build, fail, and reflect is essential for responsible AI learning.

Rather than framing AI education as a matter of technical training, I argue that it must foreground human discernment, ethical context, and social relevance. In contexts like the Philippines, where resource and access disparities remain, these dimensions are not optional. They are critical to ensuring that AI adoption in education serves more than efficiency. It must serve equity, learning, and agency.

title: A General Randomized Test for Alpha
affiliations: King's College London, University of Cambridge - Judge Business School, University of Leicester - School of Business and Erasmus University Rotterdam (EUR) - Erasmus School of Economics (ESE)

detail.title: A General Randomized Test for Alpha
detail.abstract: We propose a methodology to construct tests for the null hypothesis that the pricing errors of a panel of asset returns are jointly equal to zero in a linear factor asset pricing model - that is, the null of "zero alpha". We consider, as a leading example, a model with observable, tradable factors, but we also develop extensions to accommodate for non-tradable and latent factors. The test is based on equation-by-equation estimation, using a randomized version of the estimated alphas, which only requires rates of convergence. The distinct features of the proposed methodology are that it does not require the estimation of any covariance matrix, and that it allows for both N and T to pass to infinity, with the former possibly faster than the latter. Further, unlike extant approaches, the procedure can accommodate conditional heteroskedasticity, non-Gaussianity, and even strong cross-sectional dependence in the error terms. We also propose a de-randomized decision rule to choose in favor or against the correct specification of a linear factor pricing model. Monte Carlo simulations show that the test has satisfactory properties and it compares favorably to several existing tests. The usefulness of the testing procedure is illustrated through an application of linear factor pricing models to price the constituents of the S&P 500.

title: Do Investors Fully Understand the Seasonality in Accruals?
affiliations: King's College London, University of Houston - C.T. Bauer College of Business and Curtin University

detail.title: Do Investors Fully Understand the Seasonality in Accruals?
detail.abstract: Seasonal fluctuations in a firm's business activities can affect its balance sheet and give rise to seasonally predictable accruals. We find that seasonal patterns in accruals are associated with future stock returns. Specifically, we find that firms with historically lower (higher) accruals in a given fiscal quarter have higher (lower) stock returns in the months when those accruals are expected to be announced. Our results suggest that investors do not fully understand and price historical information on accruals seasonality. Additional analyses suggest that the emergence of this accruals seasonality anomaly is concentrated in the post-2001 period and driven by the effects of unsophisticated arbitrage against the accruals anomaly.

title: A CHECK-UP ON THE MONEY GROWTH AND INFLATION DYNAMICS IN NIGERIA
affiliations: University of Nigeria, University of Nigeria, Caritas University - Department of Banking and Finance, University of Nigeria and University of Nigeria

detail.title: A CHECK-UP ON THE MONEY GROWTH AND INFLATION DYNAMICS IN NIGERIA
detail.abstract: This study examined the correlation that exist among money growth and inflation rate in Nigeria by the use of a quarterly figures which spanned from:Q1-2017:Q4. We disaggregated money supply growth into broad money and narrow money growths to determine how each interacts with inflation. Different tests were employed to ascertain the extent of both the long term and short term relationship that among the variables. The outcomes showed a that there is long run relationship among them. The granger causality test which was employed to look at the short term relationship was able to find there is no causality between money growth and inflation. However, it found a one directional causality that ran from inflation to narrow and broad money g rowths in Nigeria during the period under review. We, therefore, settle that historical evidence on inflation is important in forecasting money growth. Thus, we note that inflation and its properties have a substantial influence on the trend of money growth. We therefore, recommend that the monetary authorities pursue inflation targeting while also using indirect monetary policy tools to check the growth in the moneystock

title: The Limits of Behavioral Law and Economics' Predictive Power
affiliations: University of Galway - School of Law

detail.title: The Limits of Behavioral Law and Economics' Predictive Power
detail.abstract: Behavioral economics' most severe criticism is that it lacks a coherent theory for predicting when irrationality will govern decision-making. BE is often therefore identified as a body of anomalies residual or exceptional to rational choice theory. This Article answers the question of why this is the case and does so by distinguishing between two types of predictive power-endogenous and exogenous. In lacking any normative foundation, behavioral economics is limited to the latter, which illuminates not only its theoretical limits but also why such exogeneity may be incompatible with a legal system based on general and uniform governance structures. The Article thus clarifies this long-running question of not only why behavioral economics is the residual of rational choice but also why it should be.

title: The impact of MiFID II on SME and fixed income investment research
affiliations: Risk Control Limited

detail.title: The impact of MiFID II on SME and fixed income investment research
detail.abstract:
The MiFID II rules on unbundling payments for research1 and execution have brought major changes to the European market for investment research. This study combines statistical analysis, surveys, interviews and legal analysis to shed light on how MiFID II has affected the research market, particularly for Small and Medium Enterprise (SME) and corporate bond issuers. 

The study shows that MiFID II reduced research budgets and lowered equity research prices particularly for larger investment firms. Research coverage and volumes for European equities have trended down for several years. MiFID II coincided with an increase in this decline for European SMEs although some of the decline may reflect cyclical effects. Research quality has not been systematically affected by the introduction of MiFID II unbundling. 

An area in which MiFID II seems to have produced structural shifts in behaviour is Fixed Income (FI) where published research volumes are lower and some providers have moved towards a strategy-analyst approach and reduced their use of publishing researchers. Also, the Investor Relations (IR) activities of issuers have been affected by MiFID II as the traditional role of brokers in facilitating contacts has been impeded, particularly in the case of contacts with foreign investors. 

This study examines the current state of SME-related investment research across European Union (EU) countries and the effect on such research of MiFID II. An important question for future study is what policy measures could be taken to increase SME investment research levels and reduce the large imbalances across countries and regions.

title: Waves, Quantum Theory, and Retail Credit
affiliations: Independent

detail.title: Waves, Quantum Theory, and Retail Credit

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The research was paid for by Agora Data as Dimitri Bianco is the Head of Quantitative Risk and Research at Agora Data. Some of the methodologies presented in the paper are being used at the firm.
declarations.funderStatement: Agora Data is the employer of Dimitri Bianco and has paid him to conduct research which includes this paper.

detail.abstract:
Retail credit modeling for losses started with simple rules and scorecards where business intuition and experience was used to generate simple monotonic or linear relationships such as consumer income where the lower the income the higher the expected loss. Next came computers and the addition of statistical models such as logistic regression. Bureau data and internal data could now be used in a more rigorous framework where the weights of different consumer characteristics such as income, past loan default history, number of inquiries on checking accounts or loan products, tradeline details, or contact information were determined by statistical theory and not solely on opinions of how to weigh them in an expert opinion scorecard (known as EJM, expert judgement model). Increases in regulations such as Basel II and IFRS 9 have also driven the demand for credit modeling (Siddiqi 2-5). Finally, machine learning was slowly adapted through decision trees for fraud modeling with products such as Angoss and really took off with easy access to machine learning development through Python. Machine learning has been the main topic in retail credit modeling in 2025 however there are many parallels to modeling retail credit in waves and leaning on quantum theory for a deeper understanding on retail credit while enhancing model predictability leading to a market edge and more efficient credit markets for consumers. This approach is only becoming possible through more granular transaction level data from companies such as Finicity and Plaid. Consumers have also gotten used to sharing their private information as a way to make products cheaper such as insurance or to enhance their experience with social media platforms. This paper will explore some of the ideas behind modeling retail credit as wave functions and a loose parallel to quantum superposition. More research is needed from banks and financial institutions who have access to this sort of transaction level data.

This paper and the ideas behind it are not intended to claim or state that credit markets are driven by a hard science such as physics. The intent of the paper is to draw ideas from modeling methodologies from physics as a new way to approach retail credit problems. Financial markets and consumers are too complex for a simple closed form solution. The ideas and modeling within this paper will deviate from physics as there is no intention to stick to the rules and laws of physics.

title: Risk Transfer for Multilateral Development Banks: Obstacles and Potential
affiliations: International Finance Corporations (IFC), Risk Control Limited, Center for Global Development and African Development Bank

detail.title: Risk Transfer for Multilateral Development Banks: Obstacles and Potential
detail.abstract: Long-term development finance provided by Multilateral Development Banks (MDBs) is key to advancing the United Nations’ 2015 Sustainable Development Goals. However, MDBs are constrained in their lending by the availability of capital. This paper argues that Risk Transfer, as a complement to equity injections, could permit higher MDB lending by attracting a broader class of investors. We describe selected examples of actual Risk Transfer transactions and provide estimates of the potential expansion in lending these techniques could yield. But we also identify obstacles that limit investors’ willingness and ability to participate in these transactions. Therefore, we recommend an agenda for international policymakers to open the way for the wider use of Risk Transfer. Still, we recognize this will be a gradual process which cannot substitute for MDB expansion through additional ordinary capital resources.

title: Infrastructure Debt Capital Charges for Insurers
affiliations: Risk Control Limited and Risk Control Limited

detail.title: Infrastructure Debt Capital Charges for Insurers
detail.abstract:
This study examines whether capital charges for infrastructure debt should be lower than the charges currently required by the Solvency II and IAIS regulatory frameworks. This question is important as (i) infrastructure investment is widely viewed as a key component of economic development and (ii) historical data on infrastructure debt strongly suggests that this class of corporate debt is much less risky than, for example, corporate bonds.

The European Authorities regarded the issue as so important that they reopened the calibration of the Solvency II charges late in the development of that framework and adopted somewhat lower charges for a restricted category of infrastructure debt. So far, the IAIS in developing its International Capital Standard (ICS) has not made any concession to the low credit risk nature of infrastructure loans.

This report revisits the calibration of Solvency II and the ICS, deducing capital charges for credit exposures with the superior credit performance of infrastructure loans. The calibration approaches adopted are designed to be as close possible in spirit and approach to those apparently used by the regulatory authorities (EIOPA in the case of Solvency II and the IAIS in the case of the ICS).

For the ICS charges, we perform a bottom up calibration using variants of the modelling approach (based on a well-known paper by Vasicek (2001)). For the Solvency II charges, we suppose that the current framework is correctly calibrated for corporate bond claims and then calculate what would be appropriate capital charges for other debt claims that have the historical credit performance observed for different categories of infrastructure loans. In both analyses, we build on past work by Jobst (2018) who studies infrastructure risk and capital charges in some detail.

An important aspect of the Solvency II capital charges is that they include a diversification adjustment that is specific to the balance sheet of the insurer performing the calculation. We calculate capital charges (i) for a purely specialist insurer only holding corporate debt and (ii) for a typical European life insurer with a balance sheet investigated in past studies by us and other authors (see Höring (2012) and Kutas, Perraudin and Qiu (2016)).

title: Spending Allocation under Nominal Uncertainty: A Model of Effective Price Rigidity
affiliations: HEC Paris and Einaudi Institute for Economics and Finance (EIEF)

detail.title: Spending Allocation under Nominal Uncertainty: A Model of Effective Price Rigidity
detail.abstract: How do swings in inflation affect shopping behavior? We build on the idea that households' price hunting intensifies with surprise inflation. In our model, households observe only local monopolists' prices and must exert effort to see other sellers' prices to eventually buy from them. This friction leads households to doubt that local price changes are idiosyncratic, even when all prices change uniformly in response to a nominal aggregate shock. In such a case, households overestimate the benefits of exerting effort, reallocating more spending toward lower-markup sellers. We show that, through this channel, output can expand significantly with surprise inflation, despite flexible shop pricing and acyclical posted markups. Using U.S. retailer scanner data, we validate our model's distinctive prediction that inflation measured over paid prices moves more slowly than inflation measured over posted prices, both unconditionally and in response to monetary policy shocks.

title: Carbon Overhang: Valuing Corporate Exposure to Future Carbon Costs
affiliations: University of California, Berkeley - Haas School of Business, University of California, Berkeley - Haas School of Business and University of California, Berkeley - Haas School of Business

detail.title: Carbon Overhang: Valuing Corporate Exposure to Future Carbon Costs
detail.abstract: This study develops a forward-looking valuation framework to quantify firm-level exposure to future carbon costs. We introduce the Carbon Overhang (COH) metric, defined as the present value of future carbon costs based on firm-level emissions projections and jurisdiction-specific carbon prices. Applying this framework to U.S.-listed firms, we estimate a market-level COH of $2.4 to $4.1 trillion-equivalent to 5% to 9% of total market capitalization. The distribution of COH is highly concentrated, with the top 25 firms-mainly utilities and energy companies-accounting for over half of the total. Still, we find substantial variation within sectors, driven by differences in operational structure and emissions geography. Adjusting for carbon cost pass-through from upstream energy providers reallocates up to 70% of the COH away from regulated utilities and toward downstream customers. Importantly, even under the most ambitious policy scenario, we find that prevailing and anticipated carbon pricing mechanisms are expected to internalize only about half of the societal damages from corporate emissions. Overall, our framework underscores the importance of forward-looking and location-specific emissions and carbon price forecasts as essential inputs for integrating carbon risk into financial analysis and valuation.

title: Streams beneath the surface: The Macroeconomic Effects of Liquidity Regulation
affiliations: King's College London

detail.title: Streams beneath the surface: The Macroeconomic Effects of Liquidity Regulation
detail.abstract: This paper investigates the macroeconomic effects of liquidity regulation by studying changes in India's Statutory Liquidity Ratio (SLR) between 1951 and 2023. Using a narrative instrumental variables strategy to isolate exogenous policy shifts, combined with a local projections framework, I examine the dynamic effects of SLR changes on key macroeconomic and financial variables. The results indicate that increases in the SLR lead to a significant contraction in output in the medium run, alongside persistent inflationary pressures and a tightening of monetary and credit conditions. These effects are asymmetric: tightening actions produce strong and persistent macro-financial responses, while loosening actions yield muted effects. I identify two main transmission channels-portfolio reallocation on the asset side, with a shift from long-term to short-term lending, and adjustments in funding structure, including increased reliance on deposit mobilization and reduced use of money market borrowings. These findings provide fresh insights into the real effects of liquidity regulation, a dimension that remains relatively underexplored compared to its regulatory counterparts such as capital requirements.

reference: Canadian Tax Journal/Revue fiscale canadienne, Vol. 72, No. 4, 2024, p. 825-835
title: Policy Forum: The Role of Critical Questions in Tax Policy Analysis
affiliations: McGill University - Faculty of Law and University of Ottawa - Common Law Section

detail.title: Policy Forum: The Role of Critical Questions in Tax Policy Analysis

publicationDetails.detailsText: Canadian Tax Journal/Revue fiscale canadienne, Vol. 72, No. 4, 2024, p. 825-835
publicationDetails.journalName: Canadian Tax Foundation (CTF) Research Paper Series

detail.abstract: This article explains what it means to ask critical tax questions, in order to show that critical tax studies are an essential component of good tax policy analysis. We demonstrate that, grounded in the three core tax policy principles of equity, neutrality, and simplicity, all tax policy analysis is critical by nature, and critical tax studies constitute no radical departure. By expressly reflecting upon whether and how a tax rule or tax regime affects people differently depending on their class, family structure, disability, race, gender, or sexual orientation, critical tax studies are instrumental in highlighting instances when these core tax policy principles are violated. Critical tax theory thus fosters rigorous tax policy analysis alongside analysis that focuses on doctrinal uncertainty, undesirable economic outcomes, and other topics. The article concludes that good tax policy discourse requires cultivating intellectual diversity, which necessitates asking critical tax questions.

title: Redesigning Higher Education for the 21st Century: Implementing a Flexible, Competency-Based, and Value-Driven Framework Aligned with NEP 2020
affiliations: Autonomous College

detail.title: Redesigning Higher Education for the 21st Century: Implementing a Flexible, Competency-Based, and Value-Driven Framework Aligned with NEP 2020
detail.abstract: To effectively implement NEP 2020, institutions must embrace innovative practices across key domains. Initiate interdisciplinary curricula fostering critical thinking, innovation, and valuebased learning. Modernize the teaching-learning process with technology-driven, studentcentric methodologies, coupled with formative assessments. Strengthen research and extension through innovation hubs and industry collaborations. Upgrade infrastructure with smart classrooms, e-libraries, and eco-friendly campuses. Prioritize student support with career counseling, skill-building, and flexible academic pathways. Promote participatory governance and ethical practices to ensure inclusivity and transparency. Establish robust quality assurance systems, leveraging feedback and analytics. By aligning these initiatives with NEP 2020, institutions can deliver holistic, future-ready education.

title: Navigating Gendered and Structural Barriers to Aspirations: Experiences of Youth in Kalyanpuri, New Delhi
affiliations: Institute of Social Studies Trust, Institute of Social Studies Trust and Institute of Social Studies Trust

detail.title: Navigating Gendered and Structural Barriers to Aspirations: Experiences of Youth in Kalyanpuri, New Delhi
detail.abstract: Adolescence is a period of intense change when young people begin to form aspirations shaped by their socio-economic realities. For adolescents and youth from underprivileged backgrounds, particularly girls, these aspirations are often constrained by limited resources, gender norms, and everyday violence. This report presents findings from research and programmatic work conducted by the Institute of Social Studies Trust (ISST) in Kalyanpuri, Delhi, through its Saathi and Yuva Saathi Centres. Using mixed methods—situational analysis, qualitative case studies, and participatory observations—the study explored how aspirations are formed and negotiated. While both girls and boys face structural barriers, girls contend with deeper restrictions on mobility, access to resources, and control over their agency and decision-making. Gendered violence, both within homes and in public spaces, further undermines their sense of agency and overall well-being. The findings underscore the importance of gender-sensitive, community-rooted interventions that expand adolescents’ real freedoms and choices, strengthen their capacity to aspire, and enable them—especially girls—to imagine and pursue more just and equitable futures.

title: Monitoring Real Estate Markets using Lag-Free House Price Indices *
affiliations: IOBE - Hellenic Foundation for Economic and Industrial Research, affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Monitoring Real Estate Markets using Lag-Free House Price Indices *
detail.abstract: House price cycles are usually larger than business cycles. Nevertheless, transitory shocks on the housing market can lead to adverse short-term effects and negative externalities. Therefore, it is important to monitor house prices in a frequent and granular fashion. In this paper, I construct lag-free house price indices across 14 EMU countries using web-scraped data and show that the data produce reliable lag-free indices that supplement the 1 to 2 quarters lag of Eurostat house price indices across Europe. Moreover, the high frequency, detailed house price indices enable the early detection of overheated markets from the country level (NUTS1) to a regional (NUTS3) geographical scale. The paper offers a quarterly and geographically granular monitoring tool of housing markets across Europe which can be useful for researchers and policy-makers alike.

reference: Laura Snyder, OBBBA: Remittance Tax Goes From Highly Problematic to Barely There, 188 Tax Notes Fed. 31 (July 7, 2025).
title: OBBBA: Remittance Tax Goes From Highly Problematic to Barely There
affiliations: Association of Americans Resident Overseas (AARO)

detail.title: OBBBA: Remittance Tax Goes From Highly Problematic to Barely There

publicationDetails.detailsText: Laura Snyder, OBBBA: Remittance Tax Goes From Highly Problematic to Barely There, 188 Tax Notes Fed. 31 (July 7, 2025).

detail.abstract: The various versions of One Big Beautiful Bill contained a tax on remittance transfers. This article compares the different versions of the tax as it was modified in each version of the bill. If it had been adopted, the House version of the bill would have been highly problematic for overseas Americans, among many others. The final version as contained in the bill signed into law on July 4, 2025 was dramatically scaled back as compared to the House version, but still victimizes the undocumented and the unbanked. It especially victimizes the intended recipients of remittance transfers - the poorest of the poor.

title: Counterparty Risk in MDB Exposure Exchange Agreements
affiliations: Risk Control Limited and Risk Control Limited

detail.title: Counterparty Risk in MDB Exposure Exchange Agreements
detail.abstract:
Multilateral Development Banks (MDBs) face significant concentration risk due to their lending patterns, often focused on a small number of sovereign borrowers. To mitigate this risk, MDBs have implemented Exposure Exchange Agreements (EEAs), a powerful tool for managing single name and geographical concentration. These bilateral agreements, first introduced in 2015, involve MDBs compensating each other in case of defaults on matched subsets of their portfolios. Initially, participating banks with identical credit ratings exchanged portfolios with matched Exposure at Default (EAD) and expected losses, disregarding counterparty risk.

However, the landscape is evolving as MDBs explore EEAs with differently rated counterparties, ranging from AAA to AA-. This shift raises crucial questions about how varying counterparty credit qualities impact deal participants’ risks. The challenge lies in determining appropriate EAD scaling for lower-rated MDBs relative to higher-rated ones, considering the dual risk of borrower default and counterparty failure.

To address this, a novel approach equalizes Expected Losses (EL) for both parties, accounting for counterparty risk. This method yields a simple closed-form equation for scaling factors, applicable in both provisioning and fair pricing approaches. The provisioning approach uses actual Probabilities of Default (PDs) and Loss Given Default (LGD) rates, while the fair pricing approach employs market-implied PDs.

Analysis reveals that scaling factors vary significantly between approaches and are influenced by the Weighted Average Life (WAL) of the EEA. For a 12.5-year WAL EEA, fair pricing approach scaling factors range from 10% to 50%, while provisioning approach factors are much lower at 1% to 3%. These findings provide crucial guidance for MDBs in structuring EEAs with differently rated counterparties, enabling more effective risk management and portfolio diversification.

title: Surplus Squeeze and Informational Hold-up
affiliations: University of York and Humboldt University Berlin

detail.title: Surplus Squeeze and Informational Hold-up
detail.abstract: We study a static bilateral trade setting with moral hazard, where a seller privately chooses quality and a buyer may pay to verify it. We show that buyer-side information acquisition can lead to informational holdup through a mechanism we call surplus squeezing: precise verification enables the seller to extract all buyer surplus, deterring inspection and causing trade to unravel. When verification is noisy, uncertainty preserves buyer surplus and sustains trade. Our framework highlights how strategic responses to learning can distort investment incentives, offering a new perspective on the limits of information precision in mitigating moral hazard.

title: The Return of the King: Political Conflict and Female Labour Force Participation in postwar Greece.
affiliations: University of Bamberg

detail.title: The Return of the King: Political Conflict and Female Labour Force Participation in postwar Greece.
detail.abstract: Little is known about the effects of political conflicts on the status of women in society. Polarizing attitudes might have a differential effect on women's lives after a conflict. To consider this, the case of Greece after the Second World War is exploited, when the country became highly polarized between left and right ideologies, resulting in a threeyear full-scale civil war. A referendum regarding the reinstatement of the monarchy is used as an indicator of political beliefs, and, in a difference-indifferences setting, it is demonstrated that 10% greater political opposition to the monarchy implied that female labour force participation was 1.4% higher after the war. A plausible mechanism is through conservative areas becoming more conservative and liberal areas becoming more liberal, and data on the construction of new churches, a conservative institution, are consistent with this hypothesis. Finally, it is found that these effects were persistent, as reflected by female labour force participation until 1981, and attitudes revealed in the European Value Survey of 1999.

title: Frontline Workers, Needs Interpretation, and Legitimacy in Elderly Care Policy
affiliations: Aalborg University - Faculty of Social Sciences

detail.title: Frontline Workers, Needs Interpretation, and Legitimacy in Elderly Care Policy
detail.abstract: What role should citizens and frontline workers be given in the development of eldercare policy? The dominant view attributes a limited role to them. However, it is important to note that this is a classic power struggle in the politics of needs: Who should be able to determine the legitimate needs of the welfare state? Many point to the relevance of Jürgen Habermas' complex theory development for clarifying legitimacy in the politics of needs. Drawing on Habermas' own thinking as well as the latest developments in elderly care, the article adds that we should have a sharper eye for the challenges to such cross-communication that arise from differences in positions of experience and understanding that are rooted in the degree of care dependency. This challenge opens up the possibility of attributing a special role to professionals in elderly care as bridge builders in the democratic discussion about the legitimacy of elderly care policy. However, this requires that they are also attributed a more active role as interpreters of needs in co-operation with citizens in need of care than current care policy attributes to them.

title: Politics of Restructuring and the Nigerian National Question

detail.title: Politics of Restructuring and the Nigerian National Question

detail.abstract: This study examined the prospect of further restructuring as a panacea for resolving the Nigerian National Question. It chronicled the various instances which restructuring has been carried out even before the country became independent till date. It was discovered that all those effort have not resolved the ethnic sentiments and agitations that has been the bane of social integration and national cohesion in Nigeria. Using the historical descriptive method, the paper recommended the constitution of a sovereign national conference to enable the various peoples that make up the polyglot called Nigeria to determine their fate and future.

title: Poverty and the Crisis of Democracy in Nigeria
affiliations: Akwa Ibom State University

detail.title: Poverty and the Crisis of Democracy in Nigeria

declarations.declarationOfInterest: None
declarations.ethicsApproval: Not Applicable
declarations.funderStatement: By the Researcher from personal funds

detail.abstract: With the triumph of capitalism over socialism and the consequent globalization of western democracy, the call for democratic governance is very strident, especially from the United States of America. Given also the benefits of democracy, this ideology of government seems more beneficial and even more attractive especially to countries like Nigeria that has hitherto been under years of military dictatorship. To this effect, Nigeria has severally experimented with democratic governments since independence. Past attempts were terminated by the military due to the failure of the politicians. But on May 29, 1999, the country successfully installed a democratically elected government.  Since then, Nigeria has had an unbroken 13 years of democratic government to date. This is the longest period in the history of Nigeria since independence. Unfortunately, after13 years of democratic governance, the expected benefits of democracy has eluded the citizenry. Democracy seems infeasible in Nigeria. Using the minimalist conception of democracy as a framework, the paper sought to discover why there is a crisis in Nigerian democratic experiment. The paper reveals that poverty is the major reason behind the failure of Nigerian democracy. Western democracy was implanted into a poor, weak and fragile economy with poor electorates that are handicapped to take informed decisions or make rational choice of leaders but are contrariwise susceptible to manipulations by politicians. The conclusion arrived at is that unless something is done to liberate the mass of the Nigerian electorate from poverty; democracy will remain infeasible in the country. It recommends a selfless leadership that will liberate the people from the throes of poverty and give them the strength of moral character to make rational and informed choice of leaders through the ballot.

title: Corporate culture of innovation in turbulent times: Insights from textual analysis
affiliations: NIDA Business School, National Institute of Development Administration (NIDA), Pennsylvania State University - School of Graduate Professional Studies (SGPS), Mahidol University International College (MUIC) and Sasin GIBA

detail.title: Corporate culture of innovation in turbulent times: Insights from textual analysis
detail.abstract:
Purpose
This study investigates the impact of economic policy uncertainty (EPU) on corporate innovation culture using a novel text-based measure derived from earnings call transcripts. Unlike traditional metrics that focus on R&D and patent counts, this approach captures the broader cultural emphasis on innovation within firms during uncertain economic times.

Design/Methodology
The study analyzes a comprehensive dataset of over 50,000 observations from 2001 to 2018. Multiple econometric methodologies—including propensity score matching, entropy balancing, and instrumental-variable analysis—are applied to enhance robustness and address potential endogeneity. The model incorporates firm-specific control variables and a time trend to capture shifts in innovation culture over time.

Findings
Results indicate a significant, negative relationship between EPU and corporate innovation culture, with a one standard deviation increase in EPU leading to a 4.8% decline in innovation culture. This effect persists across robustness checks, suggesting firms are cautious in innovation during uncertain periods. Although some adaptation occurs over time, the overall negative impact remains substantial, unaffected by firm characteristics such as profitability and leverage.

Originality
This research provides new insights by utilizing a text-based measure to assess the cultural dimensions of corporate innovation. The study contributes to literature on policy uncertainty by demonstrating its pervasive impact on innovation culture and offers valuable implications for managers and policymakers aiming to foster innovation resilience in turbulent environments

title: Recruitment on the Hot Seat: Hedge-Fund Activists Ignite Corporate Hiring Flows
affiliations: York University - Schulich School of Business

detail.title: Recruitment on the Hot Seat: Hedge-Fund Activists Ignite Corporate Hiring Flows
detail.abstract: We analyse how hedge-fund activism reshapes corporate hiring through granular job-posting records. Following a campaign, targeted firms increase both the creation and withdrawal of postings and keep advertisements open longer, signalling deliberate labour reallocation rather than indiscriminate cuts. This adjustment is most pronounced at firms with strong growth prospects and high labour intensity, turns negative when R&D commitments dominate, expands in fiercely competitive markets, and weakens when decision authority rests with a dual CEO-chair. These context-dependent effects intensify substantially when activists articulate a clear operational or strategic objective in their 13D filings. These patterns reconcile post-campaign productivity gains with observed workforce reductions, positioning job-posting dynamics as a real-time channel through which shareholder activism operates.

title: Financial Intermediation, Investment, and Monetary Policy
affiliations: Athens University of Economics and Business and Claremont McKenna College

detail.title: Financial Intermediation, Investment, and Monetary Policy
detail.abstract: We develop a search-theoretic monetary general equilibrium model in which the effective lower bound (ELB) on nominal interest rates arises endogenously from the interaction between banks and credit-dependent firms. A wedge between deposit and lending rates, driven by the financial market microstructure and firm characteristics, limits credit expansion as policy rates decline. The ELB -- a nominal rate below which monetary easing fails to stimulate output or investment -- is higher when bank market power is greater or firms face tighter borrowing constraints, highlighting the role of financial conditions for monetary policy transmission. Our findings -- theoretical and quantitative -- underscore the importance of financial intermediaries in shaping the ELB and support a complementary role for macroprudential regulation and standard monetary policy tools.

title: The Heterogeneous Effects of Financial Wealth on Housing Demand
affiliations: Neoma Business School and IESE Business School

detail.title: The Heterogeneous Effects of Financial Wealth on Housing Demand
detail.abstract: We document the relationship between equity markets and housing demand in the United States through the channel of household financial wealth. Equity market fluctuations affect household financial wealth and subsequently housing demand. Household financial wealth exposes local housing markets to equity market risks, increases expected housing returns, and drives up the comovement between local housing and equity markets. Households exhibit heterogeneous elasticities of housing demand with respect to financial wealth, which rise with income levels---thereby amplifying housing inequality during market upswings. Overall, our findings highlight financial wealth as a key driver of local housing market integration and a contributor to housing inequality.
