title: Educating Lawyers in the Digital Age: From Theory to Practice
affiliations: The British Institute of International and Comparative Law (BIICL)

detail.title: Educating Lawyers in the Digital Age: From Theory to Practice
detail.abstract:
This book examines how to make legal education more accessible across many jurisdictions by using online technologies, as well as how to make it more effective and relevant to legal practice. It takes a practical, design-based research approach to enhance and refine learning design principles for legal education.

Drawing on extensive research conducted at University College London, including interviews with legal practitioners, students, and educators, it explores what sets legal education apart from other fields. It identifies what works in online courses and offers strategies to bridge the gap between academic learning and real-world legal practice, making legal education more effective and affordable.

The book formulates seven essential legal skills and provides practical guidance on teaching these skills in both traditional and online learning environments. It also introduces a comprehensive set of learning design principles tailored to legal education. While the focus is on the legal field, the findings and recommendations have broader applications across various disciplines.

The book uses a designed-based approach to create an affordable online course with participants from around the globe and addresses several broad questions:
- What makes legal education distinct from other disciplines, and what is the role of online technologies in it
- How can legal education be more effective through online learning?
- What are the fundamental design principles for improving legal training through an online practice-oriented course for practitioners?
- How can course designers make online legal education more relevant and affordable?

Note that the document contains fragments of the book (not the entire book).

title: Invention vs. Discovery: A Patent Law Perspective
affiliations: National Law University and Judicial Academy Assam

detail.title: Invention vs. Discovery: A Patent Law Perspective
detail.abstract: This paper explores the nuanced distinction between invention and discovery within the context of patent law. While both concepts contribute to scientific progress, only inventions-which involve human ingenuity and industrial applicability-qualify for patent protection. The discussion integrates legal definitions, statutory frameworks, landmark international and Indian case law, and practical implications for researchers, innovators, and policymakers. The paper also outlines how the misunderstanding between invention and discovery can lead to failed patent claims and missed innovation opportunities, especially in biotechnology, pharmaceuticals, and traditional knowledge sectors.

title: Predictive Analytics for Business Strategy: Leveraging Machine Learning for Competitive Advantage
affiliations: Coventry University

detail.title: Predictive Analytics for Business Strategy: Leveraging Machine Learning for Competitive Advantage
detail.abstract: In today's dynamic business environment, the ability to anticipate future trends and make datadriven decisions is a critical determinant of competitive advantage. Predictive analyticspowered by machine learning (ML) algorithms-has emerged as a transformative tool in strategic planning, enabling businesses to extract actionable insights from vast and complex datasets. This paper explores how predictive analytics, integrated with machine learning techniques, is reshaping business strategy across industries. Drawing on recent empirical studies, case analyses, and technological developments, the research investigates key applications such as customer behavior modeling, demand forecasting, risk assessment, and operational optimization. The paper begins by establishing a theoretical framework that connects predictive analytics with strategic decision-making models. It then examines core machine learning methodologies-such as regression analysis, decision trees, neural networks, and ensemble models-that underpin predictive systems. Through cross-industry case studies, the research illustrates how organizations have effectively applied ML-driven analytics to gain foresight, improve agility, and outperform competitors in areas like finance, retail, and supply chain management. The study also addresses organizational and technological challenges, including data quality, algorithmic bias, skill gaps, and ethical considerations. A synthesis of findings reveals that the successful deployment of predictive analytics is not solely reliant on technology, but also on organizational readiness, leadership commitment, and a data-driven culture. By bridging technical innovation with strategic execution, this paper contributes to the understanding of predictive analytics as a key enabler of sustainable competitive advantage. It concludes with practical recommendations for business leaders seeking to embed predictive capabilities into their strategic frameworks, highlighting the evolving role of machine learning in shaping future-ready enterprises.

title: Intellectual Property Rights Provisions of Regional Trade Agreements Across ASEAN Countries
affiliations: AstraIA Gear

detail.title: Intellectual Property Rights Provisions of Regional Trade Agreements Across ASEAN Countries
detail.abstract: ASEAN's trade and economy are now undergoing digital transformation with significant growth in the online market. Technology and innovation play significant roles in the production of goods and services in all economic sectors of the region. ASEAN's Trade Agreements may facilitate the development of technology and innovation across their tariff systems applied to tech related products and services. Further, together with information technology agreements, such as the e-ASEAN Framework Agreement and the WTO's Information Technology Agreement, they create a framework to govern intellectual property rights (IPRs) which are the core element of the new technology generation and evolution. This analysis compares the non-binding instruments of the region and the provisions of its Mega-Regional Trade Agreements. Based on the initiative assessment of the impacts of regional instruments, the paper addresses the possibility to appraise the impacts of the Mega-Regional Agreements on the protection mechanisms of the IPRs under the different agreements of the ASEAN countries.

title: Greener Pensions, Greener Choices: Linking Investments to Sustainable Behavior
affiliations: Leibniz Institute for Financial Research SAFE, Aarhus University - CREATES and Aarhus University

detail.title: Greener Pensions, Greener Choices: Linking Investments to Sustainable Behavior
detail.abstract: This paper examines how offering sustainable investment options influences sustainable consumption behavior. We combine a natural experiment in which individuals receive an option to switch to a pension plan with a strong sustainability profile with detailed household register data. This sustainable option improves sustainable consumption, as reflected in electric vehicle adoption and reduced vehicle emissions. The effect is primarily driven by individuals who do not choose the sustainable plan. We show that making sustainable investment available can create positive spillover effects on other sustainable behaviors, highlighting the potential of financial tools to support broader societal change.

title: Chinese Corporate Biodiversity 2023 Data Update July 2025
affiliations: Capital University of Economics and Business, Capital University of Economics and Business and Trinity Business School, Trinity College Dublin

detail.title: Chinese Corporate Biodiversity 2023 Data Update July 2025
detail.abstract: This note provides an update to the data presented in He, Feng, Longxuan Chen, and Brian M. Lucey, “Chinese corporate biodiversity exposure,” Finance Research Letters 70 (2024): 106275

title: ESG Investing Trends in Emerging Markets: A Behavioral Finance Perspective
affiliations: Coventry University

detail.title: ESG Investing Trends in Emerging Markets: A Behavioral Finance Perspective
detail.abstract: Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) investing has gained substantial momentum across global financial markets, yet its adoption and dynamics in emerging economies remain complex and underexplored. This study investigates the evolving trends in ESG investing within emerging markets through the lens of behavioral finance, emphasizing how cognitive biases, investor psychology, and socio-cultural factors shape investment decisions. Drawing on empirical data, case studies, and recent ESG index performances, the research analyzes the behavioral drivers that influence ESG investment flows in regions such as Southeast Asia, Latin America, Africa, and Eastern Europe. Key behavioral constructsincluding herding behavior, loss aversion, overconfidence, and social norm adherence-are examined to understand how they affect ESG fund selection, risk perception, and portfolio rebalancing among retail and institutional investors. The study also explores how regulatory frameworks, media narratives, and digital platforms contribute to shaping ESG awareness and sentiment in these markets. It highlights notable disparities in ESG data availability, corporate transparency, and investor education that continue to pose challenges for ESG integration. Findings suggest that while ESG investing in emerging markets is rising, it is often driven by reactive behaviors rather than long-term sustainable convictions. Moreover, cultural and regional nuances play a significant role in defining what constitutes "ESG" in local contexts. By combining behavioral finance theory with ESG investment analytics, this paper provides nuanced insights for policymakers, asset managers, and educators seeking to enhance ESG adoption responsibly. Ultimately, the study underscores the importance of behavioral awareness, data integrity, and tailored communication strategies in bridging ESG investing with sustainable development in emerging economies.

title: Internet Appendix for "Volatility Disagreement and Asset Prices"
affiliations: Purdue University - Daniels School of Business and University of Colorado at Boulder - Leeds School of Business

detail.title: Internet Appendix for "Volatility Disagreement and Asset Prices"
detail.abstract: This Internet Appendix contains an analysis that examines the volatility derivatives market under mean disagreement, and an extension of our baseline analysis that features joint disagreement on mean and variance.

title: Bayesian Model Selection for Graphite Oxidation by Molecular Oxygen
affiliations: University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign, University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign and University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign

detail.title: Bayesian Model Selection for Graphite Oxidation by Molecular Oxygen
detail.abstract: New specialized experiments and Bayesian model selection and calibration methods are used to assess kinetics models for graphite oxidation at entry relevant pressures of 33 and 330 Pa and temperatures from 1100 to 2284 K. The three models evaluated are based on an existing model for air-carbon ablation. The experiments isolate high-temperature gas-surface interactions and mass loss, enabling low computational cost model evaluations and extensive statistical sampling. Influential reaction parameters are selected by global sensitivity analysis and parameter influence criteria. Bayesian inference is used for both parameter calibration and model class selection. The two models with dual adsorption mechanisms in which oxygen can adsorb strongly or weakly are shown to be more statistically plausible than the model with a single adsorption mechanism. Posterior distributions of calibration parameters are constructed to quantify parameter uncertainties and model errors.

title: Peer Effects in Electric Vehicle Adoption
affiliations: Pennsylvania State University

detail.title: Peer Effects in Electric Vehicle Adoption
detail.abstract: This paper quantifies peer effects of electric vehicles (EV) by area and subgroups in Michigan, USA. The peer effect has been widely used to explain consumer behavior, and it plays an important role in product adoption under imperfect information. Consumers may initially hesitate to purchase an EV; however, if they observe more EVs in their neighborhood, on the road, or in parking lots, their reluctance to buy one may be alleviated. I build a system of equations to identify peer effects from lagged cumulative EV adoption by area and subgroups of type and brand values, with other effects from charging stations and socio-economic controls. This paper provides evidence that peer effects from the cumulative adoption of a specific model play a substantial role in the new adoption of the same model. While peer effects also increase overall adoption within the same ZCTA, competing types or brand values negatively affect the adoption of new EVs. I discuss the implications of these findings and how they affect the real impact of subsidization with peer effects. This paper also finds that the impact of subsidization would be significantly larger when peer effects are considered.

title: Financial Innovations, Taxes, and the Growth of Finance
affiliations: Shinshu University, University of Tokyo and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Financial Innovations, Taxes, and the Growth of Finance
detail.abstract: Since 1980, the U.S. economy has experienced growth in finance, reflected in increases in the value-added of financial services and the overall value of financial assets. This growth has been linked to a rising share of mutual funds within financial assets and the relatively stable unit cost of finance. This paper develops an incomplete market dynamic general equilibrium model with an islands structure, where both idiosyncratic and islandlevel shocks affect firm productivity. In the model, households can hold three assets: (i) risky equity shares of individual firms; (ii) mutual fund shares, diversified bundles of these equities that hedge idiosyncratic but not island-level risk; and (iii) risk-free bonds. By incorporating declining transaction costs on mutual funds and personal and corporate income tax rates calibrated from data, this model can quantitatively explain these phenomena.

title: The Illusion of Free Electricity Household Responses to Solar Panel Program in Singapore
affiliations: National University of Singapore (NUS) and National University of Singapore (NUS) - Department of Real Estate

detail.title: The Illusion of Free Electricity Household Responses to Solar Panel Program in Singapore
detail.abstract: This paper investigates the impact of solar panel program announcements on household utility consumption. Using anonymized monthly block level electricity and water consumption data for each flat type from January 2011 to December 2020 in Singapore and a staggered difference-in-differences approach, we find that public housing buildings affected by the solar program tender announcements experience a 2.2% increase in monthly electricity consumption and a 2.4% increase in water consumption. We attribute this to a misconception about the financial benefits of solar energy, after ruling out alternative explanations such as changes in energy prices, wealth effects, and moral licensing. Our findings highlight the importance of effective information dissemination for the successful implementation of solar energy initiatives.

title: Milk and Dairy Consumption in Brazil: An Age-Related Analysis
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, Federal University of Juiz de Fora, Federal University of Juiz de Fora and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Milk and Dairy Consumption in Brazil: An Age-Related Analysis
detail.abstract: Dietary choices significantly impact health, with factors like age shaping food consumption patterns. Given the nutritional value of dairy and their relevance in Brazil, this study analyzed the influence of age on dairy consumption using data from the latest Consumer Expenditure Survey (POF). The Kruskal-Wallis and Mann-Whitney tests revealed significant differences among age groups where children and teenagers showed the highest total intake, while the elderly preferred fluid milk. Younger groups consumed more yogurt and dairy beverages. These results highlight age as a key factor in dairy consumption and reinforce dairy products as accessible, nutrient-rich foods suited to different life stages. The findings can support age-specific nutritional strategies, particularly for low-income groups, and assist the food industry in developing targeted products aligned with consumer needs and preferences.

title: Formation of International Environmental Agreements and Payoff Allocation
affiliations: Université Paris I Panthéon-Sorbonne - CERMSEM, Saint Petersburg State University, CNRS - Paris School of Economics and HEC Montreal - Department of Decision Sciences

detail.title: Formation of International Environmental Agreements and Payoff Allocation
detail.abstract: Dealing with climate change requires that all countries engage in costly efforts to reduce their emissions. The presence of negative externalities and strategic behavior have made game theory a natural paradigm to design an international environmental agreement (IEA) that codifies what countries should do. Considering that countries are sovereign and no supranational entity can impose an agreement, a stream of literature adopted a noncooperative mode of play to the formation of an environmental coalition. On the other hand, as joint optimization of all countries’ payoff leads to the best outcome, cooperative games approach has also been proposed to share the cost of climate change.In this paper, we propose a model of coalition formation that combines both cooperative and noncooperative modes of play. Starting from any given coalition, we implement a Markov process that shows sequentially which countries join or leave the coalition until reaching an absorbing state. All possible sequential scenarios are considered and an allocation to the player is made taking into account individual rationality. An illustration with vulnerable and invulnerable countries to pollution is given.

title: Characterizing Boundary Equilibria in Parallel All-pay Auctions
affiliations: University of Macau

detail.title: Characterizing Boundary Equilibria in Parallel All-pay Auctions
detail.abstract: We analyze boundary equilibria in parallel all-pay auctions, which are asymmetric in prize value, with players of multiple ability-levels. By boundary equilibria we mean those in which the players of one or more ability-levels strategically avoid at least one contest. We first show that if the player of a certain level avoids a contest, then any stronger player avoids it, and they avoid any contest with a still smaller prize as well. We then establish a sufficient and necessary condition for any possible boundary equilibrium to exist, and characterize the equilibrium participation and effort profiles. Among all the contests she possibly participates in, the top-level player assigns a greater probability to, and bids more aggressively in, a contest with a larger prize. Any nontop-level player behaves differently in the contests in each of which he is not necessarily a strongest contestant versus in those wherein he is certainly among the strongest. He is less (more) likely to participate in a contest with a larger prize within the former (latter) category, and bids with equal intensity across contests within the former but bids more aggressively in a contest with a larger prize within the latter. The social welfare at any equilibrium is entirely determined by the set of the contests that the bottom-level player possibly enters. In the interior equilibrium (everyone participates in each contest with strictly positive probability), all non-top-level players uniformly choose the same participation profile and the player of any such level bids equally aggressively across all contests.

reference: Yale Journal of Law & the Humanities, Vol. 36 (forthcoming 2025)
title: Yes, The Founders Were Originalists
affiliations: Harvard Law School and University of Chicago - Law School

detail.title: Yes, The Founders Were Originalists

publicationDetails.detailsText: Yale Journal of Law & the Humanities, Vol. 36 (forthcoming 2025)

detail.abstract:
Jonathan Gienapp's Against Constitutional Originalism accuses originalism of a kind of self-defeat, arguing that the Founders weren’t really originalists. But like Jeﬀerson Powell’s similar argument forty years ago, which encouraged a shift from original intent to original meaning, Gienapp’s work may only help along a similar shift, this time from original meaning to our original law.
Gienapp makes four main claims: that the Founders’ Constitution wasn’t conventional law; that the Founders couldn’t agree on how to read it; that much of their fundamental law was unwritten; and that no originalist theory can account for this. As we argue, the first claim is bunk; the second overstated; the third true, but no problem for originalism; and the fourth a theoretical claim that the book’s history utterly fails to defend. The Constitution was indeed law, understood as such by its contemporaries, and coexisting with other bodies of law in ways that originalists routinely respect. Far from proving the case against originalism, Against Constitutional Originalism only strengthens the case for originalism, done well.

title: Microfinance, Foreign Direct Investment and Decent Work in Nigeria: Macro Level Evidence
affiliations: University of Benin - Department of Economics & Statistics

detail.title: Microfinance, Foreign Direct Investment and Decent Work in Nigeria: Macro Level Evidence
detail.abstract: Decent work is an important agenda of the International Labour Organisation (ILO) and the United Nations (UN). Microfinance and FDI are two variables envisaged by the ILO to contribute to creation of decent work, especially in developing countries. Against this backdrop, this study examines the effects of microfinance and FDI on decent work in Nigeria, while controlling for the effects of commercial banks’ loans and advances and inclusive growth. In doing this, macro-level annual time series data covering the 1992-2022 period are analysed using various robust least squares (RLS) estimation techniques including the M-Estimation, S-Estimation and the MM-Estimation. The empirical evidence reveals negative and significant effects of microfinance banks’ loans and advances (MFBLA) on decent work, questioning the quality of work it may have contributed to proliferating. This suggests that at macro level, it may have contributed to the creation of more vulnerable employment, thus reducing the proportion of decent work in total employment in the country. FDI, commercial banks’ lending operations and inclusive growth are found to have been significant contributors to the creation of decent work in the country. These results are buttressed by evidence from the fully modified ordinary least squares (FMOLS) estimation. Based on the evidence, it is recommended that the nation’s financial sector be strengthened, and the lending institutions should make enterprise formalization and profitability important criteria for lending. It is also recommended that the government prioritises enhancing the attractiveness of the economy to foreign investment, while pursuing inclusive economic growth.

title: Horizon-specific information in option implied correlation
affiliations: SOAS University of London - Centre for Financial and Management Studies, University of Kent and University of Kent

detail.title: Horizon-specific information in option implied correlation

keywords: market return forecasting JEL Classifications: G11

detail.abstract: Option-implied correlation is an efficient predictor of market returns. We decompose implied correlation into its high-frequency and low-frequency components to examine whether its informational content is horizon-specific. We show that the highfrequency component is a robust predictor of market returns at shorter horizons, outperforming the original series of implied correlation. Similarly, the low-frequency component optimally predicts market returns at longer horizons. Decomposing implied correlation substantially improves out-of-sample predictions of market returns at horizons of up to one year.

title: Stock Price Prediction: An Integrated Review of Traditional and Modern Computational Models
affiliations: Banaras Hindu University (BHU) - Faculty of Commerce

detail.title: Stock Price Prediction: An Integrated Review of Traditional and Modern Computational Models
detail.abstract: Accurately predicting stock prices remains a critical challenge due to the market's inherently dynamic, non-linear, and stochastic behavior. This review presents a comprehensive evaluation of both traditional and modern computational models used in stock price forecasting. It examines statistical approaches such as ARMA, ARIMA, and ARIMA-GARCH, alongside machine learning techniques including Random Forest and Support Vector Machines. The review further explores the role of deep learning architectures-ANN, RNN, CNN, LSTM, and Transformer models-in capturing temporal and structural dependencies in financial data. Additionally, it investigates the growing use of reinforcement learning methods like Q-Learning, Deep Q-Networks (DQN), and Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO) for adaptive decision-making in trading environments. Finally, the review highlights the potential of generative models, particularly GAN and GAN-FD, for synthetic data generation and directional forecasting. By synthesizing findings across these domains, the paper offers critical insights into model capabilities, limitations, and suitability for various stock market scenarios, providing a solid foundation for future research and practical implementation.

title: How To Bet On Winners (and Losers)
affiliations: Universitat Pompeu Fabra (UPF) - Faculty of Economic and Business Sciences and ESADE Business School

detail.title: How To Bet On Winners (and Losers)
detail.abstract: We cast the construction of long-short portfolios as a statistical decision problem in which the investor seeks to buy the top-performing stocks (the "winners") and sell the worst-performing ones (the "losers") on the basis of stock characteristics. We derive the optimal portfolio selection rule implied by a loss function that accounts for different types of misclassification errors in portfolio construction. This approach leads to a return classification problem and the optimal rule buys or sells stocks based on their probabilities of being winners or losers, conditional on the stock characteristics. When returns are generated by an additive regression model and misclassification costs satisfy a symmetry condition, the optimal rule simplifies to the conventional sorting procedure based on expected returns. An empirical application using U.S. stock data shows that portfolios constructed using the optimal rule achieve higher Sharpe ratios compared to those built using conventional methods. Our results demonstrate that predictive signals in the cross-section of stock returns go beyond expected returns, and that properly optimized portfolio selection rules based on these signals can generate substantial economic value for investors.

title: Assessing Financial Mechanisms and their Co-Benefits for Mid-Term Transmission Grid Projects in Germany and the U.S
affiliations: RWTH Aachen University and RWTH Aachen University

detail.title: Assessing Financial Mechanisms and their Co-Benefits for Mid-Term Transmission Grid Projects in Germany and the U.S
detail.abstract: This work aims to explore financial mechanisms and their potential to maximize co-benefits for the mid-term rollout of transmission grid infrastructure. The research focuses on Germany and the U.S., examining options for mid-term capital injection into transmission development. The methodology includes case study identification and analysis, development of strategic criteria, criteria weighting and validation through expert interviews and formulation of a Multi-Criteria Decision Analysis framework. The work aims to qualitatively explore the potential of innovative financial mechanisms to accelerate transmission grid infrastructure development in the face of increasing energy demands and the sustainable energy transition to renewables.

title: Markets for Goods, Markets for Risk
affiliations: Stanford Graduate School of Business, Marshall School of Business - University of Southern California and University of Chicago - Booth School of Business

detail.title: Markets for Goods, Markets for Risk
detail.abstract: Spot markets facilitate allocative efficiency, reallocating goods to maximize society's money-equivalent wealth. Financial markets facilitate risk-sharing, redistributing optimized wealth according to consumers' risk preferences. When financial markets are incomplete, the wealth generated by efficient spot markets is not optimally shared across agents. Financial market incompleteness is not fully resolved by realistic financial securities, such as futures contracts. Market incompleteness implies that policies which distort spot market outcomes, but improve risk-sharing, can be welfare-improving. In our model, a widely criticized policy tool-commodity price controls-can be Pareto-improving, if it improves risk-sharing across agents sufficiently.

title: Factor Investing Lecture 6: Common Factors in China (Presentation Slides)
affiliations: Chinese University of Hong Kong, Shenzhen

detail.title: Factor Investing Lecture 6: Common Factors in China (Presentation Slides)
detail.abstract: These lecture notes are part of a course of The Chinese University of Hong Kong, Shenzhen on Factor Investing (DDA3600), offering a comprehensive introduction to the theory and practice of factor-based asset pricing. This lecture covers the essential data sources, including price, volume, and financial statement data, and explain practical issues such as price adjustment, handling missing values, and the treatment of untradable stocks. Methods for cleaning and preprocessing data, including outlier removal, standardization, and factor neutralization, are introduced to ensure robustness in empirical research. It then discusses the exclusion of problematic stocks and emphasizes the importance of understanding data vendor practices. Finally, the lecture systematically reviews key factors such as size, value and momentum, illustrating their empirical performance in China through portfolio sorts.

title: Distinguishing among remediation, reclamation, and offsetting in the pursuit of no net loss
affiliations: Poulton Environmental Strategies Inc. and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Distinguishing among remediation, reclamation, and offsetting in the pursuit of no net loss
detail.abstract: The mitigation hierarchy (avoid - minimize - remediate - offset) is a well-accepted framework for prioritizing impact mitigation measures. The roles of three kinds of habitat remediation are sometimes confused. Here we set out to distinguish among and compare "third step remediation" (3SR), the third step in the mitigation hierarchy, end-of-project reclamation/rehabilitation, and offsetting. The essential criteria for 3SR to contribute to no net loss of biodiversity are quality, quantity and timeliness, the last emphasizing the need to address biodiversity losses in a compressed timeframe. Using these criteria, we distinguish 3SR from end-of-project rehabilitation/ reclamation and from biodiversity offsetting, the fourth step of the mitigation hierarchy, and offsetting from end-of-project work. We briefly review two policies from Canada and Australia which unhelpfully blur these distinctions. We seek to provide greater clarity to assist all forms of mitigation measures to contribute optimally to the conservation of biodiversity.

title: Sentiment, Cryptocurrency and Inflation: A Transmission Chanel in Bolivia
affiliations: Analytics, Values and Intelligence Laboratory (AVI-Lab) and Ministerio de Economía y Finanzas Públicas

detail.title: Sentiment, Cryptocurrency and Inflation: A Transmission Chanel in Bolivia
detail.abstract: This paper examines the interplay between economic uncertainty sentiment, parallel cryptocurrency-based exchange rate, and inflation in Bolivia, leveraging high-frequency data and advanced econometric techniques. Following increased macroeconomic volatility from early 2023, Bolivia faced mounting pressure on its currency peg, leading to the rapid rise of stablecoins-particularly USDT-as alternative stores of value. Utilizing a dual methodological approach-a calibrated Dynamic Stochastic General Equilibrium (DSGE) model and a Bayesian Structural Vector Autoregression (BSVAR)-we identify a transmission mechanism where heightened uncertainty sentiment depreciates the parallel (digital) BOB/USDT exchange rate, amplifying inflationary pressures. Empirical impulse-response functions from daily data (January 2023 to April 2025) corroborate the model's predictions, showing significant and persistent inflation effects driven by sentiment shocks. Moreover, our findings underscore the stabilizing potential of monetary policy, even within Bolivia's constrained interest rate framework. This study offers critical insights for policymakers managing digital currency markets, emphasizing the need for real-time sentiment monitoring and proactive liquidity interventions to mitigate inflation risks.

title: Using Science Fiction in Technology Regulation: The PRISMS Approach
affiliations: Department of Economics, University of Leeds and University of Salford

detail.title: Using Science Fiction in Technology Regulation: The PRISMS Approach
detail.abstract:
How should new technologies be regulated? The inherent uncertainty of new technologies means regulation might stifle important innovations. But the social disruption new technologies can bring can also demand a regulatory response to protect citizens. This article proposes regulators increasingly draw upon science fiction media to predict how technologies might develop, and to build institutional capacity for navigating the uncertainty which new technologies create.

Science fiction is seeing adoption in various domains to support scenario planning and bolster resilience to uncertainty. This article develops the PRISMS approach as one way for regulators can apply science fiction media to questions of technology regulation. The PRISMS approach is utilised through a novel case study of commercial brain implants to demonstrate how science fiction can help regulators navigate the uncertainty created by this emergent technology.

title: Human Development Report 2025. A matter of choice: People and possibilities in the age of AI
affiliations: United Nations - Human Development Report Office

detail.title: Human Development Report 2025. A matter of choice: People and possibilities in the age of AI
detail.abstract:
The choices that people have and can realize, within ever expanding freedoms, are essential to human development, whose goal is for people to live lives they value and have reason to value. A world with AI is flush with choices the exercise of which is both a matter of human development and a means to advance it. The future is always up for grabs, even more so now. Trying to predict what will happen is self-defeating, privileging technology in a make-believe vacuum over the frictional realities and messier promises of people’s agency and their choices. From a human development perspective the relevant question instead is what choices can be made so AI works for people.

The 2025 Human Development Report examines what distinguishes this new era of AI from previous digital transformations and what those differences could mean for human development, including how AI can enhance or subvert human agency. People are already interacting with AI in different ways at different stages of life, in effect scoping out possibilities good and bad and underscoring how context and choices can make all the difference. Human agency is the price when people buy into AI hype, which can exacerbate exclusion and harm sustainability. And, of course, who produces AI and for what matter a lot for everyone. Letting people take the reins makes good sense, because they expect AI to be a growing part of their lives. A global survey for this Report found that, at all levels of the Human Development Index (HDI), AI use is already substantial (for about 20 percent of respondents) and is expected to shoot up fast. About two-thirds of respondents in low, medium and high HDI countries expect to use AI in education, health and work—the three HDI dimensions—within one year.

title: Monetary Policy and Rents
affiliations: Columbia University - Columbia Business School, University of Wisconsin at Madison and Columbia University

detail.title: Monetary Policy and Rents
detail.abstract: This paper studies the effects of monetary policy on housing rents. We provide comprehensive measures of rent inflation at a micro-geographic scale by constructing a new repeat-rent index. Using our rent index, we estimate the impulse responses of rents to monetary policy shocks by employing local projection methods. We find that monetary tightening increases both real and nominal rents. A 25 basis point increase in the 30-year fixed rate mortgage raises real (nominal) rents by 1.7 (1.4) percent 12-24 months following the monetary policy shock. The effect is driven by a shift in household demand from the owner-occupied market to the rental market. The increase in demand for rentals is accommodated by real-estate investors who capitalize on the higher rents. Our results highlight the distributional effects of monetary policy and call into question its capacity to effectively curb inflation.

title: Risk-scaled anomalies
affiliations: University of California at Irvine

detail.title: Risk-scaled anomalies
detail.abstract: Using a comprehensive set of 125 anomaly portfolios, I analyze the effectiveness of risk management. Volatility-managed portfolios are unlikely to produce greater alphas and Sharpe ratios relative to their original counterparts. Managed portfolio returns are 43% lower in the pre-sample and 61% lower in the post-sample, implying that the deteriorations in performance are present in the managed portfolio similar to the original portfolio. However, momentum-based strategies characterized by more negative skewness with a longer tail tend to improve after adjusting risk. The finding suggests that the benefits of risk management are concentrated on reducing crash risk.

title: Price Vs. Market-Cap-Weighted Portfolio Diversification: Does it Matter?
affiliations: Union University - School of Computing, University of Kragujevac, Union University - School of Computing and University of Sussex Business School

detail.title: Price Vs. Market-Cap-Weighted Portfolio Diversification: Does it Matter?
detail.abstract: We analyse the diversification profiles of price-weighted and market-capitalisationweighted portfolios. For that purpose, we compare the historical diversification levels of the Dow Jones Industrial Average (DJIA) and the Standard and Poor 500 (S&P500) indexes across three sets of portfolio diversification measures in different market regimes. We document different properties of the diversification measures, especially during crisis periods. To compare the indexes with different number of constituents we propose a novel approach called Exploited Diversification Potential (EDP). Our results suggest that the DJIA exploits its diversification potential better than the S&P 500. More generally, simulations show that price-weighted portfolios outperform market-capitalisation-weighted portfolios in terms of diversification potential. This result is robust to different portfolio cardinalities, simulation baskets, and sample selection cutoff periods.

title: Sparsity Tests for High-Dimensional Time Series Regressions
affiliations: University of Surrey - School of Economics, University of London and Goethe University Frankfurt

detail.title: Sparsity Tests for High-Dimensional Time Series Regressions
detail.abstract: Sparsity is a very important feature of data-rich environments. Its detection can motivate smaller, more interpretable econometric models. We propose a Hausman-type test for exact sparsity in high-dimensional linear time series models. The null hypothesis is that at most k 0 regressors have non-zero coefficients. We demonstrate how the test may be used in a sequential testing procedure, and extend its scope to accommodate data generating processes with weak or no correlation among the predictors. We establish the first order validity of block bootstrap critical values, and assess their finite sample properties via simulations. Empirically, we uncover evidence of very sparse models across a range of U.S. macroeconomic and financial target variables when using a large set of candidate predictor variables.

title: Vote Tourism: How Electoral Fraud Facilitates Elite Rent-sharing
affiliations: London School of Economics & Political Science (LSE) - Department of Government and Department of Veterans Affairs

detail.title: Vote Tourism: How Electoral Fraud Facilitates Elite Rent-sharing
detail.abstract: Why do local politicians undertake electoral fraud for national incumbents that does not yield electoral advantages? We propose that such fraud allows national leadership to screen which mayors are willing to cooperate with the regime in other domains such as rent extraction. Analyzing electoral and administrative data from Hungary, we observe that following the 2011 expansion of voting rights to diaspora populations, northeastern border settlements experienced significant increases in voter registrations without corresponding population growth. Employing a difference-indifferences design, we attribute these increases to mayors fraudulently registering diaspora voters. Utilities data corroborate the absence of actual migration, and electoral outcomes remained unaffected. Consistent with our theory, municipalities implicated in fraud received increased central government funding, and mayors allocated more procurement contracts to firms affiliated with the regime. These findings suggest that electorally inconsequential fraud can play a critical role in forging patronage networks essential to the stability of hybrid/authoritarian regimes.

title: Positive Feedback Shapes Gender Gaps in Adolescent Risk-taking - Causal Evidence from Real-risk Competitions
affiliations: Johannes Kepler University Linz and Fernuniversität in Hagen - University of Hagen

detail.title: Positive Feedback Shapes Gender Gaps in Adolescent Risk-taking - Causal Evidence from Real-risk Competitions

detail.abstract: This paper explores how positive feedback in a competitive setting shapes the evolution of gender differences in risk tolerance during adolescence. We use data from professional diving, a 'real life, real risk' environment where the notion of risk is very intuitive and associated with the height of the dive. We find that young divers are more engaged in high-risk (platform) competitions after their first win in a low-risk (springboard) competition. This effect is driven by individuals with no prior platform experience and is more pronounced for males: On average, male divers are 37% more likely to participate in platform diving after their first win compared to 10% for female divers. Additional findings indicate that the treatment intensity (for female divers) and the coach's gender (for male divers) are moderators of the effect.

title: Establishing a Baseline: Employment and Economic Profiling of the Night-time Economy in Data-sparse Irish Counties

detail.title: Establishing a Baseline: Employment and Economic Profiling of the Night-time Economy in Data-sparse Irish Counties

detail.abstract: Over the past twenty years, there has been steady growth in research and policy attention to the night-time economy (NTE), recognising its potential to support employment, drive local economic growth, and contribute to the social and cultural life of communities. However, across many counties in the Republic of Ireland, data on the NTE remains sparse, and baseline estimates are often missing. This lack of evidence makes it difficult to communicate the economic and employment-based benefits of the NTE to decision-makers. This whitepaper presents an initial attempt to address this gap by outlining a straightforward approach to profiling the NTE in underrepresented regions. By generating baseline estimates and insights, this work aims to support more informed planning and policy discussions at the county level and serve as a starting point for further data collection and analysis.

detail.abstract: This paper investigates the causal impact of mayor switches on district-level economic development in Uzbekistan from 2017 to 2023. I compile a novel dataset of mayor appointments across 208 districts and utilize nightlight luminosity data as a proxy for economic activity. Using a staggered difference-indifferences design, I find that districts that are experiencing new mayor appointments have a growth rate of nightlight luminosity around 31 ppts higher than in districts without such changes. This effect holds over several years and remains robust using a variety of estimation methods and controls. Further analyses reveal that part of the observed growth originates from expanding newly lit areas and increased local construction, highlighting infrastructure improvements as a driving force. Finally, I find personal attributes of newly appointed mayors condition the magnitude of the effect.

detail.abstract: India shows a clear cultural revolution in the 6 th century BCE in the form of Archaeology and History.This began in the Middle Ganga area but expanded over the Indian subcontinent within a few decades.Buddhism had a significant role in this cultural revolution, which affected India in many areas, including politics, economy, culture, and religion. Trade is also a part of the economy. "Uttarapatha" and "Dakshinapatha" were the most popular commerce routes during this time period. Most academics researched Uttarapatha and Dakshinapatha, but no research was done on the Rājagṛiha to Tāmraliptī trade route, which was the primary city of Buddhism and to the principal trading port in east India. this route was the historical marine and land trading routes along India's east coast. It is proven by the chronicles, jātakas, and archaeological findings which detail the interrelationship had with Buddhist monasteries and commerce guilds (Shreni). This trade route was more accurate in international trade as well as cultural exchanges during and as well as after the period of king Ashoka (3rd century BCE). And it continued until the end of the Pala period. This paper tries to trace this trade route which was knowingly or unknowingly hidden on the east coast of India.

title: Social Welfare and Filial Duties and Its Boundaries: A Political Philosophy Approach
affiliations: CSEF - University of Naples Federico II - Department of Political Science

detail.title: Social Welfare and Filial Duties and Its Boundaries: A Political Philosophy Approach
detail.abstract: This paper examines the boundaries of filial duty through the lens of political philosophy, focusing on contexts where social welfare systems are limited and familial support is treated as a moral or legal expectation. Using case studies from rural China, the Philippines, and Eastern Europe, it explores how filial obligations function as special obligations that may become involuntary and burdensome in the absence of adequate state support. The analysis draws on theorists such as Miller, Pogge, and Jeske to argue that while filial duties may originate from cultural norms or personal relationships, they can also enable structural inequalities and economic dependence. The paper proposes that filial responsibility should be reconsidered when it results in coercion or economic abuse, and highlights the need for a more balanced distribution of care between family and state institutions.

title: In Search of Common Factors in Commodity Markets: A Latent Factor Perspective
affiliations: University of North Carolina (UNC) at Charlotte - Finance, Zhejiang University - School of Economics and Academy of Financial Research, Shanghai Jiao Tong University (SJTU) - Shanghai Advanced Institute of Finance (SAIF) and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: In Search of Common Factors in Commodity Markets: A Latent Factor Perspective
detail.abstract: We propose a novel latent factor pricing model for commodity markets based on risk-premium principal component analysis (RP-PCA). Leveraging ten prominent commodity characteristics, we extract three latent factors. Our new model consistently outperforms the standard PCA model, as well as observed three-factor and six-factor models, in explaining commodity anomalies both in-sample and out-of-sample. Factor selection, spanning tests, and cross-sectional regressions confirm the robust pricing power of these new factors. Moreover, RP-PCA surpasses other latent factor models in pricing performance, and when combined with Instrumental PCA (IPCA), it further enhances the pricing of individual commodity returns. Additionally, RP-PCAbased factor timing strategies outperform static and PCA-based strategies. Overall, our analysis highlights the advantages of employing a latent factor approach to understand risk-return dynamics in commodity markets.

title: Elevating Spatial Evaluation: Satellite-Driven Confounder Adjustment
affiliations: Yale University - Yale School of Forestry & Environmental Science

detail.title: Elevating Spatial Evaluation: Satellite-Driven Confounder Adjustment
detail.abstract: Estimating causal effects of geospatial interventions, such as the presence of certain policies, on environmental, development, and conflict outcomes poses significant challenges. Traditional causal inference methods often fail to account for complex, hard-to-measure confounders in these settings. This paper proposes using satellite imagery and machine learning to adjust for confounders using a double machine learning approach. I demonstrate its effectiveness by conducting a Lalonde-style replication of findings from a land tenure RCT in Benin. The satellite double machine learning (S-DML) method recovers RCT treatment effects across multiple outcomes where traditional observational approaches fail. This approach offers several advantages: it leverages free satellite data, provides a computationally efficient way to process imagery, and enables evaluation of historical interventions. The S-DML method has broad potential applications in evaluating environmental policy, conflict, economic growth, and other spatial treatments where confounders may appear in satellite imagery.

title: The Impact of Disclosure on Diversity: Evidence from the Canada Business Corporations Act
affiliations: University of Oxford, Saïd Business School, University of Toronto - Rotman School of Management and University of Toronto - Rotman School of Management

detail.title: The Impact of Disclosure on Diversity: Evidence from the Canada Business Corporations Act
detail.abstract: We examine the impact of a 2020 "comply-or-explain" disclosure mandate implemented in Canada. This regulation imposed the first disclosure mandate extending beyond gender diversity to include racial diversity. Using federally registered public firms as a treatment group and provincially registered public firms as a control group, we establish two main findings. First, racial diversity increased among directors of firms subject to the disclosure mandate. Gender diversity also increased, but only for firms not subject to an earlier rule pertaining only to gender diversity. Second, the impact of the disclosure mandate is plausibly driven by shareholder monitoring, notably through director elections. Overall, our findings contribute to the policy debate on the effects of disclosure mandates on social dimensions.

title: Do Money Rules Outperform the Taylor rule?
affiliations: East Tennessee State University

detail.title: Do Money Rules Outperform the Taylor rule?
detail.abstract: This paper answers two questions: 1) Do money rules increase welfare as opposed to using the conventional Taylor rule? and 2) If so, when do these rules increase welfare? In an economy calibrated to match US data, we find that money rules do outperform the Taylor rule in terms of welfare. Among money rules, we see that a flexible money growth rule generates the highest welfare. This is followed by the Taylor rule with money and then the constant money growth rule. These results are robust to changes in model parameters. Next, we look at the impact of key monetary parameters on the welfare gains. We find that a low currency to deposit ratio, elasticity of substitution, reserves to money supply ratio, ratio of banking activities, and money supply to nominal consumption ratio are associated with higher welfare gains. Furthermore, the gains of using money rules are higher under monetary shocks as opposed to real shocks.

title: Commodities and Making of International Law in the Indian Ocean Region: A Historical Perspective
affiliations: Villa College (QI Campus)

detail.title: Commodities and Making of International Law in the Indian Ocean Region: A Historical Perspective

keywords: Early Modern History of Indian Ocean

detail.abstract:
The primary focus of this dissertation is interlinking the commodities that were traded in the Indian Ocean region to historical development of international law. This research attempts to cover the research gap in which the contributions made by countries of South Asia, is often overlooked in understanding the history of international law. The research seeks to identify how the commodities that were traded in the Indian Ocean region engaged in international law through transnational trade historically. A socio-legal approach was employed in carrying out the research, through the examination of various secondary resources such as books, historical texts and other journal articles which discussed the history of Indian Ocean trade, commodities that were traded by the South Asian countries and the engagement of transnational trade by these countries, through the lens of TWAIL (Third World Approach to International Law).

The findings of this research revealed that there was indeed a complex network of trade in the Indian Ocean region in the pre-modern era, which was regulated through the normative customs and rules of the countries of the region. It was also found that the countries in this region did not engage in trade similarly to the European countries. The main active players of the trade network were the ordinary merchants through establishment of thalassocracies, adopting various sorts of contracts with the societies of far-off distance lands and by engaging in diplomacy, for the ultimate goal yielding profit, despite the differences in culture, religion and societal norms.

title: Empowerment Through Education Among Tribal Women of Tripura

This paper makes an attempt to justify the over-all impact of tribal women’s education in

abundant problems of empowerment among the tribal women of Tripura.
It is observed that like other parts of India, Tripura also lacks in the field of tribal women’s

This paper also explains in detail about the social, cultural and economic impacts of the lives

title: The Impact of Partition of India on Tripura

detail.title: The Impact of Partition of India on Tripura
detail.abstract:
This paper makes an attempt to justify the over-all impact of Partition of India on Tripura.

India attained independence on 15th August, 1947 in the wake of Partition. Really, the

migration in the Princely state of Tripura.
It is observed that like other parts of India, Tripura also witnessed the worst effects of
Partition in the form of mass butchery of common people due to common riots, which
ultimately led to the outcome of the problem of the refugees. After independence, within a
decade or so, a great change came in the demography of Tripura as a result of heavy influx of
migrants from East Pakistan due to common violence. The partition of India disrupted the
chain of socio- economic relationship that Tripura built up with Colonial Bengal. Thus, it was
the worst impact of the Partition that the people of West Pakistan as well as East Pakistan
were compelled to be migrated into India in quest for peace and settlement to leave their
place of origin and to move towards their ‘uncertain home’ leaving behind them their all
ancestral property and even their personal identity. Before the Partition of India the tribal
population of the state formed the majority, but the Partition made them to the level of
minority.
This paper also explains in detail about the social, cultural and economic impacts of the
Partition of India on Tripura. The Partition of India deprived the state of its chief railheads in
East Pakistan so that the state was cut off from the rest of the country and resulted in a huge
infrastructural and economic setback for Tripura. As a matter of fact, the Partition of India
was a disaster for Tripura.

Actually, this is a kind of situation in which the tribals can retain their languages, myths, religion and social customs, while at the same time allowing themselves to a process of change in these matters. The initial contributors to this composite culture we are talking about are the early inhabitants of the land, whose origin may be traced to Indo-Mongloid blood and the people of surrounding areas- the Bengales. title: The EU Minimum Tax Directive-A conceptual discussion of a bold policy move
affiliations: Aalto, Business Law

detail.title: The EU Minimum Tax Directive-A conceptual discussion of a bold policy move
detail.abstract: The century old international tax system is in the middle of being rebuilt. In the ongoing multilateral efforts to reform international taxation to better accord with the challenges imposed by digitalisation and globalisation, the EU has taken in very active role. In the end of 2022, this has resulted in the adoption of the Minimum Tax Directive (2022/2325), which obliges EU Member States to implement the soft-law compromise achieved at the level of the OECD and the Inclusive Framework on Global Anti-Base Erosion (GLoBE) Model Rules. Particularly against the background of the EU's traditional reluctance to become active in this area, the author aims to contextualise this remarkable policy step in EU economic policy. The author demonstrates that implementing minimum taxation rules in the form of a legally binding and enforceable directive is, in principle, the proper thing to do in a setting characterised by heterogeneous interests of states and high tax competitive pressures. However, the institutional framework governing the implementation of the directive and its future development is not viable. Unanimous decision-making in the Council under Article 115 TFEU risks locking Member States into a specific version of an international soft law compromise, which continues to evolve outside the EU, without any guarantee that Member States will maintain consistent positions in this context. This reinforces the need for a serious debate on the adequacy of Article 115 TFEU as a legal basis for direct tax harmonisation. 1 | AN OUTDATED INTERNATIONAL TAX REGIME IN A CONTEXT OF GROWING MULTILATERALISM 1.1 | What are the challenges in international taxation? title: Joint Deep Calibration of the 4-Factor PDV Model
affiliations: Scuola Normale Superiore, University of Pavia - Department of Economics and Management and University of Bologna

detail.title: Joint Deep Calibration of the 4-Factor PDV Model
detail.abstract: Joint calibration to SPX and VIX market data is a delicate task that requires sophisticated modeling and incurs significant computational costs. The latter is especially true when pricing of volatility derivatives hinges on nested Monte Carlo simulation. One such example is the 4-factor Markov Path-Dependent Volatility (PDV) model of Guyon and Lekeufack (2023). Nonetheless, its realism has earned it considerable attention in recent years. Gazzani and Guyon (2025) marked a relevant contribution by learning the VIX as a random variable, i.e., a measurable function of the model parameters and the Markovian factors. A neural network replaces the inner simulation and makes the joint calibration problem accessible. However, the minimization loop remains slow due to expensive outer simulation. The present paper overcomes this limitation by learning SPX implied volatilities, VIX futures, and VIX call option prices. The pricing functions reduce to simple matrix-vector products that can be evaluated on the fly, shrinking calibration times to just a few seconds.

title: Green skills integration practices of student teachers and cooperating teachers among secondary schools: Basis for enhanced instructional plan
affiliations: Bataan Peninsula State University, Bataan, Philippines and Bataan Peninsula State University, Bataan, Philippines

detail.title: Green skills integration practices of student teachers and cooperating teachers among secondary schools: Basis for enhanced instructional plan
detail.abstract: Student teachers and cooperating teachers are mandated to teach and impart to students the needed skills for them to become environmentally conscious citizens upholding sustainable and economical practices. With that, the present study compares the green skills integration practices of student teachers and their cooperating teachers among secondary schools in a province in the Philippines as a basis for an enhanced instructional plan. The study utilizes the comparative design of quantitative research, wherein a questionnaire is used to gather data from 100 respondents (50 student teachers and 50 cooperating teachers) who voluntarily participated in the study. The study is implemented among public secondary schools in a province in the Philippines where the student teachers are deployed. As partners in the internship program, the cooperating teachers of the student teachers are included to compare their integration practices. A questionnaire is used to measure the green skills integration in the teaching practices. Descriptive statistics (mean and standard deviation) and inferential statistics (independent samples t-test) are used to analyze and identify significant differences in their integration practices. Findings reveal that cooperating teachers are more engaged in integrating green skills than student teachers, highlighting the need for enhanced training and support. A comprehensive learning plan, including targeted training and curriculum integration, is recommended to promote sustainable practices in education.

title: The paradoxical comparative statics of hypercongestion and traffic flow theory
affiliations: State University of New York at Buffalo

detail.title: The paradoxical comparative statics of hypercongestion and traffic flow theory
detail.abstract: We introduce physical highway capacity into the Greenshields-type continuous stationary state traffic flow model. With this extension, we study congested and hypercongested equilibria, without bottlenecks. The comparative statics of hypercongested equilibria with inelastic flow-demand yield paradoxes, because, ceteris paribus, less flow-demand or a wider highway (more lanes) cause traffic speed to be slower and traffic density to be higher. A formula relating the flow-demand elasticity, the elasticity of speed with respect to density and the elasticity of density with respect to highway capacity identifies which hypercongested equilibria are paradoxical. The paradoxes hold except when flow-demand is elastic enough. The paradoxes arise because the fundamental theory of traffic flow ignores that more flow-demand, given the highway's capacity, increases the mass of cars, and the density of traffic; or that more capacity given the flow-demand, decreases traffic density. This ignored relationship holds for congested but not for hypercongested traffic equilibria.

title: The Impact of Recent Changes on Philippine Education: A Five-Year Review and Forecast
affiliations: Far Eastern University, Far Eastern University, Far Eastern University, Far Eastern University, Far Eastern University, Far Eastern University and Far Eastern University

detail.title: The Impact of Recent Changes on Philippine Education: A Five-Year Review and Forecast
detail.abstract:
This research examines the relationship between the amount of government funding allocated to the SUCs and measurable relevant indicators of national and provincial educational performance in the Philippines as developments in the Educational Index, from 2020 to 2025. With recent education reforms in both the national budget with the Universal Access to Quality Tertiary Education Act and the refocusing of government spending priorities, this study will examine the connection between increasing appropriations for SUCs and increasing educational attainment. The study used available annual expenditure data for the ten largest SUCs and the yearly Educational Index score to identify a possible relationship using a simple linear regression model.

The six‐year regression yields a positive slope—each additional ₱1 billion in SUC spending corresponds to a 0.00297‐point increase in the Education Index—but the effect does not achieve statistical significance at conventional levels (p = 0.149, R² ≈ 0.26). Diagnostic tests, including residuals‐vs.‐fitted and normal Q–Q plots, support the adequacy of the linear specification and the validity of inferential statistics. Out‐of‐sample forecasts under a status‐quo budget trajectory predict the index will rise modestly from approximately 0.684 in 2024 to 0.708 by 2030. Overall, the study highlights that effective institutions and practice of policy are as relevant to efficacy as any explicit gains in relation to public investment in education, in addition to increasing funding for higher education.

title: Does Burnout hurt Performance? Experimental Evidence
affiliations: University of Arizona and  University of Arizona - Department of Agricultural and Resource Economics

detail.title: Does Burnout hurt Performance? Experimental Evidence
detail.abstract: Burnout is a phenomenon that has received significant attention in the past several decades. Meta-analyses indicate that burnout is associated with adverse consequences for performance. However, a major limitation of the current literature is that it is exclusively correlational. In this study, we conduct a laboratory experiment to acquire the first causal evidence regarding the effect of burnout on performance. We study the performance of students on a standardized test. In one treatment, burnout is induced with a recall task, and in a control treatment the burnout is not induced. The data show that inducing burnout improves performance on the test. The results suggest that the negative correlation between burnout and performance, which we also observe in our study, is driven by the effect of poor performance on feelings of burnout. The pattern of results leads to a conjecture that feelings of burnout are a reaction that serves to partially offset poor performance.

title: Strengthening the geopolitical aspects of Sri Lanka by joining the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP)
affiliations: General Sir John Kotelawala Defence University

detail.title: Strengthening the geopolitical aspects of Sri Lanka by joining the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP)
detail.abstract: This research paper focuses on Sri Lanka, an island nation geopolitically significant in the Indian Ocean and Asia-Pacific region. It evaluates the geopolitical aspect benefits versus the challenges of integrating Sri Lanka within the world's most significant free trade agreement (RCEP). Although the economic aspects of Sri Lanka joining the RCEP are analysed, the geopolitical implications and aspects are yet to be uncovered. Therefore, this research paper investigates the geopolitical implications of Sri Lanka joining the RCEP and how it will continue to do so, especially analysing the impact of relations with member states, especially after India had opted out of participating in the RCEP partnership. Therefore, this study addresses the possible benefits and challenges that strengthen Sri Lanka's geopolitical aspect by joining a trade bloc by drawing on the context of relations with countries across the Asia-Pacific, the concept of geopolitical factors, and the geopolitical significance of the RCEP. In this qualitative research, data collection was conducted among experts in relevant fields sampled as representatives of government and nongovernment institutions. The themes were explored in depth using secondary data. Interview-based qualitative data were analysed and presented through thematic analysis, followed by themes that illustrate the aspects of geopolitics. The findings of this research will contribute to the understanding of how small nations such as Sri Lanka can use regional economic partnerships to enhance their geopolitical aspects and navigate complex international relations in an increasingly interconnected world.

publicationDetails.detailsText: Journal of Economics, Race, and Policy, volume 1, issue 1, 2018[10.1007/s41996-018-0007-7]

detail.abstract: This paper examines across different quantiles of conditional wage income, how racial income disparity is impacted when the endogeneity of labor market participation is accounted for. Labor market participation is captured using the continuous variable number-of-weeks-worked-last-year that encompasses the binary variables unemployment rate and labor force participation rate. Number of small children and the presence of spouse are found to robustly satisfy all instrumental variable criteria for the number-ofweeks-worked variable. The instrumental-variable-quantile-regression technique is used to analyze the income disparity across the quantiles of conditional income distribution while controlling for endogeneity. I find that the racial disparity is stronger when the endogeneity of labor market participation is acknowledged and also that the disparity gets larger at the upper quantiles of income conditioned on the individual attributes.

However, at the regional level, some divergences emerge in the security and economic realms. The report will then attempt to investigate the future trajectories of the bilateral relationship and where convergences and divergences may emerge. While specific tensions may erupt at the regional level, such as those related to a greater Russian defense presence in Southeast Asia or a Taiwan conflict, the deep structural interests and convergences will likely prevail.

title: Divisia Aggregates and Monetary Policy in India

detail.title: Divisia Aggregates and Monetary Policy in India
detail.abstract: The aim of this paper is to understand which monetary policy variable explains economic activity better. We evaluate three different hypotheses, namely: 1) Money has more information content as opposed to interest rates 2) Divisia monetary aggregates are superior to Simple sum and 3) Broad money is better than narrow money. Our results suggest that money does indeed have more information content as compared to interest rates and that Divisia aggregates are superior to their simple sum counterparts. Furthermore, in the case of the Indian economy, narrow money (M2, DM2) explains economic activity better as compared to broad money (M3, DM3).

title: Modeling Asymmetric Volatility in Indian Stock Market
affiliations: ICFAI Business School (IBS) Hyderabad, India

detail.title: Modeling Asymmetric Volatility in Indian Stock Market

publicationDetails.detailsText: Pacific Business Review International 6.9 (2014).

detail.abstract: The main feature of any financial instruments is stochastic nature of its returns. The spread of outcome of return from the asset is called volatility which influences numerous financial decisions. The main goal of estimating the volatility is to assess the market risk. Volatility is one of the key parameters for pricing financial derivatives. Estimation of volatility helps in risk management and it also helps in efficient management of portfolios. In the present study, asymmetric nature of volatility is modeled by applying two popularly used asymmetric GARCH models i.e., GJR-GARH model and PGARCH model. BSE-Sensex is used as a proxy for Indian stock market and period of study is from 1st july, 1997 to 30th march,2013. Results of Augmented Dickey Fuller test reveals that the natural logarithmic values of Sensex returns and S&P 500 returns are stationary at their level form. Results of analysis with selected asymmetric GARCH models reveals the presence of leverage effect in Indian stock market and it also confirms the effect of periodic cycles on the conditional volatility in the market. In order to test whether the selected asymmetric GARCH models adequately captured the persistence in volatility and to test whether residuals from the selected models are free from ARCH effect, ARCH LM test is conducted. Results of ARCH-LM test concludes that there is no ARCH effect left in residuals obtained from both GJR-GARCH Model and PGARCH Model estimations.
