detail.abstract: This study analyzes the state of essential infrastructure in Iraq through the lens of the "Positive Statistics Methodology" (Al-Jassar, 2025b). It evaluates key indicators—housing tenure, in-house water sources, piped drinking water access, sanitation via public sewer networks, and municipal waste disposal—based on data from the 2024–2025 General Census. The methodology shifts focus from diagnosing deficits to highlighting empowerment, achievements, and relative improvements, linked to SDGs 1, 6, 11, and 12. The study introduces three innovative indices: the Positive Empowerment Index (PEI), the Coverage Index (CI), and the Composite Positive Achievement Index (CPAI), with a composite score of 70.10. It concludes with recommendations on applying smart technologies and innovation for a sustainable infrastructure future in Iraq.

title: Artificially intelligent institutions: On AI, platforms & productivity
affiliations: Royal Melbourne Institute of Technolog (RMIT University)

detail.title: Artificially intelligent institutions: On AI, platforms & productivity
detail.abstract: AI-driven productivity growth will arise not only through innovation and capital investment, but increasingly through a third, often overlooked channel: the embedding of AI into institutional technologies such as digital platforms, protocols, and computational governance systems. These systems act as economic infrastructure, enabling new forms of coordination, efficiency, and service delivery. To harness AI's full economic potential, productivity policy must expand its focus to include these emerging institutional mechanisms.

title: Energizing Change: How Policies and Experience Drive R&D
affiliations: Bocconi University and University of Utah - Department of Entrepreneurship & Strategy

detail.title: Energizing Change: How Policies and Experience Drive R&D
detail.abstract: Given the significance of firm R&D investment in supporting successful technological shifts, this paper asks whether policy incentives can drive firms to invest in R&D. We use data from the U.S. electric utilities industry, a setting in which most state governments have enacted renewable portfolio standards (RPSs) mandating renewable electricity. We examine whether these policies also motivate firms to increase investment in R&D. We find a positive relationship between RPSs and R&D investment, but primarily among firms with previous experience generating renewable electricity. Notably, electric utility firms focus their investments on external R&D rather than on internal R&D projects. By highlighting how policy incentives for technological change and firm technological experience work together to stimulate R&D efforts, this research deepens our understanding of technological search.

title: Does Work from Home Help Improve Women's Pay? Disentangling the Selection from the Treatment Effect
affiliations: University of Massachusetts Boston, University of International Business and Economics, University of Maryland - R.H. Smith School of Business and University of International Business and Economics

detail.title: Does Work from Home Help Improve Women's Pay? Disentangling the Selection from the Treatment Effect
detail.abstract: We investigate whether work-from-home (WFH) practices help women obtain better (or worse) pay than comparable men. The answer to this question requires teasing apart the dual mechanisms at work shaping the relationship between WFH and pay—a selection-induced wage penalty and a treatment-based wage premium. Using longitudinal data from the U.S. Survey of Income and Program Participation (2019–2022), we disentangle these mechanisms using the COVID-19 Pandemic as a quasi-exogenous shock that disrupted voluntary WFH adoption, thereby reducing the confounding of voluntary selection into WFH and the selection mechanism. Our data show that the post-Pandemic period witnessed a stronger treatment-based wage premium for women, as they experienced 6.8% wage gain when shifting work arrangement from non-WFH to WFH, while no similar wage gain is observed for men. We further explore heterogeneity in these effects by examining family constraints and job characteristics. Women without caregiving burdens or those in socially oriented, contact-intensive jobs benefit most from WFH, suggesting that remote work can buffer against gendered workplace biases. However, for women with high family responsibilities, the selection-based wage penalty can offset any beneficial mechanism associated with WFH. Our findings highlight that WFH’s impact on gender wage difference is context dependent. Whether WFH can improve women’s pay depends on who adopts remote work, why, and in what kind of job. These insights contribute to literature on labor inequality, work arrangements, and organizational policy, emphasizing the need for nuanced approaches to workplace flexibility that address both the structural and individual-level factors shaping gendered outcomes.

title: Complexity of Disciplining Input Subsidies under the Countervailing Duty Law -A Focus on the US and the WTO
affiliations: Konkuk University

detail.title: Complexity of Disciplining Input Subsidies under the Countervailing Duty Law -A Focus on the US and the WTO

keywords: WTO Agreement on Subsidies and Countervailing Measures

detail.abstract: This article explores the structural complexities of addressing input subsidies under the countervailing duty (CVD) system, with a particular focus on practices and legal developments in the US. Traditionally, input subsidies have been managed under the CVD system as 'indirect' subsidies. However, recent trends in the US reveal a shift towards addressing these subsidies within the anti-dumping(AD) framework; for example, by embracing them as a particular market situation (PMS). This article identifies why input subsidies in earlier production stages are not effectively addressed under the CVD law by examining the structural limitations of the US CVD law and the WTO jurisprudence. Specifically, through a review of upstream subsidy cases in the US from January 2011 to July 2024, the article highlights the challenges and complexities involved in applying upstream subsidy provisions. The article concludes by emphasizing the need for clearer and more effective legal disciplines on input subsidies within the CVD framework to ensure comprehensive regulation of such practices.

title: Do shareholders support corporate social responsibility, or should companies 'stick to their knitting'?
affiliations: University of Southern Queensland, School of Law and Justice

detail.title: Do shareholders support corporate social responsibility, or should companies 'stick to their knitting'?
detail.abstract: This article seeks to empirically answer whether Australian shareholders support corporate social responsibility ('CSR') or prefer companies to maximise shareholder returns. Legally, companies can consider a wide range of stakeholder interests when deciding what is in the best interests of the company. Generally, most companies continue to pursue the shareholder primacy norm by seeking to maximise shareholder value. However, corporate Australia's support for the Voice to Parliament (and before that, the plebiscite on marriage equality) departed from the shareholder primacy norm in lending its support to these causes through CSR activities. Missing from this discussion is the voice of shareholders. A survey of 236 Australians suggests that most investors would prefer companies 'stick to their knitting' and maximise profits. Where investors were willing to forgo some profit, the amounts are low. Yet, perversely, these investors hold prosocial attitudes in their consumer and donor decisions.

title: Peculiarities of Performing the Duties of a Lawyer of Military Authorities in the Area of Military Operations
affiliations: Odesa State University of Internal Affairs, Odesa Military Academy, Odesa, Ukraine and Odesa Military Academy, Odesa, Ukraine

detail.title: Peculiarities of Performing the Duties of a Lawyer of Military Authorities in the Area of Military Operations

keywords: General Staff of the Armed Forces of Ukraine

publicationDetails.detailsText: European Journal of Interdisciplinary Issues, Volume 2, No. 2, pp. 10-16

detail.abstract: The article is devoted to the study of the peculiarities of the activities of lawyers of military command and control bodies in the conditions of hostilities. The relevance of the study is stipulated by the need for legal support of military operations, compliance with international humanitarian law and protection of the rights of servicemen in the combat zone. The purpose of the article is to identify the key features of the activities of lawyers of military authorities and to develop the ways to improve the efficiency of their work in the combat zone. To achieve this goal, the study solved a number of tasks: the author characterizes the functional duties of lawyers of military command and control bodies; analyzes the regulatory and legal framework for their activities; identifies the peculiarities of performing the duties of lawyers of military command and control bodies in the combat zone; and offers recommendations for improving the efficiency of their activities. In the course of the study, the author used the methods of analysis, synthesis, induction, deduction and comparative legal method. Based on the results of the study, it is established that the effective activity of lawyers of military command and control bodies is critical for ensuring law and order, legality of military operations and protection of the rights of servicemen. At the same time, it has certain peculiarities that affect their work. Such features include: prompt response to changes in legislation, lack of access to adequate resources, increased responsibility in decision-making, confidentiality and preservation of military secrets, performance of duties in extreme conditions and speed of decisionmaking, adherence to military discipline and subordination to command. To improve the efficiency of lawyers' work, the author proposes a set of measures, including regular education and training, strengthening of cybersecurity measures, and improvement of interagency coordination. The practical significance of the study lies in the possibility of using its results to improve the legal support for the activities of the Armed Forces of Ukraine and to increase the efficiency of lawyers of military command and control bodies in combat conditions.

title: Advancing Scientific Discovery: A Machine Learning Approach to Targeted Knowledge Discovery and Exploration
affiliations: Center for Solar Energy and Hydrogen Research Baden-Württemberg (ZSW) and Center for Solar Energy and Hydrogen Research Baden-Württemberg (ZSW)

detail.title: Advancing Scientific Discovery: A Machine Learning Approach to Targeted Knowledge Discovery and Exploration
detail.abstract: Technological progress relates to the development of new scientific knowledge. We suggest applying Natural Language Processing (NLP) techniques and machine learning algorithms to make this knowledge discovery process more targeted and less depended on the intuition of individual researchers by implementing theoretical concepts about the structure of knowledge networks. Our research may serve as a starting point for a machine learning based knowledge discovery system, which allows for developing more targeted scientific roadmaps by (1) reducing the scope of the search space, (2) discovering so far undiscovered public knowledge and (3) developing theories about meaningful new knowledge combinations. We test and verify our approach based on patent abstracts of the organic solar PV technology, a research area that has been characterized by declining knowledge discovery productivity in the past. Our results show that the demonstrated approach is indeed capable of identifying new relevant knowledge component combinations and thus represents a new method in the field of materials research.

title: Rethinking the judicial duty to state reasons in the age of automation?
affiliations: KU Leuven - Centre for IT & IP Law (CiTiP)

detail.title: Rethinking the judicial duty to state reasons in the age of automation?

keywords: algorithmic and AI systems in the judiciary

detail.abstract: As judges increasingly rely on algorithmic and AI systems in their decision-making process, concerns have been raised about their impact on the judicial duty to state reasons-a duty that is essential to the right to a fair trial and the rule of law. This paper examines whether existing legal frameworks adequately ensure this duty and its underlying normative goals in the age of automation and explores how best to safeguard this duty. Central to the analysis is the question of whether the duty to state reasons itself should be redefined and impose stricter reasoning requirements on judges using AI, requiring them to articulate both 'pragmatic' and technical explanations of the systems' role in their decisions. While this approach may enhance the duty's normative goals of legitimacy, transparency and accountability, the paper also considers the potential drawbacks of imposing such a more robust reasoning obligation in AI-assisted judicial processes.

title: Liquidity and Price Informativeness of Options: Evidence from Extended Trading Hours
affiliations: Queen's University Belfast and University of Warwick - Finance Group

detail.title: Liquidity and Price Informativeness of Options: Evidence from Extended Trading Hours
detail.abstract: This paper explores the trading dynamics of the options market during extended trading hours (ETH). During ETH the options market is characterized by low liquidity and decreased trading activities, yet there is increased likelihood of informed trading. The introduction of ETH improves overall market liquidity on the following trading day, as reflected by a reduction in the quoted and effective bid-ask spreads, for both index options and their underlying constituents. The improvement of liquidity is due to the timely incorporation of overnight news into option prices during ETH. Moreover, option prices during ETH are informative for the index level and realized volatility in the subsequent regular trading hours.

reference: Trust, Safety, and the Internet We Share: Multistakeholder Insights, Edited Volume, Taylor & Francis (forthcoming)
title: Trust and Safety and Human Rights: Bridging the Fields for Better Online Governance
affiliations: Trust and Safety Foundation (TSF) and The Global Network Initiative (GNI)

detail.title: Trust and Safety and Human Rights: Bridging the Fields for Better Online Governance

publicationDetails.detailsText: Trust, Safety, and the Internet We Share: Multistakeholder Insights, Edited Volume, Taylor & Francis (forthcoming)

detail.abstract: Governing platforms at scale has grown ever more challenging, particularly as online services have become more embedded into people's lives. In particular, two fields with overlapping goals, yet distinct approaches, have emerged to address this challenge: the more nascent "Trust and Safety" field and the more established field of "Human Rights". While these fields have different origins and incentives, they complement each other to achieve shared goals of protecting online users from risk and harm. In this chapter-intended for both trust and safety and human rights practitioners working on online governance-we aim to bridge the gap between these two fields to improve their practices and, ultimately, better protect users' rights. We identify the differences between these two fields, their overlaps and areas for collaboration, and provide practical recommendations.

title: ETFs Mispricing and Wholesalers as Authorized Participants
affiliations: Universidad Carlos III de Madrid

detail.title: ETFs Mispricing and Wholesalers as Authorized Participants
detail.abstract: Exchange-Traded Funds (ETFs) pricing relies on keeping their share prices aligned with their net asset value. This is achieved through arbitrage with the creation and redemption of ETF units by authorized participants in the primary market. In this paper, we investigate whether wholesaler internalizers' activity in the ETF primary market as authorized participants affects fund mispricing. Wholesalers face lower trading costs since they can access retail order flow that can be internalized, which constitutes a competitive advantage with respect to other authorized participants. We find that wholesalers' primary market arbitrage activity decreases mispricing, helping ETF share prices to remain aligned with their net asset value, especially when there is negative mispricing. We also find that changes in ETF holdings are associated with the internalization of ETFs' constituent stocks included in their creation and redemption baskets.

title: The Role of Economic Sanctions in Shaping International Trade Relationships Case Study: Russia
affiliations: Old Dominion University - Graduate Program in International Studies

detail.title: The Role of Economic Sanctions in Shaping International Trade Relationships Case Study: Russia
detail.abstract: Economic sanctions play an influential role in international relations by shaping the behavior of states. To address security threats and uphold international norms, countries seek to punish those responsible in violating these principles through the use of economic sanctions. The paper examines the impact of economic sanctions on trade relationships and its consequences on the Russian Economy. It also seeks to analyze the evolution of trade embargo during the post-cold war era to a more resilient and sophisticated measures in the age of globalization. Through this historical perspective, this analysis examines an important case study such as Russia by evaluating the effectiveness and unintended consequences. This paper integrates valuable insights from scholarly literature not limited to Bhagwati, Pape and Hofbauer to comprehend the strategic use of sanctions as a tool of economic pressure to shape countries relationships with one another. Despite their utility, sanctions often produced complex and unintended consequences such as stifling on global supply chains, inflation, unemployment and income inequality. As globalization accelerates, interdependence amongst nations also intensifies, which requires reconsideration of sanction policies by calibrating efforts towards a more inclusive global economy.

title: Automation with Generative AI? Evidence from a Teacher Hiring Pipeline
affiliations: University of Zurich, University of Zurich and University of Zurich

detail.title: Automation with Generative AI? Evidence from a Teacher Hiring Pipeline
detail.abstract: Can generative AI improve hiring? We experimentally embed generative AI (GPT-4) into a teacher-recruitment screening process, comparing three pipelines: (i) human-only, (ii) human with AI assistance, and (iii) fully automated screening. Automation increases downstream hiring success by 11 percentage points (a 73% improvement) over the human-only baseline. In contrast, AI assistance neither improves outcomes nor productivity, as users systematically disregard its recommendations, perceiving it as incapable of distinguishing between signals of teacher quality. Our results provide evidence in favor of fully automated deployment of generative AI for an economically important task, highlighting potential limitations of hybrid approaches involving humans-in-the-loop.

title: Real Effects of Information Processing Costs
affiliations: University of Texas at Austin - Department of Accounting, CUNY Baruch College and University of Texas at Austin

detail.title: Real Effects of Information Processing Costs
detail.abstract: Reducing information processing costs is widely seen as a means to improve price informativeness and overall welfare. In this paper, we develop a model to examine the real effects of such cost reductions on corporate investment levels and their welfare implications for capital market participants. We show that corporate investment follows an inverted U-shaped pattern with respect to processing costs. This non-monotonic relation follows from two opposing forces. On one hand, lower processing costs improve price informativeness, which reduces agency frictions and increases entrepreneurs' financing capacity. On the other hand, they increase speculators' trading profits in the secondary market at the expense of initial investors, forcing entrepreneurs to compensate initial investors for future losses and reducing their financing capacity. Moreover, since trading profits are merely transfers among market participants rather than net gains, lowering processing costs does not necessarily benefit entrepreneurs or investors, nor does it always enhance overall welfare.

title: The Influence of Universities in the Activity of Local Public Administration from Romania
affiliations: National University of Political Studies and Public Administration (NSPSPA) - Faculty of Public Administration, National School of Political Studies and Public Administration (NSPSPA) - Faculty of Public Administration and National University of Political Studies and Public Administration (SNSPA)

detail.title: The Influence of Universities in the Activity of Local Public Administration from Romania
detail.abstract: This paper explores the influence of universities in Romania on the activities of local public administration, emphasizing the alignment between administrative activities and their objectives. The study is grounded in the premise that collaboration between local authorities and academic institutions can enhance the achievement of sustainable development goals. The research investigates the extent to which universities contribute to shaping the objectives and activities of local administration. The study employs a mixed-methods approach, integrating the analysis of official public documents with administering questionnaires to local authorities in cities with major university centers across Romania. The anticipated findings are expected to reveal varying levels of university involvement, highlighting the role of academic expertise in policy formulation and the degree to which local administrations leverage the knowledge and resources of nearby academic institutions. This research underscores the potential for stronger university-local administration partnerships to drive more effective and sustainable governance.

title: The Economics of Public Discipline: A Behavioral Economics Approach to Norms, Governance, and Development in India
affiliations: NESS Wadia College of Commerce Pune

detail.title: The Economics of Public Discipline: A Behavioral Economics Approach to Norms, Governance, and Development in India
detail.abstract: Discipline, though often dismissed as a personal virtue or moral construct, has profound macroeconomic consequences. In a complex, pluralistic democracy like India, public indiscipline undermines the delivery of basic services, inflates public costs, and limits the efficacy of national development strategies. This paper employs a behavioral economics lens to analyze public indiscipline as a negative externality that impairs productivity, erodes institutional efficiency, and reinforces socioeconomic inequalities. Drawing on cost-benefit analysis and empirical evidence from domains such as transport, sanitation, workplace environments, education, and ecology, this study argues for reframing discipline as a critical public economic good. Policy recommendations include behavioral nudges, civic education, and technology-driven enforcement to institutionalize a culture of developmental discipline.

title: The Private Equity Experiment of U.S. Banking Industry
affiliations: State University of New York-Stony Brook University - College of Business and Federal Reserve Bank of Boston

detail.title: The Private Equity Experiment of U.S. Banking Industry
detail.abstract: We examine 87 significant private equity investments in publicly traded banks during and after the global financial crisis, enabled by relaxed Federal Reserve regulations aimed at recapitalizing banks. Risk indicators, including market-and accounting-based metrics as well as confidential government exam ratings, worsened at these banks. CEOs were incentivized to take on more risk, leading to accelerated business lending, increased mortgage-and asset-backed securities holdings, and deteriorated credit quality. But PE investment added value. Bank share prices appreciated relative to the market in both the short-run and the long-run, comparable to contemporary PE deals in less regulated industries.

title: Evaluating Consumer Awareness and Perception of Goods and Services Tax in Belagavi City, India: A Quantitative Case Study
affiliations: S.S.S. Samiti’s M.P Mirji College of Commerce, Belagavi. and Rani Channamma University

detail.title: Evaluating Consumer Awareness and Perception of Goods and Services Tax in Belagavi City, India: A Quantitative Case Study

declarations.declarationOfInterest: no

detail.abstract: The Goods and Services Tax (GST) was introduced in India with the goal of simplifying the indirect tax system, ensuring uniformity among states, increasing transparency, and promoting ease of doing business. Having these objects, consumer awareness and perception towards GST remain limited, especially in Belagavi City. The study’s main motive is to analyze the level of awareness and perception of consumers towards GST. It explores how well consumers understand GST, such as its system, advantages, and impact on pricing and transparency. This study is both analytical and descriptive in nature. Primary data was collected from 100 respondents by a structured questionnaire with close-ended and Likert scale questions. And secondary data is also used for study. A convenience sampling method was adopted. The data was analyzed by Microsoft Excel and Chi-square test and regression analysis to assess the association between variables. The findings say many consumers are aware of GST as a unified tax replacing multiple indirect taxes with inadequate understanding of key components such as tax slabs, ITC, and procedures. The study also highlights that personal curiosity and peer discussion are the most influential factors. Consumers perceive GST to bring uniformity and transparency but also direct concern of price increases and lack of clarity. This study highlights the need for awareness campaigns, programs, educational initiatives, and government communication to bridge the gap between GST and consumer understanding. It summarizes the findings' applicability or policy significance.

title: Confirmation Bias and Asymmetric Political Polarization: Evidence from a Media Experiment in Germany *
affiliations: University College Dublin (UCD) - Department of Politics, affiliation not provided to SSRN and ZEW Mannheim

detail.title: Confirmation Bias and Asymmetric Political Polarization: Evidence from a Media Experiment in Germany *

declarations.ethicsApproval: This project received an ethical approval certificate No. ZEW-EC-2024-001.
declarations.funderStatement: We acknowledge financial support from the Leibniz Science Campus MannheimTaxation.

detail.abstract: This paper examines how confirmation bias and media fragmentation jointly contribute to political polarization. As media environments become increasingly fragmented, individuals are exposed to distinct sets of information, reinforcing ideological divides and reducing shared understanding. We argue that confirmation bias not only drives selective exposure but also amplifies political polarization as fragmented information environments create self-reinforcing narratives. Using inflation perceptions in Germany as a case study, we provide empirical evidence that preferences on media consumption reinforce extreme political views and support for radical parties, more concretely towards the right. Additionally, we document a backfire effect, where exposure to contradictory information deepens ideological entrenchment. Our findings highlight the critical role of fragmented media landscapes and biased news consumption in shaping political attitudes and electoral behavior.

title: Mr. Trump's Tariff War
affiliations: Duke University - Department of Economics, Claremont Graduate University and Utah State University

detail.title: Mr. Trump's Tariff War

declarations.declarationOfInterest: None
declarations.ethicsApproval: No patients/participants
declarations.funderStatement: Research Grant from Duke University

detail.abstract: The trade war started by President Trump is highly disruptive to both the American and global economies and is a major setback for the international cooperation that has developed over the postwar period. Mr. Trump’s views are based on a fundamental lack of understanding of how economies operate and a view of international trade that is ironically like long-discredited Marxism as well as mercantilism. Many of his national security arguments are bogus and are likely to end up reducing rather than increasing American national security. Basic accounting defines the trade deficit as the excess of American absorption of goods and services minus its production of them.  Yet Mr. Trump ignores that tariffs, non-tariff barriers and exchange rates shrink the volume of trade, but they have no impact on the trade deficit at all if the excess of American absorption over American output is unchanged. The obvious solution is to tame the huge US fiscal deficit.

title: Who Paid for the Profits of Taiwan's Central Bank?
affiliations: Academia Sinica, National Tsing Hua University, Federal Reserve Banks - Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis and National Tsing Hua University

detail.title: Who Paid for the Profits of Taiwan's Central Bank?

declarations.declarationOfInterest: None
declarations.ethicsApproval: None
declarations.funderStatement: None

detail.abstract: We analyze the interaction between the Taiwan central bank's profits and its policies. To earn large and consistent profits, the Taiwan central bank significantly expanded its balance sheet and relied on inexpensive short-term domestic funding to invest in longer-term foreign debt securities. In doing so, the central bank engineered a massive duration and currency mismatch on its balance sheet to capture term and currency risk premiums. We also argue that these large profits could not have been realized without a low rate policy combined with heavy regulations on domestic financial institutions. These regulations function like a tax on the returns of private overseas investments, effectively trapping funds within the domestic financial system. Ultimately, the profits earned by the central bank are, in effect, an implicit tax revenue levied on domestic depositors.

title: Triggering Animal Spirits? National Trends Drive State -Level Gun Interest
affiliations: University of Central Missouri - Economics & Finance, affiliation not provided to SSRN and Middle Tennessee State University

detail.abstract: Empirical studies of gun violence often struggle with endogeneity between crime and gun ownership, complicating causal inference. This paper reframes the issue by examining whether state-level gun interest is driven more by local conditions or national trends. We find strong synchronization across states, suggesting that national events and sentiment, not local factors, primarily shape gun-related behavior. These findings imply that many empirical strategies may overstate local causality and overlook coordinated national responses. This raises important implications for modeling and policy design.

affiliations: Independent

detail.abstract: This article traces the evolution of the U.S. international tax regime across four distinct historical periods: the age of benefits (1918-1960), the age of neutrality (1960-1980), the age of competition (1981-1997), and the age of cooperation (post-1998). It examines how foundational principles such as capital export neutrality, residence-based taxation, and anti-deferral measures have shaped legislative enactments from the Foreign Tax Credit of 1918 through the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017. While the framework has succeeded in balancing double taxation relief and U.S. business competitiveness, longstanding features like deferral and check the box elections have facilitated base erosion. The paper highlights the resilience of these core structures despite global reforms, questioning whether the U.S. approach remains optimal amid OECD Pillar Two's push for minimum taxes. The study provides essential context for understanding current debates on aligning U.S. tax policy with global standards.

title: Assessing the Influence of Artificial Intelligence on Corporate Tax Compliance and Financial Reporting
affiliations: The University of Lahore Islamabad Campus

detail.title: Assessing the Influence of Artificial Intelligence on Corporate Tax Compliance and Financial Reporting

declarations.declarationOfInterest: Declaration of Interest The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper. All research activities were conducted independently, and the study was not funded by any commercial, governmental, or non-governmental organization that could create a conflict of interest.

detail.abstract: This study investigates the transformative impact of Artificial Intelligence (AI) on corporate tax compliance and financial reporting processes. Using a mixed-methods approach, the research explores how AI technologies—such as machine learning, natural language processing, and predictive analytics—enhance accuracy, efficiency, and regulatory alignment in tax functions. Through case analysis, statistical data, and implementation frameworks, the study identifies key success factors, challenges, and future trends in AI adoption. Findings indicate that organizations leveraging AI experience significant improvements in data quality, error detection, and real-time compliance capabilities. The research also highlights the importance of governance, ethical AI practices, and cross-functional collaboration. A phased model for AI implementation is proposed, supported by visual data and practical recommendations for corporate entities, regulators, and technology providers. This paper contributes to the growing literature on digital transformation in finance and offers strategic insights for navigating the evolving tax technology landscape.

title: Exchange Market Pressure under the Reserve Options Mechanism
affiliations: Meliksah University and Vanderbilt University - College of Arts and Science - Department of Economics

detail.title: Exchange Market Pressure under the Reserve Options Mechanism
detail.abstract: This study develops an analytical model to obtain an index for exchange market pressure in a monetary system with Reserve Options Mechanism (ROM), a macro prudential policy tool introduced by the Turkish Central Bank aiming to reduce the adverse effects of short- term capital flows and exchange rate volatility on macroeconomic and financial stability. Our model-consistent exchange market pressure index is derived using a small open economy with rational expectations where we adopt a general, model-independent definition of exchange market pressure and follow two-step methodology proposed in Weymark (1995, 1998). We undertake counter-factual experiments to measure and evaluate exchange market pressure index for Turkish economy over the periods of 2005 to 2015. We show that exchange market pressure is inversely related to the proportion of banks utilizing the ROM facility, the size of Reserve Options Ratio, and Reserve Options Coefficients. We provide empirical evidence that exchange market pressure is significantly reduced both in size and volatility terms during the period while the Reserve Options Mechanism is in operation. Under Reserve Options Mechanism commercial banks are allowed to keep a certain percentage of their Turkish Lira reserve requirements in USD, Euro, and/or gold. Reserve Options Mechanism consists of two principal elements: reserve option ratio (ROR) and reserve option coefficients (ROCs) which are both set by the central bank. The upper limit for the proportion of domestic currency required reserves that is allowed to be held in foreign currency (FX) and gold is governed by reserve option ratio (ROR). The amount of FX and gold that can be held against per domestic currency required reserves is called the reserve option coefficient (ROC).

title: Beyond the Strike: The Struggle for Worker Power in Iran
affiliations: State University of New York (SUNY) - Stony Brook, Students

detail.title: Beyond the Strike: The Struggle for Worker Power in Iran

declarations.declarationOfInterest: n/a
declarations.ethicsApproval: n/a
declarations.funderStatement: n/a

contentFormat.other: Short Article aimed at public audience

detail.abstract:
Since 2010, Iran has seen a surge in labour protests and strikes as workers demand better wages, job security, and working conditions. Yet despite the frequency and intensity of these actions, meaningful political and economic reforms remain out of reach. Living and working conditions have largely deteriorated, and state concessions, limited and temporary, fail to address the deep economic and political issues underlying rising unemployment, the loss of stable jobs, and cuts to welfare. This raises some critical questions: Why, despite persistent strikes and protests, have workers failed to secure substantial political change? And, what is to be done to build worker power in Iran?

To answer these questions, I will trace the history of labour organising in Iran since the 1979 revolution, with a focus on the resurgence of labour activism since 2010. I explain how Iran’s unique position in the Middle East shapes the labour movement, underscoring the need for unified political organisations by and for workers. History shows that under such repressive conditions, economic demands alone are insufficient; without strong, politically rooted organisations, workers struggle to gain traction for systemic change.

title: Foreign Exchange Rate Exposure Mitigation and Connection to Economic Growth: The Nigerian Experience (2019 -2023)
affiliations: Grundtvig Polytechnic, Oba, Nigeria, National Board for Technical Education, Auchi Polytechnic, Grundtvig Polytechnic, Oba, Nigeria and Nigerian Defence Academy (NDA)

detail.title: Foreign Exchange Rate Exposure Mitigation and Connection to Economic Growth: The Nigerian Experience (2019 -2023)
detail.abstract: The increasing interest in the subject of management of foreign exchange exposure in Nigeria has been sequel to the rising transactional, translational and economic risks experienced in the country. Thus, concerns for the incessant devaluation of the naira (increasing foreign exchange rate) continued to mount, explaining the main objective of this study-in attempting to evaluate the most suitable and effective measures and techniques for the management of foreign exchange rate exposures, while attempting to demonstrate the relationship between foreign exchange rate exposures and the economic growth of a developing country like Nigeria. Expofacto design was deployed for this study. Regression analysis, descriptive statistics, residual statistics, Collinearity Diagnostics and Durbin-Watson were the techniques used to analyze data and examine the relationship between the two major variables of the study. The yearly highest foreign exchange rates (Nigerian Naira to a US dollar)-as at the official market; and the yearly average of the quarterly GDP of Nigeria, constituted the datasets, for the period 2019-2023 respectively. The study found that a statistical and significant relationship exists between the foreign exchange exposure and economic growth. The study concludes that a better exposure mitigation could be achieved with an efficient use of hedging measures (currency forwards, currency option currency futures, cross-currency swaps, or even 'natural' hedging).

title: Steris/Synergy a Decade Out: Retrospectively Assessing this Century's First Litigated Potential Competition Matter
affiliations: Econic Partners

detail.title: Steris/Synergy a Decade Out: Retrospectively Assessing this Century's First Litigated Potential Competition Matter

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The views expressed here are mine alone, and not necessarily those of Econic Partners or its clients. For the purpose of disclosing any potential conflict of interest, I worked on this matter for the Federal Trade Commission as a government employee; my views are also not necessarily those of the FTC or of any current or past FTC commissioner, and I relied solely on publicly available information in writing this paper.

detail.abstract: The 2015 Steris/Synergy merger was the first litigated matter involving potential competition issues in more than 30 years. The FTC's unsuccessful challenge alleged that Synergy's planned U.S. xray sterilization facilities would compete with Steris's gamma sterilization facilities to the benefit of consumers. Steris argued that its plans were half-baked and unlikely to come to fruition. A retrospective analysis of the merger finds support both in the trial record and in post-trial data for the FTC's challenge. In particular: (1) Steris itself appears to have used x-ray for virtually all of its incremental radiation sterilization capacity since the time of the merger; (2) Steris has become significantly more profitable since the merger consistent with (if not a dispositive indicator of) increased market power; and (3) a replication of the Synergy financial model that underpinned so much of the trial is not consistent with testimony that x-ray's financials were "woeful" and hence unlikely to support entry. More generally, I argue for an expected value approach to potential competition matters that jointly considers probability of entry and effects of entry, and that is more likely to enforce mergers with greater expected harm. Relative to an expected value approach, the current enforcement regime, which appears to assign greater weight to the probability of entry than to the effects of entry, is likely to overenforce mergers in which entry is likely but harms conditional on entry are small, and to underenforce mergers with a lower probability of entry but significant harms conditional on entry.

title: Optimal Provision of Urban Infrastructure: Theory and Evidence from Brazilian Cities *
affiliations: Getulio Vargas Foundation (FGV) - FGV/EPGE Escola Brasileira de Economia e Finanças and Brazilian School of Economics and Finance

detail.title: Optimal Provision of Urban Infrastructure: Theory and Evidence from Brazilian Cities *
detail.abstract: We investigate how urban infrastructure is, and should be, distributed within cities. Using high-resolution data on population, housing prices, and infrastructure, including sanitation access and street characteristics, for Brazilian cities, we document that infrastructure provision consistently declines with distance from the city center. Moreover, unconditional housing price and population density gradients are much steeper than when conditioning on infrastructure. To interpret these stylized facts, we consider a monocentric city model in which infrastructure is a local public good and we derive a sufficient-statistics rule for its optimal spatial allocation. This rule implies that, under certain conditions, population density and land prices should fully explain spatial differences in infrastructure. We find systematic deviations from this rule, with infrastructure biased toward central neighborhoods. While aggregate losses in welfare or city size are modest, this bias shapes city structure, implying city centers 21% denser than optimal.

title: IMPACT OF BANK PROXIMITY AND ACCESSIBILITY ON ECONOMIC GROWTH IN NIGERIA. RASHIDAT, Busari Ayanbanke

detail.title: IMPACT OF BANK PROXIMITY AND ACCESSIBILITY ON ECONOMIC GROWTH IN NIGERIA. RASHIDAT, Busari Ayanbanke
detail.abstract: This study empirically examined the impact bank proximity and accessibility on the economic growth of Nigeria within the period 1986 to 2019. The specific objectives are to assess the impact of bank proximity on economic growth in Nigeria and investigate the impact of bank accessibility on economic growth in Nigeria. Also, the study adopted the ex post facto research design and employed the Autoregressive Distributed Lagged (ARDL) and the Error Correction Model (ECM) were used to establish the short-run and long-run effect of financial inclusion determinants on economic growth in Nigeria. EGRN is Economic Growth in Nigeria which serves as the dependent variable, While ACS is Bank Accessibility and PROX is Bank Proximity in Nigeria serves as the independent variables. Findings revealed established that all the variables have a positive impact on economic growth in Nigeria both in the long run and short run. However, the probability of the ARDL result showed that Bank Accessibility in Nigeria (ACE) was insignificant in explaining the variation in economic growth in Nigeria, while the ECM revealed that Bank Proximity in Nigeria (PROX) was statistically significant in explaining the variation in the economic growth in Nigeria. This study recommended that financial authorities should put a mechanism in place that will enable banks to open more bank branches and increase the number of bank branches per certain number of population and ATMs provision for maximum formal financial services to the rural population on short team basis since bank proximity has a significant impact on economic gin the short run.

title: Balancing Tradition and Innovation: Ecological Impacts of Intensive Farming on Soil Health in Telangana, India
affiliations: Osmania University, Osmania University (OU), Osmania University (OU), Osmania University, Professor Jayashankar Telangana State Agricultural University (PJTSAU), College of Home Science, Students and Osmania University

detail.title: Balancing Tradition and Innovation: Ecological Impacts of Intensive Farming on Soil Health in Telangana, India

declarations.ethicsApproval: Not applicable. This study did not involve any human participants or animal experiments

publicationDetails.detailsText: Journal of Environmental & Earth Sciences, volume 7, issue 7, 2025[10.30564/jees.v7i7.9886]

detail.abstract: Intensive farming practices, aimed at maximizing crop yields through substantial inputs of labour, technology, and chemical fertilizers, have significantly transformed modern agriculture. However, these methods have raised serious concerns regarding soil health, environmental sustainability, and long-term agricultural viability. This study examines the ecological impact of intensive farming on soil health in the KB Asifabad District of Telangana, India, where traditional and modern farming techniques coexist. The objectives include analysing socioeconomic factors influencing farming methods, evaluating the impact of tilling techniques and fertilizer use on soil health, and promoting sustainable practices through education and policy recommendations. Findings reveal a strong reliance on chemical fertilizers, with 98.3% of farmers using them exclusively due to their perceived efficiency and rapid results. However, this overdependence has led to soil degradation, reduced microbial diversity, and environmental pollution. Conversely, despite its ecological benefits, natural manure remains underutilized due to scepticism and economic constraints. Mechanical tilling methods, while effective, have negatively impacted soil structure and fertility. The study highlights the necessity of transitioning to sustainable practices, integrating organic inputs, and adopting conservation techniques to restore soil health and ecosystem balance. This research provides practical pathways for achieving sustainable agriculture by integrating traditional knowledge with modern practices. It is particularly relevant for policymakers, agricultural extension services, and farming communities as it highlights the need for educational initiatives, financial incentives, and regulatory measures to ensure long-term soil fertility, environmental stewardship, and improved farmer livelihoods.

title: The Politics of Conscription in Northern Ireland, 1938-1946
affiliations: The University of Texas at Austin

detail.title: The Politics of Conscription in Northern Ireland, 1938-1946

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The author declares no conflict of interest.
declarations.funderStatement: N/A

detail.abstract: This article examines how wartime debates over the possible introduction of military conscription reshaped conceptions of citizenship and political authority in Northern Ireland between 1938 and 1946. Drawing on primary documents from Northern Ireland, Éire, and Great Britain, it traces how Unionists initially championed conscription as a way to affirm equal status with Britain, even as they upheld internal hierarchies that disadvantaged Catholics. Yet divisions within Unionist ranks, exacerbated by British reluctance to enforce conscription, challenged longstanding assumptions of Protestant "loyalty" and Catholic "disloyalty." At the same time, Nationalists framed conscription as an illegitimate imposition by a foreign state, underscoring their self-identification as Irish citizens under occupation. Perhaps paradoxically, by forgoing conscription, Britain gained a measure of legitimacy in Catholic eyes, encouraging some Nationalists to engage more constructively with British institutions and signaling new possibilities for political accommodation. In revealing these wartime dynamics, this analysis highlights how the conscription controversy helped recalibrate citizenship, unsettle entrenched power structures, and broaden the political landscape in Northern Ireland.

title: Bangladesh's Transition from the Least Developed Country: Navigating Export Challenges in a New Era
affiliations: Bangladesh Foreign Trade Institute (BFTI)

detail.title: Bangladesh's Transition from the Least Developed Country: Navigating Export Challenges in a New Era
detail.abstract: Bangladesh is heading toward a Developing Country with incremental growth, and Bangladesh’s current merchandise export reached USD 53.93 billion in FY2023-24. Still, export concentration on RMG and lack of product diversification may make Bangladesh uncompetitive in the world market after Graduation. Bangladesh has met three criteria for Graduation, including the Human Asset Index (HAI), the Economic Vulnerability Index (EVI), and the Gross National Income (GNI) indices, to graduate from the Least Developed Countries (LDC) to developing ones in the third triennial review. Given this view, the study aims to assess trade preference loss and to determine the impact of graduation on exports. A combination of qualitative and quantitative approaches is followed in the study, where for quantifying the impact on export, Trade Intelligence and Negotiation Adviser (TINA) is used, and 20 KIIs are taken with the purposive sampling method to evaluate the Smooth Transition Strategies (STS) of Bangladesh. Using exploratory research methodology, the study identifies the potential problems and prospects of LDC graduation and assesses trade preference loss using TINA Simulation Tools to measure LDC preference loss. Referring to the number of UNCTAD reports, articles and secondary literature, the research sheds light on how sustainable economic growth can be secured through diversified products and internal resource mobilisation. In the post-graduation era, Bangladesh will face several challenges related to preferential market access, minimum value addition conditions, and other LDC-related leverage in developed countries’ markets. As a result, the trade loss in the post-graduation era may range from US$4.7 billion to US$17 billion as per the TINA LDC preference loss simulation. The paper identifies inefficiency in resource mobilisation and export concentration as the major hindrances to overcoming the hurdles of graduation. It is crucial for Bangladesh to include trade concerns at each level of the development planning cycle to guarantee a seamless transition process for Bangladesh. This has to be supported by robust inter-ministerial coordination and consultation procedures involving various stakeholders, both from the public and private sectors. With this participatory approach and implementation of pragmatic STS, Bangladesh can go through the process of a smooth transition to becoming a middle-income country in the near future.

title: The spillovers of corporate misbehavior
affiliations: Universidade Católica do Paraná (Universidade Católica do Paraná) and University of Sheffield

detail.title: The spillovers of corporate misbehavior
detail.abstract: Corporate scandals do not occur in isolation; the negative repercussions often extend beyond the offending firm, affecting non-offending peers within the same industry. We show that when a firm's peers are involved in ESG-related scandals, the fallout significantly diminishes the valuation and financial performance of the firm, despite its lack of misconduct. Using firm-level data from 42 countries, we find that an average-magnitude scandal within an industry leads to a subsequent 1.95% equity value loss for non-offending firms. This decline is primarily driven by rising operational costs, suggesting that scandals disrupt supply chains and inflate costs across the industry. Additionally, firms impacted by their peers' scandals adopt more conservative strategies, increasing cash holdings and curtailing ESG investments. We also note that smaller firms and those with robust cash reserves exhibit greater resilience to these negative spillover effects.

title: Insiders, Outsiders, and the Constructed Limites to Social Rights in EU Law
affiliations: Lund University - Faculty of Law

detail.title: Insiders, Outsiders, and the Constructed Limites to Social Rights in EU Law
detail.abstract: This paper engages with limitations to social rights for different categories of migrants under EU law. By looking at how EU law construes accepted limitations to social rights and how the Court of Justice reviews such limitations, the paper suggests that there is room for different interpretation of limitations to social rights under secondary law in view of a more coherent un-derstanding of their function under EU law. Specifically, the paper maps the accepted limitations to the social rights of EU migrants, long-term residents, and regular migrants. By reviewing the justifications put forward behind all the accepted limitations to social rights, the paper argues that the function served by limitations to social rights is uniform across all categories of migrants: that is avoiding the presumed negative effects of migration to national redistributive mechanisms. At the same time, the Court follows different paths of review depending on the status of the migrants (EU or non-EU). While some differentiation in the approach followed by the Court is justified, the paper argues that there is room for evolution in judicial review by combining elements of the judicial approach for both EU and non-EU migrants in light of the social objectives of the EU under Article 3 TEU and the Charter. The paper presents the potential of this combination not as a groundbreaking shift in the functional approach followed by EU law to social rights, but rather as a limited change that can bring about more extensive protection of social rights for all migrants.

title: Determinants of the Match between Student Ability and College Quality
affiliations: Microsoft Corporation - Microsoft Research New England and University of Wisconsin-Madison

detail.title: Determinants of the Match between Student Ability and College Quality

publicationDetails.detailsText: Journal of Labor Economics, volume 35, issue 1, 2017[10.1086/687523]

detail.abstract: We use the National Longitudinal Survey of Youth 1997 cohort to examine how students of varying abilities sort (and are sorted) into colleges of varying qualities. How students match with colleges has implications for the design of state higher education systems and for student aid policy. Our data indicate substantial amounts of both academic undermatch (high ability students at low quality colleges) and academic overmatch (low ability students at high quality colleges). Student application and enrollment decisions, rather than college admission decisions, drive most deviations from academic assortative matching. Financial constraints, information, and the public college options facing each student all affect this sorting, but mainly by influencing the choice of college quality rather than the match between ability and quality. More informed students attend higher quality colleges, even when doing so involves overmatching.

title: Social Inflation and Social Capital Nexus
affiliations: Istanbul Esenyurt University

detail.title: Social Inflation and Social Capital Nexus

declarations.declarationOfInterest: No conflict of interest
declarations.funderStatement: No funding

detail.abstract:
A key driver of social inflation is the shifting societal perception of liability, often characterized by an increased willingness to assign blame and seek substantial compensation, particularly from large corporations perceived as having "deep pockets." This trend is exacerbated by aggressive attorney advertising, third-party litigation funding, and legal environments that favor higher jury awards. Such developments can foster an adversarial culture, where disputes are increasingly resolved through litigation rather than informal negotiation or communitybased mechanisms. This litigious environment, in turn, can erode the very foundations of trust and generalized reciprocity that constitute social capital. 
The concepts of social inflation and social capital, while distinct in their primary domains, exhibit a compelling and potentially inverse relationship, particularly within the context of the United States. Social inflation refers to the increase in insurance claims costs beyond general economic inflation, driven by evolving societal attitudes, legal trends, and increased litigation.

title: A Feminist Perspective on the Economic Dependence of Women in Pakistan
affiliations: Independent

detail.title: A Feminist Perspective on the Economic Dependence of Women in Pakistan

declarations.ethicsApproval: This essay is a theoretical analysis and does not involve human participants or case studies; therefore, ethics approval was not required.

contentType.other: This is an original, unpublished academic essay written independently. It has not been submitted for publication elsewhere.

contentFormat.other: A critical feminist analysis essay exploring the cultural, educational, and religious factors contributing to the economic dependence of women in Pakistan.

detail.abstract:
Women are as old as humankind; however, patriarchy has kept them relegated to the lower rungs
of human history. Not long ago, women in the Western world secured their fundamental freedoms
and began to address other important issues of their time. Women in the developing world,
especially in Pakistan, however, have yet to successfully realize their rightful place in society.
Strict gender roles, religion, and miseducation have hindered their path to becoming autonomous
individuals. From the perspective of Western feminist thought, this short essay explores why a
majority of women in Pakistan remain economically dependent and why they remain unreceptive
to feminist ideals.

title: Green Monetary Policy and the Scope of the ECB's Mandate: Maintaining the Right (Institutional) Balance
affiliations: Maastricht University - Faculty of Law

detail.title: Green Monetary Policy and the Scope of the ECB's Mandate: Maintaining the Right (Institutional) Balance

publicationDetails.detailsText: Greening the EU and the Rule of Law: Opportunities and Limits of the EU's Legal Powers, M. Eliantonio, K. Kulovesi, M. Peeters, and A. Savaresi (eds) Edward Elgar, open access, forthcoming 2026

detail.abstract: The European Central Bank's (ECB) commitment to adjusting monetary policy to the EU's climate goals raises novel questions about the scope of its mandate and institutional balance. Article 127(1) TFEU defines the ECB's overarching objectives in open-ended terms: ensuring price stability and, secondarily, supporting the general economic policies in the EU. This Chapter assesses how the ECB reinterpreted these objectives to design the most concrete "green" monetary policy measure to date-the decarbonisation of its corporate holdings under Decision (EU) 2022/1613. Under the Decision, the ECB innovatively reconfigured part of its operations to steer financial markets toward sustainable finance. While institutionally empowering, the Decision also incorporates self-restraining choices that prevent the ECB from encroaching on the EU legislator's prerogative to set climate policy. Only by making green monetary policy contingent on the EU legislator's measures, the Chapter argues, can the ECB remain aligned with its objectives and respect institutional balance.

title: A new generalized class of estimators for estimation of population mean under PPS sampling: Application with radiation science
affiliations: Faculty of Business, Alexandria University, Prince Sattam Bin Abdulaziz University - College of Science and Humanities Studies, Prince Sattam Bin Abdulaziz University - College of Science and Humanities Studies and Institute of Administrative Sciences

detail.title: A new generalized class of estimators for estimation of population mean under PPS sampling: Application with radiation science
detail.abstract: The primary objective of this research aimed to find out how to use the auxiliary variables to improve the mean estimation of the study variable. Our newly developed generalized estimators outperform existing estimators in terms of preciseness, as measured by the mean squared error (MSE) criterion. Using a first-order approximation technique, we investigate the salient aspects of the suggested estimators with an emphasis on the bias and mean squared error under Probability Proportional to Size (PPS) sampling. PPS sampling technique assigns more selection possibilities to units with higher size measures; it shows significant efficiency in such applications. By using auxiliary information to increase precision, a new generalized class of estimate techniques helps to compute the population mean under PPS sampling. The approach follows an actual radiation science application by means of average ambient radiation measurements over a geographical area whose topic selection probability corresponds with area size and population distribution. Because they show lower MSE, which makes them advantageous for radiological risk assessment attached with environmental health monitoring, the suggested estimators show better performance than adopted existing estimators.

title: Technological Asymmetries and External Adjustment: The Price and Income Elasticities of Import Demand in a Dollarized, Import-Dependent Economy
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN and Universidad de las Américas (UDLA)

detail.title: Technological Asymmetries and External Adjustment: The Price and Income Elasticities of Import Demand in a Dollarized, Import-Dependent Economy
detail.abstract: This paper examines the relationship between real exchange rates and Ecuadorian imports disaggregated by technological intensity and main trading partners (United States, China, and European Union) during 2000-2023. Using Autoregressive Distributed Lag (ARDL) and Dynamic Ordinary Least Squares (DOLS) models, we estimate the price and income elasticities of import demand across low-, medium-, and high-technology goods. Based on 286 monthly observations (January 2000–October 2023), the results reveal significant negative price elasticities—from -0.795 for total US imports to -1.808 for low-tech US goods—with progressively lower elasticities in medium-tech (-0.512 to -0.796) and high-tech segments (-0.444 to -0.779), reflecting limited substitution at higher technological complexity. Cross-price elasticities show competition between China and the US in low-tech goods, complementarity in medium-tech imports, and EU specialization in high-tech products. The findings highlight structural dependencies and technological asymmetries shaping import responses to macroeconomic fluctuations, with notable variation in adjustment speeds—slower for Chinese low-tech imports (-0.185), faster for European imports (-1.369). Overall, the results underscore the vulnerabilities of resource-dependent economies with limited exchange rate flexibility and high technological reliance amid global trade disruptions.

title: Expanding School Counseling: The Impacts of California Funding Changes
affiliations: University of Arkansas and RAND Corporation

detail.title: Expanding School Counseling: The Impacts of California Funding Changes
detail.abstract: Counselors are a common school resource for students navigating complicated and consequential education choices, but most students have limited access to them. We study one of the largest U.S. policies to increase access to school counselors. We use a variety of panel-based estimators to show that California’s Supplemental School Counseling Program increased the number of counselors on staff by about one and improved counselor to student ratios, but reduced average counselor experience. The expansion of counseling resulted in large increases in high school graduation and measures of school climate; it also led to more modest gains in California high school exit exam performance and some public college enrollment rates. These impacts were largest at high poverty and rural schools, as well as for students who were male, socioeconomically disadvantaged, or Black or Hispanic. Thus, expanding access to counselors may help address equity gaps in college access and student well-being.

title:
Small Donors in U.S. Politics: Myth and Reality

detail.title:
Small Donors in U.S. Politics: Myth and Reality 
(Chapter 4: Are Small Donor Fundraisers Better Legislators?)
detail.abstract: In this chapter we examine a variety of representational outcomes (e.g. roll call voting, earmark allocations, legislative effectiveness) and democratic norms to understand whether members of Congress who rely more heavily on small donors are better legislators. Our mostly null findings suggest small donor support is not associated with more normatively appealing representational behaviors.

title: Economy, Resources and Responsible Society
affiliations: EDUKIVOTOS

detail.title: Economy, Resources and Responsible Society
detail.abstract:
This book explores the economy as a science focused on the efficient allocation of scarce resources, analyzing its impact on individuals, businesses, and the state. It examines classical, Marxist, and marginalist theories, addressing key concepts such as consumption, labor, subsidies, debt, reinvestment, and market dynamics. The work highlights the relationship between personal effort and public assistance, warning about risks of dependency on state subsidies. It also reflects on the importance of responsible management, resource inventories, and accurate information for decision-making and economic sustainability.

Keywords: Economy, Resources, Consumption, Subsidies, Sustainability

title: Balanced Optimal Transport Consistency Learning for Long-Tailed Visual Recognition
affiliations: Shenzhen University, Shenzhen University, Shenzhen University, Shenzhen University, Lingnan University and Shenzhen University

detail.title: Balanced Optimal Transport Consistency Learning for Long-Tailed Visual Recognition
detail.abstract: Long-tailed data distributions hinder the practical application of deep models in computer vision, as predictions tend to be heavily biased toward head classes with abundant samples. Using pseudo-labels or contrastive losses for consistency learning, followed by fine-tuning balanced classifiers, still leads to the under-representation of tail-class features and increases training complexity. In this work, we propose a novel one-stage training strategy named Balanced Optimal Transport Consistency Learning (BOTCL) to obtain balanced representations for long-tailed data. Considering the imbalanced feature distribution in conventional consistency learning, we implement head-tail feature fusion and feature memory bank to enhance the optimal transport (OT) process in tail classes, resulting in more balanced feature learning. Instead of directly comparing blended features, consistency learning with OT maps features into a lower-dimensional probability distribution space, alleviating the challenges associated with high-dimensional comparisons in long-tailed tasks. Moreover, the distribution-aware alignment provided by OT enhances the discriminative capability of head–tail fused representations. Extensive experiments on various long-tailed benchmarks demonstrate the significant improvement of the proposed method over the previous state-of-the-art.

title: Examining Experimentation: An Elicitation Approach
affiliations: Illinois Institute of Technology - Stuart School of Business, IIT and Purdue University

detail.title: Examining Experimentation: An Elicitation Approach
detail.abstract: This paper analyzes factors that may be related to behavior in bandit problems. In an experiment, we relate behavior in the first decision of a bandit to attitudes towards compound lotteries, belief updating, risk aversion, cognitive reflection scores, and contingent reasoning. We find a significant relationship between behavior in the first decision of a specific bandit and behavior in a compound lottery problem that is similar to a one-shot decision between the two bandit options. However, we fail to find any aggregate relationship between behavior in the first decision of a bandit and belief updating, risk aversion, cognitive reflection scores, and contingent reasoning. Overall, our results are consistent with subjects disliking options that currently have a larger variance in the probability of returning a reward. Our results also suggest that subjects have difficulty responding to the incentives in an experimentation opportunity. This appears to stem from a difficulty in anticipating the information generated from experimentation and/or understanding how to apply information towards future decisions.

title: Jumps and Jolts: A Continuous-Time Model for Electricity Forward Contract Pricing
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN and Getulio Vargas Foundation (FGV) - Sao Paulo School of Business Administration

detail.title: Jumps and Jolts: A Continuous-Time Model for Electricity Forward Contract Pricing
detail.abstract: This paper addresses the limitations of traditional power derivative pricing models, which inadequately account for spikes on forward contracts dynamics. We propose a continuous-time model that incorporates both jump processes and a time-varying drift to capture shifts in hedging supply and demand. The model also includes correlated Brownian motions to reflect common shocks affecting contracts with different delivery periods. Using the generalized method of moments (GMM), we estimate model parameters using daily settlement prices of Norwegian forward electricity contracts. Simulation exercises validate the reliability of the parameter estimators. Furthermore, we demonstrate the model’s improved forecasting accuracy compared to an ARMA-GARCH model, highlighting its potential value for traders and risk managers in portfolio management.

title: How Do Quantitative Easing and Tightening Affect Firms?
affiliations: Bank for International Settlements (BIS) - Monetary and Economic Department, Bank for International Settlements (BIS) and Yale School of Management

detail.title: How Do Quantitative Easing and Tightening Affect Firms?
detail.abstract: We study how firms respond to quantitative easing and quantitative tightening policies of the Federal Reserve by constructing a novel time series of maturity-specific balance sheet shocks. We find that, on average, firms adjust their debt maturity structure, reduce interest expenses and accumulate cash, while their total debt, capital and employment remain largely unchanged. The impact of these policies differs depending on the targeted maturity segment and the credit quality of firms. Policy transmission primarily runs via bond markets. There are positive spillovers to high-rated non-US firms. Our findings can inform the design of balance sheet policies.

title: Breakdown Analysis for Instrumental Variables with Binary Outcomes
affiliations: Insper Institute of Education and Research

detail.title: Breakdown Analysis for Instrumental Variables with Binary Outcomes
detail.abstract: This paper studies the partial identification of treatment effects in Instrumental Variables (IV) settings with binary outcomes under violations of independence. I derive the identified sets for the treatment parameters of interest in the setting, as well as breakdown values for conclusions regarding the true treatment effects. I derive √ N-consistent nonparametric estimators for the bounds of treatment effects and for breakdown values. These results can be used to assess the robustness of empirical conclusions obtained under the assumption that the instrument is independent from potential quantities, which is a pervasive concern in studies that use IV methods with observational data. In the empirical application, I show that the conclusions regarding the effects of family size on female unemployment using same-sex sibling as the instrument are highly sensitive to violations of independence.

title: Impact of national policies and laws on global mangrove deforestation
affiliations: University of Tasmania, Georgetown University Law Center, Universiti Kebangsaan Malaysia, Griffith University, Georgetown University Law Center, University of Queensland, Griffith University, Oregon State University, University of Leeds, WWF-Mexico, Griffith University, Griffith University, East Carolina University, East Carolina University, National Research and Innovation Agency (BRIN), Griffith University, Griffith University, Griffith University and World Wildlife Fund for Nature

detail.title: Impact of national policies and laws on global mangrove deforestation

declarations.declarationOfInterest: C.J.B. is a member of the coordinating committee of the Global Mangrove Alliance and D.A.B. is a member of the Alliance’s steering committee. The Global Mangrove Alliance is an organization that advocates for the conservation of mangrove forests. All other authors have declared no conflicts of interest. detail.abstract: Conservation of the world’s ecosystems can occur through multiple legal pathways, from protected areas that focus on biodiversity conservation to national scale policies and laws that coordinate, manage, and regulate uses of ecosystems. Protected areas have mixed benefits for biodiversity outcomes; but the benefits of national policies and laws for ecological outcomes have not been evaluated globally. We used causal analyses to attribute changes in mangrove deforestation to policy and law adoption. We considered protected areas along with national scale policies restricting cutting and clearing, presence of a mangrove-specific policy, and coordination mechanisms. From 1996-2011, cutting and clearing restrictions reduced mangrove losses by up to 59%, but their effectiveness has diminished more recently. Protected areas also reduced mangrove loss, and were most effective in nations that lacked cutting and clearing restrictions. Our results show that national scale policies and laws are an important pathway for mangrove conservation. While protected area coverage has dominated recent dialogues on global conservation progress, our findings suggest ecosystem conservation would benefit from greater attention to strengthening policies and laws for ecosystem protection.

title: Unified 3d Point Cloud Representations in Hyperbolic Space
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Unified 3d Point Cloud Representations in Hyperbolic Space
detail.abstract: Self-supervised learning has made significant progress in Natural Language Processing and Computer Vision. Nevertheless, it encounters significant obstacles in the 3D domain, primarily due to the scarcity of available data and the considerable challenge of effectively capturing hierarchical structures. Current methods in Euclidean space suffer from feature distortion and fail to model the semantic hierarchies inherent in cross-modal data. These challenges motivate us to adopt hyperbolic space, which excels at capturing multi-scale relationships and preserving the geometric structure of complex data. In this paper, we propose HyperPoint, the first unified method for point cloud representation learning in hyperbolic space. By projecting cross-modal features such as 3D point cloud, 2D images, and text into hyperbolic space, we leverage its tree-like properties to encode semantic hierarchies with minimal distortion. Our method integrates generative and contrastive learning while leveraging multi-loss optimization to enhance feature diversity and consistency. HyperPoint achieves a new state-of-the-art in 3D representation learning, e.g., 96.1% accuracy on ScanObjectNN, 94.1% accuracy on 10w10s on ModelNet40.

title: Unite and Conquer: Consolidation in China's Rare Earths Industry
affiliations: Harvard University - Harvard Law School

detail.title: Unite and Conquer: Consolidation in China's Rare Earths Industry
detail.abstract: Most Western analyses of China’s dominance of rare earths focus on two factors: the high amounts of rare earths in Chinese territory and the low environmental standards and costs involved with Chinese mining and processing of rare earths. Both points are indeed major factors that help to explain why China has a vice grip on rare earths mining and processing, because China has been endowed with the world’s largest deposits of rare earths by a wide margin. Besides, although Chinese environmental standards have been tightened considerably in recent years, they are still more lax than in the West. However, a factor behind China’s success that has been downplayed to some extent is the consolidation of the state-owned enterprises (SOEs) that are active in China’s rare earths industry, which has lowered costs and improved efficiency by strengthening vertical integration, supply chain management, and price control while ameliorating the negative impact of mining and processing on the local environment. This article seeks to fill this gap by providing more information on the history of the rare earths industry and on the positive impact of consolidation on China's rare earths SOEs.
