title: Vocal for Local: Strengthening India's Economic Sovereignty and Global Influence
affiliations: Soban Singh Jeena University

detail.title: Vocal for Local: Strengthening India's Economic Sovereignty and Global Influence

publicationDetails.detailsText: Vocal for Local (Vol. 2), Pacific Books International. ISBN- 9789348285720

detail.abstract: The 'Vocal for Local initiative, launched as part of India's broader vision of self-reliance (Atmanirbhar Bharat), represents a strategic economic and political movement to reduce foreign dependence while fostering indigenous industries. This paper plans to examine the initiative from a political and international relations perspective, assessing its role in enhancing India's global stature through economic self-sufficiency. It explores how promoting local businesses contributes to national security, economic resilience, and diplomatic leverage in an increasingly volatile global order. The paper highlights opportunities and challenges in balancing globalisation with local empowerment. The study also considers the implications for India's trade negotiations, regional leadership, and international competitiveness. Through empirical evidence and policy analysis, this research aims to provide insights into how ‘Vocal for Local aligns with India’s long-term strategic interests.

title: Continuous Interpretation of Critical Discount Factors
affiliations: University of Potsdam

detail.title: Continuous Interpretation of Critical Discount Factors
detail.abstract: While critical discount factors are often interpreted as continuous measures of "cooperativeness" in infinitely repeated games, classical equilibrium theory does not justify this view. This paper shows that a continuous interpretation is possible when discount factors, beliefs, or both are stochastic. I formalize the necessary axioms and characterize the resulting stochastic equilibria, which are similar yet distinct from quantal response equilibria. The results contribute to both theory and applied work, offering a framework for analyzing cooperation in settings such as collusion and institutional interventions.

title: Testing and Comparing Asset Pricing Factor Models: An Out-of-Sample Perspective
affiliations: Southeast University, Southwestern University of Finance and Economics (SWUFE) - Statistical School and Center of Statistical Research, Nankai University and City University of Hong Kong (CityU)

detail.title: Testing and Comparing Asset Pricing Factor Models: An Out-of-Sample Perspective
detail.abstract: Kan, Wang, and Zheng (2024, JFE) demonstrate that estimation risk drives performance gaps between in-sample (INS) and out-of-sample (OOS) evaluations for factor portfolios. Addressing similar challenges in asset pricing model tests, we introduce the Sample Splitting Alpha (SSA) test, an OOS framework tailored for high-dimensional test assets. Our SSA test utilizes data-splitting techniques to decouple portfolio weight estimation from model testing and evaluates model performance using OOS ridge-regularized portfolios. Under standard regularity conditions, the SSA statistic asymptotically follows a Gaussian distribution, enabling straightforward inference. Furthermore, the SSA test provides a practical method for evaluating asset pricing models, directly tied to the OOS information ratio for efficient model comparison. Simulation results are presented to validate the statistical properties. Our empirical analysis finds that while many models fail to explain the risk-return tradeoffs in INS analysis, they are not rejected in OOS tests.

title: Bowling Leagues and Facebook Friends: Rethinking Social Capital in the Digital Age
affiliations: University of Vermont - College of Agriculture and Life Sciences - Department of Community Development and Applied Economics and College  of  Agriculture,  Department  of  Agricultural  Economics,  Purdue  University

detail.title: Bowling Leagues and Facebook Friends: Rethinking Social Capital in the Digital Age
detail.abstract: This paper compares the "bowling alone" method of quantifying social capital-based on the density of civic organizations and brick-and-mortar institutions-with newer approaches that draw on billions of online friendship ties to assess economic connectedness and social cohesion. Using county-level data from across the continental United States, we construct and compare indices of traditional and digital social capital, mapping their geographic distributions and assessing their correlation. Our analysis reveals that these two measures are only weakly correlated and exhibit strikingly different spatial patterns, with traditional social capital highest in rural areas and digital social capital concentrated in metropolitan regions. Each measure captures complementary, but not substitutable, dimensions of community connectedness. These results challenge the idea that either metric alone is sufficient for transformative community development, stressing the importance of an integrated approach to understanding the full spectrum of local social ties in the modern era.

title: Wage–Salary Differentials in the Indian Food Processing Industry since 1980s: A Disaggregated Analysis
affiliations: SBS College (University of Delhi), New Delhi, India and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Wage–Salary Differentials in the Indian Food Processing Industry since 1980s: A Disaggregated Analysis
detail.abstract: This study examines whether the wage-salary structure of the Indian food processing industry has undergone changes since 1981. To do so, data on wages of production workers and salaries of skilled employees were sourced from the Annual Survey of Industries. The data has been deflated and concorded using appropriate deflators and concordance, respectively. To trace the differentials and structural changes in average wage and average salary, graphical and time trend growth rate methods were used. The findings indicate that the industry has experienced significant structural changes in wage-salary differentials since 1981. The salaries paid to skilled employees have grown much faster than the wages paid to production workers. Indeed, the wage-salary gap widened over the study period, specifically, the post-reform period. Additionally, skilled employees remain closely linked to faster adoption of technology and productivity growth, indicating an increasing intensity of capital and technological improvements. It suggests that food processors and policymakers must plan well-coordinated application of labour, capital and technology in food processing operations so that India can keep up with the growing demand for processed food products in domestic and export markets.

title: Balanced Scorecard: History, Implementation, and Impact
affiliations: University of South-Eastern Norway USN School of Business

detail.title: Balanced Scorecard: History, Implementation, and Impact
detail.abstract: The Balanced Scorecard (BSC) is a strategic management framework introduced by Kaplan and Norton in 1992 to address the limitations of traditional performance measurement systems. It integrates financial and non-financial performance measures across four perspectives-financial, customer, internal processes, and learning and growth. Over three decades, the BSC has evolved into a comprehensive strategic tool adopted across industries and sectors worldwide. While its adaptability and integrative approach are strengths, criticisms include challenges in implementation, assumed cause-effect relationships, and relevance in decentralized organizations. Future research should investigate cultural adaptation; the incorporation of environmental, social, and governance metrics; and advancements driven by artificial intelligence to maintain ongoing relevance.

title: Shrink with Purpose: Optimal Covariance Matrix Estimation for Portfolio Selection
affiliations: UCLouvain - LFIN/LIDAM, LFIN/LIDAM, UCLouvain  and LFIN/LIDAM, UCLouvain

detail.title: Shrink with Purpose: Optimal Covariance Matrix Estimation for Portfolio Selection
detail.abstract: We introduce analytical linear and nonlinear shrinkage estimators of the sample covariance matrix that are optimal for mean-variance portfolio choice. Unlike the classical estimators based on statistical loss functions like the mean squared error, our shrinkage covariance matrices optimize the expected out-of-sample portfolio utility and account for estimation errors in mean returns. Our estimators shrink the sample eigenvalues more intensively than conventional methods, and they especially diminish the contribution of principal components with small squared Sharpe ratios. By jointly estimating the covariance matrix and the optimal portfolio in one step, our method delivers significant empirical performance gains relative to the usual two-step shrinkage approach. Our portfolios also help reduce turnover and outperform recent regularized mean-variance portfolio strategies.

title: Changing BASEL reforms for Banking Sector
affiliations: M S Ramaiah University of Applied Sciences - M S Ramaiah University of Applied Sciences, Department of Management Studies, Students and M S Ramaiah College of Arts, Science and Commerce

detail.title: Changing BASEL reforms for Banking Sector
detail.abstract: Scope of Money market leading to incorporation of more banks. Financial sector reforms started in 1991 provided necessary banking sector to operate based on operational flexibility and functional autonomy, enhancing productivity and efficiency in Indian banking sector. The present study has focused on BASEL reforms that effects the organizational operations of banking sector at the global level.

title: Effects of Financial Speculation on Households
affiliations: BI Norwegian Business School, Texas A&M University - Mays Business School - Finance Department and University of Iowa - Department of Finance

detail.title: Effects of Financial Speculation on Households
detail.abstract: Financial speculation is often blamed for market instability, yet its impact on households that do not invest in speculative markets is less understood. We study the impact of financial speculation, driven by cash flow disagreement, on the welfare of households that do not participate in the stock market and save in the risk-free asset. Without additional frictions, households forego the equity premium, which reduces their consumption share, though speculation itself does not affect it. While speculation increases asset price volatility and causes significant fluctuations in speculators' consumption shares, it does not affect the volatility of households' shares. Our findings challenge the view that speculation negatively affects households, instead suggesting that financial exclusion, not speculative excess, is the key barrier to wealth accumulation. Our framework serves as an important benchmark for identifying the economic mechanisms through which financial speculation impacts households.

title: A Unified Meta-Learning Theory: A Cognitive and Experimental Framework to Train Thinking and Decision Making for Human and Machine Learning
affiliations: ODEFTO TECH PRIVATE LIMITED

detail.title: A Unified Meta-Learning Theory: A Cognitive and Experimental Framework to Train Thinking and Decision Making for Human and Machine Learning
detail.abstract: This paper presents a groundbreaking synthesis of learning theory that redefines our understanding of the learning process through a comprehensive, integrative framework. Drawing upon extensive analysis of established learning theories-from behaviorism to connectivism and others-this work proposes a novel definition that positions learning as "the process of repetition, imitation, imagination & experimentation to use all the available tools, methods and techniques to train our brain & our thought process by observation & analysis to find best possible combinations to use for making better decisions than our current state to achieve a particular outcome." This is a revolutionary framework for understanding learning process to bridge traditional theories with future-ready practice not only encompasses both conscious and unconscious learning processes but also provides a revolutionary lens through which to understand skill acquisition, decision-making, and human potential maximization in the digital age. MetaLearning connotes learning how to learn and mastering the learning process.

title: DEFORESTATION AND ITS IMPACTS ON BIODIVERSITY AND ECOSYSTEMS
affiliations: EDUKIVOTOS

detail.title: DEFORESTATION AND ITS IMPACTS ON BIODIVERSITY AND ECOSYSTEMS
detail.abstract:
This document analyzes the complex impacts of deforestation on biodiversity, ecosystems, climate, and local communities. It highlights habitat fragmentation, biodiversity loss, soil degradation, and disruptions to water and carbon cycles. The text also examines social, economic, and cultural consequences, emphasizing the need for sustainable forest management, community participation, and ethical responsibility. Solutions proposed include reforestation, ecological restoration, environmental education, and public policies promoting conservation and social justice to ensure a sustainable future for both people and nature.

title: Nature Nurtures: A Study on the Academic and Behavioral Impact of Eco-Friendly Campuses on Students
affiliations: Niilm University Kaithal Haryana India, Independent and Independent

detail.title: Nature Nurtures: A Study on the Academic and Behavioral Impact of Eco-Friendly Campuses on Students
detail.abstract: This study explores the impact of eco-friendly educational campuses on students' academic performance and behavioral development. With rising global awareness around sustainability, green campuses are not only reducing environmental footprints but also creating healthier, more engaging learning environments. The study employed a mixed-method approach involving quantitative surveys and qualitative interviews among students from eco-friendly and conventional campuses. Results indicate that green campuses positively influence students' academic motivation, focus, emotional well-being, and pro-environmental behavior. The findings underscore the importance of integrating sustainability into campus design for holistic student development.

title: Optimization Configuration of the Whole Life Cycle of Photovoltaic and Storage System Considering Carbon Emission and Improved Line Loss Rate Calculation Model
affiliations: Zhengzhou University of Light Industry, Zhengzhou University of Light Industry, Zhengzhou University of Light Industry, affiliation not provided to SSRN, Zhengzhou University of Light Industry and Zhengzhou University of Light Industry

detail.title: Optimization Configuration of the Whole Life Cycle of Photovoltaic and Storage System Considering Carbon Emission and Improved Line Loss Rate Calculation Model
detail.abstract: To address the multi-objective planning problem of siting and sizing of distributed photovoltaic(PV) and battery energy storage systems(BESS) in distribution networks, this paper proposes an optimization method based on life cycle cost analysis for PV-BESS. The method incorporates carbon emissions and an improved line loss rate calculation model, which is a multi-objective bi-level programming framework. The bi-level optimization model integrating planning and operation of PV-BESS is established. The upper-level aims to optimize life cycle costs and power quality, while the lower-level targets is minimizing the operating costs, line loss rate, and carbon emissions. An improved particle swarm optimization algorithm is employed to solve the mode. Besides, an improved line loss rate calculation method is proposed, and the optimal solution is selected using the TOPSIS method based on information entropy weight. Finally, simulation results demonstrate that the planning of PV-BESS is optimized with the proposed model, reducing costs and carbon emissions, enhancing power quality. The method aligns with the dual-carbon goals and the requirements of the new power system.

title: The Impact of the Indian Demonetisation on Terrorism
affiliations: Independent

detail.title: The Impact of the Indian Demonetisation on Terrorism
detail.abstract: In November 2016, the Indian government invalidated Rs. 500 and Rs. 1,000 notes-legally erasing 86 percent of its cash in circulation overnight. Did this liquidity shock disrupt terrorist organisations? By extracting the underlying unpublished data on the true demonetization shock from one of Chodorow-Reich et al. [2019]'s heat maps, I conduct the first causal study of demonetization's impact on terrorism. Aggregate terror incidents remain unchanged, but striking heterogeneity emerges: Left-Wing Extremism (LWE) areas show no disruption, whereas in the Northeast (NE) capital-intensive attacks fall by roughly 53 percent in the first quarter post-shock (and again in the fourth quarters post demonetisation), coupled with a temporary spike in kidnappings between 64 and 255 over the six months following the shock.

title: Board Gender Diversity and Workforce Composition, Compensation, and Retention for U.S. Publicly Traded Firms
affiliations: Middlebury College - Department of Economics, University of Utah - Department of Finance, University of Utah - David Eccles School of Business and Eller College of Management, University of Arizona

detail.title: Board Gender Diversity and Workforce Composition, Compensation, and Retention for U.S. Publicly Traded Firms
detail.abstract: We use administrative data from the U.S. Census to estimate the effect of female director representation on workplace gender diversity and women's earnings. Using a difference-indifferences estimator that correctly accounts for variation in treatment timing, we show that first-time female director appointments lead to subsequent increases in workplace gender diversity. We find that the effects are driven by the improved retention of female workers in the middle and upper quartiles of the firm's overall earnings distribution. We find suggestive evidence that the effects are due to the newly appointed female directors' influence on corporate policy, as we observe stronger effects when the director is placed on one of the board's three core committees.

title: Inflation Forecast Targeting Revisited
affiliations: Heidelberg University - Alfred Weber Institute for Economics, University of Heidelberg and University of Tübingen - Department of Economics

detail.title: Inflation Forecast Targeting Revisited
detail.abstract: Under inflation forecast targeting, central banks such as the ECB adjust policy to keep expected inflation on target. We evaluate the ECB's inflation forecasts: they are unbiased and efficient but contain little information at forecast horizons beyond three quarters. In a New Keynesian model with transmission lags, inflation forecast targeting is indeed effective in stabilizing inflation - provided there is no forward-looking behavior - though the information content of forecasts is unrealistically high. In the presence of forward-looking behavior, the information content declines because monetary policy becomes more effective in meeting the target, but inflation is best stabilized by targeting current inflation.

title: Judicial Efficiency, Employment Protection, and Labor Cost Stickiness: Evidence from China's Civil Justice Triage Reform
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and Xi'an Jiaotong University (XJTU) - School of Management

detail.title: Judicial Efficiency, Employment Protection, and Labor Cost Stickiness: Evidence from China's Civil Justice Triage Reform
detail.abstract: This study examines how improved civil judicial efficiency affects enterprise labor cost stickiness. Exploiting China’s civil justice triage reform as a natural experiment and using a DID design, we find enhanced judicial efficiency significantly increases labor cost stickiness. The mechanism is that better courts empower workers, raising costs and legal risks of workforce reductions, reducing firms’ adjustment flexibility. This effect is stronger in firms with greater worker protection, higher labor litigation risk, or facing greater external pressure. This provides novel evidence on judicial reform's impact on corporate labor practices in emerging markets.

title: Public Climate Risk Concerns and Corporate Debt Behavior
affiliations: Guangxi University for Nationalities, Guangxi Minzu University and Guangxi University

detail.title: Public Climate Risk Concerns and Corporate Debt Behavior
detail.abstract: This study investigates the impact of regional public climate risk concerns on corporate debt behavior using data from China’s Shanghai and Shenzhen A-share listed companies. Empirical evidence demonstrates that increased public attention to climate risks significantly extends corporate debt maturity, driving firms toward long-term debt structures. To address endogeneity concerns, instrumental variable methods and System Generalized Method of Moments (GMM) analyses confirm the robustness of these findings. The mediation mechanisms reveal that public climate risk concerns have dual effects: quantitatively, they tighten external financing constraints and amplify short-term liquidity risks; qualitatively, they reduce corporate greenwashing practices, foster "green trust," and expand access to long-term green investment funding, thereby incentivizing debt maturity extension. The heterogeneity analysis shows that when the corporate reputation is better and the property right is state-owned, the long-term effect of corporate debt structure under the public climate risk is more obvious; In addition, due to the complementarity and regional differences between public climate risk concerns and external environmental regulation, when the environmental regulation is stronger and the geographical location is in the north, the effect of public climate risk concerns on the long-term debt structure of enterprises is more significant. By integrating public climate risk perceptions into debt structure analysis, this research contributes to the theoretical framework of corporate debt optimization and provides new insights for managing debt maturity selection and mitigating financial risks in an era of climate uncertainty.

title: Climate Calm? Long-Run Temperature Signals and Volatility in EU Carbon Futures
affiliations: University of Twente

detail.title: Climate Calm? Long-Run Temperature Signals and Volatility in EU Carbon Futures
detail.abstract: We test whether long-horizon climate information explains and forecasts volatility in European Union Allowance (EUA) futures. Daily Phase II–IV prices (2008–2024) are combined with monthly climate proxies in a two-step GARCH-MIDAS design. First, a state-space filter extracts the stochastic trend in global temperature anomalies; the trend’s first difference captures incremental shifts in the warming path. Second, an indicator flags months when the exponentiated trend exceeds its 88th percentile, isolating extreme shifts rather than ordinary weather noise. Both proxies load negatively in the MIDAS filter: faster warming and more frequent extreme shifts are associated with lower conditional variance once high-frequency weather shocks are removed. Out-of-sample, the climate-augmented model reduces one-day-ahead volatility errors by roughly 20% relative to the best conventional GARCH, a lead validated by Model Confidence Set and Diebold–Mariano tests. Feeding these forecasts into a mean–variance rule delivers higher excess and certainty-equivalent returns across risk-aversion levels. Incorporating slow moving climate metrics therefore sharpens volatility estimates and yields a clear volatility dampening effect, enhancing risk-management tools for investors and regulators.

title: Fintextsim-Llm: Improving Corporate Performance Prediction Through Scalable, Llm-Enhanced Financial Topic Modeling and Aspect-Based Sentiment
affiliations: Universidad Politecnica de Madrid, Universidad Politécnica de Madrid and Hochschule Heilbronn

detail.title: Fintextsim-Llm: Improving Corporate Performance Prediction Through Scalable, Llm-Enhanced Financial Topic Modeling and Aspect-Based Sentiment
detail.abstract: Predicting corporate performance remains a core challenge in financial research. While structured financial variables have long served as dominant predictors, recent work explores incorporating sentiment from textual disclosures. However, most approaches rely on coarse document-level sentiment, neglecting the topical context in which sentiment appears, limiting interpretability and predictive power. Further, robust topic-extraction itself remains challenging. To address these challenges, we propose FinTextSim-LLM, a scalable and interpretable framework for extracting topic-specific sentiment from 10-K filings. Our approach combines FinTextSim, a domain-specific sentence-transformer, with a lightweight, retrieval-augmented generation setup. Over 90% of sentences are classified via efficient embedding-based similarity. Only ambiguous cases, identified through entropy and silhouette score, are passed to an LLM, guided by keywords, topic definitions, document context and labeled examples. This hybrid design injects domain-knowledge, improves efficiency and enhances transparency, addressing key concerns about LLM deployment in financial settings. Empirically, FinTextSim-LLM achieves 98.2% coverage, substantially outperforming embedding-clustering and LLM-based topic modeling methods. When integrated into predictive models, FinTextSim-LLM’s topic-specific sentiment significantly enhances forecasts of changes in diluted earnings per share, outperforming financial-only models, and exceeding the effect of document-level sentiment by up to 49%. Our findings highlight the predictive value of aligning sentiment with economic topics and demonstrate that interpretable, finegrained textual signals can meaningfully improve forecasting of corporate performance. FinTextSim-LLM offers a practical pathway for researchers and practitioners seeking to integrate LLMs into high-stakes financial applications while ensuring transparency, scalability, and domain alignment.

title: Cheating on a Budget
affiliations: University of California Berkeley, Haas School of Business and McMaster University

detail.title: Cheating on a Budget

declarations.ethicsApproval: Ethics approval given by both McMaster and UC Berkeley IRBs.
declarations.funderStatement: UC Berkeley Experimental Social Sciences Lab, McMaster Decision Science Lab

detail.abstract: Social dilemmas with a shared resource pool and privately observed entitlements are susceptible to overclaiming. A dishonest claim that exceeds one's true entitlement imposes a negative externality on others. To explore such social dilemmas, we introduce a novel four-player game where each player rolls a die in private and earns their die report, subject to budget availability. We vary the timing of players' reporting (simultaneous vs sequential moves) and the available budget (limited vs excess). When resources are limited, mean reports do not differ significantly between simultaneous and sequential treatments. However, simultaneous reporting promotes greater equity under scarcity and reduces dishonesty when resources are plentiful. Frequent displays of virtue signaling take place whereby Player 4 chooses to earn zero by reporting more than the remaining budget. Our results demonstrate that these social dilemmas can be better managed by promoting simultaneous reporting structures, which obscure information about individual claims.

title: The Impact of Climate Risk on Firms' Flexible Employment Strategies: A Study of Chinese Enterprises
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, Jilin University of Finance and Economics and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: The Impact of Climate Risk on Firms' Flexible Employment Strategies: A Study of Chinese Enterprises
detail.abstract: As global warming accelerates, enterprises are increasingly facing climate risk, which not only affects their operational efficiency and cost structures but also necessitates changes in their labor strategies. This study employs data from companies listed on the A-share market from 2013 to 2023 and investigates the effects and mechanisms of climate risk exposure on flexible employment. Our findings reveal that climate risk encountered by firms encourages the implementation of flexible employment practices. The mechanism test shows that climate risk promotes flexible employment by increasing labor costs, financing costs, innovation investments, and adoption of artificial intelligence. Additional analysis indicates that climate risk positively affects flexible employment application in non-labor-intensive enterprises and firms in the non-recessionary period of their life cycle. This study uncovers the link between climate risk and flexible employment in enterprises, providing empirical evidence for firms to address climate-related challenges and optimize their human resource structures.

title: Does Inflation Targeting Track Record Matter for Asset Prices? Evidence From Stock, Bond, and Foreign Exchange Markets
affiliations: International Monetary Fund (IMF)

detail.title: Does Inflation Targeting Track Record Matter for Asset Prices? Evidence From Stock, Bond, and Foreign Exchange Markets
detail.abstract: Many central banks have adopted inflation targeting as their monetary policy frameworks since 1990. Yet, monetary authorities' track records of managing inflation with respect to the stated policy objectives have varied significantly. This paper examines how inflation targeting track records affect asset prices within three common asset classes: stocks, bonds, and exchange rates. The analysis reveals heterogeneous and enduring effects of track records on financial markets. A stronger track record in inflation targeting leads to a more negative reaction from stock markets to inflationary pressures, with effects persisting for about four quarters. Additionally, the sensitivity of rising long-term sovereign bond yields to inflation diminishes for about three quarters as the track record improves. Moreover, credible inflation targeters are more likely to allow greater flexibility in exchange rates to deal with inflationary shocks. Consequently, credible inflation targeting track records produce desirable policy outcomes by reinforcing monetary policy transmission and saving fiscal space.

reference: Forthcoming in the Journal of Accounting and Economics
title: The Promises and Pitfalls of Mandated Ownership Transparency: A Discussion of Amberger, Wilde, and Wu (2025)
affiliations: University of Chicago - Booth School of Business

detail.title: The Promises and Pitfalls of Mandated Ownership Transparency: A Discussion of Amberger, Wilde, and Wu (2025)

publicationDetails.detailsText: Forthcoming in the Journal of Accounting and Economics

detail.abstract: Amberger, Wilde, and Wu (2025, AWW) examine the impact of EU beneficial ownership transparency (BOT) regulation on cross-border investment. They find that BOT is associated with reductions in investments from non-EU financial havens into the EU and that BOT unintentionally discourages legitimate investments without deterring illicit actors. My discussion evaluates AWW's evidence, positions the paper within the existing literature, and discusses its contributions. I particularly focus on challenges in measuring illicit activities and the impact of voluntary FDI data reporting by EU countries. I also assess how privacy concerns and recent legal decisions have shaped the evolving landscape of beneficial ownership mandates and how they may affect the public scrutiny mechanism going forward. To contextualize the paper's findings, I provide new survey evidence on private firms' disclosure practices and interview-based insights into the practical use of BOT registries. I conclude with suggestions for future research.

title: Second-degree Price Discrimination: Theoretical Analysis, Experiment Design, and Empirical Estimation
affiliations: Yale University, Yale School of Management, London Business School and Airports Authority of India (AAI)

detail.title: Second-degree Price Discrimination: Theoretical Analysis, Experiment Design, and Empirical Estimation
detail.abstract: We build on theoretical results from the mechanism design literature to analyze empirical models of second-degree price discrimination (2PD). We show that for a random-coefficient discrete choice ("BLP") model to be suitable for studying 2PD, it must capture the covariance between two key random effects: (i) the "baseline" willingness to pay (affecting all product versions), and (ii) the perceived differentiation between versions. We then develop an experimental design that, among other features, identifies this covariance under common data constraints in 2PD environments. We implement this experiment in the field in collaboration with an international airline. Estimating the theoretically motivated empirical model on the experimental data, we demonstrate its applicability to 2PD decisions. We also show that test statistics from our design can enable qualitative inference on optimal 2PD policy even before estimating a demand model. Our methodology applies broadly across second-degree price discrimination settings.

title: Inflation Targets, Bands, and Track Records: A Dataset of Inflation Targeting Countries
affiliations: International Monetary Fund (IMF)

detail.title: Inflation Targets, Bands, and Track Records: A Dataset of Inflation Targeting Countries
detail.abstract: This paper presents a comprehensive panel dataset of 41 Inflation Targeting (IT) countries from 1990 to 2024 regarding their inflation targets, bands, and track records. First, data on inflation targets and bands are collected through each central bank’s historical documents. Second, several rules-based track record measures are calculated for inflation targeting countries over specific past periods to assess actual inflation outcomes with respect to the central banks’ stated policy objectives. The dataset, which covers both developed and developing countries, is useful for empirical research in economics and finance. Potential reuse areas of this dataset include studies on central banks’ adjustments of inflation targets and bands, the interplay between inflation targeting and economic performance, and the relationship between inflation targeting and financial markets.

title: Methods of Medical Treatment and (Mis)Use of an Invention: Clarifying Grant Versus Scope Of Patent Protection
affiliations: University of Windsor Faculty of Law and University of Windsor Faculty of Law

detail.title: Methods of Medical Treatment and (Mis)Use of an Invention: Clarifying Grant Versus Scope Of Patent Protection
detail.abstract: The Supreme Court of Canada is set to decide whether methods of medical treatment constitute patentable subject matter. The concerns surrounding extension of patent protection to methods of medical treatment, argued almost entirely on the grounds of patentable subject matter, assumes that a physician carrying out such treatment is patent infringer. Canadian jurisprudence has largely taken this assumption to be true. Interrogating the historical jurisprudence supporting the prohibition on patentability of methods of medical treatment, this article demonstrates that this jurisprudence is far from clear as to whether the issue is, or should be, approached as a question of patentability or infringement. An analysis of the case law on both patentability of methods of medical treatment, and what constitutes infringing ‘use’ of an invention, demonstrates that both lines of jurisprudence share similar concepts and underlying concerns. This has generated uncertainty as to whether the issue of extending patent protection to methods of medical treatment has ever clearly been a question of patentability. Rather, examining both lines of jurisprudence side-by-side, this piece demonstrates that concerns underlying extension of patent protection to cover methods of medical treatment have historically been categorized as scope of protection concerns, rather than patentability concerns. As such, the debate surrounding patent protection and methods of medical treatment is best characterized as an infringement issue.

title: Evaluating Trading Real Optionality Between NGLs and Petrochemicals
affiliations: New York University (NYU)

detail.title: Evaluating Trading Real Optionality Between NGLs and Petrochemicals
detail.abstract: Energy commodity trading strategies often exploit the real optionality embedded in physical transformation processes, such as refining one energy source into another. In the natural gas liquids (NGLs) sector, the ability to convert NGLs into petrochemicals creates opportunities for statistical arbitrage strategies that systematically capture and capitalize on price dislocations. This study examines whether systematically monitoring processing spreads between an NGL and its petrochemical derivative can lead to unique trading strategies. By evaluating both intra-and inter-spread strategies, the analysis identifies the most effective approaches and highlights the structural market dynamics that drive persistent and stable returns.

title: Patriarchy and Women's Voting Trends in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa (2008-2024)
affiliations: Universitas Islam Internasional Indonesia and Universitas Islam Internasional Indonesia

detail.title: Patriarchy and Women's Voting Trends in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa (2008-2024)
detail.abstract: This research paper pinpoints the role of the family patriarchal system in the exclusion of women in politics, by restricting women's right to vote, their public sphere, and involvement in the process of elections in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province of Pakistan. The study investigates the inequalities against women in the narrow domestic domains, thus limiting their participation through voting in elections and raising their voice in political space and decision-making in the Pakhtun society. The paper covers four general elections in the province, focusing on the role of male-dominated patriarchal culture in shaping political discourse and enforcing governance in Pakhtun society at the expense of women's non-participation in politics. Following Kate Millett's theory of patriarchy, the paper reveals that the family is a crucial institution that regulates and maintains the patriarchal structures, whereby men not only control and subjugate women inside the family environment but also restrict women's voices in public spheres and politics. This study applies qualitative methods that rely on empirical data published in academic literature, newspapers, and online sources that cover women's participation in the process of voting in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province. This research also provides important insights for policymakers, practitioners, and stakeholders to work for the inclusion of women in politics, thus advancing social justice and inclusive development in the country.

title: Volatility Regimes and Correlation Dynamics in International Stock Markets on Optimal Portfolio Investment
affiliations: School of Accounting, Finance and Economics, University of Waikato

detail.title: Volatility Regimes and Correlation Dynamics in International Stock Markets on Optimal Portfolio Investment
detail.abstract: A Markov-switching technique is used to examine co-movement dynamics between domestic and global stock markets and to develop a state-varying approach to the design of an international portfolio. A bivariate Markov switching ARCH (SWARCH) model is designed to evaluate four possible combinations of the volatility states which can characterize both the domestic and world markets, thus allowing the generation of state-varying portfolio loadings on the basis of 4-state correlations. The following conclusions are drawn. First, the domestic and global markets are more strongly correlated when both simultaneously find themselves in the same state of volatility. Conversely, this correlation is weaker when a different volatility state characterizes each market. Furthermore, the circumstances in which both the domestic and global stock markets simultaneously experience high levels of volatility prove strongest cross-market correlations, and result in least effective at reducing the risk stemming from international portfolio diversification. Next, this study determines state-varying portfolio loadings which prove effective at the task of asset allocation, particularly under conditions of market volatility. Finally, filtering structural changes out from the variance-switching process leads to a considerable decrease of the time variation involved in generating state-varying portfolio loadings, which, in turn, leads to lower transaction costs when compared to the performance of the conventional GARCH model.

title: From the Streets to the Field: Strategies for Reintegrating Former Child Laborers into Nigeria's Formal Education Through Structured Sports Programs
affiliations: Independent

detail.title: From the Streets to the Field: Strategies for Reintegrating Former Child Laborers into Nigeria's Formal Education Through Structured Sports Programs
detail.abstract: Children's formative years are inherently marked by a different form of enthusiasm, curiosity and dynamism that make learning easier. However, these attributes often fade when the environment to nurture them is non-existent. In a society like Nigeria where economic challenges are constantly on the rise, this lack of support can lead to more serious problems. Many children are forced to take on economic responsibilities, becoming active contributors to their family's income instead of focusing on their education. While helping their family is not bad in itself, the severity of what is done is not defined and the extent to which it is done is unregulated. This results in a pervasive practice of child labour, contributing to an increasing out-of-school problem. In respect to children's innate curiosity and strength, the core argument of this essay is that sports possess the capacity to pull students back into school. Sports such as football, athletics, basketball and others are not only culturally acceptable in Nigeria but also embodies the psychosocial attributes needed to promote self-esteem among children, particularly adolescents. As such, social work interventions must explore its viability to stimulate interest of child labourers in learning. This essay offers practical steps of achieving them, recognizing the role of local agents and allies in reducing the problem of child labour.

title: A Theory of Endogenous Institutions
affiliations: Universidad Alberto Hurtado and Universidad Alberto Hurtado - Economics Department

detail.title: A Theory of Endogenous Institutions
detail.abstract: This paper presents a theory of institutional determination by sovereign states. This theory posits that domestic institutions are the result of international strategic pressure exerted by the system of international relations in which sovereign states are embedded. Inclusive institutions are an equilibrium result from a competitive system of international relations that features many states, each with a high degree of local sovereignty. If there is a world empire or a decentralized international system with a strong and stable hegemon, the equilibrium outcome tends towards highly extractive institutions. Therefore, this paper argues that polycentrism in state power is a necessary and perhaps sufficient condition for inclusive institutions and, thus, for economic prosperity among the general population.

title: The enforceability of knock-for-knock indemnity clauses in offshore wind construction contracts Construction Law International (Construction Law International, IBA (March 2023)
affiliations: PEAK Wind

detail.title: The enforceability of knock-for-knock indemnity clauses in offshore wind construction contracts Construction Law International (Construction Law International, IBA (March 2023)
detail.abstract:
What happens when North Sea legal tradition meets American red tape? As offshore wind power charges into U.S. waters, it’s bringing with it a tried-and-true risk allocation tool from the oil & gas playbook: the knock-for-knock indemnity clause. Loved in Europe for its simplicity—you paid to fix your own stuff—this clause is anything but straightforward in the United States.

This article dives into the legal high seas of applying knock-for-knock in U.S. offshore wind construction. It explains how the clause works, why it's popular among developers, and where the icebergs lie—particularly in U.S. state anti-indemnity statutes, public policy exceptions, and the murky line between state law and federal maritime law. With analysis of key case law (including a guest appearance by Judge Cardozo), the paper explores whether these clauses can be enforced, and how parties can draft them to survive judicial scrutiny.

Spoiler alert: what sails smoothly in the North Sea may capsize off the coast of New York. But with smart drafting and the right choice-of-law clause, you can keep your project afloat.

title: Strict Construction Limiting "Additions" Exceptions to Michigan Ad Valorem Tax Cap in WPW Acquisition Co v- City of Troy, The Tax Lawyer (The State and Local Tax Lawyer) Vol. 8· (2003)
affiliations: PEAK Wind

detail.title: Strict Construction Limiting "Additions" Exceptions to Michigan Ad Valorem Tax Cap in WPW Acquisition Co v- City of Troy, The Tax Lawyer (The State and Local Tax Lawyer) Vol. 8· (2003)
detail.abstract:
When is an “addition” not really an addition? In WPW Acquisition Co. v. City of Troy, the Michigan Supreme Court dug deep into the weeds of tax law and constitutional interpretation to decide whether more tenants in an office building could justify a property tax hike above the cap set by Michigan's Proposal A. Spoiler: it could not. The court took a sharply technical view, holding that “additions” meant only physical additions—think bricks, not butts in seats.

This note unpacks the strange saga that followed: a city trying to claw back tax revenue after granting reductions during a vacancy slump, a legislature that tried to broaden the definition of “additions” after the constitutional amendment passed, and a court that said, “Not so fast.” The result? A legal asymmetry where municipalities must lower taxable value for lost occupancy, but can’t raise it when tenants return.

While the decision makes sense under rules of strict construction and constitutional supremacy, it creates a quagmire of fiscal weirdness and inequity—one that may lead to even more litigation unless the legislature (or another amendment) cleans it up. A case study in how one little word—“additions”—can carry a whole lot of tax drama.

title: The Symbiotic Relationship Between Economic Concentration and Political Capture: Beyond the Limits of Lobbying Data
affiliations: City of Philadelphia Law Department

detail.title: The Symbiotic Relationship Between Economic Concentration and Political Capture: Beyond the Limits of Lobbying Data
detail.abstract: This article challenges prevailing assumptions in political economy that rely heavily on lobbying expenditure data to assess the concentration of political influence. It argues that the conventional interpretation of lobbying data—as indicative of a competitive political marketplace—is both empirically flawed and conceptually misleading. Empirical deficiencies in the Lobbying Disclosure Act (LDA), such as shadow lobbying, underreporting, and the proliferation of opaque influence channels like "dark money," render the data deeply incomplete. More fundamentally, the paper critiques the underlying market analogy itself, showing how political influence is exercised through complex, multi-channel strategies that include substitution, complementation, and psychological priming—none of which are captured by lobbying disclosures. The article introduces the concept of dynamic substitution to explain how influence-seeking behavior has migrated from corporate lobbying to capital-based political spending, particularly following Citizens United. This shift has empowered ultra-wealthy individuals, whose political investments are decoupled from specific firms and more aligned with portfolio-wide ideological goals. These capital-holders fund expansive political infrastructures that operate through super PACs, nonprofit advocacy, media, and academia, further bypassing traditional transparency mechanisms. Drawing on analogies from antitrust law and theories of cumulative advantage, the article argues that the stability of lobbying data is not evidence of a lack of political concentration, but a reflection of entrenched political capture. It concludes that rising economic concentration, by enriching a small cohort of dominant shareholders, has enabled a self-reinforcing loop of political influence that erodes democratic responsiveness. By reframing political influence as a cumulative and structurally embedded phenomenon, the article calls for broader analytic and policy frameworks capable of capturing this evolving architecture of power.

title: Innovative Deals in Development Finance: Originate to Demonstrate (O2D)
affiliations: Risk Control Limited

detail.title: Innovative Deals in Development Finance: Originate to Demonstrate (O2D)
detail.abstract:
Development Finance Institutions (DFIs) value mobilisation as a way of increasing the development impact of their activities by drawing on the risk capacity of the private sector. As conventionally defined, mobilisation refers to financing contributed by private sector investors to transactions in which DFIs have participated.

Such direct mobilisation is only part of the story, however. One may hypothesise that the scale of development financing would be considerably greater if DFIs focused on deals that remove or mitigate informational or other barriers for other financial market participants. Transactions that reduce informational barriers in this way, eliciting follow-on transactions in which the original DFI is not involved, may be described as having ‘demonstration effects.’

Researchers have analysed demonstration effects in many different economic contexts. They are also frequently cited by DFIs to explain how their activities generate development. So far, however, most DFIs have not viewed demonstration effects as a key objective, and they are not commonly represented in internal DFI control frameworks such as pricing, limit setting, or corporate planning systems.

This report aims to lay the groundwork for ex-ante assessment of demonstration effects in DFI transactions. To achieve this, we examine a set of innovative transactions to identify what factors contributed to their success or otherwise in eliciting follow-on deals. Among the case studies, as well as DFI activities, we also include some private sector, developed-market transactions that did not involve DFIs to reveal key aspects of ‘market opening’ deals.

The deals we examine are shown in the below figure. The figure serves to emphasise how the deals are distributed over the three categories: (i) those for which demonstration effects are fully complete, (ii) those for which these effects are partially complete and (iii) those for which demonstration effects are in process.

title: The Response of Debtors to Rate Changes
affiliations: École Polytechnique Fédérale de Lausanne (EPFL), Nova School of Business and Economics, Goethe University Frankfurt, Goethe University Frankfurt and University of Chicago - Finance

detail.title: The Response of Debtors to Rate Changes
detail.abstract: How borrowers respond to future changes in the interest rate on their debt matters for the transmission of monetary policy and for financial stability. Combining data from a large bank, a letter RCT, and an online survey, we study this question in the context of the German mortgage market, where borrowers since 2022 have faced high interest rates  when their rate fixation period ends. We find that borrowers take various actions to reduce the impact of higher rates on monthly payments. Survey responses indicate high awareness of the evolution of interest rates and corroborate a strong propensity to prepare for the rate reset, which we show experimentally is sensitive to the size of the rate increase and to the distance from reset. Our letter intervention does not affect rate beliefs, consistent with high ex-ante knowledge and selection in who reads the letter, but increases awareness of available options.

title: Managing Burnout: The Critical Role of Middle Managers in Worker Retention and Performance
affiliations: Peking University - Guanghua School of Management, Bocconi University, Peking University - Guanghua School of Management and Peking University

detail.title: Managing Burnout: The Critical Role of Middle Managers in Worker Retention and Performance

declarations.ethicsApproval: The survey and interviews conducted in this research received IRB approval from Peking University (reference code: \#2025-17).
declarations.funderStatement: Yuyu Chen and Jingchen Zhu acknowledge support from the National Natural Science Foundation of China (grants 72394393 and 72322006, respectively). Shuo Liu acknowledges support from the Beijing Philosophy and Social Science Foundation (grant 24DTR019).

detail.abstract: Burnout is a growing concern in modern workplaces, with serious consequences for employee well-being, talent retention, and organizational performance. While middle managers are known to play a key role in shaping employee experiences, little is understood about how their day-today decisions affect burnout and productivity. This paper opens the black box of middle management by showing that the way managers allocate tasks drives both worker performance and turnover. We find that even with better information systems, outcomes depend heavily on managerial quality: good managers improve productivity and retain top talent, while other managers overburden highperforming workers, leading to burnout and attrition. These results highlight that technology alone is not enough-effective people management is critical to unlocking productivity and sustaining healthy organizations.

title: Overview of the EU's Relationship with Russian Gas: Recent Trends, Geopolitical Implications, and Economic Factors
affiliations: Stoliarchuk R&D

detail.title: Overview of the EU's Relationship with Russian Gas: Recent Trends, Geopolitical Implications, and Economic Factors

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The author declares no conflicts of interest or financial relationships that could influence the outcomes of this study.
declarations.ethicsApproval: This study does not involve human participants or animals and therefore does not require ethics approval.
declarations.funderStatement: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.

detail.abstract: Since Russia’s full-scale invasion of Ukraine in 2022, the European Union has substantially reduced its reliance on Russian pipeline gas, cutting imports from 40% in 2021 to approximately 8% by 2023. However, while pipeline deliveries declined, liquefied natural gas (LNG) imports from Russia increased significantly, making Russia the EU’s second-largest LNG supplier by 2023. France, Spain, and Belgium accounted for the majority of these imports. Despite political efforts to decouple from Russian energy, some member states—most notably Austria and Hungary—remain heavily reliant on Russian gas. The EU faces internal divisions over sanctioning Russian LNG and the future of gas transit via Ukraine, with potential implications for energy security. Long-term contracts and corporate commitments, such as TotalEnergies’ involvement in Yamal LNG, further complicate the situation. This paper analyzes recent trends, geopolitical frictions, and economic constraints shaping the EU’s energy policy, concluding that a coordinated, gradual phase-out strategy is essential to balance security, market stability, and political unity.

title: Does homeownership increase the housing stability of low-income households?
affiliations: Haslam College of Business, University of Tennessee, American University - Department of Finance and Real Estate and State University of New York, SUNY at Stony Brook University, College of Business

detail.title: Does homeownership increase the housing stability of low-income households?

keywords: Housing Choice Voucher Program JEL Classifications: G50

detail.abstract: We show that homeownership leads low-income homeowners to experience significant increases in their duration in residence relative to renting but small increases in housing burden. We trace individual households from renting to owning to establish that these patterns occur within the same household. Housing burden varies slightly with housing market cycles, family structure, and neighborhood characteristics. The duration of ownership, however, remains relatively uniform. Collectively, the evidence establishes that homeownership aided by a federal intervention to ease the transition from renter to homeowner can increase housing stability in low-income households.

title: Sailing In Calmer Waters: Trade Policy Uncertainty and Product Quality∗
affiliations: Guangdong University of Foreign Studies, affiliation not provided to SSRN and University of International Business and Economics (UIBE)

detail.title: Sailing In Calmer Waters: Trade Policy Uncertainty and Product Quality∗
detail.abstract: This paper examines a novel channel through which trade liberalization incentivizes quality upgrading by reducing trade policy uncertainty (TPU). Specifically, we analyze the impact of the US granting Permanent Normal Trade Relations (PNTR) status to China—a policy shift that effectively eliminated TPU on imports from China. Using a triple-difference estimation strategy, we find that reducing TPU encourages Chinese exporters to improve product quality for the US market, particularly among low-productivity firms, those in high-sunk-cost industries, and those located in regions with favorable market conditions. Quality upgrading by incumbent firms drives aggregate quality improvements, significantly contributing to welfare gains from trade.

title: Tuning of Mathematical Cognition
affiliations: Tecnológico de Monterrey - EGADE Business School, Tecnológico de Monterrey and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Tuning of Mathematical Cognition
detail.abstract: Standard measures of mathematical ability often conflate underlying cognitive capacity with performance dynamics shaped by the sequential structure of tasks. In this paper, we introduce a dynamic, trial-by-trial method for estimating mathematical ability that disentangles stable cognitive traits from adaptive behavioral patterns. Using two large-scale datasets, one comprising over 10,000 adults with validated SAT scores, and the other including school-age children, we show that our dynamic measure significantly outperforms traditional static metrics, such as the Weber fraction, in predicting formal math achievement. Our approach captures not only individual differences but also developmental and gender-specific tuning patterns across the lifespan. By accounting for within-task adaptation, we produce robust estimates of ability that more accurately explain observed behavior. These findings expose a methodological blind spot in cognitive assessment: temporal structure matters. Time-sensitive models are crucial for accurately inferring latent cognitive traits, with significant implications for both theoretical frameworks and applied diagnostics.

title: Racial Restrictions on Voting: Evidence from a New Pan-Anglophone Dataset, 1730-2000
affiliations: UC Berkeley School of Law

detail.title: Racial Restrictions on Voting: Evidence from a New Pan-Anglophone Dataset, 1730-2000
detail.abstract: A substantial literature studies franchise extension, focusing primarily on class-based-rather than race-based-voting restrictions. This paper constructs and analyzes a novel dataset that codes the presence of race-based restrictions on voting in 130 jurisdictions (primarily English-speaking subnational jurisdictions with substantial power to determine their electoral law) over 1730-2000. It documents extensive variation in these restrictions over time and across jurisdictions, exhibiting a cyclical pattern in sharp contrast to the continuous decline in class-based voting restrictions. To explain this variation, the paper uses a framework that emphasizes the distinction between centralized imperial control and the empowerment of local European settlers. A stacked event study analysis of the independence of colonies of settlement shows an absence of pre-trends, and implies that independence had a substantial positive effect on the probability of a racially restrictive franchise. The findings are similar but weaker for other forms of settler empowerment, such as dominion status. These results are robust to controlling for the existence and abolition of property (and other economic) qualifications for voting. They are consistent with a framework in which an imperial or federal government is less subject to capture by local settler elites, and thus more likely to promote franchise extension.

title: Macroeconomic Impacts of Climate Change under NGFS Scenarios
affiliations: Sungkyunkwan University and The Bank of Korea

detail.title: Macroeconomic Impacts of Climate Change under NGFS Scenarios

publicationDetails.journalName: Bank of Korea Economic Research Institute Research Paper Series

detail.abstract: This paper examines the environmental and macroeconomic impacts of changes in GVC (Global Value Chain) participation, cross-border externality of carbon emissions, environmental considerations in monetary policy, and international coordination in environmental policy across seven NGFS (Network for Greening the Financial System) scenarios. An Environmental Dynamic Stochastic General Equilibrium (EDSGE) model analysis shows that i) increased GVC participation, with higher reliance on imported intermediate goods, slows economic growth more significantly in high-pollution regimes, ii) stronger cross-border carbon emission externalities reduce economic growth in high-pollution regimes in the initial stages, iii) the emphasis on environmental issues in monetary policy has insignificant impact on carbon emissions while increasing macroeconomic volatility to more polluted regimes, and iv) enhanced cross-border environmental policy complementarity might initially benefit high-pollution regimes; however, delayed adjustment costs result in adverse effects over time. These findings suggest that while less stringent environmental policies may offer short-term benefits, these are outweighed by higher long-term transition costs. Therefore, a proactive environmental policy, aimed at achieving a 'Net Zero 2050' scenario, could foster more stable economic conditions. Furthermore, the environmental concerns in monetary policy should be moderated to mitigate potential side effects of indirect interventions on carbon emissions.

title: EU, Tear Down Your Walls: The Impacts of Emigration on Home Country Institutions
affiliations: Copenhagen Business School and University of Louisiana at Monroe - College of Business and Social Sciences

detail.title: EU, Tear Down Your Walls: The Impacts of Emigration on Home Country Institutions
detail.abstract: Pioneering work in the economics of immigration has investigated whether immigration impacts the economic institutions of host countries. Much less researched is how emigration impacts the economic institutions of sending nations. Using a novel natural experiment, we address this important gap in the literature. Specifically, we analyze what happened to economic institutions in Moldova after citizens of the country received the right to travel to European Union countries without a visa. This policy constituted an exogenous change in the ability to emigrate away from Moldova, drastically increasing emigration from the country. After this policy change, we find economic institutions improved in Moldova in a statistically significant way, and these effects are robust to sensitivity analysis. Our results suggest emigration improves economic institutions and that immigration restrictions in wealthy, immigrant-receiving countries may be negatively influencing institutions and economic development in poor, immigrant-sending countries.

title: Equity Accounting for Affiliates Repaying Loans: Practical Implications for the Middle East Market
affiliations: Independent

detail.title: Equity Accounting for Affiliates Repaying Loans: Practical Implications for the Middle East Market

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The author declares no personal or financial relationships with any individuals or organizations that could be perceived to have influenced this study. This research is based solely on publicly available, official IFRS sources and standards, and reflects independent analysis and interpretation.
declarations.ethicsApproval: This study did not involve any human participants or case studies and therefore did not require ethics approval or participant consent. The research is based solely on publicly available financial reporting standards and technical analysis.
declarations.funderStatement: This research was fully self-funded by the author. No external funding was received.

detail.abstract: Intercompany financing is a common feature in corporate structures across the Middle East, particularly in conglomerates and family-owned business groups. This paper examines the treatment of loan repayments by affiliates under the equity method of accounting, highlighting practical implications under International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS), specifically IAS 28, and related guidance. It also explores how these repayments affect investors' financial statements and considers disclosure and tax implications relevant to Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) markets.

title: Valorization of Copper Tailing Waste as a Binder for Assessing the Mechanical Integrity of Concrete
affiliations: Manipal University Jaipur and Manipal University Jaipur

detail.title: Valorization of Copper Tailing Waste as a Binder for Assessing the Mechanical Integrity of Concrete
detail.abstract: Copper tailing a residue left out after the extraction of copper from the parent ore. This residue is simply dumped in the surrounding locations, severely impacting the environment & human health, and hence needs urgent attention. On the other hand, sustainable resource utilization in the construction industry is very much required for reducing carbon emissions, as about 8% of carbon emissions globally are from the cement industry. In this research work, copper mine tailings (from the Khetri region of Banwas, Rajasthan, India) are used for partial cement replacement in the concrete. A concrete blend with a ratio of water/cement of 0.4 is designed to form sustainable concrete by mixing out cement with copper tailing at 0%, 5%, 10%, 15%, and 20%. The adaptability of material properties was evaluated by EDAX & XRF. The mechanical performance of concrete was analyzed on 7, 28, 56, & 84-day matured samples. Microstructural analyses were commenced by studying the morphologies of concrete samples through SEM and XRD. Results indicate improvement in mechanical performance at 5%-10% cement replacement with copper tailings waste. It was concluded that green concrete may be formed with copper tailings waste as binder at lower replacement levels.

title: Sequential Cheap Talk with Imperfectly Informed Experts
affiliations: University of Cyprus

detail.title: Sequential Cheap Talk with Imperfectly Informed Experts
detail.abstract: This paper studies a cheap talk game involving two imperfectly informed experts and an uninformed decision maker. The experts receive noisy signals about the state and communicate this information sequentially to the decision maker. In situations where experts perfectly observe the state, the information is fully transmitted to the decision maker. However, the presence of noise at both experts’ signals makes a fully revealing equilibrium unattainable. We describe the most informative equilibrium achievable under these conditions. Additionally, we refine the concept of a self-serving belief system, first introduced by Krishna and Morgan (2001b) in the context of uncertainty. We show that for a partition equilibrium to emerge, two conditions are necessary: a) the noise distribution must be bounded and common knowledge, and b) the experts’ biases are suﬃciently large and point in opposite directions.

title: Prudent vs. Positive: Fiscal Communication and Stock Market Volatility in China
affiliations: University of International Business and Economics, Peking University HSBC Business School, Central University of Finance and Economics and University of International Business and Economics (UIBE) - School of Banking and Finance

detail.title: Prudent vs. Positive: Fiscal Communication and Stock Market Volatility in China
detail.abstract: This study investigates the impact of fiscal communication on stock market volatility in China. Using a manually constructed database of fiscal statements from 2015 to 2022 and an EGARCH model, we find that while fiscal communication has a limited effect on market returns, it significantly reduces volatility. Further analysis reveals asymmetric effects: positive fiscal communication increases volatility by raising market uncertainty, whereas prudent communication reduces volatility by signaling fiscal discipline. These effects are contingent on market conditions, with distinct patterns observed in bull and bear markets. Our findings highlight the importance of strategic fiscal communication in stabilizing financial markets.

title: How Did You Find Your Job? Effects of the Job Search Channels on Labour Market Outcomes in Germany
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN and Bielefeld University - Department of Business Administration and Economics

detail.title: How Did You Find Your Job? Effects of the Job Search Channels on Labour Market Outcomes in Germany
detail.abstract: We study the effect of finding a job through one’s social contact on startingwages. Using combined SOEP-INKAR data for Germany and propensity scoreanalysis - both matching and weighting - we document that referral hiring is associatedwith a wage penalty of 10%. This penalty is stable over time. Separatingby the type of the social contact, we find that referrals from former colleagues areassociated with a 9% wage premium compared to a direct formal application. Incontrast, referrals from friends are associated with a 7% wage penalty. Our resultshighlight persistent self-selection of workers on observable and unobservable characteristics.Using information from a short test of cognitive abilities (symbol digittest) we document that workers recommended by former colleagues perform best inthe ability test, consistent with the predictions from a sorting model. The lowestperformance is recorded for those relying on the help of their friends. The effectsare primarily driven by the sub-sample of women. No significant differences acrosssearch channels are found for personality traits.

title: No Guarantees, No Gains? Rethinking the Relation Between Non-Personal Guarantees and Bank Profitability
affiliations: Tohoku University - Graduate School of Economics & Management and Tohoku University - Economics & Management

detail.title: No Guarantees, No Gains? Rethinking the Relation Between Non-Personal Guarantees and Bank Profitability

declarations.declarationOfInterest: No potential conflict of interest was reported by the author(s).
declarations.funderStatement: This project is funded by the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science (Grant numbers 25K16768).

detail.abstract: Japanese financial authorities promote lending without personal guarantees to facilitate business succession, revitalize the regional economy, and contribute to the bank stability. However, the willingness to provide non-personal guaranteed loans varies among banks. Furthermore, there are no previous studies that directly analyze the impact of non-personal guaranteed loans on bank profitability. Since Japanese regional banks disclose the proportion of non-personal guaranteed loans recently, this study aims to empirically clarify the impact of the non-personal guaranteed loans on bank profitability using 336 bank/year observations from fiscal year 2019 to 2023. The empirical results show that the proportion of non-personal guaranteed loans does not have an economically significant impact on bank profitability. This study makes an academic contribution by providing the first evidence on the impact of personal guarantees on bank profitability. It also makes a practical contribution by showing that non-personal guaranteed loans do not have a significant impact on the profitability of regional banks, at least during the sample period of this study.

title: The Impact of MLB Team Relocation on Hotel Demand
affiliations: Kennesaw State University and Berry College

detail.title: The Impact of MLB Team Relocation on Hotel Demand
detail.abstract: This analysis estimates the effect of a Major League Baseball team moving to Cobb County, Georgia on attracting visitors by observing changes in hotel room rentals. We employ a synthetic difference-in-differences event study approach to measure the causal effect of the team's inter-jurisdictional relocation within metropolitan Atlanta on hotel stays and room prices. Our analysis does not identify a demand shock from the team's move at the county level or in close proximity to the stadium. In total, the findings are not consistent with the hypothesis that sports venues offer a channel to increase community wealth through tourism.

title: Paths to Integration: Earnings, Skill Investments, and Outmigration Across Immigrant Admission Categories
affiliations: VATT Institute for Economic Research, Aalto University - Department of Economics and VATT Institute for Economic Research

detail.title: Paths to Integration: Earnings, Skill Investments, and Outmigration Across Immigrant Admission Categories

publicationDetails.journalName: IZA Institute of Labor Economics Discussion Paper Series

detail.abstract: We document substantial heterogeneity in labor market integration, skill investments, and outmigration across immigrant admission categories. Using newly available data on residence permits in Finland, we establish four facts. First, there are large initial differences in employment and earnings across labor, family, refugee, student, and EU migrants. Second, these differences diminish substantially over time. Third, the groups make distinct investments in country-specific and general skills. Fourth, both the prevalence of and selection into outmigration vary widely across admission categories. These findings align with models where investments in skills depend on the expected length of stay in the host country.

title: Spatial Patterns in the Formation of Economic Preferences
affiliations: The University of Sydney, Max Planck Institute for Research on Collective Goods, Heinrich-Heine-Universität Düsseldorf, Max Planck Institute for Research on Collective Goods and Max Planck Institute for Research on Collective Goods

detail.title: Spatial Patterns in the Formation of Economic Preferences

publicationDetails.journalName: IZA Institute of Labor Economics Discussion Paper Series

detail.abstract: We investigate how strongly the local environment beyond the family can contribute to understanding the formation of children's economic preferences. Building on precise geolocation data for around 6.000 children, we use fixed effects, spatial autoregressive models and Kriging to capture the relation between the local environment and children's preferences. The spatial models explain a considerable part of so far unexplained variation in preferences. Moreover, the "spatial stability" of preferences exceeds the village level. Our results highlight the importance of the local environment for the formation of children's preferences, which we quantify to be as large as that of parental preferences.

title: School Enrollment Shifts Five Years after the Pandemic
affiliations: Boston University and Brandeis University - Department of Economics

detail.title: School Enrollment Shifts Five Years after the Pandemic

publicationDetails.journalName: IZA Institute of Labor Economics Discussion Paper Series

detail.abstract: The pandemic induced a substantial enrollment shift away from public schools in fall 2020 and a partial return of students in fall 2021, leaving longer-term impacts unclear. We use Massachusetts state- and district-level data to explore enrollment patterns five years after the pandemic's onset. Relative to pre-pandemic trends, fall 2024 enrollment is down 2% in local public schools, up 14% in private schools, and up 45% in home schools. The highest income 20% of districts have lost more public school students than the other 80% combined, with these lower income districts having largely recovered. White and Asian public school enrollments have stabilized at levels 3% and 8% below pre-pandemic trends, while Black and Hispanic enrollments have more than fully recovered. Public school losses are almost entirely concentrated in middle grades (5-8), where enrollment is down 8%, suggesting families place particular weight on those ages when making post-pandemic schooling choices. Five years in, the pandemic has had sustained effects on the size and demographic composition of public schools. Many of the changes observed in Massachusetts appear in national data, suggesting these patterns are widespread.

title: Using Rcts in Economic Education Research
affiliations: State University of New York (SUNY) - University at Buffalo and Oregon State University - Department of Economics

detail.title: Using Rcts in Economic Education Research

publicationDetails.journalName: IZA Institute of Labor Economics Discussion Paper Series

detail.abstract: Randomized controlled trials (RCTs) have become an essential tool for economists. The credibility revolution in empirical economics emphasizes research designs that identify casual effects, and random assignment of treatment is seen as the gold standard. Implementation can, however, be a challenge in many applications. The field of economic education is in a unique position to learn from RCTs, given the ability to test interventions in the classroom or at educational institutions. We discuss what is needed to run an RCT effectively in an educational setting, drawing from the experimental literature on topics such as student success in higher education and diversity in undergraduate economics. We additionally outline quasi-experimental approaches that can be used when treatment cannot be randomized.

title: Macroeconomic Expectations in a War
affiliations: University of California, Berkeley - Department of Economics and University of California, Berkeley

detail.title: Macroeconomic Expectations in a War

publicationDetails.journalName: IZA Institute of Labor Economics Discussion Paper Series
