title: Open data in publications – non-copyrightability and attribution as drivers for equity, science and innovation
affiliations: Independent, Consortium of European Taxonomic Facilities (CETAF), Consortium of European Taxonomic Facilities (CETAF), Consortium of European Taxonomic Facilities (CETAF), Museum für Naturkunde Berlin, Tohoku University, affiliation not provided to SSRN and Independent

detail.title: Open data in publications – non-copyrightability and attribution as drivers for equity, science and innovation

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The views expressed in this publication are those of the authors and do not reflect the official positions or legal opinions of authors’ affiliations or employers. The authors have contributed to this publication in their personal capacity only. The statements in this publication represent scientific points of view. They do not constitute legal advice.

detail.abstract: The mobilization of the wealth of existing biodiversity data is fundamental for the development of large, dynamic and multifaceted datasets and their historical baselines. Biodiversity data need to be reliably and persistently linked to their sources in literary works and in databases. For this purpose, biodiversity data in scholarly publications and their associated repositories have to be transformed to provide findable, accessible, interoperable and reusable resources as a core foundation of interlinked, federated information. Unclear rights and obligations form a substantial obstacle to the reuse and effective interlinking of data, and thus to scientific workflows. Therefore, it is key to understand and implement the legal, ethical and social foundations that are crucial for arriving at informed decisions on the access to and the transformation and reuse of such data. The aim of this article is to provide legal clarity to providers and users of such data, and to give recommendations arising from the analysis of the legal background and of community norms requiring attribution, transparency, and accountability. The goal of the resulting recommendations is to empower the biodiversity sciences and data community, including publishers, authors and users, to apply appropriate legal tools as well as language that will provide legal certainty, thereby accelerating the access to and annotation, extraction and reuse of data contained within publications, both legacy and prospective. The paper is the outcome of a workshop organized during the annual meeting of TDWG, the Biodiversity Information Standards organization, held in Sofia, Bulgaria in October 2022. Its focus was on legal and contractual obligations governing data within works and databases. It also addressed community norms, focusing on attribution as well as ethical and sociocultural principles.

title: The Effects of ACA-Medicaid Expansion on Maternal and Infant Health Outcomes in the American South
affiliations: Towson University - Department of Economics and Towson University - College of Business and Economics

detail.title: The Effects of ACA-Medicaid Expansion on Maternal and Infant Health Outcomes in the American South

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The authors have nothing to declare.
declarations.funderStatement: The authors have nothing to declare.

detail.abstract: Maternal and infant health outcomes in the American South lag behind those in other U.S. regions. This study estimates the causal impact of Medicaid expansion to 138 percent of the Federal Poverty Level on maternal and infant health outcomes, using county-level data from the National Vital Statistics System (2010-2017). We employ a difference-indifferences design, comparing counties in expansion and non-expansion states, and use inverse propensity score weighting to improve covariate balance. To flexibly adjust for baseline differences, we extend the analysis with a machine learning-based Doubly Robust DiD estimator. Our findings show that Medicaid expansion significantly reduced pregnancy-associated mortality among non-Hispanic Black mothers, primarily by lowering pregnancy-related deaths, with no effect on incidental causes. No significant impact is found for non-Hispanic White mothers. While infant mortality rates remained unchanged for both groups, the expansion modestly improved birthweight outcomes among Black infants. These results highlight the potential of Medicaid expansion to reduce racial disparities in maternal and infant health in the American South.

title: Platform work and labour legislation in India: Women's engagement and the role of gender
affiliations: IIT Delhi and Independent Researcher

detail.title: Platform work and labour legislation in India: Women's engagement and the role of gender
detail.abstract: Focusing on India's digital platform economy, this study examines the gendered experiences of workers. Given the data challenge, we present a novel methodology to study the working conditions and key issues faced by platform workers in the beauty and personal services segments. Our data comprises 328 workers (both male and female) associated with two popular platforms in India. We find that most workers face issues such as algorithmic control, insufficient technical support, feedback mechanism, safety protocols, and cost concerns. The paper also draws attention to existing provisions applicable to female workers and recent legislative developments related to platform work in India. Through detailed analysis of workers' reviews and experiences, this paper calls for a calibrated alignment of India's legal framework with the swiftly evolving technological landscapes globally. In this, it emphasizes gender inclusivity to ensure equitable labour market opportunities.

title: Bridging Heterogeneities in Retail Means of Payments
affiliations: University of Newcastle (Australia)

detail.title: Bridging Heterogeneities in Retail Means of Payments
detail.abstract: Fungibility infers that IOUs issued by identical/different entities are more or less indistinguishable as they can be mutually interchanged at face value. However, indistinguishability in means of payments is largely a mythical construct as a consequence of underlying heterogeneities. The result is that instead of IOUs being fungible in an "absolute" sense (i.e. means of payments are truly homogenous), they are only fungible in a "practical" sense (i.e. in spite of heterogeneities, it is assumed that means of payments are homogenous). What then bridges heterogeneities in retail means of payments? By interlinking various legal nuances into money and payments, the overarching apexes of this paper is to argue that (1) convertibility into banknotes free of any major frictions bridges heterogeneities across all retail means of payments to safeguard financial stability and the monetary sovereignty of the domestic hegemon; (2) as convertibility into retail central bank money bridges the divide between retail means of payments, it is the retail anchor (as opposed to the wholesale) function of central bank money that predominantly secures fungibility in retail means of payments; (3) frictions during the convertibility processor the belief that frictions will develop in the near future-subverts the symbiosis across all means of payments and lifts the veil that in reality retail means of payments exhibit a degree of heterogeneity; (4) with the ever-increasing "electronification" of payment habits in society, the potency of banknotes to bridge heterogeneities may weaken.

title: Use of Fiscal Measures for Addressing Space Debris, in The Economics of Space Sustainability: Delivering Economic Evidence to Guide Government Action (OECD Publishing, 2024) https://doi.org/10.1787/b2257346-en.
affiliations: University of Florida Fredric G. Levin College of Law

detail.title: Use of Fiscal Measures for Addressing Space Debris, in The Economics of Space Sustainability: Delivering Economic Evidence to Guide Government Action (OECD Publishing, 2024) https://doi.org/10.1787/b2257346-en.
detail.abstract: Research shows that economic interests and technical difficulties often compromise compliance with soft law instruments adopted to mitigate risks from space debris. This chapter addresses the question of whether fiscal measures can be viable tools to address these concerns and overcome the inherent fragility of non-binding instruments. Leveraging a review of the existing literature and past experiences with the adoption (or proposal) of user fees for launches, this chapter suggests the design of a space debris mitigation tax scheme embedded in a framework of legal and fiscal principles.

title: New VSED Advance Directive: Improved Documentation to Avoid Late-Stage Dementia
affiliations: Mitchell Hamline School of Law, Pacific Lutheran University, Seattle University School of Law, Independent and Independent

detail.title: New VSED Advance Directive: Improved Documentation to Avoid Late-Stage Dementia

declarations.declarationOfInterest: No conflicts to disclose.
declarations.funderStatement: No funding to disclose.

detail.abstract:
People use advance directives to express preferences that direct their future care when they lack decision-making capacity. One form of advance directive, a "dementia directive," records preferences about living in various stages of dementia. This is important because many Americans want to avoid living with advanced progressive dementia. 

Unfortunately, traditional advance directives cannot dependably achieve this goal. In contrast, some dementia directives can achieve this goal, by directing cessation of manually assisted feeding and drinking. While many dementia directives have been published, most have gaps and omissions that thwart the goal of avoiding extended intolerable life in advanced dementia. 

To overcome these problems, we formulated a new dementia directive. This article explains the value of this new directive. We proceed in six stages. First, we review the prevalence of advanced dementia. Second, we identify the disadvantages of another option for accomplishing the goal of not living into advanced dementia, preemptive VSED. Third, we distinguish notable court cases where dementia directives were unsuccessful. Fourth, we review nine prominent dementia directives, noting how the Northwest Justice Project's Advance Directive for VSED remedies those shortcomings. Fifth, we review this directive's legal status. Sixth, we articulate its ethical justification.

title: The Disappearing Audit: Bias, Algorithmic Governance, And The Political Economy Of Tax Enforcement
affiliations: Drexel University Thomas R. Kline School of Law

detail.title: The Disappearing Audit: Bias, Algorithmic Governance, And The Political Economy Of Tax Enforcement
detail.abstract:
The federal income tax system is built on voluntary compliance with a backstop of credible enforcement. The foundation is eroding. Over the past decade, IRS audit rates have plummeted, particularly for high-income taxpayers, while audits of low-income filers claiming refundable credits have remained disproportionately high. This article argues that this inversion of expected enforcement outcomes is neither accidental nor apolitical—it reflects a structural bias embedded in the IRS’ resource allocation, technological tools, and risk modeling strategies.

This article examines how the IRS’ reliance on opaque algorithms—combined with chronic underfunding punctuated by acute funding cuts and political pressure—gives rise to a tax enforcement regime that disproportionately targets economically vulnerable taxpayers and spares the wealthy. The issue is not that audits are vanishing, it is that the audits that are still being performed exacerbate inequality and undermine public confidence in the fairness of the system.

By analyzing the IRS’ use of the Dependent Database (DDB), Discriminant Inventory Function System (DIF), and the Refundable Credit Compliance Model, the article shows how “neutral” algorithms can replicate and magnify racial and socioeconomic biases. These technologies, built for administrative efficiency, can ultimately end up targeting the most vulnerable taxpayers—those least in a position to challenge the system or retain representation.

Worse still, the next frontier in tax enforcement—artificial intelligence-powered audit systems—risk accelerating this inequity. If machine learning models are trained on biased historical data, they will not only continue past injustices but will accelerate and scale them. The move toward automation also threatens to obscure human bias under a veneer of technological neutrality or simple technology errors—making reform even more urgent.

This article makes three contributions: First, it reframes audit allocation as a question at the intersection of administrative law and racial-social justice, not mere tax policy administration; second, it evaluates alternative enforcement models with a focus on transparency, equity, and revenue integrity, and; third, it proposes statutory and regulatory reforms to constrain the IRS’ audit discretion and hem in automation through racial impact assessments of new enforcement technologies.

title: Research on Levelized Cost of Electricity (Lcoe) Estimation Method for Future Advanced Nuclear Energy Technologies Based on Kriging Interpolation
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Research on Levelized Cost of Electricity (Lcoe) Estimation Method for Future Advanced Nuclear Energy Technologies Based on Kriging Interpolation
detail.abstract: Under the urgent demand for global energy transition and sustainable nuclear energy development, safe and efficient spent fuel management has become a critical challenge in the international nuclear field. China is actively advancing research on Accelerator-Driven Advanced Nuclear Energy Systems (ADANES) to achieve proper spent fuel disposal and resource utilization, thereby supporting the long-term development of the nuclear industry. Accurate calculation of the Levelized Cost of Electricity (LCOE) is crucial for assessing economic feasibility. However, due to the adoption of novel fuel cycle modes and the developmental stage of the technology, empirical data are insufficient, and key cost indicator data are difficult to obtain, presenting significant challenges for economic evaluation. This study introduces the PESTEL indicator framework, utilizing sample space coordinates instead of traditional geographic distances in Kriging methods to establish spatial autocorrelation relationships. This approach more precisely captures the influence of differences in economic development levels and social acceptance across countries on ADANES reprocessing costs. Based on this framework, an Ordinary Kriging (OK) interpolation model was constructed using unit price samples from nine countries globally to provide unbiased linear estimation of ADANES reprocessing costs in China. Using China's ADANES demonstration project as an empirical case study, the model was applied to achieve spent fuel reprocessing and refabrication cost estimation, yielding a result of $1,414/kgHM. After determining the data and supplementing interpolation parameters, the LCOE for ADANES reprocessing was further calculated. The research findings provide critical data for economic evaluation of this project and offer replicable methodology and practical experience for economic assessment of cutting-edge nuclear technologies globally, supporting nuclear technology innovation and sustainable development.

title: Sustainable Biofuel Supply Chain Design: An Approach Based on Water Resource Management and Dealing with Uncertainty
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and University of Isfahan

detail.title: Sustainable Biofuel Supply Chain Design: An Approach Based on Water Resource Management and Dealing with Uncertainty
detail.abstract: This study aims to develop a sustainable biofuel supply chain, with a primary emphasis on water resource management, risk mitigation, and sustanability enhancement . Central to the proposed model is the integration of sustainable biomass specifically the Paulownia tree and recycled water, addressing critical challenges posed by fossil fuel dependency and underscoring the importance of transitioning toward renewable energy sources. To achieve this, a multi-objective mathematical model is formulated to concurrently minimize total costs, meet demand, and reduce environmental impacts. The model incorporates supply and demand uncertainties and applies the LP-metric method for optimization. To ensure balanced decision-making across multiple objectives, the Fuzzy Analytic Hierarchy Process (FAHP) is used to assign appropriate weights to each goal. The methodology further includes sensitivity analysis to evaluate the influence of key variables such as biomass supply, price volatility, and demand fluctuations. Additionally, Pareto analysis is conducted to identify optimal trade-offs among conflicting objectives. The findings reveal that the inclusion of recycled water and wastewater not only relieves pressure on natural resources but also significantly enhances the economic and environmental performance of the supply chain. Moreover, the integration of Paulownia biomass improves system flexibility and reduces associated risks. Through the use of epsilon-constraint and Pareto frontier analysis, the model provides decision-makers with adaptable solutions aligned with their strategic priorities. the study offers a practical and comprehensive approach to the design and management of sustainable biofuel supply chains, supporting long-term resource efficiency and contributing to global sustainable development goals by reducing reliance on fossil fuels.

title: The Ideas of Prosperity and Solidarity in European International Law
affiliations: University of Glasgow - School of Law and Edinburgh Law School

detail.title: The Ideas of Prosperity and Solidarity in European International Law
detail.abstract: Two distinct traditions of thinking about the ideas of prosperity and solidarity have taken shape in recent decades in European international law. One of them has developed in the context of a distinctly regionalist way of approaching matters of international legal governance that is known today as European law; the other has taken shape in the context of Europe’s postcolonial engagement with the legacies of European imperialism. What both traditions have in common is their ability to refract and problematise not only the general idea of ‘Europeanness’ but also its relationship with law, space, and justice. What separates them is the radically different answers they give to these questions and the vision of international law’s constitutional principles and guiding values.

title: The Unexpected Effects of Government Incentives on Angels' Investments in the Startup Industry
affiliations: Ono Academic College, Peres Academic Center and Ben-Gurion University of the Negev

detail.title: The Unexpected Effects of Government Incentives on Angels' Investments in the Startup Industry
detail.abstract: Business angels play a critical role in supporting entrepreneurial ventures, prompting governments worldwide to introduce policies aimed at encouraging angel investment in startups, especially early-stage ones. Among these, tax incentives are the most prevalent. However, their effectiveness in promoting overall social welfare remains a subject of debate.This study examines the effects of a policy aimed at encouraging angel investment in early-stage startups. The policy, known as the Angel Act, was implemented in Israel during 2011–2015 and revised 2016–2019. Surprisingly, our findings reveal that these policies had adverse effects on early-stage angel investments. Specifically, while total angel investments increased; the likelihood and number of angel investments in seed stage startups’ financing rounds decreased and so was the amount invested per angel in early-stage startups.This counterintuitive outcome raises a key question: Why would tax incentives intended to stimulate early-stage investment—and which investors can opt not to use—produce the opposite effect? To address this, we evaluated several alternative explanations. Our analyses suggests that the negative effect stems from adverse signaling associated with startups that either did not seek or did not obtain certification under the Angels’ Act. Such startups may be perceived by investors as higher risk or of lower quality, deterring angels due to concerns about the startups’ reputation. As a result, angel investors may have shifted their focus toward later-stage startups, which were not targeted by the policy because of their age or scope, and thus their quality was not questioned.This explanation carries significant policy implications. It highlights the potential unintended consequences of government entrepreneurship support policies that selectively grant benefits to qualifying startups. Such policies can inadvertently generate negative signals about non-qualifying firms, undermining their perceived quality and counteracting the policy’s intended goals. Policymakers should consider these potential adverse signaling effects when designing support mechanisms-particularly when implemented by high-reputation government agencies, where the signaling risk is even greater.

title: Does Family Ownership Moderates the Interplay of CEO Characteristics and Corporate Sustainability in an Emerging Market?
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, Bahria University, affiliation not provided to SSRN, Hong Kong University of Science & Technology (HKUST) and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Does Family Ownership Moderates the Interplay of CEO Characteristics and Corporate Sustainability in an Emerging Market?
detail.abstract: This inquiry explores the rarely inquired potential moderation of family ownership in the relationship of some specific attributes of the Chief Executive Officer (CEO) with Corporate Sustainability (CS). Applying the Generalized Method of Moments (GMM) to a sample of 227 Pakistani listed companies from 2019 to 2023, it is unveiled that family ownership converts the insignificant role of female CEOs and the significant and insignificant negative coefficients of the CEOs’ PhD and MS/M.Phil. Degrees to significantly positive that promote CS. The moderation of family ownership also significantly reduced the negative effects of their master's degree, business education, and domestic qualification on CS. In addition to amplifying the significant positive contribution of the CEO’s foreign education, the moderation also changed a significant negative effect of the CEO’s experience to a significant positive to promote CS. However, the moderator lessens the positive effects of the CEO’s age and accounting education in advancing CS. The moderator also could not change the insignificant nexus of CEO bachelor and engineering education with CS.

title: Designing a Self-Financing Incentive Program for Zero-Emission Trucks in California: A Market-Based, Feebate-Inspired Policy Framework
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, University of California, Davis - Institute of Transportation Studies, University of California, Davis - Institute of Transportation Studies and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Designing a Self-Financing Incentive Program for Zero-Emission Trucks in California: A Market-Based, Feebate-Inspired Policy Framework
detail.abstract: Until the price gap between diesel and zero-emission trucks (ZETs) shrinks significantly, policy intervention is necessary to accelerate the transition to ZETs. California and others have imposed annual sales requirements on truck manufacturers, coupled with purchase incentives with a limited state funding. To minimize the fiscal impact of government-funded incentives, we propose a self-financing rebate program for Class 4-8 trucks, using California as a case study. This is the first known study of truck feebates in the U.S. context, and likely globally. Under the scheme, diesel truck purchase or ownership would incur a fee, while ZET purchases would receive rebates. We consider various policy designs premised on revenue-neutrality (no cost to government) and minimizing cost burdens for transitioning fleets. Two design options are explored with multiple scenarios: a one-time upfront fee on diesel trucks at the point of sale or an annual fee on all operating diesel trucks, with the revenue used to finance rebates on ZET purchases. As an example, a one-time fee of 7% of the new diesel truck purchase price (~ $5,100 to $20,400 per truck) or an annual fee of $290-$820 per diesel truck, depending on the class, could support rebates for 74,600 ZETs. Rebates decline from up to $277,000 in the first year to up to $40,000 in the last year as ZET sales spur. Any “excess” revenues could support ZET transition by funding charging infrastructure or incentivizing used ZETs. The annual fee approach provides the broadest funding base with modest fees.

title: 글로벌 디지털플랫폼의 데이터 집중화에 따른 경제적 영향 분석(Economic Impact of Data Concentration on Global Digital Platforms)
affiliations: Korea Institute for International Economic Policy, Korea Institute for International Economic Policy and Korea Institute for International Economic Policy

detail.title: 글로벌 디지털플랫폼의 데이터 집중화에 따른 경제적 영향 분석(Economic Impact of Data Concentration on Global Digital Platforms)

publicationDetails.journalName: Korea Institute for International Economic Policy (KIEP) Research Paper Series

detail.abstract: Recent regulatory proposals on competition in digital markets, such as the EU’s Digital Markets Act and Digital Services Act, emphasize the importance of ensuring fair competition in markets to sustain innovation and avoid long-term monopolies. There is a growing concern that markets are becoming increasingly concentrated, with a small number of data-rich companies gaining prominent positions in horizontally or vertically linked markets and large user bases. This report identifies considerations for introducing policies to mitigate the market power of data-rich global digital platforms and protect the openness of digital ecosystems for potential new entrants. To this end, we examine data-related regulatory trends in major countries and theoretically discuss the implications for inter-platform competition when data gives digital platforms a competitive advantage. We then focus on data portability, the most prominent data-related regulation of digital platforms, to explore the impact of data portability regulation on digital platform competition.

detail.abstract: China’s policy of nurturing hidden champions is being promoted on the basis of a systematic development system, which has been established by consolidating the economic development policies scattered in each province by linking them to the national strategy. It nurtures hidden champions in the manufacturing industry to strengthen the foundation of the manufacturing industry and improve the localization rate of key basic parts and materials by 2025, which is the goal set by the “manufacturing powerhouse” strategy at the national level. After classifying small and medium-sized enterprises by growth stage, China is nurturing companies that can supplement the technological gap in the supply chain by focusing technology and capital. detail.title: 미중경쟁에 따른 아세안 역내 공급망 재편과 한국의 대응방안(ASEAN’s Cooperation with the U.S. and China Amid U.S.-China Rivalry: Focus on Supply Chain Restructuring)

publicationDetails.journalName: Korea Institute for International Economic Policy (KIEP) Research Paper Series

detail.abstract: This study aims to explore cooperation strategies between ASEAN and Korea from a mid-to-long-term perspective, ensuring that engagement in the U.S.-China strategic competition does not lead to reduction in domestic production capacity and exclusion from the supply chain. To this end, this paper analyzes the relationship between the U.S. and ASEAN, as well as between China and ASEAN, in a wide range of areas from trade and economic cooperation to the ongoing U.S.-China strategic competition in the region. Additionally, the study examines the economic impact of supply chain restructuring due to U.S.-China rivalry on ASEAN and Korea, and investigates ASEAN’s responses. Finally, based on the research findings and Korea’s current policies toward ASEAN, the study suggests the direction of Korea’s supply chain cooperation with ASEAN. (The rest omitted)

title: 인도-태평양 전략 추진을 위한 한-태평양도서국 중장기 협력 방안(Korea’s Indo-Pacific Bridge: Charting a Course for ROK-Pacific Islands Partnership)
affiliations: Korea Institute for International Economic Policy, Korea Institute for International Economic Policy, Korea Institute for International Economic Policy, kiep - kiep and Korea Institute for International Economic Policy

detail.title: 인도-태평양 전략 추진을 위한 한-태평양도서국 중장기 협력 방안(Korea’s Indo-Pacific Bridge: Charting a Course for ROK-Pacific Islands Partnership)

publicationDetails.journalName: Korea Institute for International Economic Policy (KIEP) Research Paper Series

detail.abstract:
The first-ever ROK-Pacific Islands Summit on May 29, 2023, marked a significant entry for South Korea (hereafter Korea) into the dynamic sphere of Pacific regional cooperation. Since 2011, Korea has consistently engaged in foreign minister-level dialogues with Pacific Island Countries (PICs), while gradually increasing its official development assistance
(ODA) to these countries. The 2023 summit, however, was a pivotal step that underscored Korea’s commitment to deeper engagement with the PICs. The summit culminated in the development of two crucial documents - the “2023 Korea-Pacific Islands Leaders’ Declaration” and the “Action Plan for Freedom, Peace, and Prosperity in the Pacific” - both
serving as comprehensive blueprints for the ROK-PICs partnership. This proactive engagement is a strategic element of President Yoon’s Indo-Pacific Strategy, aimed at elevating Korea’s role as a middle power and expanding its positive influence throughout the Indo-Pacific region. Korea’s active outreach to PICs has been warmly welcomed by both the PICs and the key regional powers. The main challenge ahead is to sustain the achievements of the summit and enhance Korea’s position as a late-entry donor in the Pacific, in the face of intensifying aid competition in the region. Against this backdrop, drawing on an analysis of the evolving dynamics of Pacific regional cooperation, this study aims to provide policy recommendations for Korea’s future engagement with the Pacific Islands. (The rest omitted)

title: 중국 태양광•BESS 산업의 글로벌 시장 독점화와 주요국 대응(Monopolization of the Global Market for China’s Solar PV and BESS Industries and Response to Major Countries)
affiliations: Korea Institute for International Economic Policy

detail.title: 중국 태양광•BESS 산업의 글로벌 시장 독점화와 주요국 대응(Monopolization of the Global Market for China’s Solar PV and BESS Industries and Response to Major Countries)

publicationDetails.journalName: Korea Institute for International Economic Policy (KIEP) Research Paper Series

detail.abstract: To achieve carbon neutrality and increase energy security, the international community is accelerating the energy transition to reduce fossil fuels and increase renewable energy. Solar power, in particular, has emerged as a fast-growing renewable energy source, as its generation costs have fallen to the level of fossil fuels and it is relatively easy to install. Demand is growing rapidly and is expected to exceed the cumulative installed capacity of coal by 2027. In addition, demand for energy storage systems (ESS) is growing in line with the expansion of renewable energy generation. Since the production of electricity from solar and wind power fluctuates depending on the amount of sunlight available and wind speeds, it is necessary to build an ESS to store the generated electricity and release it when it is needed. Among ESS, the demand for battery energy storage systems (BESS) based on lithium-ion batteries (LiB) is growing rapidly, as it is less constrained by location and can be easily dismantled and moved compared to pumped storage hydroelectricity, in which power is generated by utilizing altitude differences in locations such as reservoirs. (The rest omitted)

title: 중국 하이난(海南) 자유무역항의 무역•투자자유화 성과와 시사점(Trade and Investment Liberalization in China’s Hainan Free Trade Port: Review and Implications)
affiliations: Korea Institute for International Economic Policy and Korea Institute for International Economic Policy

detail.title: 중국 하이난(海南) 자유무역항의 무역•투자자유화 성과와 시사점(Trade and Investment Liberalization in China’s Hainan Free Trade Port: Review and Implications)

publicationDetails.journalName: Korea Institute for International Economic Policy (KIEP) Research Paper Series

detail.abstract: Recently, China has signed and applied for membership in several trade agreements, including RCEP, CPTPP, and DEPA, which are expected to promote the reform and opening up of China’s trade sector. Specifically in the area of services trade, China needs to prepare itself for transitioning from the current positive list approach to the negative list method within three years after the implementation of RCEP in 2022, while also adopting an internationally recognized methodology. Several policies are being implemented. This study analyzed the Hainan Free Trade Port policy, which prioritizes the introduction of regulatory reform and trade liberalization measures in China’s services sector. It aimed to explore ways for Korea and China to cooperate in the service industry while also assessing the potential for decentralizing the functions of the Hong Kong Free Trade Port. detail.abstract: This study assesses the previous enlargement of the EU and investigates the potential enlargement EU in the future. The European Union has established itself as a politically and economically integrated community in the European region, and it continues to evolve. The biggest change in the EU in the last two decades was the massive enlargement of the EU to the countries of Central and Eastern Europe in 2004, when eight Central and Eastern European countries joined the EU together at the same time. The discussion of EU enlargement, which has been stagnant since the last enlargement when Croatia joined the EU, seems to have been revitalized by the recent Russian invasion of Ukraine. As further changes in the EU are becoming increasingly visible, the purpose of this study is to draw implications for Korea’s future strategy to cooperate with the EU candidate countries. (The rest omitted)

title: When Ownership Meets Licensing– New Normative Expectations and the Need for NFT Categorization: All Your Projects “Are” Belong to Us
affiliations: University of San Francisco - School of Law

detail.title: When Ownership Meets Licensing– New Normative Expectations and the Need for NFT Categorization: All Your Projects “Are” Belong to Us

publicationDetails.detailsText: Univ. of San Francisco Law Research Paper (forthcoming)
publicationDetails.journalName: University of San Francisco School of Law Legal Studies Research Paper Series

detail.abstract: The current treatment of all NFTs in legal scholarship as identical digital assets fundamentally misunderstands their varied applications and the new normative expectations they create. The Moonbirds controversy of 2022, where a creator's unilateral license change affected nearly 20,000 token holders, exemplifies the crisis: token holders believed they owned digital assets that could be controlled and commercialized, but existing copyright frameworks treat NFTs merely as licenses subject to creator discretion. Picture for Profile (PFP) Projects— community-based NFT collections involving thousands of tokens often with governance and commercial rights—combine concepts of possession, community governance, and commercialization in ways that challenge traditional intellectual property licensing. Despite industry efforts to create NFT-specific licenses, empirical analysis reveals declining adoption and increasing fragmentation. Current legal scholarship debates whether NFTs should fall under copyright or property law, but such broad categorizations are premature. A better approach is a fact-based analytical framework to distinguish PFP Projects from other NFT types. Such a framework would enable courts to apply appropriate legal doctrines based on the specific NFT type rather than one-size-fits-all solutions that risk stifling innovation or inadequately protecting consumers. This article advocates for American Law Institute guidance to create default rules for the $10B, and exponentially growing, NFT market. Guidance from the ALI provides courts with practical tools to navigate potential disputes involving ownership rights, commercial licensing, and decentralized governance while balancing innovation with consumer protection in an evolving digital economy.

title: Exercise-Induced Bronchoconstriction: A Systematic Review of Diagnostic Challenges and Emerging Management Strategies
affiliations: 21 September university for medical and applied sciences

detail.title: Exercise-Induced Bronchoconstriction: A Systematic Review of Diagnostic Challenges and Emerging Management Strategies

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.
declarations.funderStatement: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.

detail.abstract: Background: Exercise-induced bronchoconstriction (EIB) is a transient narrowing of the airways triggered by physical activity. It affects both asthmatic and non-asthmatic individuals, especially athletes. Objective: This systematic review synthesizes current evidence on EIB's pathophysiology, clinical presentation, diagnostic strategies, and emerging therapies. Methods: A systematic literature search was conducted in PubMed, Scopus, and Google Scholar between 2000 and 2024 using PRISMA guidelines. The search yielded 415 records, with 36 studies. The PICOS framework guided inclusion criteria. Results: EIB is linked to osmotic and thermal stress during exercise, leading to airway inflammation [1-3]. Diagnostic approaches include spirometry, exercise challenge, EVH, and mannitol testing [1-3]. Non-pharmacologic and pharmacologic therapies (e.g., SABAs, ICS, LTRAs, biologics) show efficacy [4-6]. PRISMA flow diagram and bias assessments were applied. Conclusion: EIB is underdiagnosed but manageable with structured diagnosis and therapy. Personalized treatment and newer biologic options offer hope for refractory cases [14,15].

title: When International Trade Law Meets Tax Policy: The Example of Digital Services Taxes
affiliations: Geneva Graduate Institute and Université catholique de Louvain

detail.title: When International Trade Law Meets Tax Policy: The Example of Digital Services Taxes

declarations.funderStatement: No specific funder. However, I should note that this article is reprinted from the Journal of World Trade, Volume 55, Issue 6 (2021), pp. 895 – 920, with permission of Kluwer Law International.

keywords: Non-discrimination of Services and Service Providers

detail.abstract: With the rise of digital services taxes (DSTs) all over the world, questions have arisen regarding their compatibility with international trade law. Between 2019 and 2021, the United States initiated investigations into several DSTs and published observations on the DSTs adopted by Austria, France, Italy, India, Spain, Turkey and the United Kingdom. In addition to the argument that these taxes violate international tax principles, the US considers that they are discriminatory. This article uses this claim as a basis to analyse the likelihood for DSTs to be incompatible with World Trade Organization (WTO) law. First, it provides an overview of the unilateral, regional and multilateral tax proposals to mitigate the challenges of the digitalized economy. Second, it discusses the main legal issues that could arise under the law of the WTO, focusing on legal issues under the General Agreement on Trade in Services (GATS). While recognising that there may be good tax policy reasons to oppose DSTs, this article concludes that arguments based on WTO law provide, if at all, a weak justification to oppose such taxes.

title: Women Directors: A Critical Analysis
affiliations: Independent

detail.title: Women Directors: A Critical Analysis
detail.abstract: The Companies Act of 2013 is a watershed moment in corporate law. India passed legislation requiring one woman director on the board of directors of publicly traded and some other significant companies (Section 149 (1)). Even though India's constitution guarantees equal rights to men and women. Women still are undervalued within the workplace. As a result, women's options are limited. However, the situation has changed/diversified nowadays. Women have also made inroads into several corporate boardrooms, albeit in a limited capacity. In this situation, the Companies Act, 2013 has provided provision for the appointment of female directors to the boards of publicly traded companies, which is a positive step. This is a step in the direction of gender equality. This research focuses on female director representation on boards of directors and its impact. It is a step in the right direction. Assuring stronger levels of openness and accountability and attempting to align India's corporate governance processes with international best practices. Gender bias is a problem not only in India but also in industrialized countries such as the United States and the United Kingdom, etc. So, certainly, there is a lot of room for us to grow. It is past time we gave our female counterparts equal opportunities to contribute to humanity's advancement. A legal provision can be sufficient to reduce gender bias. People on boards of directors can use their differences to improve corporate governance. At a global level, the inclusion of women on boards of directors tends to have a beneficial impact on shareholder value. In boardroom conversations, there is a need for a plurality of viewpoints. Whether women directors have aided in strengthening the company's overall image since their appointment as women directors. The study that women on boards of directors have a beneficial impact on company success.  A board of directors that is properly organised and capable of making independent decisions for the company's benefit is the result of good corporate governance. Female directors have a good and significant impact on company success, according to the study. To improve financial viability and performance, Indian businesses should explore putting women on boards of directors and in top managerial positions.

title: Dynamic Delegation: Experimentation Cycles and Forward-Reverse Stopping Contracts
affiliations: The University of Hong Kong - Faculty of Business and Economics and Boston University

detail.title: Dynamic Delegation: Experimentation Cycles and Forward-Reverse Stopping Contracts
detail.abstract: We study a dynamic delegation problem in which a long-lived principal assigns experimentation tasks to short-lived agents, each active for only one period. The principal values experimentation more due to her longer horizon. We model this as a contextual bandit problem with type-dependent Poisson outcomes: one agent type has a known success probability, while the other is uncertain-either high or low-and is gradually learned. The optimal contract is a forward-reverse stopping contract (FRSC), generating cyclical experimentation, involving engagement, abandonment, and revival. Misaligned incentives lead to both overand under-experimentation, as the principal balances learning incentives against agents' short-termism.

Validated in a large academic health system, SCM advances the Quadruple Aim—enhancing patient experience, improving population health, reducing costs, and supporting provider well-being—while providing systems with a scalable, mission-aligned, and financially resilient alternative.

title: Estimator of What? A Note on Teaching Regressions in Introductory Econometrics
affiliations: Pitzer College

detail.title: Estimator of What? A Note on Teaching Regressions in Introductory Econometrics

publicationDetails.journalName: IZA Institute of Labor Economics Discussion Paper Series

detail.abstract: The most widely used textbooks today conflate three distinct population parameters: the population regression function (PRF), the conditional expectation function (CEF), and the causal effect. They also incorrectly suggest, and sometimes state, that the Conditional Mean Zero assumption implies causal interpretation of regression coefficients. I highlight these issues and show that by incorporating new notation these limitations can easily be overcome.

title: Non-Fatal Strangulation Laws and Intimate Partner Homicides
affiliations: University of Nottingham, University of Exeter, University of Surrey and University of Exeter

detail.title: Non-Fatal Strangulation Laws and Intimate Partner Homicides

publicationDetails.journalName: IZA Institute of Labor Economics Discussion Paper Series

detail.abstract: Do non-fatal strangulation laws save lives? Non-fatal strangulation (NFS) is a common and dangerous form of intimate partner violence (IPV) and a predictor of homicide, yet it was historically neglected by the criminal justice system. Since the year 2000, most U.S. states have enacted laws enlisting NFS as a standalone criminal offense. We compile a novel dataset on state NFS statutes and link it to the FBI Supplementary Homicide Reports from 1990 to 2019 to estimate the causal effects of these laws on IPH rates. Using a difference-in-differences strategy, and an estimator that accounts for staggered adoption and treatment heterogeneity, we find that NFS laws led to significant reductions in IPH rates. We estimate that these laws reduce female-victim IPH by 14% and male-victim IPH by 36%, among victims aged 18-34. No significant effects are observed for victims 50 and above or for homicides committed by strangers. Event-study estimates support the parallel trends assumption. Our findings suggest that NFS laws can disrupt the escalation of IPV and reduce lethal outcomes.

title: Optimal Dynamic Matching Under Local Compatibility: An Application to Kidney Exchange
affiliations: Stanford University, Università degli Studi di Messina, Boston College - Department of Economics and Koç University

detail.title: Optimal Dynamic Matching Under Local Compatibility: An Application to Kidney Exchange
detail.abstract: In the past two decades, the design and implementation of living donor kidney exchange clearinghouses have been a major success story in market design. Instead of batching and optimizing exchanges over a fixed pool of incompatible patient-donor pairs, the busiest programs now operate dynamically, matching pairs as they arrive. This feature has also sparked interest in dynamic matching mechanisms. Yet for general matching problems with high-dimensional state spaces, a full characterization of optimal dynamic mechanisms remains elusive, and only approximate solutions are known. We develop a new methodology to characterize and compute dynamically optimal mechanisms for bilateral matching over arbitrary state spaces, provided that compatibility between agent types follows a linear spatial structure. This technique applies to optimal dynamic kidney exchange and extends to other spatial matching problems. Our approach leverages second-order properties of the value function, extending recent advances in Markov Decision Processes and queueing systems, which traditionally focus only on substitutable components.

title: The Costs of Financial Crises in the United States
affiliations: National University of Singapore (NUS), Department of Economics, National University of Singapore (NUS), Department of Economics, National University of Singapore (NUS) - Department of Finance, Princeton University and National University of Singapore (NUS), Department of Economics

detail.title: The Costs of Financial Crises in the United States
detail.abstract: Using a newly-constructed panel dataset of U.S. states from 1863 to 2022 that combines bank balance sheets, real economic activity, and a systematic survey of all major chronologies of U.S. financial crises, we document the following facts: (i) financial crises are followed by a 6% decline in state-level output, (ii) output losses vary substantially across states, (iii) the severity of output losses is predictable with local contractions in deposits or wholesale liabilities, and with the incidence of bank failures, (iv) a composite measure of local financial distress, combining narrative evidence with statistical indicators, predicts state-level output losses of 3%, and (v) the share of states experiencing local financial distress predicts national output beyond a binary crisis indicator. These findings suggest that studies of systemic crises may underestimate the frequency and costs of financial distress.

title: Carbon Rollercoaster: A Historical Analysis of Decarbonization in the United States
affiliations: Carnegie Mellon University - H. John Heinz III School of Public Policy and Management, Carnegie Mellon University, University of Montreal and Carnegie Mellon University

detail.title: Carbon Rollercoaster: A Historical Analysis of Decarbonization in the United States

publicationDetails.journalName: IZA Institute of Labor Economics Discussion Paper Series

detail.abstract: This paper documents the evolution of US carbon emissions and discusses the main factors that contributed to the historical carbon emissions rollercoaster. We divide the discussion into four periods  up to 1920, 1920-1960, 1960-2005 and after 2005. For each period, we discuss the main drivers of national carbon emissions. We then discuss trends in carbon emissions in the electricity sector. Electricity sector emissions were initially very small, but would become the largest source of US carbon emissions over the period 1980-2015, and the largest contributor to decarbonization since 2007. In the final section, we distill lessons from the U.S. experience that may inform decarbonization strategies in developing economies.

title: Climate News and Accounting Comparability
affiliations: Colorado State University, Fort Collins - Department of Accounting, Lancaster University - Department of Accounting and Finance and University of Roehampton

detail.title: Climate News and Accounting Comparability

declarations.declarationOfInterest: All authors declare that there is no financial/personal interest or belief that could affect their objectivity.

detail.abstract: We examine the effect of climate news on accounting comparability. We argue that climate news informs market participants about firms’ climate exposure, inducing a reassessment of the firms’ future cash flows. This reassessment increases the variance in accounting estimates, hence reducing accounting comparability among industry peers. Consistently, we find a negative relationship between market-level measures of climate news and one-year-ahead firm-level accounting comparability. This finding is robust to several sensitivity checks. This relationship is mediated by the intensity with which firms apply accounting standards to transform economic events into accounting numbers and moderated by the extent to which firms are exposed to climate risks and by firms’ environmental performance. Our study contributes to the growing literature examining the negative effect of climate change on firm values and to the literature examining the determinants of accounting comparability. The practical implication of our study is that market participants should be cautious when comparing peer firms after periods of increased climate news.

title: What is Happening to Unionization in Japan?
affiliations: University College London, Musashi University - Economics, Reitaku University, JTUC Rengo Research Institute for Advancement of Living Standards (RENGO-RIALS) and Université Libre de Bruxelles (ULB)

detail.title: What is Happening to Unionization in Japan?

publicationDetails.journalName: IZA Institute of Labor Economics Discussion Paper Series

detail.abstract: Official government estimates show a gradual decline in union density in Japan over several decades akin to that in other countries with decentralized bargaining structures. However, new evidence from various social surveys indicates that union density has been rising in Japan. Using one of these social surveys  the Survey on the Work and Life of Workers (SWLW)  we show union density has risen by 7.3 percentage points to 29.1% in the Japanese private sector between 2011/13 and 2020/24. We decompose the growth in union density since 2011/13 to establish how much of it is attributable to changes in workforce composition. Conditioning on union presence at the workplace, compositional change accounts for 47% of the increase in union density. The remaining 53% is due to within-group change with unions increasing membership across all types of worker including some with traditionally low rates of unionization. However, establishing a union at the workplace remains key since virtually all the growth in union membership (97%) is in unionized workplaces.

title: From Regulation to Realization: How the U.S. Crypto Laws of 2025 Could Redefine Dollar Dominance in a Blockchain Economy
affiliations: University of California, San Diego (UCSD) - Rady School of Management

detail.title: From Regulation to Realization: How the U.S. Crypto Laws of 2025 Could Redefine Dollar Dominance in a Blockchain Economy
detail.abstract: In July 2025, the United States passed three landmark laws—the GENIUS Act, CLARITY Act, and Anti-CBDC Surveillance State Act—establishing the country’s first national legal framework for cryptocurrency. This paper explores how these regulations shift the role of stablecoins from speculative tools to regulated financial instruments, opening the door for broader adoption and U.S. leadership in Web3 finance. It highlights real-world crypto use in inflation-hit countries, then outlines key infrastructure priorities across stablecoins, decentralized finance (DeFi), and tokenized real-world assets (RWAs). Drawing on examples from BlackRock, Franklin Templeton, and emerging token standards, the paper proposes a path to modernize U.S. capital markets through blockchain. Clear regulation is the foundation—but real-world implementation is the next step. With the right infrastructure, tokenization could strengthen dollar dominance and make digital finance accessible to more people, not just professional traders.

title: Competition, Comity, and Confusion: Reconciling the FTAIA's Import Exclusion with its Direct Effects Provision
affiliations: Fordham University - Fordham Law Review

detail.title: Competition, Comity, and Confusion: Reconciling the FTAIA's Import Exclusion with its Direct Effects Provision

keywords: Jurisdictional Limits of U.S. Antitrust Law
Animal Science Products v. China Minmetals

detail.abstract:
The debate surrounding the Sherman Act's extraterritorial reach represents a tension between two competing objectives: protecting domestic competition and respecting the sovereign authority of other nation states.  Applying U.S. law abroad risks undermining sovereign authority by regulating foreign economies, though in some cases such regulation appears necessary to protect the U.S. economy. 

To clarify the Sherman Act's extraterritorial scope, Congress passed the Foreign Trade Antitrust Improvements Act.  However, the FTAIA's textual ambiguities still left courts with key questions, namely, what is the boundary between import and non-import commerce, and what standard applies when determining whether anticompetitive conduct abroad has a direct effect?  

This Note examines the circuit split over both of these questions.  This Note then argues that reading the FTAIA's two provisions together necessitates a narrow interpretation of imports and a proximate cause standard for direct effects.  By construing imports narrowly and direct effects broadly, courts can best protect domestic competition while striking a balance between enforcement and respect for international comity.  This Note concludes that this interpretation not only aligns with the text and legislative intent of the FTAIA but also promotes a more coherent and effective approach for antitrust enforcement for both the U.S. enforcement agencies and private plaintiffs in the global economy.

title: Understanding the Concept of Relevant Market Under the Competition Act, 2002
affiliations: National Law University and Judicial Academy, Assam,

detail.title: Understanding the Concept of Relevant Market Under the Competition Act, 2002
detail.abstract: This research note examines the concept of the "relevant market" under India's Competition Act, 2002, particularly through Sections 19(6) and 19(7), which guide the Competition Commission of India in its assessment of anti-competitive conduct. The note unpacks how relevant product and geographic markets are defined, using factors such as consumer preferences, product substitutability, pricing, and end-usage, among other factors. To make these ideas concrete, it examines landmark cases where the CCI carefully demarcated markets to evaluate dominance and abuse. It also explains the recent inclusion of supply-side substitution in market definition post the 2023 Amendment. The discussion illustrates how identifying the relevant market is the first crucial step in competition analysis, as it establishes the boundaries for assessing power and potential competitive harm. By blending statutory interpretation with actual cases, this paper offers an accessible guide to a foundational concept in Indian competition law.

title: User Perception of Chatgpt and Traditional Reference Services
affiliations: S.R. Fatepuria College

detail.title: User Perception of Chatgpt and Traditional Reference Services
detail.abstract: The advent of artificial intelligence (AI) has introduced new dimensions to library reference services, notably through conversational agents like ChatGPT. This study examines user perceptions of ChatGPT in comparison to traditional reference services provided by human librarians. Using a survey approach, feedback was collected from academic library users to evaluate factors such as accuracy, trustworthiness, user satisfaction, response time, and ease of use. Findings reveal that while ChatGPT offers rapid and accessible assistance, users still tend to trust and prefer traditional reference services for complex or specialized queries due to the human ability to provide contextual and critical guidance. The study highlights the complementary roles of AI and human librarians, suggesting that integrating ChatGPT as a supportive tool could enhance overall reference service delivery. These insights contribute to understanding how libraries can balance innovation with user expectations in the evolving information landscape.

reference: Forthcoming in the Canadian Journal of Law and Technology
title: Interoperable AI Regulation
affiliations: McGill University - Faculty of Law

detail.title: Interoperable AI Regulation

declarations.funderStatement: Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council (Canada)

publicationDetails.detailsText: Forthcoming in the Canadian Journal of Law and Technology

detail.abstract: This article explores "interoperability" as a new goal in AI regulation in Canada and beyond. Drawing on sociotechnical, computer science, and digital government literatures, it traces interoperability's conceptual genealogy to reveal an underlying politics that prioritizes harmony over discord and consistency over plurality. This politics, the article argues, is in tension with the distinct role of statutory law (as opposed to regulation) in a democratic society. Legislation is not simply a technology through which one achieves the smooth operation of governance. Rather, legislation is better understood as a "boundary object": an information system through which members of different communities make sense of, and communicate about, complex phenomena. This sense-making includes and even requires disagreement, the managing and resolution of which is a vital function of both law and indeed of any information system.
